HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Heidi Chronicles,' a Woman's Search

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: METUCHEN

 BODY:
IN 1970, Heidi Holland wandered into a women's consciousness-raising session, announced that she was just visiting and insisted that some things, like body hair and love affairs, were too personal to talk about.
Sharing, the buzzword of all groups, had limits for Heidi, who was more concerned with mattering as an individual than with being a member of a movement. Although she loosened up and got into the spirit of female bonding, Heidi never let go of her insistence that humanist was the label of choice, not feminist. 
 In "The Heidi Chronicles," Wendy Wasserstein charts a 24-year search for worthwhileness, from 1965 (when Heidi was in high school) to 1989, when Heidi is a prominent art historian on the lecture circuit.
In the play's professional New Jersey premiere at the Forum Theater Group, more than three years after it snared every theater award in sight, the Pulitzer included, the life-changing choice of Heidi as a single mother at the final curtain -- her wistful speculation that "things will be a little better" for her adopted child -- gains a new perspective. What seemed like an ending of tacked-on sentimentality to some is now right to the point and in step with a renewed sense of hope in the country.
"The Heidi Chronicles" was bracing for Broadway. That the play had a life in the theatrical marketplace is itself an affirmation of literacy and language in the big-time Broadway theater, where Ms. Wasserstein's new, glibber, less substantial play, "The Sisters Rosensweig," is to move next month -- a transfer, like "Heidi," from a small theater designated as Off Broadway.
That this one survives so soundly is an endorsement of the playwright's teasing wit and a generosity of spirit that allows equal time for the cause of two male characters -- the search for "self-fulfillment, self-determination, self-exaggeration."
Scoop Rosenbaum is Heidi's on-and-off lover, whose career as an editor progresses from the radical Liberated Earth News to the trend-setting Boomer magazine and whose character evolves from "charismatic creep" to unfilled idealist.
Peter, Heidi's friend for life, is gay, narcissistic, sarcastic and the leading pediatrician in New York under 40. If Heidi had it all, Peter would be her lover.
Ms. Wasserstein has both men asking for validation, for equal representation and value, and they get it. As Peter challenges Heidi with the question of his own liberation, it is clear that Ms. Wasserstein is not writing with the exclusivity of a single point of view.
And the playwright's deft turns of phrase don't distort her all-encompassing take on having it all, or her look back on protest marches, on those who were convinced that Ronald Reagan was going to be best for the economy, on the women who throw a "power shower" for a pregnant friend.
Ms. Wasserstein is writing from privilege: as Heidi talks of land in Litchfield County and Bucks County, Scoop's present to the baby is a silver spoon. But Heidi's careerism doesn't preclude her perception that "what makes you a person is also what keeps you from being a person" -- and the feeling that all those movements have left her "stranded."
And don't forget the play's crucial element: braininess. "My interest is in images of women from the Renaissance Madonna to the present," Heidi declares, referring to her research on neglected female artists. It is reassuring to find a contemporary play that combines respect for intellectual discipline with talent to amuse audiences.
For all its proven appeal, "The Heidi Chronicles" is a long shot for the Forum, where musicals or plays with Jewish themes are the usual bill of fare. Tossing aside autobiographical associations, Ms. Wasserstein has made a point of saying, "Heidi is not a Jewish girl." Still, the distant sounds of a hora waft through Scoop's wedding scene on a tape made just for Forum audiences.
Peter J. Loewy's passive staging and a passable professional cast serve but do not enhance a play that, thank heaven, can fend for itself. The colors of Heidi are missing in Lori Wilner's overly agreeable performance, and the charm of Scoop needs to be extracted from David Breitbarth's.
Dan Yates as Peter is more than a cliche but less than convincing. Anna Bess Lank, Susie Paplow, Lisa Heilbrunn and Tim Herman seem unfazed by their multiple roles, as is Angela Powers by her single one.
Michael Franklin-White's bland functional set design, topped by the obligatory period images (Richard Nixon, Janis Joplin, Robert Kennedy), provides its own summing up of "The Heidi Chronicles" at the Forum: a top-of-the-line product in a generic packaging.
"The Heidi Chronicles," by Wendy Wasserstein, produced by the Forum Theater Group, 314 Main Street in Metuchen. Performances run  through Feb. 21: Thursday through Saturday, 8 P.M.; Wednesday and Sunday, 2:30 P.M. Ticket information: (908) 548-0582.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Angela Powers, left, Lori Wilner and Lisa Heilbrunn in "The Heidi Chronicles." (Forum Theater Group)

HEADLINE: The New Auto Junkyard, Borne by Taxpayers

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
ACROSS the state, municipalities are struggling with a byproduct of the poor economy: the rusting hulks of abandoned automobiles that are littering the landscape.
In all Connecticut cities, officials say, the scene is repeated with increasing frequency: A person who has wrung the last mile out of a car -- often one that has been unregistered for a couple of years, so it is difficult to trace -- pulls up to a curb or drives into a vacant lot or municipal parking garage. The driver pulls off the license plates, removes the parts he wants to keep and walks away, leaving the city with a wreck that could cost hundreds of dollars for towing, storage and disposal. 
 Police departments are finding new crops of clunkers as fast as they can clean out an area, despite efforts in several cities to track down former owners and impose fines and handling fees.
 
'Sprouted Like Mushrooms'
 The traffic commander for the Hartford police, Lieut. Karl A. Spielman, said he had two officers working full time on the problem, towing 5,000 to 6,000 wrecks a year.
"One Monday after a long weekend, we came back to an area we had just cleaned up, and they had sprouted like mushrooms after a bad storm," Lieutenant Spielman said.
In 1990 the Bridgeport Police Department hauled 777 abandoned cars to the junkyard. By last year that number had risen to more than 1,300, and Officer Salvatore A. Licitra of the department's division of abandoned motor vehicles said the number wouldprobably increase again this year. During one recent week, for instance, he said, he picked up 89 abandoned cars.
"I had a 1990 Mercury we brought in recently," Officer Licitra said. "The woman had brought it to her dealer, and he told her it needed $4,000 worth of body work and a new engine, she had abused the car so badly. She never came back for it, and the dealer didn't want it, because the repairs are more than the car was worth."
He continued: "We're scrapping 1988 and 1989 cars regularly. People are running them right into the ground. These four-cylinder cars, if you don't maintain them well, they don't last, and it's expensive to maintain a car."
Occasionally the police see more than just cars. Mayor Frank J. Esposito of Norwalk said that in the last few months his officers have picked up an old house trailer, an abandoned wooden boat -- on a trailer -- and even an old oil-tanker truck.
Robert Smigel, title review officer for the State Department of Motor Vehicles, said about 25,000 abandoned cars were reported in Connecticut last year, but that includes cars left at dealers because the owners could not afford repairs and those that were left after thieves took them on a joy ride. The department does not break out the number that have been left by the side of the road with the license plates removed and the vehicle identification numbers scratched out.
The quantity of abandoned cars has been "increasing statewide about 5 percent or so a year, but I don't know what the reason is," Mr. Smigel said. "It could be just that there are more cars on the road. And I'm sure the economy has had something to do with it."
Municipal officials say the economy is the main reason for the increase. Years ago, junkyards would pay people for old cars so they could salvage the parts, Mayor Esposito said. But with environmental regulations proliferating, junkyards must often be paid to take cars that are only good for scrap.
"A few years ago, we had two companies willing to keep the streets clean and pay us $5 or $10 for every car we had them pick up," he said. "Then they wanted money to take them away. Then they were taking them free. It changes week to week, depending on scrap prices."
 
Price of Steel a Factor
 Lieutenant Spielman agreed: "When the price of steel is up, the cars don't show up. When the price is up, people don't drop them off. But you can tell just looking at the street when the price is down."
Mr. Esposito said: "People used to buy a new car every three or four years. Now people are keeping them for 10 years, until they're falling apart, and no one wants them. And there's no end in sight."
State laws on abandoned cars have changed as the problem has grown. Three years ago it might have taken several weeks and endless paperwork to scrap a car that had been left, stripped and burned, on the side of the road. New state laws expedite the process, making it easy for a town to get rid of cars of little value that are left in one place more than 24 hours. A state fund partly reimburses towns for towing fees.
"The intent was to prevent abandoned cars from becoming a public nuisance," said the Motor Vehicle Department's director of legal services, John Yacavone. "Before the laws were changed, no one wanted to take any responsibility for cleaning them off the street."
Lieutenant Spielman of the Hartford police said the new laws have been helpful. "We didn't have many towing companies that had the 15 or 20 acres they would need to store the vehicles all that time," he said. "There were a lot more administrative hassles for the cities under the old law."
 
Drivers Lose Titles
 But local officials are still frustrated by the growing number of abandoned cars. Police Officer Nick Rendeiro of Naugatuck said that the city's three-year-old towing program scrapped 70 to 80 cars last year and that it would probably be 100 or more this year. The city has also instituted a new program to trace ownership, and when the last owner is found, he is charged $99, plus towing costs and $5 a day for storage.
Officer Rendeiro said Naugatuck determined that some of the cars were abandoned because people had lost the titles and didn't want to go through the bureaucratic maze to replace them. Without the title, an owner cannot even give a car away to a junkyard.
"The junkyard doesn't want to get stuck holding a car that might have been stolen," Officer Rendeiro said. "If you bring a car to me, I can prove it's yours by checking in the computer. We've told people that if they can't get rid of the car, give us the title, pay for the tow service, and we'll take care of it from there."
Mayor Esposito said wrecks turn up everywhere, from Norwalk's finest neighborhoods, to the business district, to cul-de-sacs that see little traffic.
"I can take you into any neighborhood, and you'll find an abandoned car, sooner or later," he said. "One was stripped, left without wheels or anything, at the entrance to the parking lot of a church on a Saturday night. We had to get someone up there with a truck to tow it out, so people could attend services."
Lieutenant Spielman said he has learned to expect abandoned cars in some areas, like Ledyard Street in the south end of Hartford, just around the corner from a junkyard.
"Maybe they found out the junk dealer didn't want them, and they dropped them off rather than take them back home," he said.
Officer Licitra of Bridgeport said: "There are dead areas, places like on the sidewalk under an interstate, where no one sees people dropping them off. I have one street that we have to hit once or twice a week just to keep it clear. Before the holidays I went down that street -- 10 cars with no plates."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Officer Salvatore A. Licitra, top, ticketing car in Bridgeport. If car is not moved in 24 hours it will be removed, above. About 1,300 cars were hauled by the department last year. (Photographs by Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Anticipating Survival After General Motors

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
SQUARING his shoulders against the bitter wind that was coming off the Hudson River last week, Mayor Frank J. Rey looked down Beekman Avenue at the bustling village center. "Everybody keeps asking me, 'Will there be life after G.M.?' " he said.
"Well, of course there will be," the Mayor said. "And perhaps in the long run, it will be even better." 
 It has been almost a year since General Motors announced it would close its automobile assembly plant here, and Mr. Rey, with other members of a task force appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last year, has begun looking at alternative uses for the 96.5-acre site, where Walker Steamer cars were produced about 90 years ago.
 
'We Do Have to Get Moving'
 They are also concerned about the fate of 2,200 blue-collar workers who now roll plastic-bodied minivans off computer-driven assembly lines but will be out of jobs once the plant's doors are shut.
"Nineteen ninety-five is coming up fast," the Mayor said. "It's not a crisis yet, but we do have to get moving."
Late last month, the task force met for the fourth time since it was created, and members conceded that their initial efforts to reverse the automaker's decision had failed.
In June, Vincent Tese, the state's director of economic development and chairman of the task force, sent a letter to Robert C. Stempel, who was chairman and chief executive of General Motors at the time, asking the automaker to reconsider its plans to close the factory.
 
Another Automaker May Be Sought
 The response was an unequivocal no, and Mr. Stempel's resignation last fall, along with news that leaders of General Motors had come under criticism for failing to close plants fast enough, further reinforced the decision that the task force would have to move ahead on other fronts.
"We're finally at a point where everyone is rolling up their sleeves and coming to grips with the fact that we have to find a post-G.M. future for North Tarrytown," said Steven Vitoff, a spokesman for Mr. Tese.
But Mr. Rey said the task force took too long and lost precious time reaching what should have been an obvious conclusion early on.
"Why did it take them until January 1993 to realize G.M. was really leaving?" he said. "And now what real plans do they have to offer?"
One option being considered by the task force is the sale of the current plant -- which occupies 2.5 million square feet, or one-and-a-fourth times the area of the World Trade Center in Manhattan -- to another auto manufacturer, although the "immediate buyer-seller dynamic for that is difficult," Mr. Vitoff said.
"It's hard to mount a sales pitch when what we're trying to sell won't be available for two and a half years," he explained.
Another option is legal action -- suing the automaker for pulling out when it obtained local tax benefits eight years ago in return for expanding the North Tarrytown site.
The township of Ypsilanti, Mich., initiated a lawsuit last month, seeking either to forestall closing of the automaker's Willow Run Assembly Plant or to win monetary damages because General Motors was given $13.5 million in tax abatements. But the automaker says that the tax agreement did not constitute a contract to continue operations.
A decision in that case is due shortly, and task force members here are watching it closely to determine whether they will recommend similar action.
The task force is also calling for an environmental assessment of the site, to be paid for by General Motors, to determine whether a clean-up will be necessary before plans for the future can proceed.
But Mr. Rey sees what he calls, "a lot of maybes and little firm action," coming from the task force. "I don't have time to waste," he said, "and, frankly, I feel like I am carrying this big weight all on my shoulders."
For the 52-year-old Mayor, who grew up here as the son of an autoworker, there have been many restless nights since he learned that the plant would close -- and much sifting through old memories.
 
A Gaping Hole Expected
 "I was raised here, and now I am raising my children in this village," said the Mayor, who remembers running down Beekman Avenue after school each day to meet his father as the plant let out and walking home together.
Mayor Rey also remembers how the village grew up around the factory and how the merchants along Beekman Avenue still earn a major part of their living from the trade of autoworkers who buy sandwiches at the luncheonettes and stop for drinks at the bars before heading home.
Not only for the shopkeepers but also for the 8,152 village residents, the automaker's departure will leave a gaping hole economically, the Mayor said. For residents, the plant closing will mean that, unless a new occupant is quickly found, the tax burden that General Motors once bore will soon be theirs.
Under a 1985 agreement that gave General Motors tax-exempt status in return for the company's expanding the plant, the company pays North Tarrytown a fixed amount each year in lieu of taxes. The agreement runs through 1994. For the current fiscal year, that contribution is $1.1 million, 19 percent of the annual budget, said William T. Regan, the Village Administrator.
 
Retraining at Issue
 The automaker is also paying the Union Free Schools of the Tarrytowns $1.8 million toward a $24 million yearly budget.
"The economic impact of the plant closing for us locally is tremendous," said Dr. Donald R. Kusel, the Superintendent of Schools.
Perhaps the greatest impact will be felt by the members of the United Auto Workers, Local 664, who may find it difficult to transfer skills to other jobs.
Although Robert P. Surowiec, a General Motors personnel director in North Tarrytown, said it was "premature" to be talking about retraining workers, a State Labor Department economist disagreed and said major re-education efforts should begin at once to help workers develop new skills in a rapidly changing marketplace.
"If these workers were laid off today, their re-employment prospects would be pretty dim, very poor indeed," said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist for the State Labor Department, who recommended that the workers "set their sights now on vocational retraining."
 
Some Will Be in Demand
 The outlook for blue-collar jobs in the 1990's suggests that sheet-metal workers, tool and dye mechanics, auto mechanics, auto body repair workers, carpenters and plumbers, for example, will be in demand. And their services will command good hourly wages -- in some cases more than the $20 an hour many now earn with General Motors, Mr. Surdey said.
For an auto worker like Peter Donnelly, a 47-year-old electrician and a benefits representative for the union, the choices could include choosing an early-retirement package, training for a new career or both.
"But we're only talking about $600 a month in retirement," said Mr. Donnelly, who has worked for General Motors for eight years. "So that alone isn't going to be enough to live on. It won't even pay my mortgage."
"In a way, I'm caught in a bind," he said. "Too young to retire, too set to move away and too old to compete with younger workers on the outside. But whatever, if I have to wash dishes to survive, I will."
Some of the 2,200 workers still in North Tarrytown -- about 800 were laid off in August when the plant dropped its second shift -- will be offered the chance to move to other assembly plants, said Margaret G. Holmes, director of public affairs for the automaker's mid-size car division in Detroit.
 
Other Communities Studied
 But if even as few as 1,500 workers find themselves on the unemployment lines once the plant closes, Westchester's jobless rate will surge. Adding 1,500 workers to the 24,700 already unemployed in December, for example, would drive the rate up to 6 percent from 5.6 percent, "a sizable jump," Mr. Surdey said.
With layoffs from many companies expected to continue, Mr. Surdey said that the closing of the North Tarrytown plant is an example of why an economic recovery will "not proceed fully for some time to come."
Meanwhile, Mayor Rey -- along with a task force committee that he formed consisting of government leaders and business people -- is looking at other communities where General Motors has closed plants. The Mayor said he remains optimistic that "a company for the 1990's" will move to the North Tarrytown site.
In Norwood, Ohio, the old General Motors plant was demolished at the automaker's expense and the town built an information-processing center in its place. In Lakewood, Ga., the defunct assembly plant was purchased by a recycler.
"Here we are," Mr. Rey said, "on the shores of the Hudson River, near rail, road and water transportation, near major highways, near airports."
"How about an industrial park or a financial center? This is a great location. So, I ask the question again, 'Is there going to be life after G.M.?' Well, there's no doubt in my mind."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Frank J. Rey looking over the General Motors automobile assembly plant in North Tarrytown. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: February 8, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1541 words

HEADLINE: U.S. WILL DRAW UP A STRATEGY TO AID EX-SOVIET STATES

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration intends to create a supercommittee in the State Department to shape a unified strategy toward Russia and the other former Soviet republics, but has no intention of immediately increasing foreign aid to the area, senior Administration officials say.
In an effort to avoid what it considers President Bush's haphazard approach to the problem, the Administration has chosen Strobe Talbott, a journalist and author who has written extensively about the Soviet Union, to head the committee in his capacity as Ambassador-at-Large to Russia and the other newly independent republics. 
 Although Mr. Talbott is said to advocate an aggressive diplomatic campaign to promote reform and reduce the threat of nuclear weapons, he prefers a cautious approach on committing new aid, officials familiar with his thinking said.
 
A Focus on Russia
 The Administration, despite its early attention to crises in Bosnia, Somalia, Haiti and Iraq, has already begun to characterize the fate of Russia as the country's most important national security problem in the next decade.
If Russia disintegrates, the argument goes, it could put 20,000 nuclear weapons into the wrong hands, unleash ethnic wars on Russian soil and destabilize the region, a crisis that could "make Bosnia pale in comparison," George Kolt, a top Central Intelligence Agency specialist on the former Soviet Union, told a Senate panel last week.
By defining the debate in this way, the Administration has hopes of eventually convincing a public focused on its domestic needs that new aid to Russia is essential to American economic and political well-being.
 
New Aid Criteria
 "You sell it as an investment in your own security, that if you don't do it, it's a missed opportunity and it makes the world a more dangerous place," said one senior Administration official.
Despite Mr. Clinton's criticism of President Bush during the campaign for not committing enough aid to Russia, the thinking in the new Administration is that it will not propose spending more money than is already committed unless three specific criteria are met: Any program must have the full support of Congress and the American people; it must have a concrete impact on promoting democracy and a free-market economy, and it must be accomplished through the Group of Seven industrialized countries and other potential aid donors.
Instead of pouring in new aid, the Administration will develop an approach that will blend political, diplomatic and technical assistance with ideas about how to do more with available money. Because of the urgency of the situation, the Administration aims to have the outlines of the new policy in place for Secretary of State Warren Christopher's meeting with Russian Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev in Geneva on Feb. 25.
Senior Administration officials awaiting their Senate confirmation hearings have discovered in visiting key senators that although there is considerable rhetorical support on Capitol Hill for saving Russia, there is a great deal of resistance to adding more American money to accomplish that goal.
Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican, captured the sentiments of many of his Senate colleagues on the aid issue.
When asked about the prospects of persuading the American people to give more money to Russia, he replied: "Between extremely, extremely difficult and impossible. None of the ground has been prepared, and that takes a long time."
 
Loans, Grants and Credit
 Just how much aid the United States has committed to Russia and the other republics is difficult to calculate and subject to dispute because the aid involves outright grants, loans and credit guarantees, which may be subject to certain restrictions and distributed through multicountry programs. The United States has pledged $9.2 billion in aid to the independent republics of the former Soviet Union from 1991 through 1993. American aid in the current fiscal year will total about $3 billion.
Members of the still-to-be-announced Steering Committee on the former Soviet Union, as it is expected to be called, have been meeting informally in recent days as part of intensive brainstorming sessions. As chairman, Mr. Talbott, who has yet to be confirmed, would in effect be the Administration's policy director for the 15 former republics and would report directly to the National Security Council.
Mr. Talbott would have direct access to President Clinton, a close friend since their days as Rhodes Scholars at Oxford University.
"The object clearly was to give special prominence and attention to a very critical area, which is the newly independent states," Deputy Secretary of State Clifton R. Wharton Jr. said in an interview. "Given Strobe's very special background and knowledge and experience in this arena you could hardly find a better person to do this."
 
No Doubt on Clout
 Another senior Administration official put it more bluntly: "Strobe, as everyone knows, was Bill Clinton's roommate at Oxford. So there shouldn't be any doubt about his clout within the bureaucracy."
Although the Administration has yet to formulate its policy, trends in the thinking of Mr. Talbott and his team have emerged:
*President Boris N. Yeltsin's economic and political reforms are the best hope of reducing Russia's nuclear and conventional weapons arsenal, and the Administration will go out of its way to bolster him as a partner of the United States. The Administration intends to act as a broker on a range of issues, including persuading Ukraine to ratify the Start treaty and helping to resolve flash points in Tajikistan, the Caucasus and Nagorno-Karabakh.
*The Russian aid issue must be wrenched from the hands of what one official called the "economist gnomes and the arms-control nerds" and elevated to the level of high diplomacy. To that end, the Administration will increase pressure on the International Monetary Fund to treat Russia as a special case and loosen lending restrictions and will move to strengthen the Group of Seven industrialized countries on Russian aid issues.
 
Some Are Left Out
 *Embassies in the former Soviet Union should be transformed into outposts for promoting American businesses and helping Americans who are eager to invest but who are overwhelmed by the logistical headaches of doing business there.
*A higher priority should be placed on direct and technical assistance to help Russia dismantle its nuclear weapons and dispose of its nuclear materials; find civilian employment for nuclear technicians, and create housing so that demobilized soldiers can return home.
In a move intended to keep the committee small, but certain to be resisted, the C.I.A., the Commerce Department and the Council of Economic Advisers will not be part of the committee, but will be invited to participate.
Vice-chairman of the new committee will be Tobi Gati, the National Security Council's senior official dealing with the former Soviet Union. Other members will include Frank Wisner, the Under Secretary of Defense-designate for Policy; Lynn Davis, the Under Secretary of State-designate for Economic Affairs, and Lawrence Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury-designate for International Affairs.
Mr. Talbott's appointment has unleashed a wave of high anxiety in the ever-anxious State Department and has caused confusion over the organizational charts in the Bureau of European Affairs. That bureau will retain its office for the 15 former republics, and will still be responsible for Administrative and consular matters and for such multilateral issues as the relationship with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
But the office will report directly to Mr. Talbott on these matters. And all policy issues for the republics of the former Soviet Union will be handled by Mr. Talbott and his own staff.
The committee will retain the post now held by Richard Armitage, who was named the State Department's coordinator for humanitarian aid to the former Soviet republics by President George Bush. Mr. Armitage has been widely praised by Clinton aides but will be replaced shortly as Mr. Talbott puts his own team into place.
 
Pentagon Divided
 Complicating matters are splits within the Pentagon over how to divide responsibility for the former Soviet Union among six assistant secretaries, each of whom is entitled to parts of the portfolio, and over the extent to which the Pentagon will be willing to cede authority to Mr. Talbott.
At least for now, the new approach enjoys the support of key lawmakers who are determined to do more for Moscow.
"The Bush folks would say to us that our Government is not set up that way when we made proposals," said Senator Richard Lugar, the Indiana Republican who, with help from Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat, pushed through an ambitious aid program last year to dismantle Russia's nuclear weapons.
"Treasury had a different agenda -- not to spend money -- and all sorts of controls, and Commerce was more concerned about uranium-dumping on the American market than the importance of buying Russia's highly enriched uranium. The new team has to be able to do arms control and economics and politics simultaneously."

HEADLINE: Message and Morality;
Concerns Over Public Relations and Ethics Clash in the Crisis of Clinton's First Weeks

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The capital is running a fever, gripped by the frenzy that sets in every so often when morality and expediency get tangled up.
This time, Bill Clinton is in the soup. Mr. Clinton, who came to Washington as a populist and economic savior of the middle class, has once again been diverted by questions of the ethical standards and calculated diversity of his Administration. 
 In a Presidential debut that could have been scripted by vengeful Republicans, the new President has lurched from one problem to another. First, gay issues dominated the agenda. Then, senior citizens were upset over an Administration trial balloon suggesting that Social Security benefits might be frozen. Now women are angry about possible double standards and the hash the Administration has made of its plan to name a woman as Attorney General.
The new President stayed home most of the weekend, perhaps pondering his scalding experience with one of the capital's truths, as set out by Lyn Nofziger, the former Reagan aide who once got caught in one of the town's seasonal ethical sandstorms: "Most of the moral judgments in Washington boil down to political judgments, and a lot of people suffer from it, unfairly."
The whole scene made James Carville, the Clinton campaign strategist who still offers advice to the White House, blanch. "It has been said by others and I'll say it again: no one ever satisfied the liberal interest groups," said Mr. Carville, who was working the phones in his office today trying to assure everyone that this, too, shall pass. "Maybe God is punishing us for not picking someone with a normal name, like Mary or Susan or Elizabeth."
 
Trying to Look Blase
 On Friday, George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's spokesman, had raced around, vainly trying to persuade reporters at the White House that the day's story was the signing of the family leave bill, not the abrupt way the White House had pushed Kimba M. Wood, a Federal district judge in New York whom Mr. Clinton had settled on for Attorney General, off the sled.
By today, the White House was trying to appear blase, and officials noted that after Dick Cheney became Secretary of Defense, no one remembered all the brouhaha about John G. Tower and his drinking and womanizing, and that after Anthony M. Kennedy became a Supreme Court Justice, no one cared any more about Douglas H. Ginsburg and his marijuana problems.
"I think there's too much hysterical instant analysis going on," said one top White House official. "We're going to get an Attorney General confirmed and everything will be fine."
Among historians outside Washington, however, there was surprise at the continuing White House confusion and fear that in this new era of electronic populism, officials were less worried about how to earn a profile in courage than how to avoid getting bashed on the Rush Limbaugh show.
 
'Moralistic on Tiny Things'
 "There seems to be a real dearth of serious moral reflection in Washington that existed through the 80's and is continuing in the Clinton Administration," said James Davison Hunter, a sociology professor at the University of Virginia and the author of "Culture Wars: The Struggle to Define America." "The habit in Washington is to compensate for shallow moral reflection by being incredibly moralistic on tiny things. People go nuts over these little things."
In the latest incident, both Mr. Clinton and Judge Wood have suffered. Once again, the President was being criticized for needlessly hurting the reputation of a respected woman candidate for Attorney General. But while Mr. Clinton was scored for waiting too long to act in the case of Zoe Baird, this time around he was criticized for acting too swiftly, before the public had even weighed in.
Judge Wood and her defenders protested that the President had acted out of a fear of bad public relations and not because she had done anything to disqualify herself from the job. Ms. Baird had broken the law, they said, while Judge Wood had hired an illegal immigrant before it was illegal to do so, had filed all the proper papers and paid the necessary taxes.
"Given what happened to Zoe Baird it was all the more important that he stick by Kimba Wood once the White House had in effect announced the appointment, because she had done nothing wrong," said Alan Brinkley, a professor of American history at Columbia University. "He didn't have the courage of his convictions and that will make it much more difficult for women to be appointed to anything."
The White House says Judge Wood was disingenuous in failing to give the President and his aides the information about her child care that they were clearly seeking. Indeed, it appears that Judge Wood gave Mr. Clinton the same sort of answer that he himself specialized in during his campaign on the subject of marijuana, the draft and taxes: semantically correct but leaving out some information of vital interest to the listener.
"Bill Clinton was a little less than forthright on issues in his personal life during the campaign and now all of a sudden he's pointing at Kimba Wood and saying, 'You were too legalistic with me,' " said Mr. Nofziger, whose conviction on illegal influence peddling was overturned after the case took an enormous toll on his business, health and finances. "He could have at least stood up right away and said: 'Kimba Wood did nothing illegal. She and I don't see eye to eye.' Instead he let her go away under a cloud."
Strategists in both parties said the latest problem at the White House served only to reinforce the impression that Mr. Clinton is too intent on satisfying too many people and that he is too prone to cave in when faced with potential political consequences.
The events since Thursday have also made it clear that Mr. Clinton's White House has not yet developed smoothly running political and communications operations.
"If you have no strategic plan and if all you do is react to the media and various constituency groups, that just chews you up fast," said Edward J. Rollins, a Republican consultant. "First impressions matter, and in this case the impression is that people don't have their act together. Even their own Democratic team on the Hill is getting panicky."
Fred Greenstein, a historian at Princeton University who specializes in the Presidency, was also puzzled. "It's odd, given that Clinton seemed to be so ready to go, so facile and so bright at the Little Rock economic summit," he said. "Now there is no sense of momentum. It's almost as if they're thinking like children. After they wake up from their nap, life begins."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Building Offices Despite Many Vacancies

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Although the nation's commercial real estate market remains glutted with vacant space, Congress is spending several billion dollars building new offices for Federal workers here and in other cities.
Most of this money is being spent on projects, like the Federal office building going up in Foley Square in Manhattan, that were in advanced stages of planning or under construction before the market turned sour. But as recently as October, Congress appropriated $626 million to start 35 projects. 
 The Government, supported by developers and unions, maintains that the new construction will create jobs and provide Federal workers with the most modern offices possible. But critics of the new projects, including landlords and urban planners, contend that many were approved simply as a favor to Congress when much cheaper space was available.
 
Slipped Into Budget
 In October, Congress approved construction of 15 courthouses with adjacent office buildings. It also approved 10 new office buildings, costing more than $75 million, that had never been reviewed by the General Services Administration, the agency charged with managing and constructing Federal office space. These projects, which were slipped into the annual Federal appropriations legislation by various lawmakers, include a $4 million Social Security Administration building in Chicago, which has a 22 percent vacancy rate, and a $10 million Federal building in San Francisco, which has a 12.5 percent vacancy rate downtown and 13 percent vacancies overall.
Congress also approved spending $1.2 billion on leases for buildings that are being erected for long-term Federal tenants here, where the downtown has a 17.1 percent vacancy rate, and in Atlanta, which has a 33 percent vacancy rate downtown and 23.6 percent rate overall.
Real estate experts and urban specialists say the construction program is wasteful, and even Federal auditors say the Government cannot justify the expense. The auditors say problems with the construction program fit a longstanding pattern of mismanagement by the General Services Administration, which spends about $10 billion a year on office space, telecommunications and computers in 7,400 Federally owned or leased buildings.
"Public buildings policy is in disarray, and the American taxpayer is certainly not getting value for the burgeoning dollars being spent," said L. Nye Stevens, director of Government business operations at the accounting office, the auditing arm of Congress.
The auditors also criticized the agency for having failed to buy a single office building available at bargain prices from the Resolution Trust Corporation or from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which have 9,000 office buildings for sale.
 
Congress Is Faulted
 David L. Bibb, an assistant commissioner for planning at the agency, said that many of the auditors' conclusions were faulty and that his agency could justify most of its projects. But he said members of Congress often authorized money for pet projects instead of the projects recommended by the agency.
The economic downturn has drawn attention to the Government's real estate practices. Federal construction projects, promoted by labor unions and real estate developers, help to create jobs, stimulate local economies and assure that thousands of Federal office workers remain in town.
But landlords who may lose Federal tenants, as well as real estate experts, public policy professionals and urban specialists maintain that putting up a building just to create temporary construction jobs ignores long-term harm to older downtown blocks. "This is the kind of strong medicine that is likely to further injure the already sick urban patient," said George Sternlieb, a retired professor of urban planning at Rutgers University.
 
Conflicting Policies
 Federal auditors say the General Services Administration is a poor manager, which also has to deal with conflicting political, economic and legal pressures. There are, for example, four conflicting policies that determine where Federal office buildings should be built. While one law says the buildings should be evenly distributed around the nation, another law says priority should be given to rural locations. A budget office directive requires regional offices of agencies to be located in 10 major cities, and an executive order signed by President Jimmy Carter says Federal buildings must be concentrated in urban downtowns.
"When policies cancel each other out, it means there is no policy," said Mr. Stevens, the Federal auditor.
A study in Atlanta conducted by the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen for the real estate industry estimated that a planned 1.8-million-square-foot Federal building will increase the vacancy rate downtown to 47 percent. The study also estimated that over the 27-year life of the lease the new building would cost taxpayers $166 million more than leasing vacant space in existing modern buildings and $505 million more than Federal agencies would spend on rent if they did not move.
But General Services officials said the Government did not want space in most older buildings. Since the mid-1980's, they said, it has been Government policy to improve working conditions for employees by moving them into new buildings with high-quality office space, even if it means moving workers out of renovated buildings.
 
Debate Rages for Months
 A public debate has been raging for months in Philadelphia over new Federal offices being built by the Postal Service and leased to the General Services Agency for use by regional offices of the Environmental Protection Agency, the Internal Revenue Service and other agencies. None of the space will be used by the Postal Service, which was authorized to develop real estate for profit when it was created as a quasi-private corporation in 1991.
General Services officials say they need a single modern building, and local elected officials support the project.
Landlords say the Government could save money by keeping Federal agencies where they are, in several renovated buildings, or by scattering them among modern buildings that have two million square feet of vacant space.
Federal auditors say taxpayers will never know whether the Government is wasting money in Philadelphia because the General Services agency did not request proposals to compete with its new building.
 
No Bid Is Needed
 Because this development project is a deal between Federal agencies, there was no obligation to seek competitive bids for the space. Congress approved spending $490 million on a 20-year lease of the building, which is costing the Postal Service $192 million to build.
"Politics is driving this deal, nothing else," said Peter Linneman, director of the Wharton Real Estate Center at the University of Pennsylvania.
Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, was re-elected in November with the support of normally Democratic construction trade unions in Philadelphia, partly in recognition of his success in bringing this project and its 1,000 construction jobs to the city.
Mr. Specter said the project was economically sound. "I sat down with the G.S.A. people, and they are a very inarticulate lot," he said in an interview last week. "But if you dig out the facts, you can find out they have a very solid case for this building."

HEADLINE: SIHANOUK MOVING TO REGAIN POWER

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Twenty-three years after his ouster as Cambodia's head of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk is moving quickly to reclaim power here, this time with the support of nations that he once considered his enemies to the death.
The United Nations is on the verge of revising the 1991 Cambodian peace accords to allow the election of a President as well as a legislature, a move that would all but guarantee the Prince's return to power this spring or summer. 
 Even before the revisions, the 70-year-old Prince has announced that he is a presidential candidate, although he insists his decision is not final. Friends say that his uncertainty appears to be a negotiating ploy. In a nation that has known only civil war or terror for a generation, there is no other figure in Cambodia with enough broad popular support to challenge him.
The prince is to return here within the next few days from Beijing, where he has been receiving medical treatment after a mild stroke in November.
 
'The Essential Cement'
 "Sihanouk is the only answer," said John Gunther Dean, a former American ambassador to Cambodia who has known Prince Sihanouk since the early 1950's and visits Cambodia frequently. "I have been known all my career as a defender of Sihanouk. I know that he is the essential cement in Cambodia."
The nations tacitly supporting him include the United States, which the prince has long suspected was involved in the 1970 coup that put his handpicked Prime Minister, Lon Nol, in charge.
Diplomats and other students of modern Cambodian history say there is reason to be concerned about Prince Sihanouk, saying his mercurial personality, political misjudgments and reluctance to share authority were at least partly to blame for the coup and the subsequent rise to power of the Maoist-inspired rebels of the Khmer Rouge.
The Khmer Rouge overran Cambodia in 1975 under the nominal patronage of Prince Sihanouk, setting off a four-year reign of terror that left at least several hundred thousand and perhaps more than one million Cambodians dead from starvation, disease and execution.
 
Alliance With Khmer Rouge
 Even after the Khmer Rouge were toppled by Vietnamese troops in 1979 -- and after the mass killings of the Khmer Rouge years were fully exposed -- the Prince aligned himself with the Khmer Rouge against the Hanoi-installed Government.
"It's a matter of there being nobody else; there is only Sihanouk," said a senior Asian diplomat here. "When Sihanouk ruled, he didn't tolerate the rise of a new generation of leaders. He didn't want rivals. And when the Khmer Rouge took over, anyone with leadership skills or talent was killed."
Whatever their misgivings, many in Cambodia agree that the Prince is the best hope for national reconciliation.
Operating from his homes in exile in Beijing and North Korea, Prince Sihanouk was the moving force behind years of negotiations that led to the October 1991 peace treaty. In November 1991, after spending most of a generation in exile from Cambodia, the Prince returned to Phnom Penh and took up his new role as chairman of the Supreme National Council created as part of the peace settlement to represent all factions.
Without a coalition government, Cambodia will face de facto partitioning, with a separate state under the control of the Khmer Rouge and the likelihood of continued fighting.
The Prince's hopes of returning to power may yet be dashed by either the Government, which is believed to be responsible for recent violence against the royalist political party led by one of Prince Sihanouk's sons, or by the Khmer Rouge, who are boycotting the election to protest what they call the continued presence of Vietnamese troops in Cambodia.
The United Nations, which maintains 22,000 peacekeepers here seems determined to go ahead with the election, whatever the threats.
The Khmer Rouge boycott has raised fears that the guerrillas will attempt to sabotage the balloting with violence. But Lieut. Gen. John Sanderson, an Australian who is the United Nations military commander in Cambodia, said that he believes the elections will be largely peaceful.
"They might be able to stop the election in certain places -- but not across the country," he said.
 
Opposition to Sanctions
 Some diplomats here are equally hopeful about the intentions of the Khmer Rouge, saying that it is in the guerrillas' best interests to allow the vote, then see what offer is made to them. The prince recently spoke out against proposals in the United Nations to impose new sanctions on the rebel group, insisting that the sanctions were of no use.
In an in interview conducted last month in Beijing with The Far Eastern Economic Review, Prince Sihanouk, who is rarely accused of understatement, lashed out at all four factions in Cambodia and suggested that he was the only hope for peace in this war-shattered nation.
"Everybody is rotten, everybody," he said. "People are very upset. They say only Sihanouk is clean; the only one is Sihanouk. He should be made to come back and take charge of everything."
He continued, "I absolutely wish, my only ambition before dying, before becoming senile, is to render a last service to my country."

LENGTH: 700 words

HEADLINE: G.O.P. IS OPPOSED TO ECONOMIC PLAN

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Signaling that Republicans plan to oppose at least part of President Clinton's economic program, Senator Robert Dole, the minority leader, and three other Republican Senators said today that they disagreed with the Administration's plans for a short-term stimulus package because it would increase the deficit this year.
Mr. Clinton's economic aides have repeatedly talked about a stimulus program of $15 billion to $30 billion that would seek to create jobs and to insure that the economy does not slide back into the doldrums. 
 In a letter to Mr. Clinton today, the four Republicans said, "We fail to see how any short-term 'stimulus' package of $10 to $30 billion can have any significant impact on our economy that is now experiencing a solid recovery."
They added, "The economy already is experiencing a $320 billion 'stimulus' in the form of our annual deficit and such a package may simply add to that debt load."
 
'Spending Is the Problem'
 Besides Mr. Dole, the Senators who signed the letter were Don Nickles of Oklahoma, chairman of the Republican Policy Committee, and the two co-chairmen of the Republican Economic Policy Task Force, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Bob Packwood of Oregon.
"We think the economy is recovering," Mr. Domenici said today on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." "And I would remind listeners that in January it added 105,000 new jobs. That's about half of what anybody's major stimulus package was going to produce, spending $20, $30, or even $40 billion. What we are saying is, spending is the problem in the United States."
In attacking the stimulus program, the Republicans seemed to be asserting that the economy President George Bush handed over to his successor was in good shape, three previous years of anemic growth notwithstanding. In the fourth quarter of 1992, the economy grew by a fairly robust annual rate of 3.8 percent.
 
Fighting Unemployment
 Despite the Republican criticisms, Administration officials made it clear today that they were still tilting heavily in favor of a stimulus program.
Defending such a move, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, appearing on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" said: "The fact is that unemployment isn't down enough. There are still layoffs, still plant closings. We're pleased that some of the statistics coming in are looking favorable. We want them to keep looking favorable. And that's why a modest stimulus package is in order."
In an appearance on "Face the Nation," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said Mr. Clinton was elected to create jobs. "If it takes a stimulus package, well, then it's going to take a stimulus package," he said.
Mr. Reich said that the Administration was seriously considering three proposals that Mr. Clinton made during his campaign: raising the income tax rate on the wealthy to 36 percent, placing a surtax on millionaires and raising the alternative minimum tax.
 
Corporate Tax Mentioned
 He added that "an increase in the corporate tax" was on the table but it was unclear whether Mr. Reich was talking about raising the corporate income tax rate, currently 34 percent, or about increasing the collection of corporate taxes.
Mr. Clinton has repeatedly pledged to increase the amount of taxes collected from foreign corporations, asserting that they do not pay their fair share.
White House officials declined to say today whether Mr. Reich was broaching the idea of an increase in the corporate income tax. During the campaign, Mr. Clinton did not propose such an increase.
Asked to amplify Mr. Reich's remarks about an increase in corporate taxes, Jeff Eller, a White House spokesman, responded that throughout the campaign Mr. Clinton said that those who earn more would have to "pay their fair share."
"That applies to corporations and citizens," he said, adding, "What the President says today is no different from what President Clinton said throughout the campaign."
In their letter, Mr. Dole and the three other Republicans seemed to lay the groundwork to attack Mr. Clinton's economic plan if a significant portion of his deficit-reduction package comes in the form of tax increases rather than spending cuts.

HEADLINE: Clinton Keeping Foreign Policy on a Back Burner

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
During a meeting of the President's top economic advisers last week, the Deputy Budget Director, Alice M. Rivlin, was describing areas of the country that would be affected by the withdrawal of a Federal timber subsidy when she found herself being corrected by President Clinton over which trees were found where.
A short time later, Mr. Clinton's top foreign policy advisers were gathered in the Roosevelt Room poring over a map of Bosnia, in a nearly four-hour session intended to establish the Administration's policy for the Balkans, its first major foreign-policy initiative. The President did not correct anyone about details on Bosnia. He did not attend. 
 While Bill Clinton is being accused of stepping back from some campaign promises, there is one promise that for now he appears to be holding firm to: spending less time than his predecessor enmeshed in the nitty gritty of foreign policy.
When Mr. Clinton gathered his Cabinet and other top advisers at Camp David last weekend, some in the room were struck by what was missing when he ticked off what he viewed as the goals of his Administration for the first 100 days.
 
No Mention of Foreign Policy
 The list went like this: economic recovery plan, health care plan, welfare reform, political reform, national service. There was not a single mention of a foreign-policy objective. No wonder some lower-ranking members of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy team have confided to their colleagues working on economic and health policy about how jealous they are at the quality time the number-crunchers get to spend with the President, as compared with those dealing with foreign affairs.
"The President has basically told us all, if he can get an economic package through Congress and a health package through Congress, everything will be all right," said one senior Administration official. "If he can't, it won't be all right. I'm sure he's interested in foreign policy, but right now it's just not where he is focused. It's not where he is emersing himself in the details. None of us would accuse him of micro-managing it."
It is not that Mr. Clinton is ignoring the myriad problems that confront the United States abroad, say aides, but rather that he has essentially delegated foreign-policy formulation to Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Defense Secretary Les Aspin, the national security adviser, W. Anthony Lake and Mr. Lake's deputy, Samuel R. Berger.
On domestic policy issues, Mr. Clinton is personally absorbed in the give and take. But on foreign policy he has basically asked these aides to work out solutions and then submit them to him to be approved or rejected.
 
Policies and Briefings
 Under broad guidelines set by Mr. Clinton, they worked out the policy on how to limit the influx of Haitian refugees and then briefed him about it; they worked out the compromise on the deportees in Lebanon and then briefed him about it, and they are working up the new policy for Bosnia and briefing him about it. They were also the architects of a more integrated approach to coordinating policy toward Russia and the other former Soviet republics.
Obviously, say aides, the President is kept abreast of all the internal discussions and weighs in when he wants -- which can be fairly frequently -- but foreign affairs is clearly not his passion, or his preoccupation.
"He is there to do things when asked," said one foreign-policy official. "But that is the extent of it."
Some top Clinton aides make no apologies for his priorities.
"That is why he is President and George Bush isn't," remarked one when asked why the President did not seem very deeply involved in foreign affairs.
Since coming to office Mr. Clinton has had phone conversations with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel. He has had brief meetings with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada and the German Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel. Mr. Bush did more in an average day. Mr. Clinton still has not held a meeting of his National Security Council.
At least some who know the President well suggest that he still may be just a little intimidated by foreign matters. Some even go so far as to suggest that one of the reasons Mr. Clinton chose the 67-year-old Mr. Christopher to run his State Department is because he sees him as an elder statesman who can take care of the thorny foreign-policy matters that Mr. Clinton simply does not want to be troubled with now and is still unsure about.
"I think that the most interesting thing is that Mr. Clinton has not been present for a lot of the discussions," said one lower-ranking adviser. "My sense of it is that he does not like this stuff because he is not the master of it. He is not familiar with the details and he is not familiar with the people giving him the advice. He does not have that same well of knowledge to draw on that he does in domestic policy. Don't underestimate how raw he is."
Mr. Clinton, like his predecessors, begins his day with a briefing from a representative of the Central Intelligence Agency on developments overnight in world affairs, with Mr. Lake, Mr. Berger and Vice President Al Gore also present. The White House Chief of Staff, Thomas McLarty, also attends occasionally.
 
Marching Orders
 The briefing is followed by a discussion between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Lake over what the foreign policy apparatus will be concentrating on during the day, to make certain that they are moving in the general direction Mr. Clinton wants. Also during these sessions the President will occassionally seek some specific information about an issue.
And then they "go off and do it," said one official.
Whether Mr. Clinton will be able to maintain his approach to foreign policy will depend in part on whether a crisis abroad demands more of his attention and in part on the ability of his subordinates to design policies that work.
Mr. Clinton has been confronting some of the same problems delivering on campaign promises on foreign policy that he has in domestic affairs. He promised, for instance, to be more flexible than Mr. Bush in allowing in Haitian refugees seeking political asylum. That promise alone threatened to result in an outflow of people from Haiti, forcing his Administration to tighten Mr. Bush's restrictions by setting up a virtual naval blockade around the island while it tries to come up with a long-term political solution.
 
Looking at an Uphill Climb
 Where Mr. Clinton's advisers thought they could introduce early innovations in foreign policy, in places like Bosnia, they are finding it much harder going. And where they thought they could just count on continuity and inertia early on -- in the Arab-Israeli peace talks or with Iraq -- they are discovering that there is no possibility for progress without a major committment of time and energy by the new Administration.
These tensions were particularly apparent in the case of Bosnia, where Mr. Clinton vowed to take a more activist approach than Mr. Bush in limiting Serbian attacks. That instinct prompted his Administration to reject the peace plan drawn up by the United Nations and European Community mediators, Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, on the grounds that it gave too much to the Serbs. But the rejection came before there was a credible alternative.
That alternative is now being drawn up. But the problem the Clinton advisers have encountered is that any alternative would require a much more active role by the United States, not only at the negotiating table, but also in the form of diplomatic, economic and possibly even military pressures to coax the warring parties in Bosnia into a deal they all might accept. That has prompted some internal disputes over just how deeply the new Administration should get involved.
Charles William Maynes, editor of the magazine Foreign Policy, said, "The Administration is trying to reconcile its campaign positions with reality, and the fit has not always been very precise."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
THE ENDURING LEGACY OF ARTHUR ASHE
If a place in New York City evokes Arthur Ashe's spirit, it is surely the Harlem Tennis Center's makeshift courts, inside the cavernous 369th Regiment Armory building at 143d Street and Fifth Avenue in Harlem. It was there in 1968 -- the same year that Mr. Ashe became the first black to win the United States Open men's singles championships -- that the Harlem Junior Tennis Program was founded, to give minority children a chance to play a sport that had long been dominated by whites, until Mr. Ashe came along. The former tennis champion died Saturday afternoon at the age of 49. A1.
 
HOUSING PROGRAM STALLED IN WASHINGTON
Since the late 1980's, money from a Federal tax break for corporations has put thousands of low-income New Yorkers into new homes. Now legislation that would renew the financing is stalled in Washington, and that, coupled with state budget cuts, threatens plans for dozens of affordable housing developments in the state this year. A1. 

A RACIAL QUOTA UNDER ATTACK
In a recent court case that went virtually unnoticed at the time, an unusual racial quota sanctioned by New York City's government was declared unconstitutional by a Federal judge. The ruling -- arising from a suit that challenged a section of the the City Charter intended to make municipal government more representative -- challenged the legality of a 15-member commission that included at least one resident of each borough and members of racial and language minority groups that reflect the population of the city. Metro Matters, B2.
 
WEIGHING THE CHANCELLOR'S FATE
Since it became clear last week that the Board of Education might not renew Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's contract, there has been tumultuous lobbying for the deciding vote, which will most likely be that of Carol Gresser, the Queens representative. B3.
 
Police arrest three in a high-volume heroin operation in Greenwich Village. B3.
 
A 39-year-old woman is fatally shot by a robber in her Washington Heights apartment. B3.
 
REGION
 
SHOOTING RANGE UNDER FIRE
In the hills of Cortlandt, in the backwoods of Westchester, the county government 31 years ago chose to locate a public firing range that defies the genteel golf and tennis image the nation has about the area. Over the years, hunters and shooting enthusiasts have pierced countless bull's-eyes and shattered innumerable clay pigeons, and their spent ammunition has dropped a mother lode of lead in the moist black soil of the range. That lead -- 500 tons by some estimates -- has now been called a danger to the health of children and wildlife by Federal and state authorities, and it has become the center of a local dispute that is echoed in many of the 8,000 recreational ranges elsewhere in the nation. B7.
 
COLLEGE AID PROGRAM IN THE RED
A New York State program that helps low- and middle-income residents pay their college tuition is running more than $100 million in the red for a second year in a row because of the lingering recession, a state budget official says. As layoffs have reduced many two-income families to one income and people with jobs have been forced to take pay cuts or work fewer hours, more students from these families have become eligible for grants from the Tuition Assistance Program, or T.A.P., according to the state's Budget Division. The same factors, a spokeswoman said, make more students eligible for full, rather than partial, grants. B7.
 
SOLDIERS' NEW BATTLE: TO EMIGRATE
Uldarico D. Dumdum remembers fighting for the United States during World War II in the Philippines. Therefore, he was shattered to learn that his petition for United States citizenship had been rejected because his name could not be found in the Department of the Army's records in St. Louis. It is a story of rejection that has become familiar to Filipino veterans who won permission to apply for citizenship under provisions of the 1990 Immigration Act and then found that their applications were rejected because the Army did not have records of their service. B7.

HEADLINE: College Aid Program Is Threatened by Cuts

 BODY:
A New York State program that helps low- and middle-income residents pay their college tuition is running more than $100 million in the red for a second year in a row because of the lingering recession, a state budget official said yesterday.
As layoffs have reduced many two-income families to one income and people with jobs have been forced to take pay cuts or work fewer hours, more students from these families have become eligible for grants from the Tuition Assistance Program, or T.A.P., said Claudia S. Hutton, spokeswoman for the state's Budget Division. The same factors, she said, make more students eligible for full, rather than partial, grants. 
 The increases led to a $100.7 million shortfall in T.A.P. in the 1992-93 fiscal year, which ends March 31, following a $111.8 million shortfall in the 1991-92 fiscal year, Miss Hutton said.
To cover the red ink last year, the State Legislature approved extra money. It also reduced the maximum grant and tightened eligibility requirements. The Budget Division is now preparing another request to the Legislature to cover the shortfall, Miss Hutton said. She said that this year's shortfall had been anticipated, and the funds to cover the gap had been subtracted from an expected surplus in the state budget.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed a $30 million cut in T.A.P. in his 1993-1994 state budget released last month. The cuts would mostly affect middle-class families, with some students receiving T.A.P. grants nearly $1,000 smaller, Miss Hutton said.
Nearly 300,000 students receive grants that will total $614.4 million in the current fiscal year.

The Economy
A growing number of factories are shifting into higher gear, piling overtime on workers to handle the upswing. The stepped-up production is sometimes hard to discern in the dust kicked up by wounded corporate giants like G.M., Sears and I.B.M. And the companies enjoying a surge in business are not suddenly putting out the call for thousands of new workers. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Businesses Turning to Vietnam

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
Almost 18 years after United States diplomats fled Saigon before the advancing Communist troops, American capitalists are trickling back, hoping to employ their former enemies and ready the country for a corporate invasion.
A trade delegation of about 30 American business people arrived in Hanoi this weekend, one of the first concrete results of a Bush Administration decision in December to permit American companies to open offices in Vietnam. 
 The decision allows companies to obtain licenses from the Treasury Department, which permits them to open offices and take the first steps toward doing business in Vietnam. The companies may hire staff and sign contracts that could be put into effect only when Washington ends the embargo that was imposed after the war.
Licenses have been granted to about 15 companies, the Treasury says, and about two dozen more are in the pipeline.
With Japan, Singapore and South Korea bursting with international corporations elbowing each other for market share, American companies are looking hungrily at Vietnam as an emerging market. The attraction of Vietnam for corporations is simple: The country's 70 million people are one of the last unexplored consumer markets in Asia -- as well as a well-educated, hard-working and extraordinarily inexpensive labor pool.
Taiwan, Hong Kong and France have taken the lead in investing, followed by Australia, Britain and Japan. Tokyo reopened broad economic ties in November, leaving the United States as the only nation that preserves an embargo against Vietnam.
While investment is not risk free, because of Vietnam's deteriorating infrastructure and widespread corruption among officials, American companies have been pressing for an end to the embargo. They say they are at a terrible disadvantage in a nation that opened up to investment in earnest in 1988. But some think the game is not yet completely lost, partly because of a somewhat paradoxical Vietnamese admiration for Americans and also because of Vietnam's history.
"It is clear that the Vietnamese have set aside a range of projects for American business, not only to hopefully enjoy beneficial access to our market, but also because they have very strong and not positive resonances with respect to centuries of French, Japanese and Chinese colonial influence," said Donald Alford Weadon Jr., a senior partner at Dickstein, Shapiro & Morin, a Washington-based law firm that is opening an office in Vietnam.
Several of the American companies -- advertising agencies, law firms, real estate brokers -- that have received licenses will not be offering services or products to the Vietnamese. Rather, they are positioning themselves to provide help for corporate giants when the embargo ends. That awaits a decision in Washington that Vietnam is cooperating fully in the search for servicemen still missing from the war.
Among the large American companies believed to be hoping to explore business in Vietnam are Mobil, Chevron, Amoco and Exxon; Northwest and United Airlines; Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and Bank of America; Hewlett-Packard, Compaq Computer and Honeywell, and Bechtel, Boeing, General Motors, Caterpillar, Pepsico and Coca-Cola.
The December decision set telephones ringing off the hook at trade organizations with contacts in Vietnam. "Since the announcement, the flow of calls seeking information on questions like who would be a potential partner in Vietnam has tripled," said Virginia B. Foote, director of the U.S.-Vietnam Trade Council, a Washington group that coordinates information on investment.
Among the businesses that have received licenses to open offices in Vietnam are the Channel Marketing Corporation of Dallas, an international sales and marketing consulting firm; the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency; Vatico, a small consulting company based in Washington; Dickstein Shapiro & Morin, and Colliers International, a real estate group based in Boston.
Relations between Vietnam and the United States are governed by a "road map" the Bush Administration gave to Vietnam in April 1991, which uses a carrot-and-stick approach to gain Vietnamese cooperation on a number of issues, like fully accounting for the war's missing, in return for American steps to lift restrictions on political and economic activity in Vietnam.
The Clinton Administration is not expected to change the road map, which at this stage requires that Vietnam give full cooperation in the search for the 2,264 American servicemen still listed as missing.
Ann Mills Griffith, director of the National League of Families, POW/ MIA, said that while the Vietnamese are increasing cooperation, for her group to support an end to the embargo, Hanoi needs to "fulfill the criteria specified in the road map -- rapidly resolving repatriation of remains, and resolving cases of last sighting" when a serviceman was seen alive.
At least one very small and vocal group, the National P.O.W. Strike Force, has gone much further in opposing trade with Vietnam, sending facsimile messages to some of the 30 or so companies that planned to join the trade mission that arrived in Vietnam this weekend.
 
 
'Destroy Your Company'
 Joe Jordan of Houston, the head of the strike force, said in a telephone interview that he told the businesses, "We will go out of our way to destroy your company because you want to do business with filthy Communists who are holding American prisoners."
Irwin Jay Robinson, the director of the Vietnam-American Chamber of Commerce and a senior partner in the law firm of Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim & Ballon in New York, said two companies had dropped out of the trip but he declined to name them.
Many business representatives who fear that other nations' companies are snapping up all the opportunities in Vietnam felt that the Bush Administration moved far too slowly on the issue. And now, there is concern that the Clinton Administration, with its plans to focus sharply on domestic issues, could well do the same.
Bill Beddow, a spokesman in Washington for Caterpillar, the big equipment manufacturer, said his company believed the embargo should be ended.
 
 
'Difference of Opinion'
 "I think everybody is interested in putting to bed remaining questions over the fate of the missing and the P.O.W.'s," he said. "There is a difference of opinion on the best way to make that happen. Caterpillar believes that when a country has been isolated, its Government has been able to remain more hard line, more restrictive and less forthcoming than countries that have not been kept isolated."
Some business representatives and diplomats say the question of the embargo may well be decided before the meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in April, when Washington will again be called upon to reconsider its veto of financial aid for Vietnam from these institutions. This veto, which the United States maintains alone, has blocked hundreds of millions of dollars in aid to Vietnam, which would be used for infrastructure projects.
Any end to the moratorium on lending would be accompanied by opportunities for extensive contracts, which would go to foreign companies if the American embargo were not lifted.
