HEADLINE: Overtime and Hirings Show Some Factories Picking Up

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Much of the nation's industrial sector is shifting into higher gear, though this is sometimes hard to discern in the dust kicked up by wounded corporate giants like General Motors, Sears and I.B.M.
The companies enjoying a surge in business are not suddenly putting out the call for thousands of new workers based on the last few months' growth, but many have stepped up production lines and some have turned on the green lights for expansion. 
 Throughout the Midwest and to a lesser degree in other parts of the nation, a growing number of factories like the Mossville, Ill., engine division of Caterpillar Inc., are piling overtime on their workers to handle the upswing.
Other companies, like Krementz & Company, a jewelry manufacturer in Newark, are rescinding schedules imposed during the recession that had cut their employees' work hours to less than 40 a week and trimmed paychecks.
In addition, there are many like the Hexacomb Corporation, a packaging company in Lincolnshire, a Chicago suburb, that have reached the limits of what they can comfortably handle with overtime.
"Both our shipments and our order rates are the highest they've ever been," said Douglas H. Walmsley, Hexacomb's president and chief executive. As a result, Hexacomb has been cautiously hiring handfuls of new production employees for plants in nearby University Park, in Kalamazoo, Mich., and North Haven, Conn.
Similarly, the Brunswick Corporation has begun hiring new employees for boat production plants in Topeka, Ind., and Murfreesboro, Tenn., to take pressure off workers now on overtime after production rates were jumped 10 percent twice in the last 30 days.
"There's a lot of pent-up demand," said Jack F. Reichert, Brunswick's chief executive, citing recent industry estimates that boat sales could jump nearly 20 percent, to 250,000 this year.
There are other changes, too, that are all but invisible though no less telling. Take the calls the Eskay Screw Corporation has been getting. "In December, we started seeing people in the home building and appliance industries who had left us searching for lower prices coming back and asking if we could supply them," said Morton Sennett, Eskay's president and chief executive.
So far, Eskay, a Wood Dale, Ill., subsidiary of the Trimas Corporation, has met all of the increased demand from inventories it built up gradually last year without altering its longstanding routine of running two nine-hour shifts five days a week. The returning customers, who need the screws to avoid costly shutdowns as their production lines get busier, are willing to pay enough to reward Eskay for having invested in its inventory.
"We anticipated the recovery," Mr. Sennett said.
The broad statistics make it clear that considerable momentum is building. Last Monday, for example, the latest monthly survey of purchasing managers concluded that new orders to all factories increased in January at the fastest clip since 1983 while production rose to the highest level in five years.
On Wednesday, auto makers reported that sales of new cars surged the last 10 days in January by nearly 25 percent to the highest level in two years. Thursday and Friday, the Government published a barrage of statistics showing productivity and factory orders rising while both unemployment claims and the nation's unemployment rate dropped.
 
Caution May Hurt
 The recovery may be muted by the continued reluctance of many bigger businesses to hire new workers, who would then have the paychecks to buy goods and services that would sustain the expansion. Economists cite companies like Honeywell Inc. of Minneapolis, which invested heavily in automation equipment in recent years.
Honeywell is seeing growth in thermostats and other home controls, along with switches, sensors, valves and similar components used in washing machines, dishwashers, autos and other durable goods. But it plans to meet that growth without adding to its work force.
The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation is reopening a plant it closed in 1987 in Jackson, Tenn., but says it will be able to produce the same amount of fiberglass there with technically advanced systems that will require a staff of 80, where it once used 500.
Celentano Inc., a frozen dinner producer based in Verona, N.J., figures its automated equipment will allow it to expand output 15 percent on top of the recent 7 percent jump in orders it has seen without adding new employees. And at Inland Steel Industries in Chicago, mills are operating near capacity, backlogs are building and customers are being confronted with price increases. But plans call for continued work-force reductions.
 
Overtime Aplenty
 Over all, though, more people are likely to have more money to spend as the recovery progresses. Indeed, one side effect of the pressure on business executives to keep operations lean is that production workers who have jobs are more likely than ever to get overtime -- in some cases more than they want -- as the economy revs up.
At Caterpillar's engine group, where machine shop workers went on overtime last month and assembly workers are scheduled to join them working weekends this month, some workers dread the possibility of going to seven-day weeks even though it would add about $425 a week to the typical paycheck.
Richard Thompson, head of the engine unit, said that sales had taken off in recent months because of strong demand from the nation's heavy- truck builders. One visible sign: the number of trucks coming and going from Mossville's loading bays has jumped from 80 a day to about 100 in recent weeks. Mr. Thompson said that Caterpillar would shift workers from other units in nearby Peoria that are not so busy and farm out some operations if orders grew by an additional 20 percent.
Most pulp and paper companies also have some flexibility in how they will handle the upswing, the bittersweet side effect of how deeply they have been hit by the recession. For instance, the Boise Cascade Corporation has a long way to go before it needs to worry about adding new employees or equipment -- even though it is now running all its paper machines flat out and has a two-week backlog for its office products during what is traditionally a slack time.
The American Steel and Wire Company of Cuyahoga, Ohio, ran seven days a week through most of January to meet a jump in demand of more than 30 percent, said Thomas N. Tyrrell, president and chief executive. The company converts steel into rod and wire that other manufacturers make into springs, fasteners and other industrial components.
Profits are growing, though there is room for improvement. Further increases in new orders would allow for longer, more efficient production runs on individual items.
This week, in fact, production had to be cut to five days because of the general surge in economic activity. United States Steel, its supplier of high-grade steel, was caught short by rising demand and could not immediately fill American Steel's orders.
But other companies in industries that are benefiting from long-term growth trends are accelerating expansion plans because of the economic recovery. And it is clearly here that the recent job cutbacks at several big enterprises like I.B.M, Sears, Roebuck and the aerospace and military industries have been offset to begin to bring unemployment down.
AST Research Inc., a personal computer maker in Irvine, Calif., expects orders to grow by 28 percent in the current quarter, to 250,000 units. After initially resorting largely to overtime to handle the growth spurt that began last year, AST decided to double employment this month on its second shift to 500 workers and add a third shift by hiring 300 more workers.
"We've got to run this place 24 hours a day," said Richard F. Ottaviano, senior vice president in charge of administration. He noted that the company is also adding 30 new trouble-shooters to field telephone calls -- doubling that group of service personnel.
Similarly, a number of companies in Silicon Valley are expanding, although not always in the valley. Advanced Micro Devices Inc. has seen capacity use of its local microchip plant jump from under 70 percent at the end of 1991 to about 90 percent and is now building plants in Japan and Austin, Tex. And the Read-Rite Corporation, which produces components for disk drives, is building plants in Japan and Thailand as well as Fremont, the town next to its Milpitas, Calif., headquarters.
"We are sprinting," said Cyril J. Yansouni, Read-Rite's chairman and chief executive.
Some companies whose growth is contributing to the recovery have a hard time feeling they are part for it. One, the Manitowoc Engineering Company, a maker of heavy-lift cranes in Manitowoc, Wis., went through periods in the 1980's when it had no orders. Now it has a record backlog stretching out to next summer and is scrambling for ways to make more than two of the $1.5 million machines a week.
Some 200 workers were hired in recent months and the company is looking at investments in new tools, according to Fred Butler, president of the Manitowoc Company, its parent. But almost all of the orders are from Asia and other foreign countries.
 
Big Growth in Yogurt
 By contrast, Stonyfield Farm, a small 10-year-old yogurt maker in Londonderry, N.H., has been booming without exports.
January sales revenues were $1.3 million for a four-week period, up about 25 percent from December when they were $1.2 million for five weeks.
Stonyfield has recently ordered approximately $800,000 in new capital equipment to expand plant capacity, and its 85-employee work force is operating on three shifts, five days a week. It may soon shift to seven days.
"We're in an unbelievable growth spurt, and we don't know why it's happening just now," said Gary Hirshberg, the founder. "We are wildly excited."
But at most older companies, the optimism is more tempered. "People have been through restructuring; they've seen the staff cut in half; they've seen their friends and co-workers leave," said Theodore L. Bonsignore, chief executive of Krementz, the jewelry company. "They want to see some stability. We all do."

HEADLINE: Delay on Tax-Credit Measure Stalls Projects to House Poor

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
Since the late 1980's, money from a Federal tax break for corporations has put thousands of low-income New Yorkers into new homes. Now legislation that would renew the financing is stalled in Washington, and that, coupled with state budget cuts, threatens plans for dozens of affordable housing developments in the state this year.
In New York City alone, the tax break, the Federal low-income housing tax credit, which uses money from corporations that buy tax credits to help pay for affordable rental housing, has supplied roughly one-third of the cost of rebuilding more than 5,000 apartments since 1989.
 
Using Abandoned Buildings
 Most of the units have been carved out of abandoned buildings that the city has taken from owners because of tax delinquencies. Of the apartments rebuilt with tax-credit money, 30 percent are set aside as permanent housing for homeless people. 
 At the state level, the proposed budget shows cuts of 25 percent in financing for two housing programs on which nonprofit housing groups depend for the affordable housing they help create. Cuts in appropriations to the Affordable Home Ownership program and the Housing Trust Fund, from $25 million to $18 million each, will mean, housing advocates say, that 1,800 fewer units of affordable rental and owner-occupied housing will be created in 1993.
Already the delay in the restoration of the tax credit, its proponents say, has slowed scores of public-private housing production machines that have in the last five years produced tens of thousands of units of low-income housing in the country.
"Spending for new housing production for low-income people was virtually eliminated at the Federal level in the 1980's," said Paul S. Grogan, president of Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a national nonprofit organization that provides financing for community development.
Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, a nonprofit organization that assists with the development of homes sold to moderate-income buyers, said that if New York State's proposed budget stands, her organization will have to scratch plans for 800 homes for neighborhoods like Coney Island, Bushwick and the Atlantic Terminal area in Brooklyn, South Jamaica and Astoria in Queens, as well as the north shore of Staten Island.
State officials say there was no way of avoiding the cuts.
"We are aware of the desperate need for affordable housing," said Angelo J. Aponte, commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. "This year, for the first time, housing has been asked to participate in cost-cutting. We were not able to escape."
Mr. Grogan, whose organization, along with the Enterprise Foundation, has served in New York City as the managers of the tax-credit equity fund, said that "the work of building housing has been taken up by nonprofit organizations, tenant and community organizations and local public agencies."
 
Renewal Almost Certain
 The tax-credit bill has strong bipartisan support in Congress, making the eventual renewal almost certain. But the support it enjoys has been something of a liability. Lawmakers often use the tax credit, because of its support, to push through other less popular tax measures.
"We go through this every year," said Bart Harvey, vice chairman of the Enterprise Foundation, a nonprofit group in Columbia, Md., financed by the real-estate developer James Rouse. "The tax credit is always held hostage to larger political forces and used to carry through less popular tax initiatives."
Although renewal of the credit was part of a catchall tax bill approved by Congress last fall, President Bush vetoed it just before he left office.
Mr. Harvey said supporters of the tax credit are hopeful that it will be included in the second phase of President Clinton's economic stimulus package expected later this month. But they also worry that the debate this time around could be lengthened by political bickering over whether the tax credit should be permanent or renewable each year.
In New York, a project pending on 116th Street in East Harlem illustrates the impact of the delay in Washington.
For the last few years the pastor of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church pastor, the Rev. Peter Rofrano, has been trying to turn vacant buildings across the street into housing for the neighborhood. Now with a commitment from the city to turn the structures over to the church and its development partners, the final hurdle to a start on rebuilding is the part of the financing that is to come from the Federal tax-credit program.
"We were supposed to get started in January," Father Rofrano said. "Then the date was pushed to March or April. Now it looks like we won't get started until summer."
There are to be a total of 60 units carved out of the vacant 116th Street buildings and a third empty, city-owned property the church will take on 117th Street.
When financing for housing is delayed or cut, more than the bricks and mortar are lost. In many instances the new housing serves as the catalyst for the revitalization of neighborhoods after decades of neglect and disinvestment. And in the case of the tax-credit financing, the flexibility of the rules that dictate how it can be spent, allow it to be used to pay for more than just housing.
"The tax credit has been an important component in our 10-year housing plan," said Felice L. Michetti, commissioner of the city's Department of Housing, Preservation and Development, referring to the city's 1986 pledge to create 47,000 units of low-income housing. "The tax credit is used for development, but its value goes beyond that because the funds can be used for building operating expenses and social services like job training, and day care."
Ms. Michetti said that as part of the 10-year housing plan, so far 18,000 new units have been built and are occupied, and 17,000 units are under development. Tax credits have contributed to about 20 percent of what has been built.
Gus Rosado, executive director of El Barrio's Operation Fightback, a nonprofit community organization renovating buildings in East Harlem, said restoration of the tax credit is needed because it puts communities in charge of projects in their own neighborhoods.
"The partnership with the city and Enterprise Foundation," he said, "allows us to participate in the development of our own communities and makes us responsible for how well housing does in the future."
L.I.S.C. and the Enterprise Foundation raised $81 million for the New York City tax-credit equity fund in 1992. The money came from tax credits sold to companies like American Express and the Bank of New York. In exchange for investing in the housing, the companies receive reductions in their Federal income tax bills. L.I.S.C. and Enterprise distribute the tax-credit money to local community groups selected for their organizational skills and commitment to their communities.
 
Planning a Strategy
 Many of them, like the East New York Neighborhood Youth Corps, say their housing development divisions will be treading water if the tax credit is not restored soon. With help from the L.I.S.C., the Neighborhood Youth Corps has renovated 68 apartments in 13 buildings on some of the most troubled blocks of East New York. An additional 15 buildings with 51 apartments are nearing completion.
"We will be coming to a juncture soon where we will have to decide strategy for the next phase of development," said Carey Shea, director of the East New York organization, speaking from the office the group has renovated. "Without the tax-credit money, moving forward on our housing goals to renovate more buildings will be much harder."
The Housing Partnership, the state's largest user of the Affordable Home Ownership funds, would need $20 million in grants to meet its 1993 production goal, Ms. Wylde said. The proposed state budget would bring its share closer to $9 million.
The Partnership, which combines state and city money and bank financing to lower the cost of homes, helped develop 1,400 homes last year.
"Because the funding cuts are coming as we are using the last money of a special 1988 housing appropriation," Ms. Wylde said, "the actual impact on housing production will be greater than the 25 percent cut that has been proposed."

LENGTH: 1259 words

HEADLINE: Banks' Plan For Stimulus Is Questioned

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
After being cheered by the Clinton Administration's initial interest in their plan to loosen bank regulations as an economic stimulus, the nation's bankers are running into increasing skepticism about the merits of the plan.
The bankers officially kicked off a lobbying campaign against red tape in lending last week, timing it to closely follow the introduction of legislation to ease bank regulations by Senator Richard C. Shelby, a moderate Alabama Democrat. 
 The bankers cited stories about borrowers who were turned down by banks worried about failing tough new tests of lending standards. They presented statistics to back their assertion that the nation is in the grips of a persistent credit crunch.
 
'Half-Baked Arguments'
 But in a statement on Thursday, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, brusquely rejected the bankers' evidence as "anecdotal stories and half-baked arguments," and warned Federal bank regulators against "swallowing the kind of shotgun claims the bank lobby has launched around town."
The bankers contend that unreasonable regulations and zealous auditors are harassing bankers to the point that they refuse loans even to good customers. This theme has struck a chord inside the White House, where President Clinton still remembers how many times small businesses and bankers told him the same thing on the campaign trail.
When William Brandon, the president of the American Bankers Association, told the President-elect in December at the economic meeting in Little Rock, Ark., that lending could increase $86 billion a year if regulations were eased, Mr. Clinton welcomed the prescription as the best kind of economic medicine: a stimulant that, unlike tax cuts or new spending programs, would have no direct effect on the Federal deficit.
Since then, top economic officials in the Administration have said they plan to re-examine banking regulations to see if loosening them will substantially increase the credit flow.
 
Pressed for Explanation
 But this week, Mr. Gonzalez struck back, asking Mr. Brandon for the evidence behind his $86 billion figure. After an exchange of statements by the Congressman and the banker, Mr. Gonzalez was not impressed by the banker's explanation.
The association's forecast, it turned out, is based on historical data comparing the most recent recession, during which lending stagnated, with previous ones in which banks continued to lend.
Bank lending in the last two years was 10 percent lower than in comparable business cycles, Mr. Brandon said. If lending could now be increased by just 4 percent, a number chosen more or less at random, there would be $86 billion in additional lending, he explained.
"Bankers from across the country, particularly those in the New England states, tell me daily that the adverse regulatory environment has forced a retraction in lending far above 4 percent," Mr. Brandon said. "It is, of course, impossible to quantify precisely how much credit could be freed up."
 
Stand Is Toned Down
 Mr. Gonzalez responded, "His claim was a shot in the dark, completely without foundation," to which Mr. Brandon issued a statement, calling the $86 billion valid.
But the banking association also seemed to do some embarrassing backtracking, first distributing a statement from Mr. Brandon that said "overly restrictive bank regulations are the primary reason" for the credit crunch, then within an hour dropping that assertion.
The second version instead said, "We believe that bank regulations can be reduced to free up lending without undermining bank safety and soundness."
Mr. Gonzalez and Federal regulators have conceded that some bank rules are inefficient and might be altered. In both the House and the Senate, for example, banking committee leaders plan to introduce legislation to create a single agency to regulate all banks, a job now done by several agencies.
 
Critics See Hidden Agenda
 But some critics say the banks have a hidden agenda, not to eliminate inefficiency and unnecessary paperwork but to undermine tough new standards imposed by recent banking laws to bolster the safety of the banking system.
"While the banks say their campaign will leave vital safety and soundness laws untouched, this is simply not so," said Michelle Meier, a lawyer for Consumers Union, a lobbying group that favors tight banking regulations.
The legislation the bankers support would, among other things, eliminate rules scheduled to take effect soon to require that a bank's outside auditors attest to its compliance with lending standards. The banks argue that the requirement will drive up costs and steer banks away from relatively risky small-business loans. The bankers also want to ease rules that could make directors and officers personally liable when risky loans turn sour.
Government studies suggest that factors other than regulations were foremost in holding down borrowing during the recent recession and the early stages of the recovery, which is now well under way.
And the Government's top auditor, Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, testified recently that weak loan demand, the collapse of real estate values, corporate belt-tightening and competition from nonbank lenders had more to do with the decline in commercial lending than red tape did.
"Congress, the Administration and the financial regulators should exercise great caution in considering short-term measures to encourage more liberal lending practices by insured institutions," he said.
 
Fed Credit Study
 A detailed study by the Federal Reserve Board, while not taking sides on the dispute, provides further ammunition against the bankers. The study found that "the restructuring efforts of borrowers and the modest financing needs in the current expansion are the principal reasons for the unusually slow pace of private sector debt growth this year."
The Fed acknowledged that stricter lending standards had posed problems for small businesses in particular, as the banks had emphasized. But, the Fed study said, "a growing number of indicators suggest that the period of credit tightening has ended and easing steps may be in train."
The Fed reported several pieces of data that further undermine the banks' arguments. For example, while banks across the country face exactly the same regulations, the pattern of commercial and industrial lending activities "varies considerably" from one region to another.
 
Shift in Concerns
 The Fed's own surveys of banks and small businesses "consistently indicate" that loan demand has not been strong and that credit has been available for worthy companies. Surveys in 1992 by the National Federation of Independent Businesses show respondents "not overly concerned" about credit availability, in sharp contrast to a decade ago, when it was found to be the leading problem.
Bankers said they could not produce any academic studies linking tight regulations with credit restrictions, with one exception.
Joe Peek, a Boston University professor who works for the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, and Eric Rosengren, an economist at the Boston Fed, have issued studies showing that banks in New England reduced their lending after regulators forced them to maintain higher levels of capital.
But that is exactly the kind of regulation that Mr. Gonzalez and others on Capitol Hill say cannot be undone, and even the banks have not suggested that deregulation should mean cutting the amount of capital that weak banks must keep on hand to avert collapse.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
The Slimmer Side of a New and Sprightly Life

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
After more than two years of intense self-examination, Life magazine finally bit the bullet and made the decision to remain a monthly.
"We're through with the public hanging of the laundry," said Daniel Okrent, the new managing editor. "We have gone through a fundamental re-examination of the magazine, and we think monthly is a fine frequency." 
 Mr. Okrent, founding editor of the New England Monthly, which is now defunct, and a former assistant managing editor at Life, replaces James R. Gaines, who became managing editor of Time last week. Mr. Gaines was also publisher of Life, and in that post he has been succeeded by Nora McAniff, former New York advertising director for People magazine, another Time Inc. publication.
The naming of a separate managing editor and publisher restores Time Inc.'s cherished tradition of separation between the editorial and publishing sides of its magazines. In 1991 when Mr. Gaines, then managing editor, was given the additional title of publisher, critics saw it as another sign of the disintegration of a once-proud magazine.
 
Swinging the Ax
 Although they took over the reins less than two months ago, Mr. Okrent and Ms. McAniff have shown themselves firmly in command and ready to take tough measures to make Life more economical to produce.
Sixteen full-time staff members have been let go, although attempts are being made to place them elsewhere in the company. These include writers, reporters, researchers, proofreaders and members of the art and production departments.
The magazine has been trimmed from 10 by 12 inches to 9 by 107/8 inches. This not only saves paper, but makes the magazine a more standard size and potentially more attractive to advertisers. It will also enable it to go on the same press run with other Time Inc. magazines and to take advantage of advanced technology like ink-jet printing and selective binding.
Life will get back its own advertising sales staff. In recent years, the same advertising salespeople sold space for Life and People magazines, which Ms. McAniff said advertising professionals regarded as a weakness. She is in the process of hiring a staff whose sole job will be to sell space in Life.
In July, Life will cut the circulation rate base that it guarantees to advertisers to 1.5 million, from 1.7 million. This means that it will spend less to attract readers.
Life will also cut ad rates, a move that is expected to attract significantly more business. For instance, beginning in May, a four-color page will cost $49,500, instead of $76,605 now.
"It sounds like a really smart move," said Nancy Smith, executive vice president-director of print and media relations at Young & Rubicam. "The size reduction doesn't bother me. It sounds like it is going to help them in terms of better placement of ads. There will be more advertising in there, so the edit-ad ration will be more balanced."
There is evident relief in the decision, made in December, not to turn Life into a semimonthly, a biweekly or even a weekly, which was under serious enough consideration in 1991 that Life announced it was thinking of doing it. Mr. Okrent said the only option that was never considered was closing the magazine.
 
Middle America, and Proud of It
 Martin S. Walker, chairman of Walker Communications, a magazine consultant, remarked:
"The real issue is that Life is so imbued with the corporate culture and Henry Luce that it has a life of its own, and they tend not to make rational decisions about it. Basically, its problem has been in getting advertising -- it's a Middle America book; it's not hot; it's not exciting, and I don't know how much of it survives because advertisers are buying a Time Warner corporate plan."
Mr. Okrent said he was not considering any radical rethinking of the magazine. He wants the magazine to be topical but not necessarily news-ier, he said.
And he wants profiles to run in every issue, and even more pictures.
"Pictures are the vocabulary of the magazine," he said. "We use words to amplify pictures instead of pictures to illustrate stories."

HEADLINE: Next: Campaign Finance Reform

 BODY:
An unmistakable fog of political incompetence is beginning to form around the White House. The Bush and Carter Presidencies showed the danger of letting small droplets of error condense into an enveloping miasma. History also points out a quick fix uniquely available to Presidents -- change the subject by re-emphasizing a core promise. In President Clinton's case, one such promise is political reform.
No one can undo the mistakes of the past two weeks -- all the more reason for Mr. Clinton to get on with pushing ethics and campaign finance legislation on the Hill. But he must have the support of the Democratic leadership, and the unpleasant truth is that House Speaker Thomas Foley is still backpedaling on his pledge of swift action to clean up campaign financing. 
 The House has now approved two important measures vetoed by former President Bush: the voter registration reform nicknamed "motor voter" and the Family Leave Act. A good week's work all around. Yet Mr. Foley is reluctant to redress another damaging Bush veto killing last year's bill to overhaul campaign financing.
Mr. Foley has become the instrument of an inner circle of Democrats who believe that reform could loosen their grip on the House and who put partisan ambitions ahead of the nation's need for political reform.
His retreat represents a clear threat to Mr. Clinton, who looked weak after an inconclusive White House meeting on the issue last week with Mr. Foley and other Congressional leaders. Mr. Clinton cannot afford to leave the terms or timetable for a reform so central to the success of his Presidency to selfish members of Congress. He must grab the lead, and quickly.
Mr. Foley says he's committed to passing legislation that would reduce lawmakers' corrosive reliance on special interests and help restore competitive elections. But he won't set a timetable. That still sounds like Washington-speak for "we like our perks; the people can wait." True, the House did pass a promising reform package last year. But there wasn't anyone in the White House who wanted to sign it, much less make it tougher.
The Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, has put the campaign finance issue on a fast track, with the clear goal of getting reform legislation to the Senate floor by late next month or soon thereafter. Mr. Foley, who says he's "eager," also says he'll get around to the issue in the spring or maybe the summer. That's eagerness?
Ordinarily, a lag of a few months might not ring alarm bells. But to delay in this case could have heavy costs -- killing, for example, any chance that the reforms would apply to the 1994 Congressional elections. And it gives nervous incumbents and Washington insiders who profit handsomely under the system time to organize a fatal filibuster -- or to dilute the provisions until they seem more a collection of loopholes than serious reform.
The Speaker's excuse is that forcing members to cast tough votes on a campaign finance measure now could jeopardize Mr. Clinton's domestic centerpiece -- an economic package that will also require them to see beyond their own political needs.
He's got it backward. Swift enactment of a campaign finance measure incorporating Mr. Clinton's professed ideals of cleaner government would enhance the new President's battered standing with the public in ways that could only help make his economic arguments seem more persuasive.
With Mr. Foley's help, serious campaign finance reform could still be the crowning achievement of Mr. Clinton's first 100 days.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Clinton Direction

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
Whither the infant Administration? We do not have to wait for the unveiling of the Grand Master Plan for the Economy, scheduled for Feb. 17, to find out. All a pundit needs is a handful of public signals, a few whispered tips and his handy-dandy divining rod.
Q: Which path will the new President take -- deficit reduction or economic stimulus? 
 A: Both.
Q: But wouldn't such policy resemble the pushmipullyu, the beast with heads at both ends?
A: Not a bit; here's how it works. Pick any number from 15 billion to 30 billion (the specific figure doesn't matter; Congress will change it anyway). That's the job-creating fiscal stimulus, a combination of new Federal spending ("investment") on electronic highways and computer-directed leafraking ("infrastructure").
Q: Won't such spending add to the deficit?
A: The deficit will start to be reduced, sometime next year, by an infusion of new taxes to help pay for the heavier spending in the works, pleasing liberals, with a small portion set aside for deficit reduction, pleasing conservatives.
Q: But if the economy is already making a strong comeback, why do we need the stimulus of increased spending? Won't that lead to inflation?
A: Let me let you in on a dirty little secret: No Democratic economist will ever admit this, but they don't think inflation of about 5 or 6 percent is such a bad thing. It would rescue real estate, which in turn would bail out banks and insurance companies now hung up on bad real estate loans; "reasonable" inflation would also allow government to reduce the deficit with cheaper dollars.
Q: Hold on, now -- if the Clintonites are going to raise taxes to pay for new spending, and even put a few bucks in the kitty to sop up some red ink, where's the stimulus? Won't it be a wash, and not contribute to inflation?
A: That's the theory. And the theory even steals a leaf from the supply-siders, holding that the coming boom will increase all tax revenues and reduce unemployment and welfare costs.
Q: If that's so, then why increase spending and raise taxes at all? Why not leave good enough alone, and let the pendulum swing back up to prosperity?
A: Ah-hah! You have come to the nub of the matter. The basic idea is redistribution: taking money (and the social services now bought with money) from the richer and giving it to the poorer, with a fresh fillip -- taking incentives away from old-fashioned industries and giving them to newfangled industries.
Q: What's so bad about soaking the richies, issuing health stamps and boosting the hackers?
A: Not enough richies. The surtax on incomes over $1 million will make populists feel they got even with successniks, and Ross Perot's notion of stripping Social Security benefits from successful working retirees will be adopted, but will produce relative pin money.
The increase in top rates first from 31 percent to 36 percent and later to 40 percent will generate more at first, but won't do the redistributive trick. That great day for sharing will come with the bite on the main source of the country's wealth -- the middle class -- which will be hit with energy taxes, sin taxes, and a pain-concealed value-added sales tax.
Q: How will this help growth industries doing their job-creating thing in clean exurban parks?
A: Redistribution of government incentives will begin with a capital-gains tax break that discriminates against old profits and old companies. And under the rubric of "managed trade," our chief protectionist will retaliate against foreigners who stand in the way of new-class companies.
Q: And redistributing healthwealth?
A: Hillary Robinhood Clinton has taken personal charge of this social equalization. Because the Republican alternative was accurately self-satirized at the Alfalfa Club in three words -- "Don't Get Sick" -- Democrats have a clean shot at removing the profit motive from health care, homogenizing treatment and killing the goose that lays the golden pills.
Q: Is this a new Democratic philosophy?
A: No; it's the old liberal redistribution dodge in designer jeans. But cheer up: the President proposes, Congress disposes; a little gridlock would be a healthy thing.

HEADLINE: The Law Can Recognize Sexual Harassment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Crying Wolf in Albany" (Op-Ed, Jan. 23), Sheryl E. Reich states that the charges of sexual harassment made this month by Earlene Hill, a member of the New York State Assembly, against some of her male colleagues did not constitute sexual harassment because those who perpetrated the acts had no power over her and "were not in a position to deprive her of anything to which she was entitled nor did they threaten to do so." 
 Ms. Reich claims these are nothing more than insensitive remarks to be brushed off or verbally responded to, unless they became so frequent and widespread that they prevent a woman from doing her job. (How long one should wait until the remarks are considered to be frequent, widespread and disruptive of one's work is left unanswered by her.)
If women want to enter the male-dominated areas of the legislature, courtroom and boardrooms, according to Ms. Reich, they should get used to loutish behavior. Charges of sexual harassment, when nothing more than rude behavior is involved, trivialize the issue.
It is Ms. Reich who fails to understand the nature, history and even the laws surrounding sexual harassment. Sexual harassment is a legal construction. It did not exist until sexual discrimination was included under Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act. In 1977, in Tompkins v. Public Service and Gas, the courts made it clear that harassment of a woman would no longer be seen as a personal problem, but as sex discrimination, for which employers might be held responsible.
As women began to enter the workplace not merely as workers, but also as professionals, the definition of sex discrimination once again had to be redefined by the courts. Female physicians have reported sexually harassing encounters with male physicians who are not their bosses but their colleagues.
Dr. Frances K. Conley, a prominent female neurosurgeon at Stanford University, quit her position in 1991 to charge publicly that she had been subjected to 25 years of harassment in her male-dominated specialty. A court decision in Minnesota established that co-worker harassment was as inimical to a woman as that by a boss.
All law reflects the temper of the time. Law is dynamic and reflects the political and social conditions of the age. Our conception of sexual harassment has evolved to meet the changing social, political and economic conditions of our times.
Rather than offering women instructions in verbal retort to bad come-on lines, Ms. Reich would do well to check in with Assemblywoman Hill and other women who view law as the dynamic tool that it is, one that has been used to redress wrongs that those in power viewed as the way things have always been done around here.
 
RUTH MALZBERG SILVERMAN
Merrick, L.I., Jan. 25, 1993

HEADLINE: New York Has a Reasonable Labor Settlement

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Labor Agreement Will Haunt New York City" (letter, Feb. 2) by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan is fundamentally false and misleading. 
 The true cost of the contract is 8.25 percent, as we said when we announced the agreement. Contrary to the Comptroller's assertion, that figure of 8.25 percent includes not only the percentage increases city employees will receive in the next 39 months, totaling 7.16 percent cumulatively, but also the benefit increases and the present-value charge for the one-time $700 payment to employees.
Present value is a universally accepted method used by labor economists, auditors and accountants. The Comptroller's own office routinely uses this very technique in evaluating labor agreements.
Certainly, it is puzzling that the state's elected auditor cannot perform in this instance so simple a calculation. But beyond that, it is also discouraging that Mr. Regan so resolutely ignores how reasonable a labor settlement we have achieved for this city, well below the rate of inflation.
He even disregards the $1 billion to $1.5 billion saved by this settlement, compared with the costs he and his own staff predicted in a Dec. 17 report for the inflation-driven settlement they expected us to accept.
Moreover, the State Comptroller would have New Yorkers wrongly believe that no gains were made in achieving productivity in this contract. This is simply untrue. Laying aside the separate announcements by this administration of significant productivity initiatives in the Sanitation and Probation departments, this latest contract with municipal labor unions contains a historic first:
It provides for the first time ever for a binding process that will result in at least six productivity initiatives beginning by mid-1993. This is hardly symbolic.
 
NORMAN STEISEL
First Deputy Mayor
New York, Feb. 2, 1993

HEADLINE: Social Security Won't Be Subject To Freeze, White House Decides

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Bowing to protests from retirees, the Clinton Administration has decided against freezing cost-of-living increases for Social Security recipients as a way of lowering the Federal budget deficit, a White House spokesman said.
Mr. Clinton's decision went against the advice of his budget director, Leon E. Panetta, who had advocated a one-year freeze on the adjustments. The President had been warned by members of Congress that such an idea would go nowhere. 
 But the White House has still not ruled out increasing the taxes on Social Security benefits. Some Administration officials have suggested that this proposal would be more acceptable to the 30 million people who now receive monthly Social Security benefits, since it affects only those recipients who also receive substantial income from other sources.
 
'Special Contract' With Elderly
 Mr. Clinton has come under intense political heat over Social Security cuts since the White House floated the notion on Capitol Hill last month. Trying to mend fences at a White House meeting on Friday night, Mr. Clinton reassured leaders of the American Association of Retired Persons, an influential lobbying group, that he considered Social Security to be a special contract with the nation's elderly.
Mr. Clinton told the A.A.R.P. officials that he was also considering a plan to include the cost of prescription drugs under Medicare.
Asked today if Mr. Clinton was still considering a freeze on cost-of-living increases, George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said, "I think it's very unlikely it's something the President wants to do."
 
'Cut Government First'
 Mr. Stephanopoulos said curbing Social Security cost-of-living adjustments would hurt low-income people disproportionately and conflict with the principles Mr. Clinton is using to define his economic choices.
"The principles are, cut Government first, get the most from those who made the most, achieve both investment and deficit reduction and be fair," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
In October, the Government announced that Social Security benefits would increase by 3 percent to keep pace with inflation starting with checks in January 1993. The increase meant the average Social Security recipient's check rose to $653 from $634.
A one-year freeze in cost-of-living increases next year would save as much as $15 billion in 1997, or about 10 percent of the total deficit reduction the Administration is seeking.
Mr. Stephanopoulos did not say whether Mr. Clinton might still propose an increase in the taxes on Social Security benefits. Under current law, retired couples with annual adjusted gross incomes above $32,000 and individual retirees with adjusted gross incomes above $25,000 must pay income taxes on half of their Social Security benefits. The Congressional Budget Office and others have suggested that one possible way of raising more money would be to make 85 percent of such income taxable.
 
Other Economic Issues
 As Mr. Clinton continued to lay the groundwork for the economic speech he will deliver to a joint session of Congress on Feb. 17, he has wrestled with a number of related issues that he hopes will allow him to set the stage for the bitter medicine he is expected to recommend.
On Tuesday, he will announce his plans to meet a campaign promise to cut the White House staff by 25 percent, and on Wednesday will announce a plan to cut administrative costs by 3 percent across the board, White House officials said.
But the President's announcement of staff or spending reductions in the White House will not be as sharp as Mr. Clinton promised during the campaign, and will not take effect until next fall, White House aides said.
In the meantime, the Clinton Administration plans to keep the White House staffed at Bush Administration levels, and is almost certain to request additional financing from Congress.
As recently as Jan. 12, Mr. Clinton told voters he would "present to the United States Congress a plan to cut the White House staff by 25 percent."
The announcement Tuesday will not precisely keep that promise, according to White House officials.
"We're biting the bullet on staff, with cuts virtually across the board," said one White House official. "But the final figure is going to be in the mid to high teens, not 25 percent." He added, however, that Mr. Clinton would announce a cut in overall White House spending, achieved through reductions in salaries and privileges, that "would be in the mid-20's."
Mr. Clinton said today that he had largely made up his mind about the elements of the economic package, which is expected to include tax increases for upper income individuals and consumers.
"I have made the decision on the general outline of the stimulus program, and I have made a lot of the specific decisions within it, but we're going to go back over it all one more time to refine it," Mr. Clinton said in a brief question-and-answer session at the White House.
For two days running, Mr. Clinton has been meeting with the members of National Economic Council to discuss spending and tax options. And he has been consulting with political advisers from his campaign, including Paul Begala, James Carville and Stanley Greenberg, on the best way to sell the plan he will present Feb. 17.
Today, the President announced plans to ask Congress to extend unemployment benefits for an additional 26 weeks beyond the 26 weeks now provided that end March 6.
"The old ways of doing business are simply not good enough anymore," Mr. Clinton said. "Unemployment compensation must now be both a short-term lifeline for workers and a long-term link to the skills that it will take for them to get where they want to be, back in the work force."
Mr. Clinton also announced today that he would abolish the Council on Environmental Quality and replace it with a new White House Office of Environmental Policy. That office, which would be about one-third of the size of the current council, will be headed by Kathleen McGinty, an aide to Vice President Gore who would assume the title deputy assistant to the President.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2435 words

HEADLINE: Winning the Cold War and Losing a Job

SERIES: Peace Penalty: Connecticut's Morning After First of three articles.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn.

 BODY:
Bill Sullivan sells cars for a living, but like everyone else here, he also counts submarines.
When Congress restored $2 billion last summer to the all-but-scuttled Seawolf submarine program at the Electric Boat shipyard just across the Thames River in Groton, Mr. Sullivan immediately felt the blip. His General Motors dealership ended the year selling more cars than any year since 1987, even as the recession deepened in Connecticut. But there was a troubling crack in that increase: much of it came from the used-car lot. Many new car lines plummeted 35 percent or more in one year.
 
A Shrinking Behemoth
 Similar fault lines are everywhere here, as the most Pentagon-dependent corner of the nation shudders and shakes toward a future after the cold war. In many ways it is a story of waiting for the worst. Unemployment is still lower than much of the rest of Connecticut, even though it has more than tripled from the 2 percent that was the norm through the 1980's to 6.5 percent as of December. 
 And the great sprawling behemoth of Electric Boat, with its chain-link ambiance and vast enclosed prefab submarine bays, remains open, though shrunken. More than 13,000 employees still cross the gate every day.
What is racking New London now is the certainty that nothing about this place, from the good union jobs and benefits in the weapons plants to the culture of life under the military umbrella, can be counted on to be the same, or even recognizable, by mid-decade.
 
200,000 Jobs Lost
 And similar dramas are being played out all over Connecticut, a state reeling from the twin demons of recession and cuts in military spending that have devastated the very foundation of its prosperity -- its manufacturing base.
Connecticut now has a work force of 1.4 million. In all, the state lost about 200,000 jobs, or one nonfarm job in eight, in just four years.
About one in six manufacturing jobs are gone, a casualty rate that rivals Michigan's in the early 1980's when the auto industry was going through its torment. And military cuts may eliminate another 30,000 jobs through 1997.
In the New London area, the implications of such cuts are everywhere.
From the Groton public schools, where nearly one of every two children has a parent in the Navy, to the city government, whose tax collections ratchet up and down with every change in Pentagon deployment schedules, to the real-estate brokerages, which saw home prices fall 10 percent in a matter of months last year as the Seawolf came under review, watching the vicissitudes of the military dollar is the local equivalent of tracking the stock market, and lately the only direction is down.
"People are pulling in, hunkering down, shutting in, shutting off -- it's a survival mode," said Christopher J. Emerson, senior pastor at the Mystic Congregational Church, where about 35 families in the 400 family-congregation have simply pulled up stakes and moved in the last two years.
At Family Services, a nonprofit mental health counseling service, the number of people seeking out-patient treatment rose 30 percent in 1992, including many people who had jobs but could not cope with living under the cloud of uncertainty. Counselors said that every mental health category from family violence to alcohol and drug abuse was up.
"What bothers me is that we're just beginning this cycle of down building," said Jay C. Bloom, the president of Family Services. "We've got three to four years ahead of cuts that will ripple through the economy."
 
Numbers Tell the Story
 The numbers tell much of the story. In 1990, the military accounted for almost 60 percent of the 110,000 jobs in New London County. But because such jobs pay so well, the military accounted for 81 percent of the total payroll in the county, according to studies of Federal figures by the state.
In 1989, the Pentagon spent $9,785 per capita in direct contracts in New London and its suburbs. That is more than three times what was spent in the second most military-dependent area in the nation, Dallas-Fort Worth, which received $2,852 per capita in direct contracts. Long Island, with Pentagon spending of $1,236 per capita, ranked fourth.
Those dollar totals are already just a memory even though the full effects have not yet hit home. The Navy, which once envisioned a fleet of 29 Seawolf subs, will now get only two. That has already pushed Electric Boat, which employed 18,000 people in Groton at its height in the mid-1980's, to shed nearly 5,000 jobs. Another 6,000 or more jobs are to be cut by 1997, even under the most optimistic scenario. In the worst case, Electric Boat will simply close.
The Navy has also begun shrinking its undersea warfare research laboratory, a sprawling 26-acre waterfront complex where submarine technologies and weapons systems are developed and tested. The lab had 1,400 employees last fall, 1,000 of whom will be gone within three years as the work is consolidated with another base in Rhode Island. Smaller suppliers have been battered and some have shut their doors.
"Everybody has come down to the attitude of 'I worked today, I got a paycheck Friday, I don't have any control over this,' " said Brian Cosgrove, a 36-year-old electrician at Electric Boat, who said his optimism rises and falls about whether he will have a job in six months. "The American dream is on hold," he said.
Mr. Cosgrove knows what that is like. He has 13 years on the job, and is vested in his pension plan, but he fell from a ladder several years ago, injuring his knee and keeping him on what is called a "light duty" roster. When the layoffs come, it could be by seniority, or it could be other criteria, like keeping only the able-bodied workers, he said. His fiancee, Paula Neas, is expecting the couple's second child in May.
 
The Past
Happy Marriage To the Military
 Putting dreams on hold is a mindset now increasingly common to this still-tough seaport city, which first rose and fell with the fortunes of the whaling fleets in the 1800's, and then rose again with a very similar working-class prosperity after World War II by building the new leviathans of undersea warfare for the Navy.
In interviews from City Hall, to shot-and-a-beer waterfront bars like the Sub, to Shalett Dry Cleaners, purchased in November by an optimistic couple moving here from Atlanta, the sense is repeated again and again that New London is a place apart. The clock was stopped here, residents say, at a time when skilled blue-collar union jobs were still the respected bread and butter of the community and where a child could and often did follow his father's footsteps as a welder, pipe fitter or painter down at the Boat, or E.B., as the Electric Boat shipyard is known.
Even if every other manufacturer in America fled overseas in search of cheaper labor, residents said, the Navy would not, if only for reasons of national security. Workers here were outside the commercial system, and so their sense of immunity and perhaps arrogance grew, even as much of the American economy was restructured in the 1980's.
"E.B. was always there, always the secure place to get a job," said Elaine M. Kuhn, a 48-year-old resident of neighboring Montville who was laid off last year from her job as buyer in the shipyard's purchasing department. "I thought, well, I'll go to E.B. and I'll probably retire from E.B."
So far, Ms. Kuhn has been unable to get a new job. She did find holiday employment, working about 10 hours a week as a sales clerk at two clothing stores, but those jobs withered with the end with the Christmas shopping season.
 
A Particular Local Culture
 Whether the particular local culture, with its mixture of blue-collar machismo and waterfront raucousness, will fade along with the military boom is also unanswerable. New London is a hard-edged place, where a compact and hilly brick downtown, built mostly in 1800's on whale-oil profits, abuts an industrial waterfront and a deteriorating seaside amusement park called Ocean Beach Park. Home to 29,000 people, it is the urban core of the region, and seems not to have changed much since Eugene O'Neill frequented the Dutch Tavern on Green Street, which still serves beer and burgers.
Music lovers say New London comes closest of any Connecticut city to having its own sound, a blues-influenced rock led by groups like Little Neil and the Vipers and the Savage Brothers, who play a six-nights-a-week schedule on a local club circuit that ranges from Moby Dick to El 'n Gee. If you want yuppie dance clubs and disco lights, go to Hartford. "Down here, they really like rock and roll," said Jill Mucciarone, a bartender at Moby Dick's.
The police say New London also has the most drug arrests per capita of any Connecticut city, and a reputation -- partly because of its location, midway between New York and Boston off Interstate 95 -- as a neutral ground for mid-level drug dealers from those cities to make their connections.
Other residents say the unchanging military presence also helped preserve the conservative traditions of the Irish, Italian and English immigrants and their descendants who make up a majority of the region's population, and those traditions are now the bedrock, for better and for worse, on which the region will have to rebuild.
"A lot of not wanting to change has been very positive, but a lot has been not very positive," said William T. Christopher, president of the small hospital here, Lawrence & Memorial. "This resistance to change has kept it dependent on things that are now not dependable, like the military."
As an institution, Mr. Christopher's hospital, Lawrence & Memorial, is preparing for a future of distinct limitations. The hospital's $50 million rebuilding plan, begun last year, envisions an aging population and little or no growth into the early years of the next century. Health services will be distributed through the county, with fewer beds and more out-patient geriatric services.
 
The Present
Jobs Are Fewer, And Pay Is Lower
 Skilled welders still make $16 or more an hour in the shipyard; pipe fitters average $13, and a secretary might make $14. And that does not include health benefits. In the world outside the military cocoon, that it is a package hard to duplicate. There have also been illegal fringe benefits like the theft of materials.
Hundreds of laid-off military workers are now croupiers, dealers and waitresses at the booming Foxwoods gambling casino operated by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe just north of here in Ledyard. Out of about 1,000 laid-off military workers who got help with job searches over the last six months through a Federal grant program run here by the Southeastern Connecticut Private Industry Council, 200 of them ended up at Foxwoods, according to the Council's Executive Director, John A. Beauregard.
Most casino workers earn about $7 to $10 an hour, including tips, Mr. Beauregard said. By comparison, the laid-off military workers who have sought help from the Private Industry Council were making $12.40 an hour, a figure skewed by the larger numbers of higher-salaried white-collar workers who were in the first waves of layoffs. More recent groups of laid-off workers are weighted toward the blue-collar trades, he said.
Throughout the city and the region there are tales of people living without health insurance, and people like Ms. Kuhn who work from one short-term job to the next, and of people who simply moved away.
Luigi J. Fristachi may soon join that exodus. Mr. Fristachi, who is 58, and his wife, Lois, 54, both worked at Electric Boat and both lost their jobs on the same unforgettable day, Nov. 30, 1990 -- the first day of their midlife crisis, Mr. Fristachi said.
Trained in the military as computer engineer, he sent out more than 350 resumes, and received what are called "contingency" offers from two military companies: if the companies get a certain contract, Mr. Fristachi would get a certain job. In both cases, the contracts went elsewhere and Mr. Fristachi resumed his search. His unemployment checks, meanwhile, ran out more than a year ago. Mrs. Fristachi has gone through a series of temporary secretarial jobs.
"Our heads are just above water," he said. "But I refuse to get really depressed -- that's so self-defeating."
And there are winners, or at least people who feel that have broken even.
Albert Banks, for example, was laid off as a pipe fitter at Electric Boat in late 1991. Now he is a chef. Having graduated from the Connecticut Culinary Institute, he traded heavy labor on submarines for the more delicate art of judging the perfect medium rare at the Steak Loft restaurant in Mystic.
Down at Shalett Dry Cleaners on Bank Street, Bill Keeney also believes that bad times define the moments of keenest opportunity in business. He should hope so. Mr. Keeney and his wife, Bea, bought the 65-year-old company in November. They had a successful dry cleaners in Atlanta, the very center of the rising new South, but decided to sell to come home to New London where they both grew up, in belief that the place that gave the world the submarine sandwich will rise again.
"Sure, there may be some difficult times ahead," Mr. Keeney said. "We may just have to work a little harder, that's all."
 
The Future
Staying Optimistic Amid Uncertainty
 Local planning officials believe that one of the most dire clouds on the region's immediate horizon is not the retrenchment of Electric Boat and its chain of subcontractors, but rather the Navy's plan to move out its undersea warfare research laboratory.
In addition to the jobs that would actually be pulled from the area, development officials fear that many of the subcontractors who work in very close harmony with the laboratory will pull out as well, resulting in a loss by 1997 of more than 10,000 people, or about 6.3 percent of the region's total population of 167,000, from the naval underwater laboratory alone.
The Federal Government's policy of buying the homes of military personnel who cannot sell -- a likely scenario, city planners say, given the depressed housing market -- would then swamp the market with Government-owned properties that would have to be liquidated at fire-sale prices, further pulling down the region.
"We're really in a sort of never-never land -- we don't know what's going to happen," said Bruce G. Hyde, New London's director of Development and Planning. "So many things that would affect our future are out of our control."
Next: How individual companies, large and small, are coping.

HEADLINE: AIDES GIVE CLINTON BOSNIA PEACE PLAN

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Senior aides to President Clinton have presented him with a peace plan for the Balkans that includes the appointment of a special United States envoy to begin negotiations with the warring factions, senior Administration officials said today. They said the plan would also commit the United States to helping enforce any agreement, although it would not do so alone.
The officials would give few details of the plan, which they said the President had not decided whether to accept. They said no decision had been made on who the envoy might be, and it was not clear if enforcement efforts would involve American troops. 
 The officials presented what they called their "aggressive diplomacy" as an effort to complement the negotiations of the special international envoys Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen. They said the United States effort did not in any way mean that the Administration rejected or was trying to supplant the joint United Nations-European Community talks, which have been accepted by the European allies and Russia as the only alternative for peace.
By offering its own process, the Administration hopes to produce a settlement more acceptable to the Muslims in Bosnia and Herzegovina and to stave off a diplomatic blitz by the two negotiators to force the Muslims to embrace what they regard as an essentially flawed plan.
Mr. Clinton told the visiting President of Turkey, Turgut Ozal, today that he did not support the plan proposed by the two envoys and would present his own plan in "a couple of days," Turkish officials said.
 
No 'Punishing the Victim'
 In effect, Mr. Clinton has rejected the demand by Mr. Vance and Lord Owen that the Security Council impose sanctions on any party that does not embrace its plan. That would have required the United States to punish the Muslim-led Government of Bosnia, a move that an Administration official called "punishing the victim."
But the Administration plan, in what officials have disclosed about it thus far, does not seem to diverge from proposals made in recent days by Mr. Vance and Lord Owen on ways to improve their plan, which Mr. Clinton and his top aides consider impossible to enforce. Washington is also concerned that the Vance-Owen plan would reward Serbian aggression by dividing the country into ethnic enclaves but leave some territory acquired through "ethnic cleansing" in Serbian hands.
In addition to appointing an envoy who would meet the Bosnia Muslims, the Bosnia Serbs, the Serbs of what remains of Yugoslavia and the Croats, the Administration's plan would take these diplomatic steps:
*The creation of a commission to monitor human rights in Bosnia.
*The tightening of international economic sanctions against the Serbs.
*The creation of an international tribunal to try those accused of war crimes.
*The reiteration of the warning to Serbia by the Bush Administration that it will not be allowed to occupy Kosovo, a formerly autonomous province of Serbia with a 90 percent ethnic Albanian majority.
 
Turk Advises Arm-Twisting
 The American officials said Mr. Clinton was presented with the plan during a Cabinet-level meeting at the White House on Friday night that included his national security adviser, W. Anthony Lake; Mr. Lake's deputy, Samuel R. Berger, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
The Turkish officials said today that Mr. Ozal had advised Mr. Clinton to "twist the arm of the Europeans," who have been unwilling to enforce the United Nations-mandated ban on Serbian flights over Bosnian territory.
Mr. Ozal warned Mr. Clinton that if he embraced the Vance-Owen plan, which would divide Bosnia into 10 autonomous provinces, he would be approving Serbian "ethnic cleansing" of the territory. The Turkish leader added that the Vance-Owen plan, which he said would require an enormous commitment of ground forces, was ultimately unenforceable.
 
Fears About Kosovo
 The Turkish officials said Mr. Clinton had declined to reveal the details of the American plan to Mr. Ozal, but had assured him that the approach would be tougher on the Serbs. Mr. Ozal was said to reply, "If this killing continues, you will not be successful."
Mr. Ozal stressed during his meeting at the White House that the Serbs had already begun to move into Kosovo, Turkish officials said. He said Albania's President, Sali Berisha, told him in a telephone conversation on Sunday that the Serbs already had 120,000 troops in Kosovo, that every city had been surrounded with heavy weapons and that high schools and universities had been closed.
During his two-week visit to the United States, Mr. Ozal has been very critical of what he sees as Western paralysis and lack of will to stop the Serbs from "ethnic cleansing."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Fall as Auction Nears

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday as investors and traders prepared for the beginning of the quarterly auctions today.
The auctions begin with the sale of $15.5 billion of three-year notes today and follow with $10.75 billion of 10-year notes tomorrow and $9.25 billion of 30-year notes on Thursday. 
 The price of the 7.625 percent 30-year bond was down 14/32 yesterday, or almost half a point, to 1059/32 as the yield jumped to 7.19 percent from 7.15 percent Friday. The current 6.375 percent 10-year note dropped to 1004/32 , down 13/32 as the yield rose to 6.36 percent, up from 6.30 percent. And the price of the current three-year note dropped 6/32 , to 10116/32 , and the yield rose to 4.54 percent from 4.47 percent.
 
Other Sectors Affected
 Trading was light in both the corporate and tax-exempt municipal bond markets because of the coming Treasury auction. Traders said corporate bond prices were a little lower, while the prices of actively traded municipal bonds rose slightly.
Primary dealers, who do the bulk of the buying at Treasury auctions, often worry about the problem of "digesting" the billions of dollars of securities sold in the auctions. The fear is that the new supply will drive prices up and yields down.
In addition, before an auction many primary dealers sell some of the securities they already hold. One reason is to lighten their holdings so they can take on new issues. The dealers also hope that the selling will drive down the price of the new issues so that they can buy them for less.
But William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities Inc., a primary dealer, said his firm was not interested in buying bonds now because the rally this year has already brought yields down to levels not seen in six and a half years.
He also said he was concerned that the rally had not been driven by economic fundamentals.
"My supposition," he said, "is that the market is trading on politics and not the economy, and that if Clinton does not say the exact right thing, this market could have a lot of problems."
Other traders seemed to be less worried. Some said yesterday that they expected the digesting of the new supply to be difficult but that there would be buyers. Still, the usual pre-auction caution was reflected by one relatively optimistic trader who said, "You always are tentative when you have a big run-up into supply."
When yields rose in the secondary market yesterday, the yields in the when-issued market for the auction also moved higher. But these yields were still lower than those in the secondary market.
Traders said this differential reflected good demand.
If the differential holds, it is still possible that the coupon on the 30-year bond will be either 7.125 percent or 7 percent, the lowest since the 30-year bond began to be issued regularly again between 1975 and 1977.
The yield on the 10-year note in the pre-auction market was 6.32 percent, up from 6.26 on Friday but still below the 6.36 percent on the current 10-year note. The yield on the 30-year bond was 7.15 percent, up from 7.11 percent on Friday but below the 7.19 percent on the current 30-year bond in the secondary market.
The yield on the three-year note was 4.69 percent, up from 4.62 percent Friday and well above the 4.54 percent on the current three-year note.
In the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the average discount rate for three-month bills was 2.94 percent, down from 2.97 percent last week. The average discount rate on six-month bills was 3.09 percent, down from 3.10 percent last week.
Following are the results from the Treasury auction yesterday of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Florio Seeks $15.6 Billion In New Budget

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Faced with an electorate complaining about governmental gridlock, the Democratic administration outlined today a $15.6 billion budget with no big surprises for the next fiscal year and Republican legislative leaders made only pro forma objections.
Although the Republican leaders who control both houses of the Legislature made it clear that they reserve the right to cut both spending and taxes, the vow was more rhetoric than reality. In a tight-money year when Gov. Jim Florio and all legislators are up for election, both parties have an interest in producing a spending plan and avoiding the politically damaging specter of a government that can get nothing done. 
 The new budget proposal, which Governor Florio is to formally present to the Legislature on Tuesday, is about $900 million higher than the current year's, in part because the Florio administration expects a revenue increase from existing taxes because of an improving economy.
 
Cuts in State Workers
 In addition to the $15.6 billion, the budget includes a $150 million unappropriated surplus.
But the spending plan also foresees a further shrinking of state government, through attrition or early retirement, by about 4,700 employees this year, for a savings of $136 million. If that happens, said the State Treasurer, Samuel F. Crane, by the end of the next fiscal year, June 1994, the number of state employees will have dropped by 10,000 since Mr. Florio took office in 1990, from 71,000 to 61,000.
The reductions have been forced both by stagnation in the economy, which has reduced state revenue from taxes, and by the insistence of the Republican majority in the Legislature on cutting both taxes and spending.
Although Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian said today that he and his fellow Republican leaders in the Legislature would "go through the budget line item by line item and program by program as we did last year" seeking cuts, both he and Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, the chief Republican budget officer in the Assembly, agreed that a substantial understanding had already been reached on major budget items such as education aid and health care for the uninsured.
"I would hope there will not be the degree of acrimony there was last year," said Mr. Frelinghuysen, who was the Repubican point man last year on cutting $1.1 billion from the budget of $15.7 billion originally proposed by Governor Florio. With later additions, the budget for the current fiscal year is $14.8 billion.
 
Help from Washington
 Although Mr. Haytaian said, "my gut feeling is that there will be cuts" in the proposed budget, he did not pledge to cut either taxes and spending. Last year, at his urging, Republicans did both, leading to vetoes by Mr. Florio that were promptly overridden.
Trenton budget makers were helped out considerably this year by the new Clinton Administration in Washington. Only weeks after President Clinton took office -- helped in no small measure by New Jersey Democrats, who delivered the state to a Democratic presidential candidate for the first time in 28 years -- the Florio administration was informed that $412 million in disputed Medicaid payments would be forthcoming in time to be included in the current budget.
Another $96 million was also available for this year because the Federal Labor Department deferred for a year the payment of $96 million in unemployment insurance funds.
 
Republicans Urge Caution
 However, these pieces of good news were more than offset by other budget demands. Last year the state raised $900 million through revenue devices that cannot be repeated this year. And New Jersey faces another $900 million or so in increased costs for other items, including Medicaid, schools and corrections.
Furthermore, the budget is based on the assumption that the state is climbing out of the recession. To balance it, the Florio administration is counting on about a billion dollars in added revenues from increased tax collections resulting from expected economic growth.
The accuracy of those revenue forecasts was a subtext of today's news conference of Republican leaders. While Mr. Haytaian suggested that "a tax cut for the middle class" ought to be considered, he acknowledged, "I'm not sure that we can attain it."
And Mr. Frelinghuysen urged caution in assessing the new revenue projections, insisting they might be "too optimistic," in effect countering Mr. Haytaian's hint about a tax cut.
Noting the apparent conflict, Joseph V. Doria Jr., of Bayonne, the Democratic leader in the Assembly, said, "One would think they could at least see eye to eye on the matter of revenue forecasting, instead of subjecting the public to a good-cop, bad-cop routine."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Democrats outlined a new $15.6 billion budget for New Jersey that was met with only minor objections from Republican leaders. Samuel F. Crane, left, State Treasurer, and Richard F. Keevey, the budget director, left a news conference yesterday in Trenton after discussing the proposals. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)
 
THE NEW JERSEY STATE BUDGET: FLORIO'S PLAN FOR FISCAL 1994:
 
At A Glance
Total spending: $15.6 billion, an increase of $904.3 million or 6.1 percent.
 
Taxes: No new tax increases.
 
State workforce: No layoffs, but workforce will be cut by 4,700 through attrition and early retirement. This would mean a total cut of almost 10,000 state workers over four years.
 
Health care: An $81.5 million fund to be set up to support hospitals serving large numbers of uninsured patients. The Federal Government will provide $81.5 million in matching funds.
 
Transportation: No transit fare increases for the third consecutive year.
 
Education: Aid to local school districts increases $255 million.
