HEADLINE: States Cutting or Freezing Their Cash Welfare Benefits

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Faced with severe budget deficits, state governments have made sharp cuts in cash welfare programs in the last two years, weakening society's safety net and in some cases even promoting homelessness, according to a report made public today.
The report, by two private research groups, said the cuts in some states would "hit the poor more sharply" than the Federal reductions of the early 1980's. 
 Those Federal cuts fell more heavily on the working poor and produced a national outcry, the report said. By contrast, it said, the current cutbacks have hit more heavily on those who do not work and have attracted much less public attention.
"Part of this is probably a reflection of a hardening of attitudes toward very poor people," said Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. The center, a Washington research group with liberal politics, wrote the report with the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York in Albany.
 
Cuts and Freezes
 In surveying Aid to Families with Dependent Children, or A.F.D.C., the main cash welfare program, the report found that five states had cut benefits in 1992 and 39 others had frozen them, despite a 3 percent increase in the cost of living.
In Nevada, a recipient's purchasing power fell by 9.2 percent in 1992 because of inflation and a 6.4 percent cut in benefits. In California, the report said, two straight years of cuts had reduced the value of benefits by 16 percent.
Critics of the report said it presented an incomplete picture of antipoverty spending by concentrating on cash assistance. While benefits from those programs have declined, they said, other programs have expanded, most notably the Medicaid program, which provides health insurance to low-income people. In addition, the Federal Government has recently expanded tax credits and child-care programs for the working poor.
Noel Card, a spokesman for the American Legislative Exchange Council, a group of conservative state legislators, said the reductions in cash assistance "would probably be a hardship for a relatively small percentage of people."
 
No Outcry Over Some Cuts
 The report comes as the Clinton Administration, also facing big budget deficits, is searching for ways to constrain Federal spending and may propose other cuts in social programs. Budget officials briefly considered a freeze in cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security recipients, but backed off in the face of opposition from groups representing the elderly.
No such outcry has greeted the fate of the women and children who have suffered the recent welfare cuts. They have scant power in state capitals and have seen the purchasing power of their cash benefits decline 43 percent in the last two decades. Increases in food-stamp allotments have mitigated a little more than half of that decline.
The report said the cuts had been most severe in California, Illinois and Maryland. It said Connecticut, Oklahoma, Rhode Island and Wyoming had also enacted substantial reductions.
The report concentrated on three cash welfare programs.
The largest is A.F.D.C. which covers about 4.5 million families, mostly headed by single women. The House Ways and Means Committee found the average 1991 benefit for a mother with two children was $402 a month, rising to $623 when food stamps were included.
The report also examined general-assistance programs, which provide cash to about a million people, including single adults and childless couples. Only 28 states have such programs, which receive no Federal money.
Of them, 14 states cut programs in 1991 and 8 states cut them in 1992. After the cuts, the average for maximum benefits is $215 a month. The report said some recipients, like those living in welfare hotels, would be forced into homelessness as a result.
The third benefit covered by the report is Supplemental Security Income, a Federal program providing assistance to people who are elderly, blind or disabled. The basic Federal benefit in 1992 was $422 a month for an individual, but 27 states supplement that by an average of $32 a month. The report found that five states had cut the supplement last year and 21 others froze it.
Taken together the three cash assistance programs account for less than 5 percent of the average state's annual budget, and the report's authors argued that bigger savings could have been found elsewhere, with less human suffering. Some states compounded the effect by passing taxes that fall disproportionately on the poor, the report said.
Criticism of the report focused more on what it omitted than on what it said. Mr. Card, the spokesman for the legislators, said the state budget crises were now being driven in part by Federal Medicaid laws, which have required states to insure more poor people. Medicaid spending now accounts for 14 percent of the average state's budget.

HEADLINE: Wrestling Health-Care Costs to the Mat

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
From his third-floor office in a sleek building near the domed Capitol of California, Tom J. Elkin is a commander in the war against the ever-rising costs of health care.
"I know what is a reasonable price for a compact disk or a refrigerator," he said. "But what is accessible health care worth? I don't know yet what a fair price is for the product we're buying. That's what we're after." 
 Mr. Elkin has plenty of ammunition in this crusade to drive costs to rock bottom. Each year he buys $1.3 billion worth of health care as associate executive director of the California Public Employees' Retirement System, or Calpers, which represents more than 875,000 state and local government employees and their families across California.
 
A Promising Prototype
 He has taken up the banner of "managed competition," a hotly debated approach for reorganizing the nation's medical care that has attracted growing support in Washington. In essence, the approach holds that costs can be controlled by forcing health providers to compete with one another under government supervision.
Calpers is a prototype for insurance-purchasing cooperatives, a concept that lies at the heart of managed competition. The cooperatives are envisioned as giant pools that smaller companies and individuals would join to gain leverage in buying coverage from competing health plans.
But Calpers has already shown promise, even without the benefit of the sweeping national changes in insurance, tax incentives and delivery of care called for by proponents of managed competition. Exercising the power of its numbers, Calpers shocked the health industry in California last year by freezing new enrollments for the state's largest insurer, Kaiser Permanente, because it refused to restrain its rate increases. Apart from Kaiser, Calpers was able to hold 20 other insurers it deals with to average premium increases of 3.1 percent in 1992, when the state industry average was 13.2 percent.
 
Favored by Clinton
 Today, Calpers is expected to announce what it considers another great success: average premium increases in the low single digits for 1993.
Promoting such competition has been endorsed in principle by President Clinton and has drawn support in both liberal and conservative circles. But the full-blown proposal for managed competition includes other major changes that are more contentious, and it is not clear how many Mr. Clinton or Congress will embrace.
Managed competition, as envisioned by the informal group of health economists who originated the concept, would require all employers to offer coverage to full-time workers. Tax incentives would push most people into health maintenance organizations or other groups that offer comprehensive care but limited choice.
On the other side, most doctors, hospitals and insurers would join health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s -- clinical partnerships that curtail their freedom but offer subscribers health care for a single overall fee. To promote comparison shopping, the Government would study each H.M.O.'s quality and cost of care, while a national board would decide what coverage should be mandatory and which medical procedures were wasteful.
Skeptics say managed competition, with its combination of regulation and free market innovation, is untested. In fact, it is being tried here in California to some degree, although these efforts cannot be fully effective in the absence of a comprehensive national scheme.
 
Insurers Forced to Cut Waste
 Pressure from Calpers, an early example of the kind of giant insurance-purchasing cooperatives called for in managed competition plans, is forcing Kaiser, Health Net and other insurers here to root out wasteful administrative costs, reduce unnecessary care and squeeze hospitals and doctor groups to lower their rates.
"The experience of Calpers is a preview of what the nation will encounter, given President Clinton's commitment to hold down health-care costs," said Gray Davis, the state Controller, who sits on the 13-member Calpers board. "Ultimately something has to give -- speed of access to elective surgery, the right to choose a doctor, the range of procedures that will be covered. Everybody wants the best care."
But Mr. Elkin maintains that far more fat can be trimmed away before consumers notice such effects. "You'd be amazed how low some of these plans will go with their rates before it goes to the quick," he said. "There is an astronomical amount of unnecessary administration and unnecessary procedures. We have not gotten fully into it yet."
 
Elective: a Point of View
 Yet one person's unneeded procedure -- a hip replacement, for example -- may be what another doctor and patient feel is necessary, illustrating how divisive any uniform national standards may become.
Calpers, a 57-year-old agency, administers health-care plans not only for the state government but also for 784 other public employers, including local school districts, cities and even tiny entities like the California Prune Board, which has eight employees. Joining the cooperative gives each employer bargaining power it would otherwise lack. Calpers offers its members a choice among 19 H.M.O.'s, with which it negotiates rates and services; it offers a traditional health insurance plan for members in remote areas not served by H.M.O.'s.
The agency was galvanized into creating an ambitious program to eliminate waste when fast-climbing premium increases peaked at 21 percent in 1990. With the advice of Alain C. Enthoven of the Stanford University Business School, a founder of the managed-competition concept, Calpers took a tough new stance starting in 1991 and began to standardize benefits among plans to make comparisons easier. It demanded detailed data from each provider so that the costs of services could be compared, then used that information to encourage carriers to cut waste.
For 1992, it set a zero increase as its initial negotiating position. When Kaiser, an H.M.O. that cares for about 345,000 Calpers members, insisted on increases of more than 10 percent, Calpers barred new enrollments in it.
 
A Bit of Consumer Choice
 "That served as an example that Calpers meant business," said Scott R. Kelly, vice president of major accounts at another major carrier, Foundation Health, a California Health Plan, which is a profit-making company based in Sacramento that serves about 78,000 Calpers members. Foundation settled for a 2.9 percent increase. (Kaiser said it was unable to go so low because it offered richer benefits.)
For the most part, the Calpers system appears to be well accepted by patients, although some younger, healthier workers have complained about rising premiums. Under the system, a member chooses among participating H.M.O.'s and may then pick a personal physician within the H.M.O. selected. If the patient seeks care outside the H.M.O., he must pay himself.
For all the new pressures, leaders of Kaiser and the other H.M.O.'s here say they prefer managed competition to alternative proposals because it maintains a measure of consumer choice and avoids the kind of government-run plan used in Canada, which leaves insurers with little role.
Indeed, any system that pressures more people to join H.M.O.'s stands to benefit large, efficient operators like Kaiser, which has 4.7 million members and 6,500 doctors in California.
"We are a strong exponent of managed competition," said Robert J. Erickson, senior vice president for government relations for Kaiser in California. He added that Kaiser expected to ask Calpers for "little or no rate increase" for the coming year.
 
Treatment by the Rules
 H.M.O.-type medicine has long been more accepted by patients and doctors in California than in some other areas, like New York City, and it remains to be seen whether Calpers's success could be matched in communities that resist H.M.O.'s. But even here, patients may soon find their care more closely managed in ways like these:
*Health Net is beginning an experiment this month in which neonatal nurses will make six monthly telephone calls to certain pregnant Calpers members to give them advice and encourage them to seek early maternal care. The results will later be compared to other pregnancies in which such calls were not made.
*The 80-doctor Bay Shores Medical Group in Torrance has installed a new computer system meant to thwart patients who visit different doctors within the group to get excessive prescription pain killers and other drugs or to seek redundant care. The system is also used to detect when doctors prescribe excessive diagnostic tests.
*Southern California Permanente Medical Group, which contracts with Kaiser to care for 2.3 million people, is developing strict guidelines for its 3,200 doctors to bring consistent care to its network of hospitals and clinics. For example, its medical director, Dr. Frank E. Murray, said the guidelines would probably eliminate routine mammography for women before age 50 because research had found no benefit in early testing.
Such tight management has forced a new reality on doctors. After eight years of private practice, Dr. Mark P. Schwartz, an internist, found his work dwindling as his patients joined H.M.O.'s. So he left his practice in 1990 and became a salaried employee of a group, Bay Shores in Torrance. "The handwriting was on the wall," Dr. Schwartz said.
The change was something of a shock. "In a setting like this, there's a great deal of attention to the dollar figure," he said. "So I had to reorient my thinking in terms of what can I spend for a test.
"The consensus is there has not been any suffering in patient outcome. But my big fear is how far this will be taken."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dr. Diane Y. Petersen, shown examining William McKenna, is one of the 80 doctors working at Bay Shores Medical Group in Torrance, Calif. Bay Shores is one of the many doctor groups forced to cut wasteful administrative costs and reduce unnecessary care because of health-care competition. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times); In his war against the ever-rising costs of health care, Tom J. Elkin, associate executive director of the California Public Employees' Retirement System, has taken up the banner of "managed competition." By forcing health providers to compete with one another under government supervision, he hopes to drive costs of health care to rock bottom. (Susan Spann for The New York Times) (pg. D21)
 
Table: "The Plan for Managed Competition"
 Managed competition would involve sweeping change in the organization of medical care, insurance and incentives.
 
HOW IT WOULD WORK
Doctors, hospitals and insurers would form partnerships, like health maintenance organizations, and compete on the basis of price, consumer satisfaction and medical success. A government agency would report publicly on medical performance and costs.
Cooperatives organized by states would give small businesses and individuals the same bargaining power as large companies.
A combination of employer mandates and Government subsidies would enable those now uninsured to join a cooperative.
A national board would set basic benefits to be offered.
Tax breaks for businesses and individuals would be limited to the cost of the most efficient partnerships. Those who want extra benefits would pay for them with after-tax income.
 
THE POTENTIAL ADVANTAGES
Government-guided market forces, rather than dictates and rationing, would hold down costs.
Public accountability would promote competition among providers.
Evolving national standards for appropriate care, and feedback to doctors on results, would reduce useless and wasteful procedures.
Individuals and employers would become more cost-conscious.
Discrimination by insurers against high-risk individuals and wasteful case-by-case oversight by insurers would end.
 
THE MAIN OBJECTIONS
Critics say the plan would not halt rapid inflation of medical costs. Some say the nation must also set and enforce a ceiling on medical spending, and some liberal critics also say a Federal takeover of medical care would be more efficient.
Some conservatives say that large purchasing groups and national boards would curtail choice by consumers and doctors, and would lead to costly bureaucracies and rationing. They would prefer ending the link between employment and health insurance, instead altering tax incentives to help individuals directly buy the coverage they want.
Achieving consensus on basic benefits and on which technologies deserve coverage may be politically impossible, some critics say.

HEADLINE: A Health-Care Theory Hatched in Fireside Chats

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

 BODY:
The basic theory of managed competition in health care was developed by an informal group of health experts who call themselves the Jackson Hole Group, after the Wyoming city where they meet periodically at the home of Dr. Paul M. Ellwood, a doctor and leading health economist.
The main theorist has perhaps been Alain C. Enthoven, a professor at the Stanford University Business School. But over the last three years the concept has been refined around the fireplace of Dr. Ellwood's house, where guests have included academics, public officials and leaders of the insurance and health industries. 
 "This amounts to a radical restructuring of the health system while relying on conventional market forces." Dr. Ellwood said.
At the core of the plan are health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, partnerships made up of doctors, hospitals and insurers that supply health care to their members at a fixed annual fee. These partnerships would compete for the business of big companies and of big purchasing cooperatives organized by the states on behalf of small businesses and individuals.
 
Wide Appeal, Many Doubts
 Over the last several months, managed competition has emerged as central in the debate in Washington over how to revamp the nation's health-care system, now plagued by runaway costs while leaving 35 million people uninsured. Managed competition's promise of holding down costs and improving care has wide appeal, but doubts are also being voiced: Can it really contain costs, given the continuous introduction of expensive technology? Will competition come at the expense of innovation and patient health?
One criticism comes from Dr. Arnold Relman, former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine. While endorsing managed competition in principle, he fears that too much control over medical decisions will go to investor-owned insurance companies. He favors H.M.O.'s jointly owned by doctors and patients. "If doctors accept responsibility for living within a budget, they are in the best position to practice prudent medicine and do it efficiently," Dr. Relman said.
Other critics, like Dr. Steffie Woolhandler of Harvard Medical School, favor a nationalized system like Canada's, in which the government pays the bills and people keep their own doctors. "Managed competition totally disrupts the doctor-patient relationship," Dr. Woolhandler said.
President Clinton, while endorsing managed competition, has also endorsed a national cap on medical spending; the Jackson Hole Group rejects that as heavy handed. But some experts argue that costs will keep soaring unless the Government imposes an overall limit.
"New technology pushes costs up exponentially," said Dr. Alan L. Hillman, director of the Center for Health Policy at the University of Pennsylvania. "H.M.O.'s will say, 'We offer the latest and greatest.' "
 
A Not-Quite-Free Market
 A variation on the spending cap is gaining favor among Presidential advisers who believe that competition and budget limits can be married. This notion would impose no explicit national cap; instead, the regional cooperatives that buy health insurance for their members would be told that they could pay a fixed amount per person to the H.M.O.'s in each region. That payment would be set by a national health board. Individuals could opt for more extensive coverage but would have to pay the difference in costs.
A chief proponent of this approach, called capitation, is Paul Starr, a sociologist at Princeton University who is advising the Clinton Administration. Federal or state sanctions, he said, could be imposed on cooperatives that fail to conform to the mandated limit.
This idea is endorsed by the Jackson Hole Group, although they do not favor the comprehensive regulation that some want to accompany it. Professor Enthoven argues that excessive growth in overall costs should be controlled by specific actions aimed at the causes: reviewing new technologies, taking antitrust actions against H.M.O.'s, or altering the patients' deductibles or fees.
"We should do it through incentives rather than just trying to sweep costs under the carpet by imposing some lid," he said.

HEADLINE: Campus Journal;
Learning 54 Languages With a Missionary's Zeal

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: PROVO, Utah

 BODY:
From distant countries they bring back fresh insights and a love of language and culture so strong that here at Brigham Young University, education is a great feast of language.
There are nearly 30,000 students at "the Y," as this Mormon university perched on the Wasatch Mountains is known, and at any one time about 10,000 of them are studying one of 54 languages. 
 Most Mormon men and an increasing number of women interrupt their educations to go on proselytizing missions for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Many go abroad after receiving an eight-week crash course in a country's language, culture and religion. They are expected to learn to converse in the language from the locals.
When they return after two years to re-enroll at Brigham Young, they have often acquired such a passion for the country they worked in that they decide to study the nation's language and culture in more depth.
That passion is fed by an elaborate technical support system comprising a language laboratory, recording studios, translating booths and computer programs written by the university's faculty members.
One recent afternoon, students in the language lab were found staring at television monitors in the study of Korean, Japanese, German, Russian, French, Spanish and Italian. A Japanese student studied Spanish; a Mexican studied Japanese.
Outside the lab, in the stairwell to the second floor, a yellow poster advertised a class in "business Chinese," accompanied by this note of caution: "Limited Space -- Register Now." It is a warning not taken lightly at a university where classes in Mongolian, Icelandic and Afrikaans are known to fill up quickly, and where Tongan, Tahitian or Samoan have been offered.
Brigham Young "has always been in the forefront in a wide variety of developments" in language education, said Phyllis Franklin, executive director of the Modern Language Association, a national organization of English and language teachers.
Ms. Franklin said Brigham Young's ambitious language program is rare at universities these days because budget problems have devastated many language departments.
Those cutbacks have worsened an already deteriorating picture of language study. Despite an increasingly global economy and a growing global consciousness, American college students are studying foreign languages less. Ms. Franklin said that in 1960, 16 students out of every 100 enrolled in college were taking a foreign language. In 1990, the rate had dropped to 8.5.
Brigham Young's language program stands apart from other big efforts, like those at the University of Wisconsin at Madison or Yale University, and not only because a third of its students are studying a foreign language at any time, or because 54 different languages are offered. Perhaps only at "the Y," most students start their formal study of a foreign language after they can already converse in it with ease.
The Mormon missions are the reason. Before embarking, Mormons get their basic language training at a center on campus that is run by the church but is independent of the university. What they learn in the crash course is barely enough to help them order groceries in a store. But they then spend two years abroad submerged in daily conversation, picking up a working knowledge of the local language and, often, a fascination with the culture.
The experience can transform them. "Before I got there the only thing I knew about Korea was 'M*A*S*H,' " said Paul Wulfenstein of Las Vegas. "I slaughtered their language for the first year; then I started to pick it up."
He returned from Korea in February 1991 to complete some courses at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas before transferring this semester to Brigham Young. He is enrolled in intermediate-level Korean classes and has declared Korean his major.
For Valerie Peterson of Pleasant Grove, Utah, learning the Japanese language broadened her world immeasurably. Before she went on a mission to Tokyo about two years ago, she lived close enough to the Brigham Young campus to commute.
She is now enrolled in intermediate-level Japanese courses in which she must be drilled on the elaborate pictographs she never had to master before. Sitting cross-legged and shoeless in the hallway at the Knight Building recently, Miss Peterson said she can speak Japanese with ease but still reads it at the level of a 5-year-old.
Miss Peterson has decided to major in Japanese. "It presents so many opportunities, I don't know where to start," she said. "I think I'll give translating a shot."

TITLE: EDUCATION PAGE (NYT)

HEADLINE: 6th Match Game a Draw For Polgar and Spassky

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Judit Polgar and Boris Spassky agreed to a draw today after the 43d move in the sixth game of their exhibition chess match. 
 The 16-year-old Polgar, the world's youngest grandmaster, now leads the 10-game event by a score of 3 1/2-2 1/2. She and Spassky, a former world champion, are playing for a $120,000 winner's share of a $200,000 purse.
The next game will be on Thursday.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	LUCERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 9 (AP) - Where will the world championship be held next summer? Finding a site and a suitable purse for the match -- between Gary Kasparov, the champion, and Nigel Short, an English grandmaster -- has not been easy in this recession year.
On Monday, the International Chess Federation said it had received two bids. The larger, for $5.6 million, came from Jugoskandic, the Yugoslav sponsor of both the Polgar-Spassky match and the recent match between Spassky and Bobby Fischer; the site would be either Belgrade or Sofia, Bulgaria. The other bid, from Santiago de Compostela, Spain, was for $666,667. The purse for the last championship, in 1990 in New York and Lyons, France, was $3 million.

HEADLINE: Identity Crisis for London's Theater District

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Harold Pinter's drama "No Man's Land," which opened on Feb. 8 in the West End, is the latest longshot entry in the London theatrical sweepstakes that, over the last year, have seen more losers than winners.
More than a dozen ambitious plays and musicals have swept onto the West End stage -- some, like the Pinter play, coming off successful runs in London's small fringe theaters -- only to disappear without a trace, starved by half-full houses in spite of strong and often enthusiastic critical reviews. 
 "Grand Hotel," the Tommy Tune-directed musical that ran for two and a half years on Broadway, lasted barely four months here, and folded in November. The Beirut hostage drama "Someone Who'll Watch Over Me," starring Alec McCowen, Stephen Rea and James McDaniel (who are now appearing in the New York production), drew packed houses in suburban Hampstead, but closed in November in the West End after a run of only six weeks. And the Victorian romp "Trelawney of the Wells," which opened in early December to mixed reviews, closed abruptly last month, despite a cast that included Michael Hordern and Sarah Brightman.
The recession -- Britain's longest-running economic drama since the 1930's -- has clearly taken a toll on London theater, thinning the ranks of potential theatergoers, including foreign tourists who, in ordinary circumstances, fill nearly one of every three West End seats. Ticket prices, which have increased 24 percent since 1991, have had an effect, too, as producers try to recoup some of the higher cost of theatrical production in London.
 
Larger Issues at Stake
 But some critics and producers say the West End's difficulties are not merely the result of a downturn in economic fortunes, but rather a reflection of something much larger: the notion that the West End is struggling to redefine itself in the face not only of waning audiences but also of a nagging sense that truly innovative theater is being done elsewhere.
"The West End is in search of itself," said Nick Allott, the executive producer of the Cameron Mackintosh organization, who brought "Miss Saigon" and "Les Miserables" to the London stage, where they continue to be two of the West End's most enduring hits.
Mr. Allott says there is a broad belief that theater here has undergone a gradual restructuring over the last decade. As a result, new and original drama is now almost exclusively the province of the subsidized theater or regional theater, while the commercial theater -- the heart of the West End -- has become increasingly anodyne.
At the heart of the problem are soaring production costs. According to one estimate, the cost of putting on a straight play in the West End has nearly tripled in the last 10 years, to as much as $375,000 for a production with a small cast and perhaps one set change. (Such a play would cost about three times that much on Broadway). As a result, critics argue, London producers and theater owners have been forced to raise ticket prices -- which can be more than $30 for many straight plays and close to $50 for musicals -- to recover growing expenses. And, perhaps more importantly, they have become increasingly wary of taking risks.
Michael Billington, the theater critic of The Guardian, wrote last summer that the West End had become "a neon wasteland," filled with glitzy musicals and popular revivals. In an article on the West End, he fumed: "Too many tacky shows. Too little value for money. Too few drama producers with the Mackintosh flair. Too little investment."
Not everyone agrees with that assessment. The Society of West End Theaters, which monitors audience and ticket data and aggressively markets London's commercial and subsidized theater, argues that the situation is not nearly as bad as critics like Mr. Billington contend. In fact, the society argues, the constant churning among West End playhouses is a sign of vitality rather than of trouble.
There is also evidence, theater managers say, that a slight improvement in the economy is giving a second wind to a number of commercial productions that might not have survived only a few months ago. "Our Song," a melancholy ramble about male menopausal crisis, starring Peter O'Toole, has been playing to good houses; a revival of Noel Coward's "Hay Fever" that opened in November has extended bookings through May, and a production of Oscar Wilde's "Ideal Husband" has been playing to good audiences since it opened in early November.
Perhaps gambling on better times to come, the producers of "Kiss of the Spider Woman," which opened in the West End in October to critical acclaim (and won the Evening Standard's award for best musical), recently announced that they would accept ticket requests through September, though the show has been playing to less than full houses.
Moreover, theater managers argue that the number of flops and early closings was no worse than average last year. Of London's 50 commercial and subsidized theaters, 8 are currently dark.
Robert Fox, a producer who will bring Dame Maggie Smith to the West End in March in "The Importance of Being Earnest," said, "I don't think it is much different than it ever was, in terms of the plays that get to the West End." West End producers have always put a high premium on commercial value, he added. "It has never been an experimental forum, and that's why places like the National and Royal Shakespeare Company and Hampstead have funding," Mr. Fox said. "They can afford to be more daring, because the government is there to share the risk."
If many West End theaters do have trouble sustaining audiences, some producers say, the problem may be self-evident: too many theaters chasing too few theatergoers.
"You just don't have 40 great attractions playing at 40 different theaters that are going to persuade people to come out and spend money they are not willing to spend," said Duncan Weldon, a producer of two current plays, "Lost in Yonkers" and "Cyrano de Bergerac." "Especially not these days," he added, "when people have already cut down on their expenditures because of the economy."
Faced with so many empty seats, in fact, West End theaters in recent months have embarked on one short-term remedy: aggressive discounting schemes, including two-for-the-price-of-one ticket deals. Breaking a longstanding taboo, a few have also experimented with Sunday performances, in the hope of attracting more weekend trade.
But the more long-term result may be a gradual thinning of the number of working London theaters, because they can no longer survive if only half their seats are filled.
"In another five years, when it comes to a choice between having a dark theater and playing to half-full houses, I think we will have a situation here more like Broadway: more dark theaters," said Mr. Weldon.
It is a measure of the West End's stagnation, some critics argue, that the shows that draw the biggest audiences are the same ones that were drawing big audiences two and three years ago, notably Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals like "Cats" and "Phantom of the Opera."
The popular drawing power of Mr. Webber's name and craft is such that lines stretched for two blocks along the Strand a few weeks ago when ticket sales opened for his newest production, "Sunset Boulevard." The top ticket for the show, which is to open in June, is a London record: the equivalent of $48.
It is when the Lloyd Webber and Mackintosh musicals and a handful of others are subtracted from London theater statistics that the West End's overall performance begins to look especially thin. Hilary Strange, an agent for Equity British Actors, the union for stage performers, said that life had become more difficult for actors.
"A few years ago, you had a reasonably good chance of getting a play that would have a year's run," she said. "Now you work in spurts, because most of the new stuff tends to last three months at most, and you have to then latch onto something else."
 
Bombing, Literally
 There are other explanations offered for the West End's problems in the last year. The Society of West End Theaters says that the Irish Republican Army scared away a lot of business during the fall, when they exploded several small devices in the West End, one of which killed a pub patron.
Others complain that new parking restrictions in central London have complicated the lives of theatergoers from the suburbs, and several critics ritually bemoan the aging, cramped theaters.
Thelma Holt, a longtime London producer, takes issue with those who argue that the West End is on the ropes, reduced to nothing but tourist theater. "That is an outdated view," she said. "The fact is, the fringe and subsidized theater and the West End all complement one another."
She pointed to several plays, like the new Pinter drama, which have moved to the West End from either the fringe or the subsidized theater. The most recent example was the Jim Cartwright play "The Rise and Fall of Little Voice," which earned good reviews and big audiences at the National Theater and just completed a very successful three-month run in the West End. And Peter Shaffer's "Gift of the Gorgon," which closes at the Royal Shakespeare this month, will reopen in the West End in March.
At the same time, however, no commercial producer has moved to bring to the West End such talked-about productions as "The Madness of King George III," which played to sold-out houses at the National Theater last year, or Tony Kushner's "Angels in America," which ran at the National's Cottlesloe Theater.
"People are always trying to kill off the West End," said Ms. Holt. "It's like the measles; it's one of those things that just comes around every so often."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The West End in London is suffering from an economic downturn and a lack of identity, and tickets are readily available for most shows. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Blackstone Leads Group Bid For Canada Grocery Chain

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
In what would be one of the largest leveraged buyouts so far this decade, a unit of the Blackstone Group, an American investment bank, said yesterday that it and a Montreal-based group were seeking to acquire Univa, the second-largest supermarket chain in Canada, for about $1.25 billion in cash and debt.
Blackstone Capital Partners L.P. and Unigesco Inc., the Montreal group, are the principals in the transaction. Blackstone Capital is a New York-based investment fund. Unigesco is Univa's largest shareholder, with a 26 percent stake. 
 Under the terms of the transaction, Blackstone Capital would put up $300 million in cash for an 80 percent stake in Univa. Unigesco's equity investment would be roughly $75 million, for which it would receive the remaining 20 percent of the company.
 Sensitive to Canadian attitudes about foreign ownership of local companies, Blackstone Capital agreed to liquidate its interest in Univa in no more than seven years. At that time, the joint venture with Unigesco would be dissolved, and control of Univa would be vested in Unigesco.
 
A Tailored Transaction
 "We have tried to design the transaction to accommodate the needs of people in Canada," said Stephen A. Schwarzman, president and chief executive of the Blackstone Group. "We don't keep our investments for as long as seven years anyhow, and we have agreed to give Unigesco the right of first refusal on major asset sales."
In order to finance the balance of the purchase not covered by equity, Blackstone Capital and Unigesco will need to raise close to $900 million in bank loans and other forms of debt securities.
 Mr. Schwarzman said the partners were "far along" in obtaining commitments from several major American and Canadian financial institutions.
In a news release announcing the deal, Blackstone Capital and Unigesco said they expected that about 40 percent of Univa's capitalization after the transaction was completed would be in the form of either equity or debt bearing no cash interest for five years.
Mr. Schwarzman said bank debt to finance the transaction would be raised in Canada, and subordinated debt in the United States.
Univa, which had sales of more than $6.5 billion last year, has a 40 percent share of the supermarket business in Ontario and about a 45 percent share of Quebec's supermarket business, Mr. Schwarzman said.
"In the United States you don't typically get market shares that are this big," Mr. Schwarzman added. "This is a very well-positioned business."
Nevertheless, given Canada's current -- and continuing -- economic slump, people familiar with Univa said the Blackstone Capital offer was extremely rich.
More than 60 percent of Univa's stock is owned by three large shareholders.
 
 
Empire's Stake
 Marilyn Brophy, an equity analyst for the First Boston Corporation in Toronto, said that in addition to Unigesco's 26 percent interest, the Empire Company, another Canadian supermarket operator, owned 24 percent and Caisse Depot, Quebec's largest pension fund, owned around 13 percent.
Ms. Brophy said Empire, which had expressed interest in pieces of Univa's business in the past, might make a competing bid. Empire's board was scheduled to meet today to consider its response to the Blackstone Capital offer.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Good News Is Bad for Bond Prices

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury market got a light jolt of good economic news yesterday afternoon that was enough to push prices of notes and bonds down a little after the first of the Treasury's three quarterly auctions this week went well.
But the Treasury market has retained most of the big gains of the January rally despite the fact that President Clinton has yet to present a clearly detailed deficit reduction plan and now appears to be dropping some of the toughest ideas he has considered. 
 The economic news was the Johnson Redbook report that showed that department and chain store sales rose at a seasonally adjusted rate of 3.7 percent in the first week of February. This showed that consumer buying continued to remain stronger than many analysts had thought.
 
Happy With Auciton
 "This is the first time the market has paid any attention to any economic news," said one bond trader, who argued that the recent string of data showing the economy moving at a nice pace should have been raising some concern about inflation and pulling Treasury prices lower.
The Treasury auctioned $15.5 billion of three-year notes at an average yield of 4.73 percent, and investors and traders seemed to be happy with the results. "It was an honest auction," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "There seemed to be some solid demand from large institutional investors."
After the auction, the yield on the new three-year note, which has a coupon of 4.625 percent, dropped to around 4.68 percent, a sign that there was demand for the new notes. But the gains were lost after the report on department store sales, and the yield finished at 4.73 percent, the same as the average at the auction. The Treasury will auction 10-year notes today and 30-year bonds tomorrow.
Prices of current Treasury notes and bonds, which had been lifted by the three-year auction results, fell after the Johnson Redbook report. The two-year note was off 3/32 , with the yield rising to 4.20 percent, up from 4.17 percent Monday. The price of the current 10-year note fell 5/32 as the yield increased to 6.38 percent from 6.36 percent.
The price of the current 30-year bond was off 2/32 as the yield rose to 7.20 percent from 7.19 percent. The discount rates on six-month and one-year Treasury bills rose slightly, to 3.10 percent and 3.34 percent, respectively. The 2.92 percent discount rate on the three-month bill was unchanged.
But traders said they still thought there was a good atmosphere for the remaining two auctions this week, although some were worried about what President Clinton might say in his town meeting in Detroit tonight as he begins to sell his economic program. In late trading, the yield in the when-issued, or pre-auction, market was 6.34 percent on the new 10-year note, up from 6.32 percent Monday, and 7.15 percent on the new 30-year bond, unchanged from Monday.
A successful 30-year auction tomorrow could see the yield fall below the 7.10 percent low of April 1986, the lowest level since the Treasury began to issue 30-year bonds regularly in the late 1970's.
The quarterly auctions commenced yesterday as more of the details of Mr. Clinton's economic plan became public. And one factor that could begin to worry the bond market is that, as of now, there is more talk of new spending and tax increases than spending cuts.
For example, on Monday, Mr. Clinton announced a plan to extend unemployment benefits for 26 weeks at a cost of about $3 billion. His communications director, George Stephanopoulos, said the Administration was unlikely to propose any kind of freeze on cost-of-living increases for Social Security. But the Administration is still considering raising the taxes on Social Security benefits.
 
Waiting on Military Spending Cuts
 The major spending reduction to be outlined so far is in the military budget, a place Democrats have traditionally gone for spending reductions. And last week the Administration indicated that the package of tax cuts and spending increases to stimulate the economy would be about $31 billion, more than the $20 billion many analysts were counting on.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, Louisiana issued $602 million of general obligation bonds, including $477 million of series A refunding bonds and $125 million of series B improvement bonds. The series B bonds, with a coupon of 5.875 percent were priced to yield 5.90 percent in 2011, 2012 and 2013. The taxable equivalent yield is 8.55 percent. The lead manager was Merrill Lynch. The noncallable bonds are insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation and therefore are triple-A rated.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- ADVERTISING;
Cigarette makers encourage smokers to wear their favorite brands on their sleeves.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
WHO'S going to clothe America this spring? Donna Karan, Ralph Lauren, Philip Morris, L. L. Bean, R. J. Reynolds . . .
Don't laugh. The nation's largest tobacco marketers are undertaking their most extensive efforts ever to entice Americans into wearing their cigarette brand names. It is estimated that they will spend upward of $300 million this year to persuade consumers to collect proofs of purchase or coupons redeemable for clothing and other merchandise. 
 Tobacco Road is beginning to look like Seventh Avenue as longtime give-away items like T-shirts and caps are being complemented by pricier jogging outfits, scarves, vests and belts. A black leather jacket from Virginia Slims V-Wear -- "the fashion collection with a streetwise attitude," a brochure gushes -- goes for 350 universal product codes from packs, while a pullover from the "Marlboro Adventure Team" -- "you won't want to take it off, ever," the Official Gear Catalog promises -- goes for 180 product codes.
Most of the garments are festooned with advertising imagery, as camels and cowboys replace polo ponies and alligators. For example, apparel promoting Benson & Hedges Special Kings bears its logo or its slogan, "Take the edge off." For some, like V-Wear, identification is generally confined to labels.
The promotions are at the heart of strategies intended to shore up sagging sales of full-price cigarettes, which are losing market share to discount smokes. Brands with unfamiliar names like Bristol, Misty and Bucks, priced up to a dollar a pack less than their higher-priced counterparts, have an estimated 30 percent of the $47 billion American cigarette market -- 10 times more than a decade ago.
"If you're going to make a good living in the tobacco business, you focus on full price for the same reason that Willie Sutton focused on banks," said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. in San Francisco. "That's where the money is."
While 80 percent of Philip Morris's American unit sales last year came from full-price brands, he estimated, those brands accounted for 95 percent of earnings; at Reynolds, the comparable figures were 69 percent of sales and at least 80 percent of profits.
So the promotions act as incentives to encourage smokers "to buy your cigarettes for reasons beyond price," he said. "You can give things away; you just don't want to give price away."
Lawrence S. Wexler, senior vice president of marketing at Philip Morris U.S.A. in New York, which is sponsoring the promotions for Benson & Hedges, Marlboro and Virginia Slims, said: "This is a way of adding value to our premium trademarks, and giving consumers looking for a reason to continue buying them a way to do that."
His counterpart at the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company in Winston-Salem, N.C., agreed. "If you take $5 off a carton of cigarettes, the smoker perceives it as $5, and it costs us $5," said David N. Iauco, senior vice president of marketing. "But if you take merchandise with a perceived value of $5 that costs us $3, the economics are better."
For its popular Camel brand, Reynolds is introducing the third in a series of Camel Cash Catalogs, starring the Joe Camel cartoon character. Camel's gain in market share last year -- unusual for a full-price brand -- was in large part a result of the second catalogue promotion, Mr. Iauco said.
Even so, whether the tobacco industry's wearables will wear well remains problematic.
"We don't know if they will succeed at counteracting the fact that cigarettes are so expensive right now," said Laurie Petersen, editor of The Cowles Report on Database Marketing and Management, a newsletter in New York.
Another problem is the opposition of antismoking activists. The promotions are "yet again another way of making smoking appear glamorous and attractive," said Joy Epstein, administrator for Federal issues at the Coalition on Smoking or Health in Washington. In December, the coalition, representing health groups like the American Cancer Society, filed a petition with the Federal Trade Commission demanding the Marlboro Adventure Team promotion be withdrawn because it violated a voluntary industry code by associating smoking with physical activities "requiring stamina."
Opponents of smoking also contend that the apparel's brand identifications transform smokers, and sometimes youngsters below the legal smoking age, into walking billboards. Unlike actual billboards and other cigarette ads, the clothing need not carry health warnings.
"We get flak from the antismoking groups for anything we do," said Mr. Iauco, adding that parents who complained about Camel merchandise ordered by their children were asked to return it.
The promotions represent a more sophisticated version of previous marketing campaigns, known as continuity programs. In the earlier efforts, smokers could order merchandise similar to that carried by trading-stamp catalogues, rather than brand-related apparel. In 1932, Brown & Williamson introduced coupons on its Raleigh brand. Its catalogue, now in its 70th edition, according to a company spokesman, is on its way to outlasting the Sears, Roebuck catalogue.

HEADLINE: Study Sees Dip In Investment From Abroad

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Foreign investment in companies and real estate in New York City slowed substantially in the early 1990's, although not as sharply as the decline experienced throughout the country, a new study shows.
The study, conducted for the Dinkins administration, found that there were 75 transactions involving foreign companies in New York City in 1991, the lowest level since 1977. Throughout the 1980's, there were about 100 such deals each year. 
 However, the city, which has lagged behind other parts of the country in recovering from the recession, did manage to increase its share of the business in comparison to other regions around the nation, the study, which was done by James Orr, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, found.
 
'Fairly Well Positioned'
 About 10.4 percent of the deals or transactions involving foreign direct investment in the United States in 1991 were in New York City, up from 7.5 percent in 1988, the study said. Still that figure is below the 12.5 percent hit during the national boom in mergers and acquisitions in the mid-1980's.
"Even though the total is down, the city has slightly increased its share of the national number of foreign investment transactions in key sectors for the city," Mr. Orr said. "This suggests that foreign investors in these key sectors still consider it important to be in New York. Indeed, the city seems fairly well positioned to benefit when foreign investment in the United States recovers."
Recessions abroad and in the United States are undoubtedly a big reason for the slowdown in foreign investment in recent years.
But the city has done particularly well in the areas most important to its economy -- namely financial, insurance and real-estate services, business services and retail trade, Mr. Orr said in an interview yesterday.
 
'Pretty Trustworthy'
 To be sure, the share of total investment deals or transactions is a crude measure. A better gauge would be the city's share of the dollar value of total foreign investment in the country. Conceding that, Mr. Orr said reliable data on the value were not available. He defended the use of the transaction figure, saying it was "a pretty trustworthy indicator of how the city is faring."
A new study by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics also documented the importance of foreign investment to New York City. Relying on data from the fourth quarter of 1990, the bureau found that foreign-owned companies not only accounted for 208,544, or 7.2 percent, of the nongovernment jobs in the city but also paid higher wages than American companies do. "Foreign investment is a substantially more important source of jobs in Manhattan than in any central core of any major economic area of the country," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the bureau's regional Commissioner.
The studies were released as a city delegation of government, business and cultural leaders led by Mayor David N. Dinkins is preparing for a weeklong visit to Japan to promote New York. With his aides flashing business cards in Japanese and English and with Japanese dignitaries looking on, Mr. Dinkins yesterday announced the details of the Feb. 20-27 visit.
A main purpose of Mr. Orr's study was to help city officials to pinpoint the countries and companies most likely to invest in New York. And Mr. Dinkins cited it in discussing the importance of the trip. In terms of the number of transactions, the Japanese were the largest source of such investment in the second half of the 1980's and in the early 1990's.
 
No Quick Payoff
 The Mayor said that while he hoped that the trip to Tokyo, Osaka and Kyoto would ultimately result in more Japanese investment and tourism, he did not expect a quick payoff. "No, I don't expect to come back with deals," he said.
With the Japanese economy in a slump and Japanese companies retrenching, one New York business leader at the City Hall news conference conceded that one goal of the trip was to insure that such companies did not abandon New York. "You want to make it clear that New York is not the one to pull out of," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry.
Mr. Dinkins and business leaders went to Europe last spring to pay courtesy calls on companies with operations in New York City and to woo others, especially medium-sized concerns, interested in establishing or expanding operations in the United States.
It typically takes many months, if not years, for foreign companies to pick locations in the United States and to negotiate deals. And a weak European economy has undoubtedly caused companies to put expansion plans on hold. The Mayor said yesterday that the trip had not yet produced tangible results, but he seemed hopeful that deals might soon be struck.
 
'Serious Negotiations'
 Mr. Shelp said contacts with 280 mostly medium-size European companies had resulted in "serious negotiations" with 26 companies in industries like software, retailing, tourism and food processing. Some were arranging visits to inspect possible sites for operations in New York, he said.
In December, Mr. Dinkins unveiled a long-range economic "vision" for strengthening the city's economy that was billed as a mold for forming new policies. The need for strengthening the city's position as a leading international business center figured prominently in the vision.
In an interview, Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said the the Dinkins administration intended shortly to step up "in a major way" programs aimed at cultivating closer relationships with foreign companies, business organizations and consulates in New York.
 
Biggest Share
 Of the 1,582 foreign direct investments in the city from 1974 through 1991, Britain had the biggest share, with 23 percent, followed by Japan with 18 percent, Canada and France with 9 percent each, Germany with 7 percent, Italy with 4 percent and the Netherlands and Switzerland with 3 percent each.
Of the transactions, 24.7 percent were in manufacturing, including publishing companies; 22.8 percent in wholesale and retail trade; 19.9 percent in finance, insurance and real estate services; 13.3 percent in other services, like advertising, and 10.6 percent in property.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics found that foreign-owned businesses employed 501,451 in the 26 counties in the metropolitan region, which was a larger portion of private-sector jobs than in the country as a whole -- 6.9 percent versus 5.2 percent. Foreign-owned companies also paid their employees 24 percent, or $684, more per month, than the average for all companies in the region.
Manhattan boasts the region's largest concentration of employment by foreign-owned companies, with 177,296 employees, or 35.4 percent of the regional total. Those accounted for 9.6 percent of Manhattan's private-sector jobs.
Other counties that had concentrations of 20,000 or more employees of foreign-owned companies included Nassau and Westchester in New York; Bergen, Essex and Middlesex in New Jersey, and Fairfield in Connecticut.

HEADLINE: Roosevelt Raceway Fraud Case Is Sent Back to Federal Court

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 9

 BODY:
After almost six years of controversy, a Federal court will hear claims that the owners of Roosevelt Raceway engaged in fraud when they obtained $54 million in tax-free development bonds to buy the property.
The owners had promised to continue operating the track, but within four years, they shut it down and put the property on the market for development. 
 Horse owners, horse trainers and track employees had accused the track owners of fraud and deception, and their case had been rejected by the Federal District Court. But a three-judge panel of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in Manhattan ruled late Monday that the track employees had a right to present evidence to support their claim under the Rackeeter Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act known as RICO.
The decision, written by Judge Ellsworth A. Van Graafeiland, sent the matter back to the Federal District Court.
The more than 3,000 horse owners, grooms, blacksmiths, parimutuel clerks and other racetrack employees affected by the raceway's closing are seeking $50 million in damages, which would be tripled under the Federal RICO statute, should the owners be found guilty of conspiracy to defraud the workers.
 
'Our Day in Court'
 Bernard Persky, the lawyer for the workers, described the decision, which was made public today, as "a major victory."
"We can now have our day in court," he said. According to court papers, the workers contend that the defendants are "guilty of a colossal fraud -- that they never intended to continue the track in operation, but planned instead to use the property for much more lucrative purposes."
But Anton J. Borovina, the lawyer for the owners, Roosevelt Raceway Associates, described the ruling as "narrow in scope."
"They still have the obligation to establish their claim." he said. "All of the agreements made by the owners were done so in public, so how can anyone claim they were deceived?"
The principal owners named in the suit are Charles L. Evans, William B. Hopkins, Barry B. Goldstein and David A. Stevenson.
They purchased the track in 1984 with $54 million in tax-free bonds issued by the Town of Hempstead Industrial Development Agency. At the time, the owners said they had no intention of closing the track and selling it to developers.
But citing hard times, the owners closed the track in 1988. The recession prevented a quick sale of the site, and the parcel -- the largest tract of undeveloped commercial property in Nassau County -- became a white elephant and a political embarrassment to Hempstead's Republican leadership when questions were raised by track employees about the issuance of the tax-free bonds.
 
New Plans for Site
 An inquiry by the State Investigation Commission released in December 1991 cleared the track's owners of criminal wrongdoing, but said that Hempstead did not adequately investigate the raceway purchase before issuing the bonds.
The state inquiry also cleared Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican and former Hempstead Presiding Supervisor, of charges that he improperly tried to seek Federal tax exemptions for the raceway.
Last year, Hempstead lifted a moratorium on development of the site, approved new zoning requirements and spurred commercial construction as a means to stimulate Long Island's economy.
The Hempstead Town Board then approved plans for a major retail development by Wal-Mart and Sam's Club. Together they will employ 1,000 construction workers and create 650 permanent jobs once completed.
 
Rezoned for Mixed Use
 Construction is now under way, and officials do not expect the court ruling to interrupt plans for the 162-acre site, according to Anthony J. Santino, a spokesman for the town.
"This is a matter between the track owners and the former employees of the raceway, and has nothing to do with the town, so we have no comment," Mr. Santino said.
The arrival of Wal-Mart and Sam's Club will complete the first step in the redevelopment of the raceway site, which was rezoned for mixed use, including 555 housing units, a 10-screen movie theater, an office complex and hotel and conference center. Down the street to the west is Roosevelt Field, one of the largest shopping malls in the New York area. To the north is Fortunoff's and the newly built Price Club Plaza.
Mr. Persky said the suit by the raceway's former employees included an option to seek an end to the new construction at the raceway, but he declined to say whether he planned to pursue such a course in court.

HEADLINE: Florio, a Budget Proposal And an Election Platform

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
In a year in which both he and all 120 members of the State Legislature face re-election, Gov. Jim Florio used much of his annual budget address today to trumpet the successes of his first term in office and to set the platform on which he is expected to seek a second term.
Leading politicians agreed that it was definitely an election-year presentation, although they disagreed about whether that was good or bad. Mr. Florio's speech and his budget won cautious praise from the Republicans who control the Legislature, which must approve the spending plan, though it came under immediate attack from two candidates for the Republican nomination for governor -- Christine Todd Whitman and Cary Edwards. 
 More surprisingly, the budget was criticized by the State Senate minority leader, John A. Lynch, the second most powerful elected Democrat in state government, after Governor Florio. Mr. Lynch's attack today was driven by anger that the proposed budget did not fully restore the homestead rebate program that gives tax refunds to some homeowners and renters. The program was cut in half, to $350 million, last year.
 
'Fiscal Gimmicks'
 "It's clearly an election-year budget -- high on promises but low on problem-solving," Mr. Lynch said in a statement that was distributed to reporters as Mr. Florio delivered his speech. "A budget backed by $4 billion in fiscal gimmicks and $412 million in Medicaid reimbursements should have enough money in it to restore the homestead rebate program to what it was before the Republicans cut it last year."
The proposed budget that Mr. Florio released on Monday for the 1994 fiscal year is a $15.6 billion spending plan shaped largely by political deal-making -- from collaboration with the Republican legislative leaders on major spending to the last-minute infusion of $412 million in Medicaid reimbursements with the help of President Clinton.
Today, Mr. Florio went before a joint session of the Republican-controlled Legislature to outline his broad budget goals: guaranteed health-care coverage for all New Jersey residents, tougher law-enforcement programs, a program to train youths for high-tech jobs.
 
Awkward Position
 With the coalition of Mr. Florio and the Republican legislative leadership seemingly in accord on the budget, it left the Republican gubernatorial candidates and Mr. Lynch, the Senate Democratic leader, in the awkward position of hitting their own party members with the political arrows intended for their traditional enemies, and it left the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican, in the even odder position of defending Mr. Florio.
"Governor Florio's budget is great electioneering but lousy economics," said Mrs. Whitman, who held an impromptu news conference in one corner of the State House corridor as Mr. Edwards held a competing news conference several yards away.
But Mr. DiFrancesco said, "This is a good election-year budget," adding that the Republican legislative leaders had agreed on 85 to 90 percent of the budget, including spending on education, health and jobs creation.
 
'Months of Discussions'
 In his speech, Mr. Florio said: "No one wants to see a repeat of the budget hell of last year. This budget I submit today is based on months of discussions I've had with the leaders of this distinguished body."
Mr. Florio, in the final year of his first four-year term in office, has yet to announce for re-election, but much of his speech today had the ring of a politician on the stump.
"You know, when I was a kid growing up in Brooklyn, my Uncle Tom Florio got me one of my first jobs -- shoveling up after the horses at a stable in Prospect Park," Mr. Florio said. "At that time, I thought I was lucky to have a little pocket money. I never imagined it would be such a good apprenticeship for being Governor."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weaker Against Yen On Expected Trade Pressure

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the yen yesterday on speculation that leading Western countries may exert pressure on Tokyo to push up the Japanese currency.
Gold prices rose 50 cents an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York to settle at $328.90 for current delivery. A late quote from the Republic National Bank said spot delivery settled at $328.55, up 40 cents from Monday. 
 The Japanese Finance Minister, Yoshiro Hayashi, is scheduled to meet Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen on Saturday to address worsening trade tensions between the United States and Japan, prompting speculation that a yen appreciation could be offered as a quick cure.
 
Effect of a Higher Yen
 A higher yen could make Japanese goods more expensive in the United States, curbing imports, and lower the cost of American goods for Japanese consumers, encouraging exports and helping address the trade imbalance. In 1992, Japan's trade surplus with the United States grew 14.3 percent, to $43.67 billion.
David Rolley, an international economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, said that currency traders were gambling that the Clinton Administration would be more confrontational on trade issues. But he doubted that much would come out of Saturday's meeting.
Besides the speculative binge, Mr. Rolley said, the yen's strength stems from increased capital flow into Japanese assets.
In Tokyo, the dollar ended at 122.35 yen, down from 124.73 yen Monday. Later in London, it eased to 124.18 yen, from 124.28 yen Monday. In New York, the dollar slipped to 121.28 yen, from 123.73 yen late Monday.
The dollar fell to 1.6513 marks late yesterday in New York from 1.6573 late Monday. Earlier in London, the dollar traded at 1.6525 marks, down from 1.6553 marks Monday.
The British pound was at $1.4315 in late New York trading, down from about $1.4375 Monday. In London, the pound finished at $1.4305.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Monday quotes, included: 1.5285 Swiss francs, down from 1.5365; 5.5955 French francs, down from 5.6075; 1.2670 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2631, and 1,528 lire, barely changed from Monday's 1,527.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Carter Hawley Hale Selects Storehouse's Top Executive

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said today that David L. Dworkin, a veteran retail executive, would become president and chief executive of the department store chain, effective April 1.
Mr. Dworkin, who is now chairman and chief executive of Storehouse P.L.C., a London-based retailer, will succeed Philip M. Hawley, who has said he plans to retire. 
 The 49-year-old Mr. Dworkin faces considerable challenges in taking charge of Carter Hawley Hale, the largest retail chain in the West, which emerged from bankruptcy protection in October.
 
Struggle with Debt
 Carter Hawley expanded rapidly into nine regional chains throughout the 1970's and 80's, but it took on considerable debt to fight off a takeover bid from the Limited Inc. The debt burden forced the company to sell some specialty chains and eventually to file for protection from its creditors.
While Carter Hawley has substantially reduced its overhead costs, mainly through a debt-for-equity swap with the Zell/Chilmark Fund of Chicago, the Los Angeles-based retailer must still find ways to attract new customers amid a stubborn regional recession.
Carter Hawley Hale operates 83 department stores, including the Broadway, Weinstock's, Emporium and Broadway Southwest, which had sales of $2.1 billion last year. Retailing analysts have said that Carter must begin broadening its customer base, stocking more fashionable goods and upgrading aging stores.
 
Interested Party
 To accomplish this, however, the company may have to consolidate some operations or seek additional cash from Zell/Chilmark, its largest creditor and shareholder, the analysts said. Zell/Chilmark bought 80 percent of Carter Hawley's $600 million in unsecured debt last year in return for 75 percent control of the company's common stock.
Sam Zell, the Chicago investor who heads the fund, said in a statement today that Mr. Dworkin was "a proven star in the retailing industry," citing his recent turnaround of Storehouse P.L.C.
Before joining Storehouse in 1989 as chairman and chief executive of its British Home Stores division, Mr. Dworkin served as president of Bonwit Teller in New York and as president of the Neiman Marcus Company in Dallas, a Carter Hawley division. Mr. Dworkin has been executive vice president of Marshall Field & Company in Chicago and senior vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue in New York.
 
Experiments Set
 In a telephone interview from his home in London, Mr. Dworkin said that after conducting a comprehensive study of Carter Hawley's operations, he would begin testing a variety of ideas to turn the stores around.
"We need to develop a strong market plan so that we start buying the product that best represents the customer base, and I don't think that has been done for some time," Mr. Dworkin said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David L. Dworkin, who is to become chief executive of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. April 1.

HEADLINE: Modest Decline Continues In Yields Offered by Banks

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Yields to be offered at banks on money market accounts and certificates of deposit in the week beginning today suggest a continuing modest decline.
In the New York market, average six-month certificate yields are lower than at 20 major banks across the country, while money market yields are about the same everywhere.
According to the latest survey by The Bank Rate Monitor, yields on money market accounts in the New York area are down an average of a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 2.66 percent. Analysts note that the slide in money market account yields is now nearly two months old.
 
Mixed Moves on C.D.'s
 The average New York rate for three-month certificates of deposit dropped a basis point, to 2.76 percent, while the average yield on six-month certificates rose a basis point, to 2.96 percent. 
 New York banks posting the sharpest changes this week included EAB, which dropped 10 basis points off its money market account, to 2.48 percent. Chase Manhattan took 21 basis points off its three-month C.D., leaving it at 2.63 percent. Anchor Savings, however, raised the rate on its six-month C.D. by 55 basis points, to 3.60 percent.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks were largely unchanged, with the average money market account off a basis point, to 2.63 percent. Six-month C.D.'s were unchanged at 2.99 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, average discount rates declined further, to their lowest levels of the last six weeks. The auction is regarded by many as a harbinger of rate changes that banks might make.
The average rate at auction yesterday was 2.94 percent for a three-month Treasury bill, down 3 basis points, and 3.09 percent for a six-month bill, down a basis point.
Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, said the continued downward drift in savings yields indicated that loan demand remained weak despite recent positive economic signals.
"Banks simply do not have to replace those funds by bidding up deposit rates," he said. "Moreover, last week's easing in interest rates by Japan and Germany could help set the stage for further easing by the Federal Reserve, if that becomes part of President Clinton's recovery scenario."

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Asking the Questions

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is sick to death of it. The President ran on the economy, but all anyone wants to talk about these days is who's taking care of the kids of the candidates for attorney general.
So it seems fitting to take a break from the witch hunts surrounding who paid what when to the sitter to discuss a pressing economic issue. 
 Child care.
The United States needs a national child care system for all families, from the poor to the well-to-do. If the withdrawal of two talented women lawyers from consideration for service in the Clinton Administration because of baby-sitter stuff ends in a welter of class wars and gender hostilities, we will have missed an opportunity to begin a process that should have started two decades ago.
By 1995, two-thirds of the women with preschool children are expected to be working outside their homes. Yet child care has never been a major political issue. And the most depressing thing about the debate these last few weeks has been the defeatism of the dialogue: I have to make do with inconvenient, expensive, even unsafe child care arrangements -- why shouldn't you?
Last week the President talked about wanting to immunize all American children. If we had a system of early childhood care, well-baby programs would be an obvious part of that care. Last week the President talked about wanting to get people off welfare. Women on welfare will tell you one of the greatest impediments to getting off is child care and its cost. "It's the biggest problem in our lives," one mother of three said of herself and her friends.
At the York Street Project in Jersey City, which offers high school classes to women who have dropped out and housing to those who are homeless, the nuns who run the place say it took them only a year to realize that child care would be the linchpin of their efforts, that women couldn't show up for classes or make it to work if they didn't have a safe and stable place to leave their kids.
Our late entry into the world of child care policy gives us plenty of other national programs to consider. In France, nearly all children between the ages of 3 and 5 attend free preprimary schools. A third of all younger children are cared for in licensed and monitored family day-care homes or day-care centers.
In the United States women frequently set up family day care in their own homes with no training or licensing. The Government family day-care system in France includes local hub offices that provide equipment, activities and oversight and a nurse-director who hires and trains providers and matches them with children. Parents pay on a sliding scale based on income.
The system is so good that a group of American experts studied French facilities in 1989. One of them was Hillary Rodham Clinton, then chair of the Children's Defense Fund, now the obvious person to spearhead child care policy. Ms. Clinton is already working on health care, but maybe it's time to start thinking of child care as a subset of health care, providing for the physical, mental and emotional health of many of America's children.
We know what we don't want: We don't want a big government child care monolith. We need a range of options, from corporate centers and benefit packages to family day care and government subsidies. We need community centers and community information banks about sitters.
Where's the money to come from? people will ask. But a better question is where the money's now going. Businesses are losing billions of dollars every year in lost employee time because of child care problems. Government is paying billions in public assistance to women who say a major impediment to going back to work is finding child care they can afford.
And the biggest little cash economy in America turns out to be baby-sitting, not just for briefcase moms with immigrant sitters but for family day-care providers who don't report their income and for women on welfare who supplement their checks with baby-sitting money.
But this is more than an economic issue. America pays lip service to liking kids, but you can't prove it by how they're treated or the priority given their care. It may take some time to find answers for us on this issue. But it's time, past time, that we started asking the questions.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
