HEADLINE: Less Is Key to an Insurer's Success

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me.

 BODY:
As many insurance companies fret over the prospect of losing their health business under health-care reform, one quietly growing insurer here, the UNUM Corporation, seems destined to prosper if some widely expected proposals emerge from Hillary Clinton's office this spring.
For the last several years, UNUM has flourished as a result of its decision to abandon the traditional health-care insurance business and focus on add-on benefits. It is now the nation's leading group disability insurer and packages an array of benefits for employers that range from dental to group life to coverage for eyeglasses. 
 Now, as the Clinton Administration is considering tax changes that would encourage employers to provide only basic health coverage to workers, health economists expect the demand by individuals for these supplemental policies to grow rapidly.
 
 
Greater Danger
 What is more, disability insurance is a growth business. While most middle-class Americans are familiar with the need for life insurance coverage, it is only as the baby-boomer generation ages, with families dependent on two incomes, that consumers are realizing the greater danger of losing income from injury than from death.
As a result, UNUM's prospects, at least in the eyes of insurance analysts, are steeply on the rise. The company's stock is up more than 50 percent from a year ago.
[UNUM ended New York Stock Exchange trading Tuesday at $56, down $1.50. The company reported an earnings gain of 21 percent for 1992, to $248.8 million, on revenues of $2.6 billion.]
"The goal now for insurance carriers is to find niche opportunities," Mark Puccia, a director with the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said. "UNUM is the classic case of a company that has done that effectively."
In a move expected to help cash in on a growing demand for supplemental benefits, UNUM announced in December that it was merging with Colonial Life and Accident of Columbia, S.C., an insurer that specializes in accident, cancer and other life insurance products. Combined, analysts say, the companies could dominate the multibillion-dollar supplemental coverage field.
 Also in December, UNUM announced a deal under which the 8,300 life insurance agents of the Equitable Companies would sell only disability products designed by UNUM, a concession by the giant Equitable that it could not compete in that segment.
"When we go into a marketplace, we want to stake out a leadership position," James F. Orr 2d, UNUM's chairman and chief executive officer, said. "When it comes to health-care reform, I think we're one of the best-positioned companies in the business."
UNUM, with offices that peer down over the quaint docks and gray shoreline islands off Portland, was known as the Union Mutual Life Insurance Company here since before the Civil War and until 1986, when it became the first major insurer to de-mutualize. Until then, UNUM was a modest regional insurer that rarely attracted attention as a company with major national or international growth prospects.
But since 1986, when it changed its name to the Latin word for the numeral one, the company has blossomed. Earnings have risen to $16 billion from $10 billion and its return on equity has risen to 16 percent, from 7 percent, far exceeding the industry average. Compared with 1980, when the company had assets of $2.3 billion and 1,872 employees, UNUM has become a behemoth by Maine standards, with assets of $11 billion and 5,725 employees.
 
 
What Not to Be
 At the heart of the company's success, analysts and corporate executives agree, was UNUM's decision of what not to be.
In 1987, it decided to leave the medical insurance business despite growth of the health-care sector because of the growing dominance of the majors. Today, many health economists say there will be no room for the kind of midsize health insurer that UNUM used to be. Under managed competition, they predict, the health insurance industry will be increasingly governed by giants such as Prudential, Cigna and Blue Shield-Blue Cross organizations that have the money and the experience to compete widely on the basis of price. Between 1982 and 1990 UNUM also abandoned other meat and potatoes of the life insurance business: individual life insurance, general investment contracts, individual annuities and pensions.
What was left was a disability business backed up by a huge data base on the disability risks of Americans that is unmatched by any other company. Elaine D. Rosen, the senior vice president for employee benefits and disability division, said the company's actuarial data, gathered over several decades, allowed it to classify long-term disability customers into more than 200 separate categories by factors such as industry, geography and occupation.
 
 
Potential Market
 Unlike life insurance or the crisis-ridden fields of automobile or health insurance, experts see disability insurance as an area of strong growth for years to come. Margaret M. Alexandre, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said the potential market for disability insurance of 117 million Americans was only 36 percent penetrated, largely because most consumers were just realizing the need for disability policies. Ms. Alexandre estimates the business will grow 5 to 8 percent over the next five years. UNUM, which has about 25 percent of the group long-term disability market, now between $2.5 and $3 billion in premiums, expects to see its market share grow 1 percent for each of the next five years as the market expands.
In addition, UNUM, like a number of other companies, offers group dental, life and retirement savings plans and designs so-called cafeteria packages of medical benefits that supplement major medical coverage. With UNUM's help, an employer is able to offer its workers a wide choice of benefits, depending on the employee's needs and how much either the company or the worker is willing to pay. Offering those kinds of choices may be crucial if Washington this year adopts at least part of the model of health-care reform known as managed competition, which would attempt to hold down medical costs by giving consumers, rather than employers, more choice of which types of health insurance they buy.
"Because UNUM sells a full line of health and specialty products, if employees suddenly find themselves with minimum-level coverage, they will begin to shop for others," said Ms. Alexandre of Salomon Brothers, who predicts 13 to 15 percent growth in earnings for UNUM for each of the next five years.
"UNUM," she adds, "has just the product line to deal with that new market."
 
 
Company in Transition
 Nonetheless, in a visit to the company's headquarters, UNUM at times still seemed in the midst of its transition from a modest New England employer to a savvy international corporation. Ward Graffam, president and managing director for European operations, said he had never been on a plane to Europe before he got his job three years ago. A company spokeswoman half jokingly referred to insurance benefits that are only available from companies outside of Maine as insurance "from away."
And with declining interest rates, the company may face pressure to raise prices to make up for lower investment income. That could make UNUM's products less competitive and cost it market share. Also, claims for new diseases that do not have much of an actuarial history, such as Epstein-Barr syndrome, carpal tunnel syndrome and AIDS, could dim the company's long-term growth plans.
But Mr. Orr boasts about UNUM's prospects. The company has successfully acquired disability insurers in Canada and Britain, has opened an office in Tokyo, and sees opportunities to build embryonic long-term disability markets in Europe and Asia. One particular target will be multinational corporations that will want to buy benefits from one company for operations in many nations across Europe.
The company says its data base will also help a major expansion into long-term care insurance, a product that demographers say has great promise as baby boomers face old age. Although it is still unclear how well the insurance industry can estimate the proper premium to cover the cost of long-term disabilities decades from now, UNUM says its experience in predicting illnesses will give it an advantage.
The company began selling long-term care policies in retirement communities in 1987. From the data gathered from elderly customers there, says David Hughes, senior vice president for long-term care, UNUM is finding the risk predictable, insurable and profitable. The company now has 10,000 long-term-care customers and hopes that the $15 million business will eventually match its group disability line, which earns more than $750 million in premiums annually. Although not profitable yet, executives say long-term-care insurance will help the company reach its goal of 18 percent return on equity by 1998.
"I wouldn't bet against that goal," said an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein. "UNUM is a very well-positioned company."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 13, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the growth of the UNUM Corporation misstated the rise in the company's earnings since 1986. They have risen to $248.8 million from $112 million.

HEADLINE: Russia's Gay Men Step Out of Soviet-Era Shadows

BYLINE: By JILL J. BARSHAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 9

 BODY:
After decades of enduring persecution and intimidation in the old Soviet Union, homosexuals in Russia are emerging into the open for the first time, even though they say they continue to feel mistreated and threatened by hostile public attitudes and by old laws that remain on the books.
Today, gay groups are officially registered and gay newspapers are published under municipal government laws. In addition, a handful of homosexuals organized a demonstration in front of the United States Embassy at the time of President Clinton's inauguration last month. 
 The few homosexual activists are largely ignored by the mainstream, however, and gay newspapers are only circulated privately.
There is also no organized movement among homosexuals or their supporters to demand that laws banning homosexuality be repealed, but a few officials say there is a chance that the laws can be quietly eliminated.
While hoping and in some cases pressing for legal changes, homosexual groups say that their problem is less with the law than with social attitudes and ignorance.
 
'Russian Walls Are Thin'
 "I'm more afraid that my friends and family will find out than the law," said a successful businessman who is 28 years old. "Your socio-economic stature can protect you from the authorities. It is unfair, but true, that most of the gays in prison are from the lower classes."
He lives alone in a comfortable, one-bedroom apartment. But even at home, he keeps up his guard, asking to speak quietly during an interview.
"Russian walls are very thin," he said. "If my neighbors knew I was gay, they would look at me differently and use it against me."
Under Article 121 of the criminal code, a holdover from the Soviet era, "sexual relations between men are punishable by prison terms of up to five years." Lesbian sexual relations are not mentioned and thus legal. The Government sentenced 10 people to prison for homosexual relations in the first half of 1992.
 
Quiet Pressure for Change
 Among those seeking to change the law are a few people in the Government, although they apparently have taken no overt action on the matter.
"Homosexuals are in a quasi-legal situation," said Sergei B. Romazin, head of judicial reform at the Justice Ministry. "My personal opinion is that we need to change this situation immediately. Article 121 should be repealed, except when rape is involved."
In the fall, a proposed new criminal code omitted the language on the "crime of homosexuality," but it is considered possible that it could be reinstated.
 
Ukraine Law Repealed
 The Ministry of Justice could not provide reliable statistics on the present number of prisoners convicted for homosexuality, but Mr. Romazin said he would "release those in prison immediately as soon as the law is changed."
There is some precedent for removing the legal ban on homosexuality. The Parliament in Ukraine, the most populous state outside Russia in the Soviet Union, decriminalized homosexuality last year.
However, in order to get the old law off the books, a new law was enacted that requires compulsory testing for exposure to the AIDS virus for prostitutes, drug addicts, foreigners, and other "high-risk" groups. Because homosexuals could be included, many say this new law allows some of the old sanctions to remain in effect.
 
Endemic Homophobia
 Homophobia is strong throughout Russia, especially in the provinces. A 31-year-old journalist at an independent newspaper in Kazan, Tatarstan, said that in his home province "very few people know I'm gay."
"Tatars are not Americans," he added. "They wouldn't understand.
Russian society has a long history of official discrimination. A 1964 Soviet sex manual instructs, for example: "With all the tricks at their disposal, homosexuals seek out and win the confidence of youngsters. Then they proceed to act. Do not under any circumstances allow them to touch you. Such people should be immediately reported to the administrative organs so that they can be removed from society."
During the Soviet period, the threat of Article 121 was employed by the K.G.B. to end careers, destroy reputations, or blackmail artists and writers into staying within the bounds of the party line.
Sergei Paradzhanov, one of the Soviet Union's greatest directors and a homosexual, was arrested under Article 121 in 1974 and sentenced to five years in a labor camp. Colleagues believed that he was really paying the price for his controversial films.
 
Inflexible Attitudes
 Attitudes have not changed much since. In a 1991 public opinion poll conducted in Chelyabinsk, an industrial city in the Urals, 30 percent of the respondents aged 16 to 30 years old felt that homosexuals should be "isolated from society," 5 percent felt they should be "liquidated," 60 percent had a "negative" attitude toward gay people and 5 percent labeled their sexual orientation "unfortunate."
One of the many abuses of the old regime was the "gay list." The police used to conduct "raids in places where gays met to do document checks," said Pavel Masalsky, a former prisoner convicted for homosexuality and no other crime.
From these checks, the Ministry of Internal Affairs compiled lists of suspected homosexuals. At trial, a name on this list was sufficient proof of guilt. Even today proof of actual sexual relations is not required.
Mr. Masalsky, 29, an electrical technician, was a victim of the "gay list" as well as what he said was the medical profession's ignorance. He was sentenced in 1984 to three years -- an average term -- after a friend betrayed him to the authorities.
 
'A Nightmare to Remember'
 After the arrest, he said, "I was first subjected to a physical during which the doctor concluded I was gay. The main evidence against me at the trial was the Ministry of Internal Affairs' 'gay list'. It's a nightmare to remember it all."
In the army, which until recently was obligatory for all young men, gay troops face consequences ranging from physical harassment by fellow recruits to court martial.
Public tolerance and visibility are improving, however, slowly undercutting the stigma of homosexuality. In the past, homosexuals were forced to hide out in underground clubs and public bath houses. The more adventurous would stroll about the well-known fountain in front of the Bolshoi Theater. Now there are more respectable places for gay men, particularly in Moscow and St. Petersburg.
 
A Moveable Disco
 An openly gay discotheque, financed by American gay businessmen, floats around Moscow every weekend. Sometimes it is moved across town at the last minute to avoid harassment from anti-gay thugs, known as "repairmen" in Russian slang.
Kevin Gardner, an American who is head of the Moscow chapter of the United States-based International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission, said that there are hundreds of gay organizations throughout Russia.
In Moscow, there are a half dozen officially registered gay publications such as Impulse and Risk, which cover topics from homosexual life abroad to AIDS issues. In St. Petersburg, the gay organizations Krylia (wings) and the Tchaikovsky Foundation (Tchaikovsky was homosexual) are registered with the city government. Even in Russia's industrial heartland in the Ural Mountains, an organization called Rights of Sexual Minorities has existed for years.
"These groups don't have an organized political agenda," said Mr. Gardner. "A few activists have made appeals to repeal Article 121, but many are afraid to come out politically until Article 121 is repealed." Many gay organizations, trying to circumvent the legal prohibition, publicly emphasize AIDS awareness over gay rights as a more acceptable agenda.
Homosexuals say they fear that attitudes in Russia are so deeply ingrained that they will probably never enjoy the freedoms found in the United States. One of the Russian businessmen interviewed, for example, dreams of creating a male family with an adopted child but acknowledges that it could probably never happen.
"The law would forbid the adoption and society is not ready to accept a permanent gay relationship," he said. "There is no gay district in Moscow where gays can openly live like Castro Street in San Francisco. Even if the law were repealed, my life wouldn't really change for the better."

Gay couples danced at a closed party last month at a club in Moscow. Such gatherings are held sporadically and are unpublicized. (Gleb Kosorukov for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S TOWN MEETING;
CLINTON LAYS BASE FOR NEW SACRIFICE TO BOOST ECONOMY

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
Laying the groundwork for the economic proposals he will offer next week, President Clinton returned last night to the talk-show format he used during the fall campaign and tried to prepare the nation for higher taxes and painful budget cuts.
Mr. Clinton sought to use the televised "town meeting" broadcast from Southfield in suburban Detroit to persuade Americans that he was not being diverted by the issues that dominated the first two weeks of his Administration: whether to allow homosexuals in the military and the ill-fated search for an Attorney General. Instead, he emphasized that he was working on almost nothing but the economic plan he will introduce Wednesday. 
 Mr. Clinton vowed that the overall package would be "fair to all Americans." But in reply to a woman who tartly reminded him that she had voted for him in part because he said he would reduce taxes on middle-class people like her, Mr. Clinton said, "I wish I could promise you I won't ask you to pay any more."
 
Spreading the Pain
 But he did not do that. "I cannot tell you that I won't ask you to make any contribution to the changes we have to make," Mr. Clinton added. [Excerpts, page A26.]
The President vowed to try to ease the pain, though, by making clear that he would spread it around, announcing for the first time that he would seek to raise the tax rate on corporate incomes. The rate is now 34 percent, and officials have suggested that Mr. Clinton might want to increase it to 36 percent.
At the opening of the one-hour show, broadcast over Cable News Network and C-Span and on 17 local channels around the country, Mr. Clinton said he could already see "after only three weeks how easy it is to get out of touch, to get caught up in the trappings of Washington."
 
Variety of Tough Questions
 He promised he was "going to try to stay in touch with you this whole four years so you can tell me what you think."
And the audience in Southfield, along with satellite-linked groups in Atlanta, Miami and Seattle, did. If Mr. Clinton thought that by venturing out of Washington into the heartland he would be able to stick to economy and health care, he was wrong.
He was peppered with tough questions on the very subjects he has sought to avoid from reporters in Washington: homosexuals in the military, broken campaign promises, American policy in the Balkans and the reversal of his position on Haitian emigres. In addition there were very local questions, like what to do about hurricane-damaged Homestead Air Force Base in Florida, aircraft-plant layoffs in Washington State and tainted hamburger meat.
But the President fielded each question with the same sort of flowing, cogent answers that he achieved in similar events during the campaign. It was, all in all, trademark Clinton style: switching seamlessly from technocratic policy explanations to folksy homilies to make his points. Health-insurance regulations, he said, "were a blizzard of rules that could choke a horse."
Prowling the television soundstage with a cordless microphone, Mr. Clinton treated each exchange as if it were the sort of impromptu, intimate conversation that two friends might have over a kitchen table.
Later in the evening, Vice President Al Gore had his own question-and-answer session at a high school auditorium in Ontario, Calif., where he told the audience of 300 people and cable television viewers that the Administration was preparing to take strong measures to get the economy moving.
Referring to Congressional Republicans, he said, "they don't want any economic stimulus program because they think everything is just great as it is. Well, you know what, ladies and gentlemen, they haven't been to California lately."
Praising the decision to cut White House perks and staffing, Mr. Gore noted that a once-exclusive dining hall had been converted to a cafeteria for all workers. "Our new Secretary of Labor said he had already gotten some great ideas from people in the cafeteria line," he said.
 
Emphasis on the Economy
 In Mr. Clinton's forum, the questioners seemed to be right on top of the news, with one woman even asking the President in a particularly pointed manner how he could justify announcing a peace initiative for Bosnia yesterday that in effect amounted to negotiating with "war criminals."
Everytime he could, Mr. Clinton made the economy his subject of choice, and he also took the opportunity to fashion his expected defense for a retreat from the campaign assurances that he would not add to the financial burdens of the middle class.
"There's been some bad news," he said in his opening statement. "With all these economic improvements, we aren't generating new jobs, and the deficit of this country is about $50 billion a year bigger than I was told it was going to be before the election.
"So we have to put together a plan that keeps my commitment to you, invests in you and your jobs, in your education, your health care, your future, that brings that debt down, that deals with the health-care crisis, and that does it in a way that's fair to all Americans."
Seeking to put as much pressure on Congress as he can before introducing his proposals for higher taxes, lower spending and job growth, the President urged listeners to "tell your Senators and Congressmen whether I am right or wrong" after they hear his ideas on Wednesday in a speech to a joint session of Congress.
Despite some appearances to the contrary, Mr. Clinton said, he has been working "almost exclusively" on his economic program since his election.
White House officials said the stations screened potential audience members to make sure there was a balance of different questions and perspectives, but they insisted that none of the questions were screened. Questions were asked round-robin from city to city, with local newscasters serving as moderators.
 
Echoes of Perot
 The questions were as focused, and diverse, as any White House news conference. Some came from former Ross Perot volunteers or echoed Perot voters' concerns with the budget deficit and cleaning up Washington.
Mr. Clinton told a questioner who said she had been a campaign worker for Mr. Perot and wanted to know why the President did not support a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget: "It's basically a gimmick."
He added that to force the Government to eliminate the deficit quickly would cause unemployment to rise.
"The important thing is not to balance the budget overnight but put it on a steady path," Mr. Clinton said, citing the example of Japan, which he said managed to eliminate a budget deficit over 10 years.
"We have to do two things at once," he said. "We've got to increase investment in jobs and reduce the deficit."
 
Poignant, Personal Questions
 Some questions grew out of the experiences of members of the audience. A Haitian-American woman asked why Mr. Clinton was backtracking on his promise to allow more Haitian refugees into the country, and a young girl asked how the President could help her avoid the temptations of drug peddlers.
One of the more poignant moments came when Mr. Clinton was gently questioned about crime by a man whose son had been killed for a leather jacket. "I wish I knew how to have an immediate impact," the President replied.
He repeated his support for legislation in Congress that, he said, would put more police officers on the streets of urban areas and impose a waiting period for those seeking to buy handguns. Mr. Clinton described violence among the young as "maybe the biggest problem we've got today in terms of their future and the future of the cities."
A questioner from Seattle, Vicki Detwiler, related a double-dose of woe. She told of her 16-month-old son who is in a hospital's critical-care unit, one of the scores of people in the Northwest with food poisoning from a fast-food restaurant. Her husband, at her side, lost his job two days before their son was stricken, she said, and that deprived them of their health insurance.
What would Mr. Clinton do, Mrs. Detwiler asked, to insure "that no one else has to go through what we have gone through?"
The President, who earlier in the day had spoken with two sets of parents of other food-poisoning victims, noted that he had assigned his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, to devise a health-care plan in the next 100 days.
"If we don't do well on this, we'll never balance the budget or restore the health to the economy," he said. "It's a terrific human issue, but it's a big economic issue for America."
 
'Appalled' Over Gay Debate
 Mr. Clinton said he shared the frustration of many voters who felt it was a mistake for Washington to spend much of his first week in office debating whether homosexuals should be allowed in the military. He blamed Republican Senators for the attention given to the issue, saying they were trying to score partisan political points.
"I was frankly appalled that we spent so much time in the first week on that rather than getting the economy going again," he said. "I tried to put off the gays in the military issue for six months."
Mr. Clinton insisted that he personally "spent very little time on it."
Still, he seemed ready, even eager, to address the issue.
Arguing that homosexuals had always served in the military, he said the only real issue was whether they should be free to state their sexual orientation openly. "Your Government spent $500 million to get rid of 16,300 homosexuals in the military," he said. "The issue is, should you be able to say what you are and not get kicked out?"
The President also had to defend his handling of the search for an Attorney General. He said that his last candidate to withdraw, Judge Kimba M. Wood, did not withdraw because she had done anything illegal but because "she knew the person providing the child care was doing something illegal."
Mr. Clinton said the issue was ultimately whether an Attorney General, who oversees the Immigration and Naturalization Service, should meet a higher standard.
 
Question on the Balkans
 Questioners did not ignore foreign policy. Mr. Clinton was quizzed, for example, on his Balkans policy, which was announced earlier in the day. He defended the plan to get involved in negotiations over the republics of the former Yugoslavia and to pledge American forces to help enforce a peace settlement. But the President assured listeners that he would commit American troops only as peacekeepers after a settlement there.
"We are not committing today to make war," he said.
Mr. Clinton said the United States' experience in the war in the Persian Gulf underscored the wisdom of working closely with the United Nations in such situations. He also argued that the United States simply had a moral obligation to become involved in Bosnia, saying that in the absence of such involvement, "the terrible principle of ethnic cleansing will be validated."
The President demonstrated his political deftness when a Miami-area resident opposed to the closing of Homestead Air Force Base asked about the base's fate. Mr. Clinton made no promises, saying he would go along with a commission that makes recommendations on closing bases.
But he called the Homestead base "an invaluable asset" and promised to find a nonmilitary use for it if it was closed.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S TOWN MEETING;
With a Cue From Larry, Phil and Franklin D.

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Presidents since Andrew Jackson have used whatever means they had to go over the heads of journalists and other intermediaries to speak directly to "the people," especially when beleaguered.
Bill Clinton did so to good effect during his campaign last year, and tonight he demonstrated his skills again in an electronic town meeting that owed much to Ross Perot, Larry King, Phil Donahue and the latest satellite technology. 
 He got more questions on subjects he would rather have avoided -- Haiti, Bosnia, homosexuals in the military and his difficulties in finding a successful candidate for Attorney General -- and fewer on subjects he wanted to emphasize -- jobs and the economy -- but he seemed thoroughly in command.
 
Themes of Campaign
 The President had to defend himself against an accusation that he was reneging on his promise not to raise taxes on the middle class, and he had to field a demand from Mr. Perot's campaign coordinator in Michigan that he back a balanced-budget amendment. But the exchanges sounded genuine, they showed him talking with voters, and they made for lively television.
Perhaps most important of all, Mr. Clinton found ample room to voice his concerns about sick people and people facing economic difficulties, echoing themes of 1992 that have been drowned out during the last few weeks.
Like Franklin D. Roosevelt's fireside chats during the New Deal and Lyndon B. Johnson's televised appeals during the Vietnam War, President Clinton's question-and-answer sessions are intended to build a constituency in the country at large for programs resisted by entrenched interests or a skeptical press corps in Washington.
Mr. Clinton mounted both direct and indirect attacks on the news media. He said that Kimba M. Wood, the Federal district judge from New York who withdrew her name from consideration for Attorney General, had been treated "quite unfairly," but blamed that largely on erroneous press reports suggesting that she was about to be nominated. Those reports were based in large part on disclosures from his own Administration.
He also deplored public attention to the homosexuality question, saying, "I spent very little time on the issue myself." It was he, nonetheless, who pledged in his campaign to do away with the military ban on gay men and lesbians and pressed forward on it in the first hours of his Presidency.
The President's appearance in a television studio in a Detroit suburb marked the start of a politically crucial effort to sell a package of tax increases and cuts in benefits to a nation notably resistant to sacrifice. Once again, as in 1992, Mr. Clinton beamed his message on unconventional channels.
 
Ducking a Question
 He said at the very end of the broadcast that he planned many such appearances, and he ducked a question about formal news conferences in the future. So far he has held none.
Journalists complain now, as they have before, that they are being circumvented. But in the long run Mr. Clinton is no more likely than his predecessors to completely avoid news conferences, with their more searching interrogation, and the professionals do not always ask the most revealing questions anyway.
Perhaps the question that most damaged George Bush last year, for example, was the one asked by a young woman in the audience during a debate in Richmond about the impact of the recession on his friends and acquaintances. The question put Mr. Bush on the defensive by making him look unfeeling in his reaction to economic privation. His response was the equivalent, in its way, of Michael S. Dukakis's seemingly passionless response to a newsman's question in 1988 about how he would react if his wife were raped and murdered.
Mr. Clinton, by exposing himself tonight to the questions of a carefully screened group of ordinary voters, apparently sought to turn the tables on those who have tormented him the most in recent days. The Administration made no secret of that; Jeff Eller, a White House spokesman, said members of the audience had been told, "The President would like to focus on jobs and the economy."
Angry callers to radio talk programs and to Capitol Hill offices have had a major impact on the opening phase of Mr. Clinton's Presidency, as have many commentators in Washington who have given him poor grades. Neither represents a true cross section of American opinion, as the White House argues with considerable force. Programs like tonight's give Mr. Clinton a forum that is considerably more deferential, if no more balanced.
As the President arrived in Detroit, he took a bit of poetic license. Glossing over all the other problems he has had to deal with in a jam-packed 21 days, he told the crowd that welcomed him that he had been "doing almost nothing but focusing on the economy."
 
On the Public's Mind
 The country will no doubt welcome a return to a discussion of the economy and jobs. Those were the issues that won the election for Mr. Clinton, and opinion surveys suggest that they remain the issues most on people's minds.
But all the electronic magic in the world counts for nothing if the public feels it is being cheated or deceived. Johnson's pleas to voters to support "your President" went for naught when television showed voters a war they judged unjust; Richard M. Nixon's insistence that he was not a crook paled against the evidence that his Administration was caught in a huge lie.
Mr. Clinton will have to convince people on the merits that the sacrifices he calls for are equitably distributed. It is a question of sharing the pain broadly among older citizens and young, between the rich and the middle class, between cities and suburbs and between various industrial sectors.
"Listen to what I say next week, decide whether it's fair," the President told a questioner tonight.
Having lost some of the populist momentum of his campaign in the appointment of wealthy lawyers to major positions and in the largely inadvertent early emphasis on social issues that won him little mass sympathy, Mr. Clinton is seeking to get it back. Cuts in White House staffing levels, increased taxes on the very rich and tonight's talk with the folks are intended to do that.
His supporters are hopeful that things are entering a new phase.
"I admit that I see eerie parallels to the Carter Administration," said a prominent Democrat who served in that Administration. "There have been too many mistakes. But the core of what Bill Clinton stood for in the campaign remains intact, and we will soon see whether he can deliver on it."

U.S. ACCEPTS BOSNIA PEACE PLAN
The Clinton Administration abandoned its tough talk of using force to end the Balkans war and embraced an international peace process that would allow Serbs to keep lands seized in Bosnia and Herzegovina. A CENTER ROLE FOR MOSCOW

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1505 words

HEADLINE: Complexity of a Fiscal Giant: A Primer on Social Security

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Some are 65-year-old couples living on golf courses and celebrating their retirement with Caribbean cruises. Others are 90-year-old widows surviving on cans of soup.
But the nation's 41 million Social Security recipients are getting more from the system than they put in. And many have something to lose as the Clinton Administration's deficit-cutters struggle this week to find a politically palatable way to restrain the $303 billion program, perhaps the nation's most politically volatile. 
 Earlier this week, White House officials bowed to intense political pressure by saying they would not freeze the program's annual cost-of-living adjustments. A one-year freeze, advocated by Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, could have saved more than $41 billion over five years, according to the Congressional Budget Office. But it would have inflicted its pain blindly, taking from the shivering widow and the well-off couple alike.
Despite its step back, the White House may still seek to restrain the system by raising the taxes on benefits. This would spare the poorest of the elderly because their incomes are too low to be taxed. But it is likely to encounter resistance from those generally opposed to tax increases and from groups of the affluent elderly, who are well organized and ready to resist.
 
Need vs. Greed
 Whatever changes Mr. Clinton and his lieutenants propose, they must be ready to engage a deeper Social Security debate, one about need versus greed.
More specifically, the proposals to rein in the program rest upon two surprisingly complex questions: How needy are the elderly? And how generous is the Social Security system?
The answers begin in a swirl of numbers and assumptions that are strongly contested by policy experts and little understood by the public.
The confusion is understandable. Social Security takes from the rich and gives to the poor. But it also takes from the poor and gives to the rich.
It is a pension plan designed to pay most to those who contribute most. But it is also a welfare program, meant to protect people most in need.
 
A Broad Constituency
 That Social Security benefits go to the rich, poor and everyone in between gives the program its political muscle, but it also makes the program difficult to characterize.
"Precisely because you've built this great heterogeneous coalition, you can't think precisely about who the beneficiaries are," said Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at Northwestern University. "Some are needy, some are greedy and some are on the edge."
No one doubts that the United States has waged a largely successful fight against the poverty of the elderly, thanks to increases in Social Security benefits. In 1959, 35 percent of the elderly lived in poverty, according to the Census Bureau. Today only 12 percent do, compared with 14.2 percent of the population as a whole.
The Government currently considers an elderly person poor if the annual income is less than $6,500.
And while the incomes of the elderly have risen, other Americans have fared less well. The poverty rate for children, for instance, has risen to 22 percent, a figure that makes them almost twice as likely to be poor as the elderly.
 
Arguments for Sacrifice
 Many analysts point to such disparities in arguing that it is time for the elderly to share some of the sacrifice that comes with deficit reduction.
"In some sense, Social Security is a victim of its own success," said Richard Burkhauser, an economist at Syracuse University. "It has dramatically improved the well-being of the elderly. And the question is, Is enough enough?"
But others say the declining poverty rate is misleading. While Social Security has saved many elderly people from poverty, the majority still have low to modest incomes.
Figures compiled by the House Ways and Means Committee show that 60 percent of the elderly have annual family incomes under $20,000, and 28 percent have incomes of under $10,000. By contrast, only 8 percent live in families with an annual income of $50,000 or more.
For those earning less than $10,000 a year, Social Security payments provide, on average, almost 75 percent of their income.
"The stereotype of the relatively poor elderly is much closer to reality than the stereotype of the greedy affluent," said Patricia Ruggles, an economist at the Urban Institute, a research group in Washington.
 
Bite of Medical Bills
 Individuals retiring in 1992 received a maximum monthly Social Security payment of $1,088, depending on their contributions to the system over the years. Those who earned the average of the minimum wage throughout a lifetime of full employment received $481 a month. Those who worked less, received less.
Like many economists, Ms. Ruggles argues that income alone answers only part of the question about how well the elderly are faring. Because of rising medical costs and restraints put on the Medicare program, many people have seen their expenses rise sharply in recent years.
The incomes of the elderly also tend to erode, unlike those of most younger Americans, who can expect to see their incomes grow. This, too, can make older Americans less willing to sacrifice in the name of deficit reduction. "The comfortable 65-year-old guy off playing golf can leave a starving widow at age 80," said Timothy Smeeding, also an economist at Syracuse.
That situation can arise, Mr. Smeeding said, because a retired couple is often forced to cash in some of its assets to pay medical bills, thereby reducing the amount of interest and dividends it will earn. In addition, most private pensions are not indexed to inflation, so their value typically erodes. And husbands on average die sooner than their wives, leaving widows with reduced Social Security benefits.
 
Reaping More Than Was Sowed
 While the well-being of America's elderly varies widely, one fact about their Social Security benefits is central to discussions of fairness: all groups of current retirees receive significantly more back from the system than they contributed to it, even when interest and employer contributions are included.
Actuaries know it, but many elderly people do not.
"Congressmen don't go up and down the country saying, 'You guys didn't earn your Social Security checks,' " said Mr. Jencks, the Northwestern sociologist.
Social Security is often called a regressive system because poor people pay a higher percentage of their incomes in Social Security taxes than rich people do. (Annual income above $57,600 is exempt from the 6.2 percent payroll tax.)
But the system is simultaneously progressive because the benefits are set up so that low-earners, upon retirement, get a relatively higher subsidy than high-earners do.
Consider, for instance, a man retiring in 1991, who has earned the equivalent of the minimum wage for his entire working life. Calculations by the House Ways and Means Committee estimate that, with an average life expectancy, he will receive 2.13 times as much in benefits as he and his employer contributed, even counting interest. On average, that will amount to a $38,000 subsidy.
By contrast, the worker who has paid in the highest amount during his working career will get a less-generous subsidy. That man, retiring in 1991, can expect to receive benefits that are only 1.27 times higher than what he and his employer contributed, with interest. He can expect to receive a $32,000 subsidy.
The figures are different for women, since they have a longer life expectancy. But the principle remains the same: those with the lowest contributions get disproportionately more from the system.
 
Decreasing Generosity
 That principle is often cited by the defenders of the system, who argue that Social Security helps take care of the neediest.
But the system is fast becoming less generous for everyone. The Congressional Research Service estimates that by 2030 it will take an average retiree 18 years to get back the equivalent of what he and his employer paid in, with interest. In 1980, that figure was only 2.8 years.
And the research service estimates that under current rules the most affluent young workers, who pay the most taxes, will never receive the equivalent of their contributions.
So, where in this complex program can deficit-cutters find savings?
The likeliest option is a tax increase on benefits. At present, half of the Social Security benefits to individuals with annual incomes of more than $25,000 (or couples with incomes above $32,000) are taxed. By taxing 85 percent of those benefits -- which is the amount taxed on most private pensions -- the Government could raise about $29 billion over five years, the Congressional Budget Office estimated.
While that would spare the neediest of the elderly, political opposition is still likely to be fierce.
"Nobody's proposing to tax the people who are really struggling," Mr. Jencks said. "But people may think, 'Well, they'll start with them but soon they'll be taxing me, too.' "

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 4109 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S TOWN MEETING;
Excerpts From Clinton's Question-and-Answer Session on TV

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a televised question-and-answer session with President Clinton in Southfield, Mich., and studio audiences there and in three other cities, as transcribed by The New York Times:
 
CLINTON. Let me first of all thank all of you for being here in Michigan, and thank our audiences in Washington and Georgia and Florida for joining us, and all the people across this country who are watching this event. I started doing these televised town meetings a year ago in New Hampshire. Between June and November I did nine that were televised alone, including one here at this station. And I wanted to come out of the White House three weeks to the day after I became President because I can see now after only three weeks how easy it is for a President to get out of touch, to be caught up in the trappings of Washington and basically to be told by people that nothing needs to be changed, or you can't change things. 
 Let me just briefly say I want to take as much time as possible for questions, but I want to say one or two things real quickly. I believe I got elected on a commitment to change America, to create jobs, try to raise incomes, to face the health-care crisis, to try to liberate the Government from special interests and turn it back to the people; and to try to reduce the deficit and put America on a path to long-term health and recovery, bringing the American people together.
There's been some good news and bad news since I won the election. The good news is that the productivity of American firms is up, people are buying houses because interest rates are down, consumer confidence is up since the election -- I like that. People think things are going to be better. There's been some bad news. With all these economic improvements we aren't generating new jobs, and the deficit of this country is about $50 billion a year bigger than I was told it was going to be before the election.
So we have to put together a plan that keeps my commitments to you: invest in you and your jobs, in your education and your health care and your future -- that brings that debt down, that deals with the health-care crisis, and that does it in a way that's fair to all Americans.
I've got another week. I've been working almost exclusively on the economic issues of the country since I became President. I've got another week to put it together and I wanted to come up here tonight and just listen to your questions, answer them as candidly as I could, and share with you as much as I can my feelings about where we're going to go. But I'll say this, all the hundreds of thousands and maybe a million miles that I've traveled, I never saw one person along the highway with a sign that said: "Things are just fine the way they are. Don't change anything."
So I'm going to keep trying to change, and I'm going to try to stay in touch with you this whole four years, so that you can honestly tell me what you think. I'm really proud of the fact the voter turnout was not only up, we not only had the biggest crowd for the inauguration in history, but the mail and the phone calls to the White House are running at record levels -- some good, some critical -- but that's good, that's democracy. And it proves that people really feel, at least so far, that I'm going to listen and try to move forward. And that's what we're here to do tonight.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
The Deficit
 
Q. The American people, Mr. President, feel that Congress does not have the political will to balance the budget. If this is true and, as you say, if the economy is your priority, will you support a strong balanced budget amendment, one that is not watered down? And with us send a signal to Congress that we need them to face the issue. And when can we expect Washington to start to solve this enormous problem of ours?
 
CLINTON I think you can. First of all, I'm not for any version of the balanced budget amendment that I have seen, because I think it is basically again a kind of way of putting the decision off that would give us five years to deal with it.
Secondly, if we balanced the budget tomorrow, we'd drive unemployment up because it would require such terrible sacrifices. We need to do -- I hate to say this again, but did you look at what the Japanese did? They had a huge deficit in the 1970's. About as big, even a little bigger than ours is now. And they brought it down over about a 10-year period until, in 1990, they were the only major industrial country with a balanced budget. And one reason they had low unemployment and high growth.
So what I -- let me just tell you what I'm doing to do, and I wouldn't rule out other measures later. I'm going to try to get the Congress to pass the modified line-item veto bill that the House passed last time and the Senate didn't. I strongly support it.
I'm going to try to pass a strong campaign finance reform law and a lobbying reform law to free the Congress of undue influence of special interests.
I'm going to ask them to cut spending dramatically a broad range of areas. And to raise some more money. To try to bring this deficit down in a dramatic way that will send a signal that we're going -- that we're in control of our own house again and we're going to lower interest rates as a result of it and get this economy going again.
I think that's what we want. The important thing is not to balance the budget overnight, but to put it on a steady and decided downward tack. If we don't do it, a lot of -- let me just say there's no virtue in any of this unless it helps you. Let me just answer that -- a lot of people say to me, Why do you want to balance the budget; it's no fun cutting spending or raising more money to balance the budget or reduce the deficit. If you reduce the deficit, the United States doesn't borrow so much money. We have more of your tax money to spend on the education of your children or on developing new jobs or on health care. We keep interest rates down, and it's easier for you to borrow money in the private sector, so you create more jobs.
If the deficit gets bigger and bigger and bigger every year it weakens the economy. So, we have to do two things at once that no government in your country's history has ever done. We've go to increase investment in jobs and reduce the deficit.
And we're going to do it. And I think we can start next week. Look at my plan, see how you like it and see if the Congress responds. I predict to you that they will respond in a bipartisan fashion and reduce the debt for the first time in a long time.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Family Leave
 
Q. Why did you choose to tackle the gays in the military and the family leave bill first versus getting right to the economy and the Federal deficit?
 
CLINTON I didn't. I did choose the family leave bill first. Let me answer the questions separately. I chose to deal with the family leave bill because I knew there was a majority support in both houses for it and because I thought it was a pro-family bill. I thought it was a bill that would be helpful to strengthen the American family, with so many people forcibly in the work force. It contained an exemption for small business. It had been passed twice by the Congress before and vetoed. I thought it would help families and illustrate we had ended gridlock. I didn't choose to -- I tried to put off the gays in the military issue for six months. Senators in the other party wanted it dealt with now. They saw it as a way to delay family leave and to throw the whole Federal Government into debating that. I actually spent very little time on the issue myself. I met with the Joint Chiefs on a number of issues including that. And met with the Senate Democrats on the Armed Services committee. But I was frankly appalled that we spent so much time the first week talking about that instead of how to get the economy going again. It wasn't my idea. My agreement with the Joint Chiefs was to study the issue for six months so we could focus immediately on the economy. Thank goodness that's what we're now doing.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
The Middle Class
 
Q. Right. I'm concerned about your campaign promise to not raise the taxes for the middle class and how you intend to keep that promise.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
CLINTON Well, first of all, I did put out a plan which didn't contain a middle-class tax increase but I also repeatedly said, and I said in the debates in front of 100 million people, I refuse to say "Read my lips," that's not responsible. Now what's happened since the election? We have been told since the election that the Federal debt every year is going to be $50 billion bigger than we were told it was before the election. Now, I wish I could promise you that I won't ask you to pay any more, but I can tell you this: Look what I'm doing. I'm doing my best to keep my campaign commitments. I have first of all started by cutting the Government. I cut the White House staff by 25 percent yesterday. I bet that's never happened in the lifetime of anybody in this audience and it's real cuts. Today I announced $9 billion in cuts in the central Administration of the Federal Government -- $9 billion.
I have also said that before I ask the middle class to pay I'm going to ask the wealthiest Americans and companies, who made money in the 80's and had their taxes cut, to pay their fair share and I'm going to cut more Government spending. But I cannot tell you that I won't ask you to make any contribution to the changes we have to make. We have got to do two things at the same time: We've got to bring the debt down for the reasons that the first questioner so clearly articulated. And secondly, we've got to invest more in creating new jobs, in educating people and providing health care for all Americans and controlling costs. I'm doing my best to do that in the way that is fairest to middle-class America, but I have to be honest with you. The debt is $50 billion a year bigger than we were told it was before the election. I'm doing my best.
I have done nothing almost for three weeks but wrestle with this budget, try to cut costs and find ways to finance what we have to do, but we've got to change what we're doing. Let me say, I do have an alternative. I can play the same kind of games with you that have been played for the last 10 or 12 years, and this is not a partisan comment. This happened out of Washington. I could give you a bunch of smoke and mirrors and pretend the deficit's not there and then three or four years from now we'd be spending 20 cents of every tax dollar paying off the debt and it's not right. So, I'm going to do the best I can. Listen to what I say next week. Decide whether you think it's fair and tell me and your senators and congressmen whether you think I'm right or wrong.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Jobs in Aerospace
 
Q. My question is: How can America meet the challenge of maintaining our leadership in the very important aerospace industry?
 
CLINTON The answer, I think, is twofold. First, a lot of those aerospace workers who lost their jobs, lost their jobs because of cutbacks in defense which had to come at the end of the cold war. That is, we couldn't keep spending so much more than all of our competitors in these high-wage countries on defense without paying an economic price for it. But we couldn't -- we shouldn't have cut defense as much as we did in terms of high-tech, high-wage employment without a plan to reinvest in other industries and other technologies to put those people to work. So the first thing we have to do is to invest more in converting these high-wage jobs to other technologies. The second thing we need to do, frankly, is to take a serious look at the aerospace industry itself.
The Congress passed a bill last year that was never enacted, that we're now trying to get up and going. Where I will appoint someone and they will appoint some people to a commission to focus on how to rebuild the aviation industry in our country in two ways. No. 1, people who work for Boeing, McDonnell-Douglas and other subsidiary companies -- how can we get more jobs in making these planes and selling them at home and around the world. And No. 2, how can we do something about the commercial airlines themselves to avoid further bankruptcies and massive layoffs like -- we've got a Florida station here with us tonight. Miami has been devastated by layoffs at Eastern and Pan Am. So we're going to work on that.
And I assure you that I'm going to have a strategy to try to invest in commercial aviation. And we're also going to either have to -- we're going to -- either the Europeans are going to have to quit subsidizing Airbus and trying to deny us access to those contracts -- which is something else that's going on now -- or we're going to have to meet the competition. I am not going to roll over and play dead. Seven -- seven technologies are going to shape the high-wage jobs of the future. And one of the biggest is commercial aviation. The United States has a lead there. We are losing it because we have not fought to maintain it. And I assure you as soon as I get this budget and this investment plan, this jobs program, sent up to the Congress, we're going to start working on defense conversion and aerospace.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Homosexual Troops
 
Q. Having served in the United States Navy for five years aboard a guided missile destroyer, and also doing isolated duty in Alaska, and as a Christian and having the opportunity to minister to a number of men in the Navy, I believe it would just add continued undo pressure on a situation that is already pressure-packed to begin with. And I want to know why do you want to lift the ban and what impact do you see the ban having on the military?

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
CLINTON Let me tell you why I favor lifting it, very briefly. We have now, and everyone concedes we have always had, homosexual men and women in the military service. I received a letter from a retired officer, a woman, the other day who told me she left the service because she could not be honest about her sexual orientation, even though she was a distinguished officer with a remarkable service record -- one of many such letters I have received.
Your Government spent $500 million to get rid of about 16,300 homosexuals from the service in the 1980's. Now, here's my position. If there are homosexual men and women in the service anyway, if we know they have served with distinction and they have always been there, the issue is should you be able to say what you are and not be kicked out. This is not about conduct, this is about status. I believe there ought to be the strictest code of behavioral conduct applicable here. I also believe there ought to be an even stricter code applicable to sexual harassment, whether homosexual or heterosexual. The biggest sexual problem in the armed services, according to the men and women who talk to me, involves heterosexual harassment. I think there ought to be a tough code of conduct. If people do wrong, they ought to be gotten out.
But I think people should not be asked to lie if they're going to be allowed to serve. Because the question is not whether they should be there or not, they are there. So the narrow question of this debate is should you be able to stay and admit it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Fighting in Bosnia
 
Q. How does one negotiate with war criminals without a clear enforcement to let them know that they have to stop with the atrocity? And how does one insure that the Serbs will not continue with their atrocities and that they will negotiate in a good faith and that they will lay down their arms? Will you ask NATO for their enforcement of the terms of agreement and give them the authority to use force in this case? And will you also help Croatia regain its sovereignty on the territories it's lost so that 700,000 people can return to their homes? Thank you.
 
CLINTON Thank you. I'm glad you asked the question in the way you did. I was afraid you were going to ask me why we agreed to get involved in this process today. Just for the benefit of the people who don't know as much about it as you, let me tell you what happened today. Today, the Secretary of State announced a new policy by our Government that we would agree to become more involved in what is going on in Bosnia, not in committing our ground troops now or anything like that, but in trying to get involved in these negotiations to protect the rights and the integrity of the Bosnians, the Croatians and others who have been basically subject to the assaults of the Serbs. That we would be in a position to say we're not going to enforce a peace agreement on the Croatians or the Bosnians that they don't believe in, but that if we can get an agreement then the United States would participate -- not alone, but with the United Nations and with Europe -- in guaranteeing that the agreement would protect the basic human rights of the people involved and the terms of the agreement.
Now people say, So, we are not committing today to make war in the former Yugoslavia. We are committing to try to help get a peace and then to enforce it. Why is that? Because if we don't, No. 1, the terrible principle of ethnic cleansing will be validated. That one ethnic group can butcher another if they're strong enough to do it at the end of the cold war. No. 2, that problem could spread to other republics and nations near there. Never forget it's no accident that World War I started in this area. There are ancient ethnic hatreds that have consumed people and led to horrible abuses. You know about it -- the rapes of the women, the murders of the children, all these things you have read about.
We've got to try to contain it and I think we have to be very stronger -- much stronger standing up to aggression. We've got to get the heavy weapons out of utilization, you implied that. We've got to toughen the embargo against the Serbs. We ought to open a United Nations war crimes inquiry and we ought to enforce that no-fly zone against Serbian aircraft strongly. Those are the things that I think we should do.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Tainted Meat
 
Q. Mr. President, actually, our child is at Children's Hospital in Seattle, but he is in intensive care and critical condition. And only two days prior to him going in there with e coli poisoning from tainted meat, my husband lost his job and we were lost without medical coverage. I'm Canadian originally and always took comfort in the medical system there, and in knowing that my children would be taken care of. My question to you now is, What are you prepared to in regards to the tainted meat problem? And is there any hope in the near future of seeing universal health care so that no one else has to go through what we've gone through?
 
CLINTONLet me first of all say I thank you for being on the program and I hope your child will be well. I did call two other sets of parents who were in the hospital with their children on the way out here, just to inquire about that and to get their ideas about what we should do. Let me answer your second question first. As I'm sure you know, I've asked my wife to head a task force to come up with a bill within 100 which will bring a new system of health care to America, which offers us the chance to provide basic health coverage to everybody, to stop people from losing their health coverage when they lose a job, to stop people from their inability to change jobs because they've had someone in their family sick, and to bring the cost of health care in line with inflation.
I think we can do that, and if we don't do it, we'll never balance the budget and we'll never restore health to this economy. Fifty percent of the projected deficit growth between now and the year 2000 is all in health-care costs. So it's a hard -- it's a terrific human issue but it's a big economic issue for America. And the answer to your question is, within 100 of my becoming President, we're going to have a bill to the Congress to do just what you said.
Now the second thing, this e coli thing, have you all been following it up in Washington? It's a -- I asked the Secretary of Agriculture, Mike Espy, who is responsible for the regulation of the slaughter houses and the meat before it comes to a restaurant, to go up there and look into the situation. And we think there are two things that have to be done. First of all, we've got to make it clear to people who are providing fast food that they've got to do everything they can to comply with our cooking regulations. Some of those viruses would have clearly died had the heat been observed.
On the other hand, we've got to find ways to do more inspections and to try to do them in a more effective way. And so we are reviewing now the possibility of not only hiring more inspectors, which I've already agreed to do, but secondly, seeing if there is some way we can do a better job of actually inspecting the meat, empowering the inspectors to do some more things. We have got to do that and I can tell you, if you have any other ideas I'd like to have them. The parents, it struck me, that I talked to today, had actually some quite good ideas that we're going to pursue. And I want to invite you and any others who are listening, who have other ideas, to let me know. You can look forward to more inspectors, and we're looking for ways to inspect better, as well.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Child Care
 
Q. That's what I want to know. Obviously going to be a working mother I'm very concerned about the child-care crisis, which has been finally been thrown into the spotlight with Nannygate. And I would like to know what your first thing is that you're going to do to address the child-care issue to make it affordable and reasonable.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
CLINTON Is your biggest concern the cost of child care, or the availability of quality care?
 
Q. The quality of the care. The quality of what I can get for the affordability of what I can get. If it's even worth it to go back with what we have available.
And what about working mothers who don't have any choice about going back to work? Where can they take their children and have it be affordable and quality care where they're sure their children are safe and getting good care.
 
CLINTON Well, I think there are two or three things we can do that we're working on now. The first is, to work in partnerships with states to help them to develop high standards for child care, but also quality care at affordable prices. And one of the things that we did in my state when I was Governor is to spend a good deal of our training money, for example, training people who were on welfare but who were quite intelligent and capable for taking care of their own children, to work in child-care facilities. And moving them from welfare to work in ways that took maximum advantage of money the taxpayers were spending already and lowered the cost of child care. And we often put these -- these child-care facilities in and around job-training facilities to help working mothers and working parents that were going back to school. Sometimes they were going to school and working at the same time. I think we can do that.
The second thing we can do is to increase the earned income tax credit, for working Americans and especially middle- to lower-middle-income working Americans so that they will have more disposable income to pay their child-care expenses.
The third thing we can do is simply to increase the child-care credit itself. We basically have got to make the economics of this work. And I think there are lots of other things that can be done, but they won't affect the population as a whole. The population as a whole needs to be helped by making sure you've got a steady stream of trained quality child-care workers and then more income for middle-class people, either through the child-care tax credit, or through the general earned-income tax credit, which basically says if you work 40 hours a week and you've got kids in the house, you shouldn't be put into poverty because of your other expenses including child care. The government ought to reduce your tax burden, if necessary, even give you money back as long as you're working hard and playing by the rules and you need to take care of your kids.

HEADLINE: Japan Official Plans No Initiatives in U.S. Visit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Japan's Foreign Minister, preparing for what could be an uneasy first encounter with the Clinton Administration, says that economic disputes "cannot be allowed to destroy Japan-United States relations" but that he had no major new initiatives to defuse tensions over trade.
In an interview Tuesday evening, Michio Watanabe, who also serves as Deputy Prime Minister, acknowledged that balooning trade surpluses and American calls for a tougher trade policy were creating a turbulent atmosphere for his meetings this week in Washington with President Clinton and top Administration officials. 
 Mr. Watanabe's statement that he would be offering no major new initiatives came in spite of advice from the United States Ambassador, Michael H. Armacost, that he bring something with him to defuse tensions that have deepened in recent weeks.
Mr. Watanabe's mission comes at a moment of extraordinary nervousness within the Japanese Government about the country's biggest single alliance. Though President Clinton has said little about trade policy, Japanese officials openly worry that his stress on "economic security" is leading to potential confrontations.
Mr. Watanabe said, though, that "we are not in any way afraid of Mr. Clinton."
A senior American official suggested that the main purpose of the trip -- during which Mr. Watanabe will meet President Clinton, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Secretary of Defense Les Aspin and several others -- "is really an effort to find out how upset Washington is with the trade deficit."
If the Administration is viewed as disorganized on its trade goals, many here suggest, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party may determine it has more time before it has to make politically unpopular moves here to open markets further or force companies to purchase more imported goods.
During his interview, Mr. Watanabe suggested that he would argue in Washington that Japan's soaring trade surpluses -- roughly $44 billion last year with the United States, and $136 billion with the world -- were a statistical aberration, not a reversal of Japan's commitments to change its ways.
 
Rising Value of Exports
 "Japanese companies do not feel like they are exporting more," he said, referring to the skyrocketing value of Japanese exports.
But American officials say that if Mr. Watanabe attempts to explain away the trade numbers in Washington, it would almost certainly backfire, especially since the Administration seems eager to to stand up to Tokyo.
Japan is also expected to argue that it is taking at least some steps to stimulate its economy, in the process increasing Japan's demand for imports. To this end, the Bank of Japan last week announced that it was lowering the official discount rate from 3.25 percent to 2.5 percent.
Mr. Watanabe attributed the trade imbalance to the rise in the value of the yen against the dollar, which makes Japanese goods more expensive overseas and makes exports seem to grow in value. He also said that the value of exports has risen because Japanese makers are selling higher quality and more expensive products, like the Toyota Lexus, not more products.
Usually, a mission like Mr. Watanabe's would attract little attention in Tokyo. But Japanese officials have gone to extraordinary lengths to cast the visit as the first step to define a new relationship with the United States, before the Clinton Administration rules on a string of economic disputes.
 
Withdrawal of Trade Complaint
 The atmosphere may have improved even before Mr. Watanabe's arrival in Washington as a result of an announcement by the three major American automobile manufacturers that they would not file complaints of unfair trade against Japanese auto makers, as they previously said they would.
Aides to Mr. Watanabe described the action as welcome but not likely to have much impact in light of the many other disputes on the agenda.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
