HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
Christopher's Remarks on Balkans: 'Crucial Test'

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Warren Christopher's news conference today:
 
OPENING STATEMENT 
 Today I'm announcing a series of steps that President Clinton has decided to take with regard to the former Yugoslavia. The President believes that it's time for the United States to become actively and directly engaged in the multilateral effort to reach a just and workable solution to this very dangerous conflict.

 	 	 		. . .	 	There is also a broader imperative here. The world's response to the violence in the former Yugoslavia is an early and crucial test of how it will address the concerns of the ethnic and religious minorities in the post-cold-war period.
First, the President decided the United States will actively engage in the Vance-Owen negotiations bringing the full weight of American diplomacy to bear. We know these negotiations will not be easy. We know the options have narrowed because of past inaction. We do not expect miracles, but we believe we can make a difference. We strongly support the efforts of the United Nations and the European Community through the Vance-Owen negotiations to arrive at an agreement that would bring peace to Bosnia.
Now, in order to insure the most effective possible communication between us, President Clinton has today named one of our top diplomats to be our Government's envoy to these talks. Ambassador Reginald Bartholomew will be that envoy.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Second, the President is communicating to the Bosnians, Serbs, and Croatians that the only way to end this conflict is through negotiation. No settlement can be imposed upon the parties both on grounds of principle and on grounds that an imposed settlement would be far more difficult to sustain than one that the parties have voluntarily reached. At the same time, we believe that each party must be prepared to accept a resolution that falls short of its greatest goals.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Third, the President will take actions to tighten the enforcement of economic sanctions, increase political pressure on Serbia and deter Serbia from widening the war. We've informed the Serbians that we plan to raise the economic and political price for aggression. We will work with our allies, the Russians and others, to achieve that result.
We remain prepared to respond against the Serbians in the event of a conflict in Kosovo caused by Serbian action, and, in addition, we will work to strengthen the international presence in Macedonia.
Fourth, the President is taking steps to reduce the suffering and bloodshed as the negotiations proceed. He's calling on all parties to stop the shelling and other violence. He has communicated to all concerned that the no-fly zone over Bosnia should be enforced under the U.N. resolution. He has urged that humanitarian aid be allowed to flow to those in need. And we are considering further actions to promote greater delivery of this aid.
Moreover, we're putting together a U.S. Government team to assess the humanitarian needs as they exist at the present time, and on an urgent basis. The President is also seeking the creation of a war crimes tribunal at the United Nations to bring justice and to deter further atrocities.
Fifth, the President has taken steps to make clear to all concerned that the United States is prepared to do its share to help implement and enforce an agreement that is acceptable to all parties.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Sixth, and finally, the President has consulted widely with our friends and allies on these actions.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. Mr. Secretary, could you please tell us, was there any sentiment in the review toward assisting the Bosnians more directly with weapons? Or even using American air power to silence those Serbian mortars, which President Clinton seemed to be suggesting he might do when he campaigned last August and a lot of world leaders have asked the United States to do.
A. On the first half of your question, we did consider carefully providing weapons to the Bosnians. In the end we concluded not to do that. In consultation with our allies it became clear that those countries that have troops on the ground there, France, the United Kingdom and Canada, felt that their troops would be gravely endangered if we lifted the embargo on weapons to the Bosnians.
We think it's important that those troops stay there. We felt they would not stay there if we lifted the embargo, and on balance we thought it was a step that would be unwise to take.
With respect to the use of air power directly, similar considerations were involved. This situation has evolved a good deal. I must say it has gotten worse. It is less simple. Our options are less good than they were at the time the President spoke when he identified in August the need to take more aggressive action on this subject.
So although those two steps were considered, we concluded that they would not be constructive steps to the resolution of this problem and we should pursue the steps that I've outlined in my statement.
Q. Can you explain two different aspects? You said that in an effort to try to get more humanitarian aid in, number one, that you would work for enforcement of the no-fly zone. First, does that mean you are going to seek that on an urgent basis at the U.N.?
And secondly, you said aid should be allowed to flow more freely. As you know, the U.N. has already said that it is -- all necessary means could be used to get that aid in. Are you talking about shooting your way in to get the aid to people who need it? What are you talking about?
A. On both subjects we're considering how we might best achieve that with respect to getting the aid in . . . , and we're also consulting with our allies on that point.
The statement speaks for itself. But it certainly does leave the implementation for further discussion. In particular I would say for consultation with our allies. We are quite reluctant to move into this situation and take steps without a full opportunity to consult with them to determine whether or not they feel the steps that might be taken would be useful.
But we have not ruled out quite determined steps that might be taken to make sure that the aid gets to those in the country who are starving and need medicine.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Mr. Secretary, you indicated in the past that you were unhappy with some aspects of the Vance-Owen plan. Is Mr. Bartholomew, Ambassador Bartholomew, going to arrive in New York with a U.S. map of Bosnia and how it should look? Do you have specific ideas? can you be a little more specific about what you're looking for that will make this a more equitable settlement?
A. My unhappiness with the Vance-Owen plan, if one is to call it that, in the past has been that the parties were not in agreement and there appeared to be an effort to impose it on the parties. And, as I said in the course of my statement, I think the likelihood of sustaining an agreement where the parties are not in agreement -- or sustaining a plan where the parties are not in agreement -- is much less than it would be if they were in agreement. We will not arrive with a map. We're going to be in the role of sponsors, using our good offices. We have no prescribed solution. The solution is mainly up to the parties. But we think with the full weight of diplomacy and in the background of U.S. power that we can be helpful to the parties in coming to an agreement.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Clinton's Campaign '93: A Different Trail but a Familiar Format

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOUTHFIELD, Mich., Feb. 10

 BODY:
When President Clinton stepped onto the spare, blue soundstage at station WXYZ-TV here, the carefully screened audience, billed as a group of skeptical questioners, burst into giddy applause.
The President's reception in this Detroit suburb was better than any he had received in the campaign, during which he first grew fond of the question-and-answer "town meeting" format he used tonight on his first trip outside Washington since his inauguration three weeks ago. 
 Once the meeting began, Mr. Clinton warmed quickly to the task he likes best -- campaigning. There was scant material difference between the appearance of Bill Clinton the President and Bill Clinton the Presidential candidate, who appeared in nine such forums from June to November last year.
 
Protected From Reporters
 The Detroit audience, one of four assembled in studios around the country, was bused to the television studio in advance of the program, allowing them to be protected from the questions of hundreds of reporters gathered here. Station officials guided them immediately into the studio and allowed them to grant advance interviews only to the local television affiliate.
After the meeting several in the audience gave Mr. Clinton good reviews. "It's an impossible job," said James G. Littles, a college professor. "All he has to do is try."
Harry W. Weaver 2d, a high school coach, said, "Whether it was a publicity stunt or not, he tried to use it to show he can connect with people, to have our input."
On a small but symbolic point, WXYZ won the battle over the sort of stool Mr. Clinton would sit on. The black lacquered chair with the green upholstered seat looked like a kitchen highchair, but Mr. Clinton largely ignored it, instead pacing along the edge of the raised stage.
Mr. Clinton's arrival here was as carefully choreographed as the most elaborate White House political event. An outside political adviser, Paul Begala, a familiar figure from the campaign, accompanied the President, and he used an airport speech to rally his supporters around the notion of shared sacrifice.
 
Greeted at an Air Base
 In brief remarks to about 200 people who greeted him on his arrival at Selfridge Air National Guard Base in nearby Detroit, Mr. Clinton said he had been "doing almost nothing but focusing on this economy" since he took office, and had come to Michigan for his first post-inaugural trip because he had seen "everything about America writ large here in this state," including economic troubles and racial tensions.
"But remember," he continued, "everywhere I went in this election I said, 'Do not vote for me if you're going to quit on Election Day. Do not come to the inaugural and celebrate the victory unless you're going to help us make the victory good.' "
The trip today on Air Force One was the President's first. Wearing a blue poplin jacket that bore the Presidential seal and his embroidered name, Mr. Clinton took a tour of the specially outfitted Boeing 747 during the flight.
"He didn't miss Air Elvis," said Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, referring to the charter jet that Mr. Clinton used in his campaign for the Presidency.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
'Plan B' Is Really 'Plan A'

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb 10

 BODY:
For the first time since the collapse of the Soviet Union, Moscow is moving into the center of the diplomatic arena as a result of President Clinton's conclusion that Russia can exert significant influence, for better or worse, over the fate of the United States plan to end the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
By making clear today that it wants to involve President Boris N. Yeltsin in the search for a Balkan settlement, the Clinton Administration appears to be seeking both to persuade Moscow to pressure the Serbs to compromise and to insure that Russia does not use its Security Council veto to obstruct the plan. 
 In some ways the situation is reminiscent of the big-power line-up in the Middle East during the cold war: The United States hopes to use its influence with Bosnian Muslims to push them toward compromise, just as it once sought to restrain Israel, while relying on Moscow to bring along the Serbs, just as the Soviet Union was asked to put pressure on the Arabs.
 
Together, at Last
 The two international mediators, Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, are likely to find their diplomatic efforts considerably strengthened by Washington's approach. Once the mediators, Washington and Moscow all agree on a formula, any faction that resists it is going to find itself isolated.
An audible sigh of relief went up this morning after Secretary of State Warren Christopher telephoned the mediators to explain that he was not seeking a territorial settlement more favorable to the Muslims, but wanted a deal that all three sides could accept.
 
Moscow Presses Ahead
 Mr. Vance and Lord Owen expressed their respect for Reginald Bartholomew, who will represent Washington in the peace talks, but also vowed to "keep the pressure on for an early agreement on a comprehensive peace settlement in the context of the discussions already under way in the Security Council."
The fact that any deal the Clinton Administration helps to broker is unlikely to be very different from the Vance-Owen plan are proposing was made clear in Moscow today when the Deputy Foreign Minister, Vitaly I. Churkin, urged the Security Council to approve the plan and end the embargo on the rump Yugoslav federation if the plan is accepted by all. "We have only two hopes in this situation," he said. "One is Cyrus Vance and the other is Lord Owen."
By sending Mr. Bartholomew to Moscow immediately and by telephoning President Yeltsin this morning, President Clinton is asking Moscow to use its considerable psychological influence with the isolated Serbian government to reach a settlement.
 
The Ties That Influence
 Ethnically Slav like the Serbs, sharing the same Orthodox faith and speaking related languages, Russia is about the only country to have shown any sympathy for Slobodon Milosevic, president of the Serbian republic. Mr. Milosevic is widely blamed for starting the civil war in Bosnia and he may also be the only man capable of ending it through his influence over Bosnia's nationalist Serbian leadership.
To encourage Mr. Milosevic to press the Serbs in Bosnia, the United States, Britain and France are ready to impose a much tighter economic blockade on Serbia and Montenegro, which make up what is left of Yugoslavia.
But sanctions against Serbia have proved unpopular with the assertive Russian Parliament, raising fears that President Yeltsin might use his Security Council veto to block a tighter squeeze.
Involving Mr. Yeltsin is thus an attempt both to insure that new sanctions will not be needed and to persuade him not to veto them if they are.
 
No-Longer-Great Expectations
 The Clinton Administration, by making clear above all that it has no plan to divide Bosnia in ways that favor the Muslims, has pricked the bubble of Muslim expectations that were inflated by Washington's criticism of the Vance-Owen plan as rewarding Serbian "ethnic cleansing."
Encouraged by talk of a Washington policy review, the Muslims refused to negotiate until they had seen what President Clinton would offer.
Today Bosnia's Foreign Minister, Hari Silajdzic, said his Muslim-dominated Government would never negotiate unless the Serbs surrendered the guns that are shelling Sarajevo. "We will not negotiate with guns at our head," he said at a news conference.
But the United States has now made it clear that all the Muslims can expect is what the Vance-Owen plan already offers: tough enforcement measures to insure that the Serbs do not violate a settlement, a war-crimes court, strong human rights safeguards and some territorial adjustments.
If the Muslims do not accept, they will have no allies left to turn to.

With him was Bosnia's delegate to the U.N., Muhamed Sacirbey, left. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Law Failed to Stem Illegal Immigration, Panel Says

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
With the Clinton Administration still smarting from the problems with the child-care arrangements of Zoe Baird and Judge Kimba M. Wood, a new Government report contends that illegal immigration continues unchecked and is making a mockery of a 1986 law that was intended to curb it.
Foreigners who seek low-wage jobs -- working in homes, cleaning office buildings, doing the heavy lifting on construction crews, sewing in garment shops, bringing in the nation's fruit and vegetable harvests -- are rarely competing with Americans for those jobs. 
 Both employers and their unauthorized workers run some risk, but the risk is small because enforcement is difficult. Workers have easy access to fraudulent work documents, and the Government has been reluctant or unable to track down most violators.
Next week the Commission on Agricultural Workers, created under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, will submit to Congress the most thorough study yet of the immigration law. Established to appease farmers who feared that the law would cut off their labor supply, the commission only examined the law's effect on farming. But its findings of widespread illegal immigration apply to all parts of the economy that attract unauthorized foreign workers.
 
'Oversupply of Farm Labor'
 After six years of study, the commission's 12 members concluded: "Rather than a stabilization of the labor supply, there is a general oversupply of farm labor nationwide. Unauthorized immigrants continue to cross the southern border in large numbers."
The commission suggests tough new controls on illegal immigration, including development of a fraud-proof identification document for immigrants. Senator Alan K. Simpson, a Wyoming Republican who was an author of the 1986 law, has long espoused such a document, but it raises the hackles of those who regard the document as an invasion of privacy.
Others say the Government could do more to improve the wages and working conditions of menial jobs so that more Americans would be willing to apply for them. The commission says wages and working conditions will improve if the law really stems the supply of foreign workers.
Both the commission and various immigration experts say the steady influx of unauthorized workers worsens working conditions for everyone. "You get low pay for household work, poor conditions and people being taken advantage of," said George High, executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies, a small Washington-based research group.
 
'Systematic Effort' Needed
 Demetrios G. Papademetriou, a scholar at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the Labor Department's immigration policy director in the Bush Administration, said, "What we don't do is make a systematic effort to control immigration."
Mr. Papademetriou, whom commission officials consulted about their report, said it was impossible to know how many immigrants had illegally entered the United States. But he said the most plausible estimate was 3.5 million, of whom 500,000 were farm workers and 350,000 were domestic workers. He said the domestic workers were concentrated in New York City and northern New Jersey, and in Los Angeles, Chicago, Miami and Houston.
The Internal Revenue Service estimates that two million Americans employ domestic workers -- cleaning house, caring for children, tending gardens -- and that only 250,000 of those workers meet all the requirements of the immigration and tax laws.
"It's massive in Washington, D.C.," said Michael Maggio, an immigration lawyer here. "They're working in the homes of our lawyers, our journalists and our government officials."
At the same time, the nation's principal enforcement agency, the Immigration and Naturalization Service, largely ignores violations in farming and domestic work because of insufficient staff. Instead, the agency concentrates on factories and work sites where it stands a better chance of finding large concentrations of workers who lack the proper documents.
 
Searches Called Inefficient
 Under pressure from farmers, the Reagan Administration refused to let the agency conduct unannounced sweeps of farms or ranches in search of such workers, requiring instead that it first inform the owner of the farm where it expected to find the workers.
Tracking down unauthorized maids and child-care workers is inefficient, the agency says. "We don't do very much in the area of domestics." said Verne Jervis, an I.N.S. spokesman. "It's not productive. We've got 1,500 investigators, nowhere enough people to concentrate on household help."
On its face, the 1986 immigration law seems tough. It granted amnesty to several million immigrants who could show that they had been working in the United States for at least 90 days. But it also established penalties of $100 and up to six months in prison against employers who knowingly hired illegal aliens.
The law requires an employer to ask a job applicant for any of a variety of official papers -- a visa, a driver's license, a Social Security card. But it does not require that the employer verify the document. As a result, a thriving industry of counterfeit card makers has emerged.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Voices of New Women Resound in the Senate

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Debate in the Senate sounds a little different these days.
Senators have always gone beyond the records of hearings and studies when they debated legislation. They cite lessons they learned as governors or businessmen, and most of all in wartime. And all of those familiar notes were sounded last week when the Senate debated the family leave bill and argued about homosexuals in the armed forces. 
 But in addition, during the family leave discussion, the senators heard two altogether different voices of experience. Two Senators told how they had to quit their jobs when they gave birth.
Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, recalled that 16 years ago, "when I worked as an executive secretary in Seattle, I became pregnant with my first child."
"At that time," she went on, "even though I was working out of economic necessity, there were no options for working mothers." She had to quit.
Then Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, recalled: "Thirty-five years ago, when I gave birth to my daughter, Katherine, there was no maternity or family leave. I left my job to have my child."
Floor arguments hardly ever affect votes in the Senate. But these two speeches suggested the kind of influence the new women in the chamber may expect to have. They add a different voice, a perspective that senators in the past have absorbed, when they absorb it at all, from constituents and witnesses and sometimes from their wives.
Two days later, another of the chamber's new women was heard from. But this time, Carol Moseley Braun, an Illinois Democrat who is the only black in the Senate, offered a deeply researched argument that the ban on homosexuals in the military was as much rooted in prejudice as the refusal to integrate the Navy was in 1942.
She read old memorandums on the reluctance of whites to be near blacks or to sleep near them that sounded eerily like today's arguments about straight and gay members of the military.
But Senators Feinstein and Murray were not reciting history; they were talking about their own lives. Ms. Feinstein, who is now 54, later recalled that when she was working for the state government and became pregnant "the words 'maternity leave' weren't really known."
She divorced a couple of years later and learned other hard lessons about employers' reluctance to hire a woman with a small child. "We're bringing a different perspective," she said. "We are talking about another kind of experience."
Since those days, Ms. Feinstein has traveled a conventional politician's route to the Senate. She was a member of San Francisco's Board of Supervisors for nine years and then its Mayor for nine more.
Ms. Murray had a shorter, less visible apprenticeship. Now 42, she was elected to the Senate after just four years in the Washington Legislature and four years on a suburban Seattle school board.
Quitting a job to have a child was not the only previously unsenatorial experience Ms. Murray described to the two or three of her 99 colleagues who were present. She also told of how difficult it was for her brothers and sisters to arrange time off from their jobs to care for her seriously ill parents. As a State Senator in 1992, she could juggle her time when her sisters and brothers, none of whose employers gave them leave, could not.
"I am of the infamous sandwich generation, charged with caring for my own children and my parents at the same time," the Senator said. "I personally understand the emotional consequences. I also know that when my family is safe and well cared for, I do a better job at work."
It is rare for someone to come to the Senate without longer political experience than Ms. Murray's, or at least without some other form of celebrity like Bill Bradley's basketball stardom or John Glenn's soaring experience as an astronaut. Senator Murray, in fact, seems like the sort of lawmaker who the advocates of term limits think will arrive in droves if the incumbents are forced to leave: a citizen-legislator.
She sounds that way. "People feel they've been left out of government," she said later in the week. And while "you have to be here to matter," she said, "I want to say what my next-door neighbor would say."

"At that time, even though I was working out of economic necessity, there were no options for working mothers." (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton Tells Cabinet to Cut Work Force and Privileges

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton ordered his Cabinet officers today to slash 100,000 jobs from the Federal work force over the next four years, to cut back executive perquisites and to dissolve obscure Government commissions like the Advisory Panel for the Dictionary of Occupational Titles.
If all the reductions were carried out, Mr. Clinton said, they would save $9 billion over four years. He provided no documentation to back up that number. 
 The announced job cuts, which Mr. Clinton said would be accomplished through attrition and not layoffs, came a day after he declared that he was shrinking the White House staff by 25 percent.
Together these moves are meant both to fulfill campaign promises and to demonstrate that the Government is already going on a diet before Mr. Clinton asks the American people and Congress in a speech scheduled for Feb. 17 for tax increases and even broader deficit-reduction programs.
 
Concern in Private
 While Congressional leaders and their staffs publicly welcomed today's moves, some also expressed concern that in his zeal to fulfill his campaign promises, Mr. Clinton may take steps that lead to a different sort of gridlock, one in which agencies cannot perform up to standard because clerical help has been eliminated, because cuts are not carried out coherently and because already overworked auditors are further reduced in number.
Mr. Clinton announced the latest belt-tightening moves in a Cabinet meeting, after which members of the Cabinet were asked to take the lectern and, in a bureaucratic version of show and tell, explain where they were cutting and how much they enjoyed it.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, who is less than 5 feet tall, broke up the room when he declared: "My predecessor was traveling, I discovered, by first class whenever my predecessor had to travel around the country. I'm traveling coach. Of course, I don't need the leg room."
 
Out With 'Pony Perks'
 Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said he was eliminating the "pony perks" in his department. This was a reference to a plan on the books to expand a horse-riding center at the Manassas National Battlefield in Virginia for the convenience of politicians and high-ranking officials.
Mr. Clinton today signed three executive orders for the cuts. The first requires Cabinet and agency heads to cut the 2.1-million-member civilian Federal work force by 100,000 jobs by the end of 1995, with 10 percent of the cuts coming from senior management. Each year, about 200,000 workers leave Government service, and the idea would be to leave some of these vacancies unfilled.
The second executive order tells departments to reduce their administrative costs by 3 percent a year on average, leading up to 5 percent in the fourth year of Mr. Clinton's term.
The third order abolishes Government boards and agencies that Mr. Clinton deems of marginal significance. Examples of such panels, which cost about $150 million a year, are the Advisory Panel for Animal Learning and Behavior, the National Sea Grant Review Panel, the Weather and Climate Coordinating Committee, the Board of Tea Experts and the Advisory Panel for the Dictionary of Occupational Titles.
 
'To Shrink the Gulf'
 Mr. Clinton also announced that he was issuing additional directives "to shrink the gulf between government and the average citizen."
One is cutting the number of officials in each department who will be able to use home-to-office limousines, with a 50 percent reduction in the limousine fleet in the current fiscal year. Another is an unspecified "tightening of the rules for using Government airplanes," with a goal of eliminating unnecessary planes.
Finally, Mr. Clinton said he was ordering the elimination of perks like below-cost executive dining rooms and free memberships in private health clubs for senior officials.
The last Democratic President to impose across-the-board White House and administrative cuts was Jimmy Carter, whose White House operation was debilitated in part by the indiscriminate way in which he made reductions, particularly in his Congressional liaison operation.
Charles O. Jones, professor of political science at University of Wisconsin at Madison, who has written a history of the Carter Administration, said:
"What we learned from the Carter experience is that this kind of symbolic stuff will only be meaningful if it enhances the White House's ability to deliver on health care and the economy. If Clinton can make that connection, people will hail him for it, but if this complicates his ability to deliver on the big things, it will be as well remembered as Carter's."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Warren Christopher, left, Defense Secretary Les Aspin, center, and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown attending a Cabinet meeting yesterday at which President Clinton ordered his Cabinet officers to slash 100,000 jobs from the work force within four years. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Saudi Minister Warns Against New Oil Taxes

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
The Saudi Arabian oil minister, Hisham M. Nazer, made an indirect but strong plea today for the Clinton Administration not to impose taxes aimed at reducing oil consumption and imports.
Mr. Nazer, speaking at a conference of oil executives sponsored by Cambridge Energy Research Associates, hinted that the Saudis and other large oil exporters might respond in ways that he did not detail. Oil import fees "defy the logic of geology and economics," he said. Mr. Nazer indicated that the Saudis' heavy investments in in new producing fields, as well as in American refining and marketing outlets, would suffer if Washington approved oil-related taxes. 
 "We see constant discrimination against oil in many policy measures and initiatives under the pretext of security of supply or the guise of environmental protection or simply alleviating budget deficits,' Mr. Nazer said.
Saudi Arabia replaced Russia last year as the world's largest oil producer, with daily output of 8.5 million barrels.
 
A Push For Higher Prices
 Carbon, gasoline or oil-import taxes in the United States would likely lower demand for OPEC oil and reduce oil prices at a time when Mr. Nazer is leading a campaign within OPEC to pare production quotas and push prices higher.
Oil traders said they anticipated that 11 ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would agree to reduce daily output by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day, from 25.5 million barrels at a meeting that opens Saturday in Vienna. A failure to reduce output could send world prices down by $2 or $3 a barrel.
World oil prices jumped by more than $1 a barrel two weeks ago, when Mr. Nazer was quoted as saying that the Saudis would join Iran in pushing for production cutbacks to raise prices. But a pact is far from certain, and history suggests that if one is reached, it may not be followed for long. A Kuwaiti oil official did nothing here Tuesday night to calm concerns within OPEC over his nation's rising exports.
Nader H. Sultan, president of the refining and marketing subsidiary of the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, told more than 500 oil executives at the conference that the kingdom expects to increase daily output to two million barrels by this summer, from 1.7 million barrels currently.
OPEC members have omitted Kuwait from production quotas since its battered oil industry resumed pumping oil a year ago after recovering from the 766 oil well fires set by Iraqi soldiers during the Persian Gulf war.
 Yet analysts said OPEC was worried that Kuwait soon would pump too much oil into a slowly improving global market. The other OPEC ministers are looking for a pledge from the Kuwaitis in Vienna to halt expansion projects temporarily in exchange for a deal to keep exports near two million barrels a day.
Mr. Sultan apparently signaled in his remarks that the Kuwaitis may resist. He said the Kuwaiti oil industry must increase its "spare" capacity to higher levels to generate revenue for rebuilding the war-torn country, although he added that it was unclear how much more was needed. Kuwait produced as many as 3.7 million barrels of oil in the 1970's.
Bernard J. Picchi, senior oil analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, said oil prices would fall if Kuwait was not part of an OPEC deal. "If Kuwait is not brought into the quotas, there will be a real lack of market confidence in any OPEC agreement."
 
'Too Many Producers'
 Philip K. Verleger Jr., a visiting fellow and energy economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said that OPEC was unlikely to keep any agreement for long. "There are too many producers competing for market share," he said. "They can't do it."
In his speech today, Mr. Nazer of Saudi Arabia said the policies favored by environmentalists were "alarming" and that the oil industry had been unfairly singled out as the "culprit" of ecological disorder. He said energy taxes anywhere in the world would blunt the economic development needed to lift more than a billion people from poverty.
"Abject poverty is indeed the worst environmental pollutant facing mankind," he said. "There is no need to rush into costly policies. I cannot think of any means to bring about global economic development without the use of energy, especially oil."

HEADLINE: Random House Closing a Division

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN

 BODY:
Random House Inc. said yesterday that it was closing its troubled Turtle Bay Books division, which was started just over two years ago by Joni Evans, the former publisher of the Random House adult trade division.
As a result, Ms. Evans ended her often-turbulent five-year relationship with the New York publishing giant. 
 Turtle Bay, which from the beginning has been very much Ms. Evans's project, failed to produce any national best sellers or to meet its operating costs, despite a list of authors that includes several who have been successful.
 
Swan Song This Spring
 Alberto Vitale, the chairman and chief executive of Random House, said yesterday that a "difficult publishing environment" doomed the efforts of Ms. Evans and her staff, and that it was now necessary to discontinue operations after the division's spring 1993 books come out.
Ms. Evans deplored the decision to close Turtle Bay, but said she preferred that to the severe scaling back of operations that Mr. Vitale had initially suggested.
"I'm very disappointed in what I think is an abrupt and premature decision," she said. "I want to maintain good relations with Random House and to possibly work with them again, but when I put my all into something and feel I collected the best talent, and then have it prematurely taken away, it makes me want to look around at other opportunities elsewhere."
She also said she had turned down an offer by Mr. Vitale of another position within Random House.
Ms. Evans, who is 50, was recruited in 1987 after the breakup of her marriage to Richard E. Snyder, the chairman of the rival Simon & Schuster, where she had been head of the trade book division. She was hired by Robert L. Bernstein, Mr. Vitale's highly regarded predecessor at Random House's helm.
 
Rose Rapidly
 Random House had hired Ms. Evans to start her own imprint, but within six weeks she was named publisher of the adult trade division, the country's largest publisher of general-interest books.
But in October 1990, she was replaced by Harold Evans -- who is no relation -- after a tenure that mixed visible successes and failures. The following January, with considerable fanfare, she began Turtle Bay.
There has been speculation in the publishing industry over the last couple of weeks that Turtle Bay was in trouble, though few predicted that it would be dissolved this quickly. People close to Ms. Evans thought that it would be given at least until the end of the year to prove itself.
In its size, operations, even its selection of material, Turtle Bay established itself as a boutique publishing house. It was based in a town house in the Turtle Bay section of Manhattan in the East 40's, away from other Random House operations.
Ms. Evans and two former Random House editors who worked with her, Susan Kamil and Julie Grau, reveled in Turtle Bay's nearly all-female staff and its collegial atmosphere. No one held an official title, and editorial sessions were casual.
 
Well-Established Writers
 The three editors were able to bring 20 authors or so with them from Random House. These included some established writers and some celebrities -- among them, A. S. Byatt, Carol Matthau, Ann Beattie, Julia Phillips, Geoffrey Wolff, Michael Caine, Joan Rivers and Erica Jong.
Some Turtle Bay books were well reviewed and some, Ms. Evans said, were profitable. But the division left an impression in the industry of consistently falling short of expectations.
For example, Michael Caine's autobiography, "What's It All About?", was bought for a reported $750,000, and, Ms. Evans said without confirming the amount, "it well earned its advance" with 130,000 copies in print.
But despite an extensive and elaborate promotion and advertising campaign, the book failed to make the best-seller lists of The New York Times or Publishers Weekly, widely regarded as the two most important national rankings. It did make some regional best-seller lists.
Ms. Evans and Mr. Vitale said they started talking several weeks ago about Turtle Bay's future. They said Mr. Vitale wanted to make its lists smaller and to lower its expenses.
But Ms. Evans said such a "scaling down" was intolerable to her.
"It became clear that we had different philosophies," she said. "I always considered this as a long-term process, that it would be three to four years before we broke even, and I thought he did, too. But somewhere along the way, the landscape changed. Alberto thought it it was a tough economic time and the scale-down was necessary. I didn't see it that way. I wanted to have the time I thought I had."
 
Changing Realities
 Mr. Vitale said he did not renege on any agreement with Ms. Evans to give Turtle Bay a certain amount of time to develop, but he conceded that "conditions have changed since the decision" to start the line.
"The reality," he said in a statement, "is that the birth of Turtle Bay coincided with a period of surging competitiveness and streamlining throughout the publishing industry, a reality that now makes it necessary and prudent for us to take this step."
Mr. Vitale said all the writers under contract with Turtle Bay would be consulted and, with their approval, would be placed with editors at other Random House divisions. He said he hoped that Ms. Grau would remain with the company, but that he did not expect Ms. Kamil to.
The three other Turtle Bay employees, lower level assistants, would also be absorbed by the company, he said.
Other publishers agreed that the current climate in the industry was less tan hospitable, and several said that the 18 books Turtle Bay had published did not perform well enough to merit further investment in a floundering division.
Figures on what Turtle Bay had cost Random House could not be immediately obtained because Random House's parent, Advance Publications Inc., the Newhouse family company, is privately held and officials were not providing information.
In all, Turtle Bay had more than 50 books under contract.
Jack Romanos, who is president of Paramount Publishing's consumer group, a Random House competitor, said, "A large imprint like this, that really operates as a small company within a large company, must be instantly successful in this publishing environment."
Turtle Bay, he added, was without any apparent commercial success or a flagship author, "and the absence of those two factors obviously had to contribute to this decision."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joni Evans, whose Turtle Bay Books has been closed by its parent company, Random House Inc., after operating for two years. (Fred R. Conrad for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: And Now, Let Your Lips Do The Dialing

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In one of the most significant advances for telephone customers since touch-tone dialing, people will soon be able to dial a telephone number by speaking the name of whomever they are calling.
The voice service would allow each member of a household to compile a separate voice directory of dozens of names. When a wife says "Mom," the phone will recognize only her voice and call her mother; when her child says "Mom," the phone will call only his mother. 
 The system comes from the Nynex Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest local telephone company and the parent of New York Telephone and New England Telephone. Nynex said yesterday that it would soon begin testing the service, which it calls Voice Dialing, on March 15 for 400 customers in Bay Shore, L.I.
 
Expected to Spread
 U S West, another of the big regional phone companies, has licensed the Nynex technology and is already conducting a small market test of the service. Other phone companies are expected to follow.
Nynex said that the service would be offered in Manhattan in 1994 and that within two years it hoped to install the service for 7 million of its 12 million customers. Voice Dialing works on existing telephones and does not require customers to buy additional equipment. For the phone company, too, the technology also primarily uses equipment already installed in its central offices.
Voice Dialing is expected to cost $4 to $6 a month, and Nynex said it would be offered first in areas where there is heavy demand for call-waiting, call-forwarding and similar services. Nynex plans to file for approval from New York and New England state regulators later this year.
As with all new technologies, there are pitfalls. Nynex officials acknowledged that identical twins could use each other's Voice Dialing directory or that on a good day the impressionist Dana Carvey might be able to activate George Bush's directory.
The Sprint Corporation and other long-distance companies are working on what are known as voice-verification systems, which would allow calling-card customers to dial by voice rather than punch in lengthy access codes. But those systems would need to be more discriminating than Voice Dialing, in order to prevent criminals from using stolen cards.
In setting up a Voice Dialing directory, a customer dials a special access code, like *99, recites a name two or more times, then punches in a telephone number. Afterward, the customer picks up the phone, waits for a beep, then says the name. The phone dials the number automatically -- and will do so in the future each time the person speaks the name. Or at any time, the customer can dial manually.
 
No Estimate of Cost
 "And you don't need a thick instruction manual to use it," said Casimir Skrzypczak (pronounced SKRIP-sack), president of Nynex Science and Technology, the company's research unit.
Elizabeth Ricci, a Nynex spokeswoman, declined to estimate how much the company would invest in the project.
The technology, which has been under development since 1987, works like this: A customer says "Casimir Skrzypcsak" into the telephone, which is a microphone. A Nynex computer listening at the other end of the line turns the sound into a unique string of computer-code digits, defined by 22 parameters like the caller's pitch, intonation and speed.
The customer then dials Mr. Skrzypcsak's number, 555-1234, which the computer also turns into computer code, or digitizes. For computer purposes, the first set of coded digits -- the name -- is now equivalent in meaning to the second set of digits, the phone number.
The reason that Voice Dialing is so easy to use and is available in 10 languages is that the words themselves do not matter. Indeed, in a White Plains market test in 1990, a young boy taught the Voice Dialing system to recognize his dog's barks.
 
Not All Voice Systems Are Alike
 Voice Dialing differs from other voice-recognition technologies that have other purposes.
The long-distance company American Telephone and Telegraph, for example, has installed voice-recognition technology to replace some human long-distance operators; computers search a caller's sentence for certain key words, like "France," for example, by way of determining which menu of services to offer the customer. In Nynex's Voice Dialing, callers use isolated words rather than sentences.
Nynex sees Voice Dialing as leading to more efficient use of its networks. In regular touch-tone calling, people misdial 15 out of 100 times, company research has found. In Voice Dialing, Nynex officials said, the system will make a mistake 5 out of 100 times on the first try, and only 1 out of 100 on the second.
A voice dial is also as fast or faster than touch-tone or rotary dialing, depending on how quickly one speaks.
And unlike a technology that is linked to a particular piece of equipment, the case with personal computers or voice-operated programmers for VCR's, Voice Dialing can be used on any phone connected to a household or business line.
 
Prospects and Limitations
 In the future, the Nynex service may also work with what are known as screen-based phones and thus make voice mail and other services easier to use, said Sharad Singhal, director of speech recognition applications at Bellcore, the research arm of the regional Bell companies. For example, it may someday be possible to simply say, "Toys 'R' Us" and have the phone tap into a store's computer and display a list of toys on sale that day.
But Peter L. Hampton, director of consumer applications at the Yankee Group, a high-tech consulting firm in Boston, suggested that Nynex might have been smarter to introduce the service for car-phone users, where hands-free application would obviously make sense. At home, he said, customers may be more skeptical.
Although Nynex has no current plans to offer Voice Dialing for cellular customers, company officials said there were no technical hurdles to doing so.
 
A Way to Increase Traffic
 For Nynex and other phone companies, services like Voice Dialing are important contributors to revenue, which has grown relatively little during the recession. Nynex's 1992 revenue dropped last year, to $13.16 billion from $13.23 billion in 1991.
Moreover, phone companies have been vastly expanding capacity for local, domestic long-distance and international long-distance lines. To prevent a glut of capacity, companies must encourage customers to make more calls and fill the expanding pipelines.
Making phoning easier -- simple enough for children and dogs -- would seem to be one way of doing that.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New York Sues to Halt Kraft's Cereal Deal

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
Kraft General Foods' $450 million acquisition of Nabisco cereals was challenged on antitrust grounds by New York State yesterday.
The state's lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, seeks a preliminary injunction to halt the merger and have Kraft and its parent company, the Philip Morris Companies, barred from acquiring any company that makes cold cereals for 10 years. 
 The Nabisco acquisition was completed on Jan. 4 after the Federal Trade Commission had reviewed the transaction and found no objections, Kraft said in a statement. A similar offer to acquire Nabisco's cereals in 1992 was withdrawn by General Mills Inc. after F.T.C. regulators and Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General, raised antitrust questions.
 
 
Kraft to Fight Suit
 Kraft called the lawsuit "completely without merit" and said it would fight it. Mr. Abrams said the suit was filed yesterday because his office had only recently received documents requested from the two companies. Mr. Abrams said the companies were informed on Monday that the suit would proceed.
According to papers filed with the suit, the Kraft-Nabisco merger has allowed Post to improve its market share, to 14.49 percent from 11.52 percent. The deal also has put the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation out of the cold cereal business.
Kraft, which makes Post cereals, like Grape Nuts, Raisin Bran and Honey Bunches of Oats, is the country's third-largest producer of cold cereals behind the Kellogg Company and General Mills Inc.
The top six companies last year, which had included Nabisco, the sixth largest, as well as the Quaker Oats Company and the Ralston Purina Company, had about 90 percent of the industry's $7 billion in sales.
"This is a highly concentrated market," Mr. Abrams said at yesterday's announcement of the filing of the suit. "Going from six major companies to five makes further concentration. The last thing this industry needs is less competition."
Mr. Abrams stood beside several boxes of cereals and complained that their prices "are going through the roof."
In court papers, Mr. Abrams contended that the six leading companies, before the merger, had created a "tight oligopoly." He also charged that they had engaged in little price competition and that "the firms enjoyed unusually high profits."
He cited statistics, provided for his office by an agricultural economist at the University of Connecticut, Ronald W. Cotterill, that showed prices of cereals had risen 71 percent, compared with a 37 percent increase in overall food prices, in an eight-year period through 1991.
"That's a dramatic difference," Mr. Abrams said.
 
Some Are Surprised
 The lawsuit surprised some in the industry.
A spokesman for RJR Nabisco, Jason Wright, said his company was "somewhat surprised, if not baffled" at the lawsuit, noting the F.T.C.'s apparent approval. A spokesman for the F.T.C. declined to comment.
Ronald B. Morrow, an industry analyst for the Smith Barney, Harris Upham Company, said he was "shocked" to learn of the Attorney General's action and suggested that if Mr. Abrams were truly concerned about high prices, "he would go after the price leaders," Kellogg and General Mills.
Mr. Morrow also noted Nabisco's reduced market share, which, according to Mr. Cotterill's figures, fell to 2.97 percent, from 4.86 percent in 1990, and said the merger might help increase competition.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Attorney General Robert Abrams, who is challenging Kraft General Foods' acquisition of Nabisco cereals on antitrust grounds. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Stocks Edge Ahead, But Dow Slips by 2.16

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market moved slightly higher yesterday, although several of the large blue-chip issues were weak. As a result, the Dow Jones industrial fell for the third consecutive day.
Most of the weakness came as stocks responded to sharp losses in bonds, following a disappointing 10-year note auction by the Treasury. The third and last leg of the refunding will take place today with the auction of a new 30-year bond. 
 Blue-chip issues, down marginally for most of the trading session, slipped further in late afternoon following news about the auction and a surge in interest rates. The Dow ended the day down 2.16 points, to 3,412.42. At one point during the session, the Dow slipped below 3,400 before recovering.
Among the Dow stocks that fell were Eastman Kodak, down 1 3/4, to 52; United Technologies, down 2, to 45 5/8, and I.B.M., down 1 1/8, to 52 1/4.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 251.9 million shares, up only slightly from Tuesday, suggesting that an orderly market pullback was taking place.
Gainers on the Big Board led losing issues by 952 to 873.
Other market indicators were slightly higher.
 
Nasdaq Index Gains
 The Nasdaq composite index gained 2.81 points to finish at 695.02 on the strength of Intel, up 4, to 114 1/2, and other semiconductor stocks, including biostocks like Biogen up 5/8, to 34 5/8, and Amgen, up 2 3/8, to 54 3/4.
"The stock market gave a good account of itself considering the bond market took it on the chin," said Lawrence Rice, chief market strategist at Josepthal Lyon & Ross. The fact that it was able to bounce back, he said, continues a trend since 1987, which is to buy on the first dip.
"Anytime you have a small correction, it opens up buying opportunities," Mr. Rice said. "There was good breadth in the market, with a lot of money going back into over-the-counter stocks. Drug stocks were good buy as we approach the next week's State of the Union address, by which time there shouldn't be any new surprises regarding health care.
"I saw a lot of bottom fishing in pharmaceuticals and selected large biotech companies. With all the rotating in the market, came increased volatility in the averages and individual stocks, particularly in the gaming group."
Caesars World closed at 46, up 2, but was as low as 43 3/4 on the day, while Mirage Resorts, up 1, to 39 3/4, traded down to 37 at one point.
Informix, a California software company, which earlier this week reported a rise in fourth-quarter earnings to 67 cents a share from 27 cents, saw its stock fall 2 1/4, to 34 1/2 yesterday. A number were concerned that 1993 income may not increase at the same rate as last year.
The Atlas Corporation, which mines gold in Nevada, lost almost half its value yesterday after the company said it expects to report a second-quarter loss of $3.6 million from operations. The company, which commissioned an independent operations audit last month, said the preliminary data indicated that the company will have serious financial difficulties in the near term unless it raises additional working capital.
Shares of American Dental Laser, a maker of dental products, rose 3/4, to 6 1/2. The company said a Japanese manufacturer was willing to pay $3 million in royalties for the rights to make its KCP 2000, a device that uses a jet stream of tiny particles to prepare teeth for fillings.
Dell Computer was down 2 5/8, to 36 1/2, after the mail-order personal computer maker cut prices an average 8.7 percent across its product line Tuesday amid signs of thinning demand.
In Japan yesterday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 67.63 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 17,089.90. The Tokyo market will be closed today for a holiday, National Founding Day.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Corporate Green Warrior;
Sun Oil Takes Environmental Pledge

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Valdez Principles, a code of corporate environmental conduct devised after the 1989 Alaskan oil spill, won its first major corporate endorsement yesterday. And the company that signed on is an oil company.
The Sun Company of Philadelphia, the 12th-largest oil company in the United States, became the first Fortune 500 company to endorse the principles. Fifty smaller companies have already backed them. 
 In May, a resolution endorsing the principles was submitted at the company's shareholder meeting by the New York City pension system but drew just 6 percent support. After the vote, though, management met with the principles' backers and worked out a compromise.
Sun negotiated various "adaptations" of the principles to fit its business. For example, the first of the 10 principles, protection of the biosphere, says, "We will reduce and make continual progress toward eliminating the release of any substance that may cause environmental damage to the air, water, or the earth or its inhabitants." Some environmentalists would say that includes the pollutants that are released when Sun's gasoline is burned, as well as the carbon dioxide that adds to global warming. and is released when Sun's gasoline is burned.
In the statement adopted by Sun, the company says, "We will reduce our overall emissions to the environment (air, water and land) with special emphasis on toxic substances."
"This is not a commitment to go out of the petrochemical business or the fuels business," Sun's chairman and chief executive, Robert H. Campbell, said at a ceremony in New York yesterday. But, he said, there was "tremendous philosophical congruence" between what Sun was already doing and the environmental principles. He said, though, that he did not foresee major changes in company operations.
The principles were renamed last year and now known as Ceres, for Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies. Joan Bavaria, co-chairwoman of Ceres, said discussions were continuing with other oil companies. Exxon is not among them, she said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Generally Advances; Gold Prices Climb Sharply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued to advance yesterday against most major currencies in anticipation of favorable American economic data and a weakening German economy. But it again lost ground against the Japanese yen.
Gold prices rose sharply. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $333.40 an ounce, up $4 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $3.50 an ounce, to a late bid price of $331.80. 
 Analysts said the dollar drew strength from comments by German officials who downgraded their economic outlook for this year. Gunter Rexrodt, Germany's Economics Minister, predicted his country's gross domestic product would decline by half a percent this year, and a separate Government report predicted a stagnant economy.
A weak German economy makes the nation's central bank more inclined to keep interest rates low, which makes yields on United States securities more attractive by comparison.
Also supporting the dollar are expectations that today's report on January retail sales will be better than expected, said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
 
Yen Strengthens
 In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 121.52 yen, down 0.83 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at a higher rate of 120.93 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 121.15 yen, down from 121.275 yen on Tuesday.
The yen has gained strength in recent days amid increasing pressure on Japan to reduce its trade surplus. A strong yen makes American goods cheaper for the Japanese.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4263, from $1.4312 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.4255 to buy one pound, less than Tuesday's $1.43025.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6595 German marks, up from 1.65425; 1.5370 Swiss francs, up from 1.5315; 5.6135 French francs, up from 5.6020; 1,548.25 Italian lire, up from 1,528.00, and 1.26465 Canadian dollars, down from 1.26775.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6555 German marks, up from 1.6516; 1.5340 Swiss francs, up from 1.5279; 5.6030 French francs, up from 5.5935; 1.8625 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8591; 1,542.25 Italian lire, up from 1,525.50, and 1.2658 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2675.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Lower But Taxables Change Little

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were mixed in the latest week.
The current survey of tax-exempt money market funds by IBC/Donohue's Money Fund Report showed that tax-exempt yields fell sharply for the seven-day period ended Tuesday, largely because of a sharp inflow of funds after a rise in tax-exempt yields the previous week. 
 Assets of tax-exempt funds rose by $1.5 billion in the period, to $102.5 billion. As more money flowed into the funds, the prices for shares in the funds rose, pushing the yields lower.
 
'A Seesaw Effect'
 "We have had a seesaw effect from week to week in tax-exempt securities," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donohue's. "When yields go up, funds flow in. When yields go down, funds flow out."
Managers of tax-exempt portfolios made only slight adjustments in the week, paring the average number of days left to maturity of securities being held to 53 from 55.
The average seven-day compounded yield for a tax-exempt fund fell 12 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 2 percent, and the average seven-day simple yield fell by a similar amount, to 1.98 percent.
Statisticians for The Money Fund Report calculated that over a 30-day period the compounded tax-exempt yield averaged 1.92 percent, down 7 basis points from the previous week. The 30-day simple yield fell a similar amount, to 1.90 percent.
From its survey of tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million, The Money Fund Report said the best performer for the week was the Evergreen Tax Exempt Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 2.71 percent. The fund is distributed by Evergreen Asset Management in Purchase, N.Y.
 
Taxable Funds
 Meanwhile, for the seven-day period ended yesterday, assets of taxable money market funds rose $7.3 billion, to $487.5 billion.
Institutional assets increased $6.7 billion in the period, to $177.9 billion, accounting for most of the rise.
Average days left to maturities of securities in money market portfolios remained unchanged at 61. The fact that maturities remain abnormally long suggests that portfolio managers are not expecting any imminent move in short-term interest rates, analysts said.
The average seven-day taxable compound yield fell a basis point in the week, to 2.76 percent, while the seven-day simple yield fell a similar amount, to 2.73 percent.
The 30-day compound yield fell 3 basis points, to 2.79 percent, while the 30-day simple yield fell 4 basis points, to 2.75 percent.
For the second consecutive week, the top-performing taxable fund with assets of more than $100 million was the Olde Premium Plus Money Mareket Series, with a seven-day compound yield of 3.60 percent. The fund is distributed by Olde Asset Management Inc. of Detroit.
By comparison, the average yield on bank money market funds was 2.71 percent for the week ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, down 2 basis points from the previous period.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
To raise Federal revenue, reduce those sacred tax preferences.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IT'S simply a matter of arithmetic. To cut the promised $145 billion from the budget deficit without gutting the military or declaring generational war on the Social Security lobby, President Clinton must ask for higher income tax rates on the middle class or float some brand new tax like an energy levy.
Or is it that simple? The White House has apparently not given much consideration to one very alluring route to raising major bucks, slashing revenue-reducing tax preferences -- what economists call "tax expenditures." 
 Preferences ranging from the home mortgage deduction to the tax-deferred status of life insurance savings are defended by well-organized interests. But as Mr. Clinton is surely discovering, there are no easy ways to raise $145 billion. And the armor protecting tax expenditures may be less formidable than first appearances suggest. Consider some lucrative targets:
Fringe Benefits. For many earners, especially well-paid ones, fringes amount to a quarter or more of their compensation. And while there are limits on what employers may dole out tax-free, the big-ticket items have hardly been touched. Treating pension contributions and health insurance premiums as fully taxable income would add a whopping $103 billion to Federal coffers.
That reform might seem as likely as . . . well, the collapse of Communism. Pension contributions represent much of the private savings in America. And Lloyd Bentsen, the new Secretary of the Treasury, spent much of his influence as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee trying to increase savings incentives, not reduce them.
But in these sober times, one could still imagine tighter limits on gold-plated pension perquisites. And in the case of health insurance, a cap on untaxed outlays would dovetail with efforts to make consumers more conscious of what their employers' dollars buy. According to the Congressional Budget Office, limiting a family's tax exemption to the first $4,800 a year of health insurance would raise $28 billion in 1997.
State and Local Taxes. The 1986 Tax Reform Act eliminated the deductibility of sales taxes, but left property and state income tax deductions virtually intact. That suits affluent residents of high-tax states. And it suits conservatives, who want to shift government responsibilities from Washington.
Nonetheless, eliminating the deduction would be a tempting way to raise $44 billion in 1997, and to hit hardest at the rich. The initiative might be made palatable if it were part of a grand bargain on health insurance -- one in which Washington assumed the full costs of care for Medicaid, the 900-pound gorilla of state budgets.
Mortgage Interest. The home mortgage interest deduction may be the most sacred of the tax expenditure cows. But Van Doorn Ooms, the research director of the Committee for Economic Development, points out that it also creates a major distortion in capital markets, increasing incentives to build houses at the expense of productivity-enhancing industrial investment. And, of course, there is the not-so-small matter of revenue forgone: $48 billion in 1997.
Elimination of the interest deduction would, in fact, be more problematic in economic terms than is generally understood. Ideally, argues Eugene Steuerle, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, the interest would remain deductible, but Washington would somehow assess the rental value of owner-occupied housing and tax it -- just as it now taxes the rental income from commercial real estate. And although eliminating the deduction would, on balance, make taxes more progressive, there would be more than a few slips between cup and lip: those with substantial savings could avoid the pain by paying off their mortgages.
Deduction Limits. Limiting deductions to the rate allowed at the lowest tax bracket was proposed in the seminal tax reform plan put forward in the 1980's by two Democrats: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri. The plan, never adopted, retained the most cherished personal deductions, but limited their value to the lowest bracket. A family in the highest tax bracket (today, 31 percent) would thus still have been able to deduct an unlimited amount of interest or charitable donations or state taxes. But the savings would have been computed as if the taxpayer were in the lowest bracket (15 percent). Potential revenues: $63 billion in 1997.
Not everyone is infatuated with this sleight of hand. Mr. Steuerle sees no reason why a person who earns $80,000 and gives $10,000 of it to the United Way should pay more tax than someone who earns $70,000 and gives nothing. Nor is it clear why a family with a $100,000 income and $50,000 in nursing-home bills should be denied a top-bracket deduction. But there is a Solomonesque justice to the approach that Mr. Ooms believes "would make it more salable than a lot of alternatives."
James Poterba, an economist at M.I.T., notes, moreover, that most voters would be left untouched by the change because just 28 percent of all taxpayers itemize deductions -- down from 39 percent in 1985. And by everyone's reckoning, the change would be very progressive, undoing a portion of the shift in income distribution toward the wealthy in the last two decades.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:

Support Declines
To independent film makers short of money, the thought of losing a major sponsor is a nightmare. For the last several years Columbia Tri-Star Home Video (formerly RCA Columbia) has financed the production of dozens of films that won critical acclaim during short theater runs before moving into video stores. This year the company plans to curtail that support. 
 Production money from video companies often goes into genre or exploitation films but seldom finds its way into more ambitious efforts. One such movie backed by Columbia Tri-Star is "The Waterdance," released on tape yesterday. The film, Neal Jimenez and Michael Steinberg's film about paraplegics ("small in scale, it is big in feelings," Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times), was also recently nominated for an Independent Spirit Award as best first feature film.
The annual awards will be presented next month by the Independent Theater Project/West, a group of 2,000 independent producers and directors. Among the other films cited in the nominations are Carl Franklin's "One False Move," Allison Anders's "Gas Food Lodging" and John Sayles's "Passion Fish." All were financed by Columbia Tri-Star Home Video.
Many of the films are the kinds of low-budget productions that are ignored by studio movie divisions but turn into moneymakers on videocassette and in other residual markets in the United States and abroad. Steven Soderbergh's "Sex, Lies and Videotape," released by RCA Columbia in 1990, is a prime example. More recently, such acclaimed films as "One False Move," "Mississippi Masala," "Deep Cover" and "A Midnight Clear," all distributed by Columbia Tri-Star, have done very well as videos.
But the company doesn't plan to back films like "The Waterdance" in such numbers in the future. "The economics of those types of pictures have changed," said W. Patrick Campbell, the president of Columbia Tri-Star Home Video. He cited declining foreign theatrical and television revenues as one reason the films are no longer so profitable.
Mr. Campbell said Columbia Tri-Star and its parent, Sony, would not cut off production funds altogether, but he did not indicate how many films the video company would finance in the future. "There's a way to stay in it, but we have to look at it in a different light," he said.
 
Protests Over a Store
 Televised protests this week over the opening of an adult video store in Chelsea in Manhattan raised an old specter for video dealers. "It's terrible for video's image," said Norman Scherer, a New York dealer. "Stores are highlighted and isolated as pornographers."
That concern isn't shared by Don Rosenberg, the executive vice president of the Video Software Dealers Association. The organization represents 4,000 dealers, 60 percent of whom carry adult films along with other titles.
"In the early 80's, if they heard I was a video dealer, people would ask me for adult titles," Mr. Rosenberg said. "Now if you say video store, people don't think of adult movies."
 
NEW VIDEO RELEASES
 
Death Becomes Her
1992. MCA/Universal. $94.99. Laser disk, $34.98. 1 hour 43 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.
 An eternal-youth potion keeps Madeline Ashton (Meryl Streep) looking great even after death but does nothing for her nasty disposition. Dead or alive, a star has her flanks to protect, primarily from Hollywood colleagues ready to bury her at the first sign of a wrinkle. On the home front, there's an old romantic rival (Goldie Hawn) who has also quaffed the potion and is out to make off with Ashton's husband (Bruce Willis). While the rivalry is grounds for slickly manipulated body parts and other special effects, Robert Zemeckis's film suffers from a screenplay that Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times "is wildly uneven, sometimes as wicked as a fashion-minded fairy tale and at other times unaccountably coarse and flat."
 
Surviving Desire
1992. Fox Lorber. $89.95. 1:26. No rating.
 Characters in the films of Hal Hartley crawl out on long limbs of emotional risk but even while falling never seem to lose their cool. Here, in a film made for the "American Experience" television series, a professor of literature (Martin Donovan) becomes infatuated with an intense young woman (Mary Ward) who is keenly but fleetingly interested in the professor. Round about the couple are an assortment of characters who are adept at Mr. Hartley's penetrating dialogue and "passionate about the idea of love and desire and survival, even while knowing they might very well end up looking ridiculous" (John O'Connor).
 
Lovers
1992. Worldvision. $89.95. 1:45. Spanish with English subtitles. No rating.
 Vicente Aranda's dark, romantic melodrama slyly plays off its setting in the controlled world of Franco's Spain. Discharged from the army, Paco (Jorge Sanz) is scheduled to marry the sweet, frugal Trini (Maribel Verdu) and dutifully settle down as a happy, hard-working member of the middle class. Instead he encounters the voracious Luisa (Victoria Abril), a young widow who teaches him many methods of love as well as a few crooked ways of going nowhere in business. Mr. Aranda views the chaotic developments dispassionately, never burdening events with larger meaning in a "sophisticated and highly accomplished work" (Vincent Canby).
 
Surviving Desire
1992. Fox Lorber. $89.95. 1:26. No rating.
 Characters in the films of Hal Hartley crawl out on long limbs of emotional risk but even while falling never seem to lose their cool. Here, in a film made for the "American Playhouse" television series, a professor of literature (Martin Donovan) becomes infatuated with an intense young woman (Mary Ward) who is keenly but fleetingly interested in the professor. Round about the couple are an assortment of characters who are adept at Mr. Hartley's penetrating dialogue and "passionate about the idea of love and desire and survival, even while knowing they might very well end up looking ridiculous" (John O'Connor).
