HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Peering Into a Dismal 21st Century

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Preparing for the 21st Century
By Paul Kennedy
Illustrated. Random House. $25.
In his previous book, "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers: Economic Change and Military Conflict from 1500 to 2000," Paul Kennedy brought us the bad news that nations rising to supremacy by winning wars tend to get overextended in a way that undermines the source of their wealth, and that the United States is undergoing such a decline. Mr. Kennedy, who teaches history at Yale, didn't think the fall-off necessarily had to end with a crash. He just meant to sound a warning so that leaders could soften the landing. 
 The book set off a debate so lively that conferences had to be organized. At one of them, as Mr. Kennedy explains in his new book, someone got up and told him he should stop worrying about nation-states and start thinking about forces that are "transnational" in nature. Mr. Kennedy did, and "Preparing for the 21st Century" is the penetrating result. In it, the news gets even worse than it was in "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers."
When Mr. Kennedy thought about transnational forces, what first came to mind was the English country curate Thomas Robert Malthus (1766-1834) and his dire observation "that the power of population is indefinitely greater than the power in the earth to produce subsistence for man." Mr. Kennedy reflects that what allowed the British people to escape the fate Malthus predicted for them was first, emigration, second, the improvements in British farming that eventually constituted the Agricultural Revolution and third, the Industrial Revolution. Mr. Kennedy adds that a fourth solution had been suggested by earlier events in revolutionary France, "namely, internal unrest followed by external aggression."
Mr. Kennedy then writes, "Those same interrelated issues -- overpopulation, pressure upon the land, migration and social instability, on the one hand, and technology's power both to increase productivity and to displace traditional occupations, on the other -- still confront us today, with greater force than ever." The difference is the increased intensity of the problems now compared with the late 18th century.
Population is exploding, especially in the so-called developing regions of the world, Mr. Kennedy points out. According to the World Bank's calculations, there may be as many as 11 billion people on the earth by the second half of the 21st century. But the forces that saved humankind from a Malthusian fate, while still in effect, are likely to have more ambiguous consequences.
The poorer people of the world can still migrate but are less likely to be welcome wherever conditions are more promising. Biotechnological innovation will doubtless revolutionize agricultural productivity, but it "could lead to further tensions over agricultural trade, as food exporting countries like Australia and the United States find that their produce, while needed by developing countries unable to pay for it, is not required by rich nations increasingly able to create their own biotech substitutes at home."
Robotics and automation are on the verge of creating a new industrial revolution, Mr. Kennedy predicts. But while the resulting boost in productivity will benefit countries with a shortage of labor, like Japan, it will hurt countries with large pools of cheap, unskilled workers.
To complicate matters further, he argues, the rise of multi-national corporations is blurring the meaning of nation-states. Employing mainly manipulators of information, or "symbolic analysts," as Robert Reich has called them, these extraterritorial companies are likely to widen the gap between the haves and have-nots.
And on top of everything else, there is the environmental crisis to worry about: the pollution of the air; the depletion of water, forests and natural resources, and what the author regards as the inevitable heating of the planet's atmosphere through the greenhouse effect. While Mr. Kennedy's vision has a far-reaching sweep, it does not make for encouraging reading.
After reviewing these potential problems, the author turns his attention to "regional impacts," or the varying abilities of different parts of the world to cope. In chapters called "The Japanese 'Plan' for a Post-2000 World," "India and China," "Winners and Losers in the Developing World," "The Erstwhile U.S.S.R. and Its Crumbled Empire," "Europe and the Future" and "The American Dilemma," he analyzes the vulnerabilities of these various nations that are likely to make matters even worse.
Intended as "a guide to understanding global changes," not "as a technical primer for responses to them," "Preparing for the 21st Century" does not assess in detail the planet's chances of surviving. Still, the book's impact is crushing. Mr. Kennedy writes near the end: "It is inconceivable that the earth can sustain a population of 10 billion people devouring resources at the rate enjoyed by richer societies today -- or at even half that rate. Well before total world population reaches that level, irreparable damage to forests, water supplies and animal and plant species will have occurred, and many environmental thresholds may have been breached." When you come to the end, you are so depressed you barely have the strength to close the book.
Mr. Kennedy, on the other hand, whistles past the graveyard: "Nothing is certain except that we face innumerable uncertainties; but simply recognizing that fact provides a vital starting point, and is, of course, far better than being blindly unaware of how our world is changing." After all, he points out, even Malthus ended his "Essay on Population" on an upbeat note, allowing for the possibility that humankind could change its ways and avoid the fate predicted for it.
To this Mr. Kennedy adds, "The same is as true today." Yet one of the main points of his book is that what held for Malthus is less true today. Oh, well, maybe a conference can be organized to work things out.

HEADLINE: Connecticut's Strategy: Ingenuity and Investment

SERIES: Peace Penalty: Connecticut's Morning After -- Last of three articles

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Connecticut's struggles to heal its economy and stop the loss of jobs caused by military cutbacks have not turned the tide.
Economists say that while the end of the recession may yet lift the state's other industries, like insurance, banking and real estate, military contractors are unlikely ever again to require the number of workers they needed even five years ago. The implications of that fact resonate through just about every aspect of life in the state.
 
Along With Aid, More Setbacks
 "If you took Connecticut's difficulties and blew them up to the national level, you'd have social revolt in the streets," said Edward J. Deak, a professor of economics at Fairfield University. 
 Government has not given up.
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., for example, has begun one of the boldest efforts in the nation to help industry, including direct investments of state money to help military contractors develop new products. And the state's Congressional delegation is fighting on several fronts to win President Clinton's help, both in preserving weapons programs and in financing conversion efforts.
 
Continuing Layoffs
 Yet every day, it seems, there are more layoffs.
Just last month, Pratt & Whitney, the jet-engine maker, said it would dismiss a third of its Connecticut work force of 20,000 over the next two years. Pratt & Whitney had successfully cut its dependence on military sales to 30 percent of its overall sales, relying instead on a bustling commercial business -- until those orders fell off abruptly because of the airlines' continuing troubles.
 
Staggering, but Coping
 "It's almost like a boxer receiving two body blows," said Paul Getman, managing director of Regional Financial Associates, an economic research firm. Just like Pratt & Whitney, he said, the whole Connecticut economy has been hit from two sides: by military cutbacks and the recession. "They can survive one, but surviving two is very tough -- that's what they've got, two very severe body blows."
 
The Challenge
 Using Old Skills For New Demands
 
 
Unlike the situation in some states with big Air Force or Navy bases, a high proportion of Connecticut's military workers hold manufacturing jobs: skilled, high-technology manufacturing jobs making products for aerospace and undersea warfare. That group of skills is the state's great hope. If it is lost, economic development officials say, a whole segment of Connecticut's future could slip away with it.
Connecticut gave the world the Colt Peacemaker, known as the gun that won the West, and the Nautilus, the world's first nuclear submarine. Connecticut supplied cannons to George Washington, trench mortars to the doughboys of World War I, and M-16 rifles to the troops in Vietnam. Tank engines built in Connecticut drove the mechanized forces of the United States in the war in the Persian Gulf.
Now the race is on to save what can be saved. From the State Legislature, to the local communities that have banded in new alliances, to business executives and workers in plants across the state, the sense of urgency has ignited public debate about where Connecticut goes from here.
There are signals of change, if not outright hope.
"These people are New Englanders, they understand change, they live with the seasons," said John C. Markowicz, president of Sonalysts Inc., a diversified military contractor in Waterford. "People here still believe if you put your shoulder to the wheel, good things will come."
 
State as Venture Capitalist
 The State Department of Economic Development has received national attention for doing what in most states, and certainly in the Federal Government, would be considered taboo: investing taxpayer dollars directly in companies that the state believes are growing in the right direction.
Although only $9 million has been invested so far in three companies, the underlying ideas, and the risks, are large indeed. Just like venture capitalists on Wall Street, the state could make a handsome return on its investments, or lose everything.
"It's industrial policy," said the state's Commissioner of Economic Development, Joseph G. McGee. "We're trying to use these years to change public perception. We're saying that this will take a sustained commitment of Connecticut tax dollars in order to create an alternative industrial base."
"As long as we have winner investments, it's a home run," he said. "As soon as we blow $5 million on a deal that goes bad, all hell's going to break loose."
The state's first direct investments began early last year, with a $3 million infusion of tax money in Textron Lycoming, a military tank-engine maker that was seeking a commercial jet engine contract. Then Pratt & Whitney received $3 million to help re-engineer its aircraft jet engines as gas turbine generators to produce electricity. The Kaman Corporation, a helicopter parts maker just outside Hartford, got $3 million to help it market a new commercial heavy-payload helicopter.
 
A Daunting Crusade
 The state has also issued more than $200 million in loans, loan guarantees, and outright grants to manufacturers that might otherwise have left the state.
But time and time again, small steps forward have been overshadowed by walloping layoffs and plant closings. Even Governor Weicker's boundless optimism has seemed to flag.
Mr. Weicker, who has made a second career of appearing on shop floors around the state, announcing new grants and help for manufacturers, was cornered by reporters at the State Capitol just hours after Pratt & Whitney's most recent layoff announcement. Asked for his reaction, he paused. The silence continued as he stared down, lost in thought, until it seemed he would not speak at all.
"Obviously, first of all, one of sadness," he said, finally.
Other organizations have tried to help. The Naugatuck Valley Project, a nonprofit industrial development group, has helped arrange employee buyouts of some small military-dependent companies that were in danger of closing. In 1991 it induced a team of consulting engineers to work without pay on a plan to turn Textron Lycoming's tank engines into electrical generators that could run on methane gas from landfills. Company officials say the plan is under consideration.
 
Pockets of Job Growth
 Community leaders in southeastern Connecticut, the most military-dependent corner of the state, have banded together to ponder the region's future and decide the distribution of state and Federal grants. The Legislature has turned a corner, passing sweeping changes in how manufacturing is taxed and regulated.
Not all is gloom. Companies like Pfizer, the pharmaceutical company, continue to expand in the state. Tourism has also expanded since the opening last year of the Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino in Ledyard, owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe. And many small companies in fields as diverse as computer-disk manufacturing and biotechnology are growing as well. Exports at some companies have also soared.
But economists say none of those things can drive the Connecticut economy. Wages in tourism are lower than in military work, and the smaller companies, though they might yet grow into giant employers, do not have the weight to ride to the rescue this time around.
 
'A Wake-Up Call'
 And the workers may not be there when those companies do grow. Although the unemployment rate was 7.4 percent in December, only one-tenth of a percentage point above the national December unemployment rate of 7.3 percent, economists say that one explanation may be that there are simply fewer people to count. Connecticut was the only state in the nation to lose population last year, according the Census Bureau. Between July 1, 1991, and July 1 1992, the number of residents shrank by 8,000, or two-tenths of 1 percent.
"Everyone has received a wake-up call within the last two years in Connecticut, and my sense is that there is some initiative that makes me more optimistic than I otherwise would have been," said the Rev. Kevin D. Bean, an Episcopal priest who has studied the military industry and who helped found the Naugatuck Valley Project in the 1980's.
"But the fact is," he added, "the ongoing and inevitable down-sizing of the whole Pentagon procurement system is going to have major impact on communities from East Hartford to Southington, Stratford and Bridgeport."
 
The Strategy
Asking for Help, Relying on Hope
 Connecticut's Democratic-led delegation in Congress waged a guerrilla war last year, calling in enough political debts to push through -- over the objections of President Bush -- approval for a second $2 billion Seawolf submarine to be built in Connecticut.
Now comes the hard part.
Having worked for the election of President Clinton, they face the task of getting the new Administration, however friendly it might seem, to focus on the type of multilayered problems that affect military-dependent areas like Connecticut.
"I haven't seen anything yet that indicates a real strategy," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat who led the Seawolf fight last year. "But at least they're interested in doing it."
The nine-member delegation -- six Democrats and three Republicans -- claims to have its own battle plan, hammered out in weekly meetings: get Connecticut as many military contracts as possible, while pushing for every possible dollar of a $1.8 billion economic conversion and relief fund, passed by Congress and likely to enter the Federal budget pipeline this spring.
 
Competition on All Fronts
 Another track is to push exports, to both military and civilian markets around the world, while fighting off other states with similar aims.
California, for example, has begun an effort to organize its huge delegation in Congress -- one-fifth of the House of Representatives -- to try to get its share, or more, of Federal military contracts and economic conversion aid.
Arizona has begun an aggressive effort to lure military companies, with national advertisements about the benefits of lower taxes and dry desert climates. The pitch has worked. Hamilton Standard, a unit of Hartford-based United Technologies, said late last year it would expand in Mesa, Ariz., where it will manufacture pneumatic valves now made in Windsor Locks.
Mr. Clinton's every utterance is being analyzed. During the campaign, he supported building a second Seawolf. But members of the Connecticut delegation believe the President has not closed the door on building even a third Seawolf.
Comments by Defense Secretary Les Aspin have also inspired vague hopes. Mr. Aspin favors bolstering the Navy's capacity to move troops and cargo by sea. That means more ships, which would probably be built at Newport News, Va., the Navy's main shipbuilding center. But if Virginia gets all that new business, the Pentagon might, out of fairness, shift to Connecticut some of the submarine maintenance work now going to Virginia, or so the thinking goes.
 
More Cooperation
 Military experts also say that Mr. Clinton has shown no inclination to deviate from his campaign promise to concentrate cuts on operational and maintenance accounts in the military budget rather than hardware purchases, a strategy that could favor Connecticut.
But Mr. Aspin's goals of beefing up the Navy's transport capacities could hurt the state, because Connecticut produces few products related to the building or maintenance of surface supply or troop ships.
"Aspin will buy different things than Cheney would," said Gregory A. Bischak, executive director of the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, a nonprofit research group. "Connecticut is not well positioned to get those contracts."
There are signs, however, that the delegation may be at least getting the attention of the military contractors themselves, some of whom in the past have shown little inclination to discuss their affairs.
Officials of United Technologies, for example, said on Wednesday that they had agreed to a meeting next week in Washington with the Congressional delegation to discuss the job cuts at the company's Pratt & Whitney unit, and "whether there are things we can do together to focus attention on the condition of the U.S. aerospace industry."

HEADLINE: Tearing Down the Barricades to the Disabled;
New York City Is Seen as the Proving Ground for a Federal Anti-Discrimination Law

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Federal law bans discrimination against the 43 million Americans with physical or mental impairments and promotes their employment rights and access to places to work, learn and shop. But it doesn't address the question of what to do when a motorized wheelchair short-circuits and catches fire while crossing 34th Street.
What it takes to bring down barriers to the disabled in New York City -- from developing emergency repair service for broken wheelchairs, to revamping subway stations -- gives a glimpse of the broad-scale changes it will take to make the goals of the 1990 Americans with Disabilities Act a reality.
 
New York's Experience
 If history is any guide, the rest of the country will be watching what happens with private and public initiatives here. The Federal law's provisions on access build significantly on New York's experience in the 80's, when the city became a leader in legal action to protect the disabled from discrimination, even using the language of local laws. 
 "The sentiment in Washington was that if regulation worked in New York with the country's largest -- and somewhat aged -- transit system, it would work anywhere," said James Weisman, a counsel for the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association, which sued the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in the mid-80's and secured substantial changes, such as ramps and elevators at major subway stations.
Despite initial skepticism among M.T.A. officials about whether the disabled would ride public transit, the agency's records show that bus chairlifts are used 15,000 times a month. The bus fleet is 91 percent equipped with lifts. In addition, 22 subway stations now have elevators or ramps and renovation of others is planned, said Walter J. Noonan Jr., the authority's officer in charge of compliance with the Federal law.
 
New Subway Cars
 Now the agency is testing new subway cars with special areas for wheelchair users, investigating a Japanese-made escalator that accommodates wheelchairs, and developing individualized service for those unable to use public transportation.
The new career of Denise McQuade, who has spent 41 of her 44 years in a wheelchair, says something about gains by New Yorkers with disabilities -- and about how far they have to go.
On Sept. 30, 1981, Ms. McQuade swung out of her wheelchair and sat stubbornly for seven hours on the steps of an M.T.A. bus in Manhattan until the vehicle's chairlift was lowered so she could roll aboard. Her defiance inspired "Denise and the M.T.A.," a catchy song often performed by an advocacy group for the disabled.
Last month, an exuberant new chorus was added as Ms. McQuade went to work at the M.T.A. Her job: to help the authority, which is responsible for operating 3,600 buses and 6,000 subway cars, to comply with the Federal law.
 
Short-Circuit on 34th St.
 But even as government agencies help barriers fall, other obstacles arise -- like keeping a wheelchair in good operating condition on the mean streets of New York City.
Eileen Healey, board chairman of the Center for Independence of the Disabled, in Manhattan, knows those obstacles first-hand: It was her wheelchair whose motor caught fire on 34th Street.
Potholes are a more everyday menace, said Michael M. McIntyre who travels 75 minutes, by subway and bus, from his home in the Bronx to reach the Queens Independent Living Center, where he is director. The potholes can shake wires loose, leaving a wheelchair immobilized.
"A mechanized chair is a complex piece of machinery which will break, and its user is fortunate if there is a vendor willing to make repairs in a reasonable amount of time," said Ms. Healey. Her center and Mr. McIntyre's have been trying, so far without success, to secure an emergency repair service modeled on automobile clubs.
 
'Hidden Disabilities' Included
 Wheelchair users are the most visible members of the population covered by the Federal law. It also applies to those with visual or hearing losses, psychiatric illnesses and those with a range of "hidden disabilities," from epilepsy, cancer and diabetes to substance abuse.
The people who use wheelchairs and the people who sell and service them both have complaints about the government.
For poor people, the issue is the need for a physician's written prescription, and a guarantee of reimbursement by a government agency, before a new chair or major repair can be obtained -- a procedure that can take months.
And those who can afford to buy chairs themselves have no redress for defective chairs or shoddy repairs, said Ms. Healey. "Wisconsin has a 'lemon law,' but there has been no rush from other states to follow it," she said.
 
Getting to Work
 Vendors, in turn, complain that low reimbursement from Medicaid or Medicare make house calls uneconomic. A few of them hold "wheelchair clinics" at locations such as the International Center for the Disabled, where they make repairs and demonstrate new models.
But even the worry of wheelchair repairs is a luxury to disabled people still struggling to enter the work force.
"It's an old saw but the best social service program is a job," said Chris K. Olander, executive director of the J.M. Foundation, a private organization. "People with disabilities need to secure economic clout and not be tied to a welfare check."
His foundation and 32 other philanthropies created the Funding Partnership for the Disabled, which will give $2 million this year to community organizations to integrate the disabled into society, especially through employment.
 
Agencies See Progress
 Statistics are scarce about employment trends nationwide since the Federal law's adoption, but state agencies see progress.
"We know hundreds -- and there may be thousands -- are finding jobs in spite of the recession, not necessarily leading to careers but simply something to put bread on the table," said Rosemary Lamb in the State Office of the Advocate for the Disabled in Albany.
But in New York, 105,000 to 175,000 people with disabilities are looking for jobs, state agencies estimate. Organizations that place handicapped applicants say the recession has hurt hiring and forced them to shift strategies.
Just One Break in Manhattan, for instance, placed 250 people in jobs in the last year, down 25 percent from the year before. Consequently, said Mikki Lam, its executive director, "we are increasing the number of job rallies we hold, bringing together corporate employers and qualified disabled applicants."
 
Fewer Placed in Jobs
 With assembly line jobs disappearing, the National Center for Disability Services in Albertson, L.I., now focuses more on training for medical or environmental testing laboratories. It placed 300 people last year, also 25 percent fewer than in 1991.
"Still, those 300 people turned into wage earners now earn $4.5 million instead of the Government paying them $2 million in Social Security benefits," said Dr. Edwin Martin, the center's president.
Probably the strongest misgivings about the Federal law came from some business groups that argued that requirements for renovations in buildings could bankrupt small businesses. The objections focused on key but vague provisions in the voluminous act requiring those who own or operate "places of public accommodation," such as restaurants, hotels and shops, to remove architectural barriers if such changes are "readily achievable."
 
Avoiding Litigation
 Such worst-case scenarios have not occurred, said Justin Dart, chairman of the President's Committee on Employment of People with Disabilities.
Six hundred complaints about accessibility have been filed with the Justice Department, but virtually all of these are being negotiated to avoid litigation.
Business groups and disability advocates alike say their strategy is to promote education and negotiation. The Better Business Bureau, for one, is working to bring its 250,000 members together with disability advocates, said Barbara Bode, executive director of the Bureau's Council.
"We're pushing voluntary compliance with the A.D.A.," she said of the Federal law. "And we're finding suddenly business recognizes there are 43 million new customers out there -- that's our line for 1993."
 
No Major Outcries
 The National Federation of Independent Business, representing 600,000 small businesses, has not heard major outcries, said Nelson Litterst, the federation's legislative representative. "It's too early to gauge impact, but we're urging members to utilize services such as Goodwill Industries' offer, without fee, to walk business managers through the workplace and recommend accessibility changes."
Recent studies made for United Cerebral Palsy Associations in 18 cities, including New York, said that, since the law was passed, 76 percent of the businesses surveyed reported making alterations in the workplace like building ramps or purchasing sound-amplifying equipment for the hearing impaired. More than half of the adjustments cost less than $100 apiece.
In New York City, members of Disabled in Action are touring neighborhoods and asking merchants to remove relatively small impediments such as a doorstep at the entrance. Frieda Zames, a mathematics professor who uses a wheelchair, visited 40 locations on Manhattan's East Side to push the "One Step" campaign. "A number complied and told me later they were getting new customers," she said.

LENGTH: 709 words

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Taking the Lead, Timidly

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Finally, the U.S. has accepted a leadership role in the Balkan crisis. That is the main point of the modest diplomatic initiatives unveiled yesterday by Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
Reversing the largely rhetorical and passive stance of the Bush Administration, President Clinton has now committed the U.S. to finding a comprehensive plan to combat the deadly virus of nationalism that threatens to obliterate hope for a new world order. 
 But there should be no illusions about yesterday's presentation. It represents a retreat from Mr. Clinton's promised tough approach. And the fact that Mr. Christopher did the unveiling shows the President does not want to commit himself fully and personally to this enterprise.
Also noteworthy, Mr. Christopher carefully sidestepped calling his offerings a "plan" or even a "policy." And rightly so. What he outlined was, rather, a means to a plan -- if one can be devised with the approval of the U.N., Western European allies, Russia and the warring parties in Bosnia themselves.
With the American military and allies all resisting the use of force, with allies and Russia refusing to arm Bosnian Muslims, with the U.N. digging in against deviations from the Vance-Owen peace plan and with widespread concern that foreign crises will divert energies from domestic priorities, the Christopher approach was probably the most Clinton aides could cobble together now.
At bottom, what Mr. Christopher presented reflected a series of complicated bureaucratic and diplomatic compromises, a tentative and temporizing patchwork that raises more questions than it answers.
First, how will the appointment of a special U.S. envoy avoid transforming a U.N. responsibility into an American responsibility? Such usurpation is wrong for the Bosnian crisis and disastrous for any long-term effort to strengthen the U.N. No effective plan for Bosnia will ever command the necessary international backing unless rooted in the Security Council.
Reginald Bartholomew, the envoy and a first-class pro, will be under great pressure from his superiors to act with or without Cyrus Vance and Lord Owen. But the lead should remain with them and the U.N.
Second, how can Mr. Christopher continue to speak publicly of supporting the Vance-Owen ethnic enclave proposal -- thereby undermining the Administration's own plans to modify it -- when he continues to damn it privately? If Clinton aides believe it is fundamentally flawed, their own efforts merely to modify it make little sense.
My own view is that no negotiated peace will be possible for some time. Bosnian hatreds run too deep. Even if the parties signed an agreement, they would bloody it daily. No peacekeeping force, of 50,000 or 100,000 or whatever, could stop them.
Third, while the Christopher approach thankfully offers to put new teeth into the economic embargo against Serbia, do Administration officials really believe this will compel Belgrade to stop the war, let alone roll back its territorial gains? The currency most appreciated in the Balkans, as elsewhere, is force.
Fourth, does Mr. Christopher's dance around the central issue of threatening and using force mean the U.S. will not prompt discussions of force for months to come? To be sure, he spoke of unspecified U.S. military involvement to enforce a treaty agreed to by all parties. He also alluded to the possible use of U.S. troops to help humanitarian deliveries. But these measures barely scratch the surface of what will be needed.
In my opinion, only the prospect of the West intervening and/or arming Croats and Bosnian Muslims can stun the Serbs into stopping. I know well the fears, difficulties and dangers in this course. But I am equally convinced that limited military means can be found to send the necessary messages and protect population centers and aid deliveries -- means and manpower far less than the 100,000 troops that will be needed to police any "negotiated" settlement.
European leaders know the futility of diplomacy without force. But rather than risk using force, they are prepared to accept the strategic and moral consequences of ethnic cleansing. Mr. Clinton, now that he has edged toward the Balkan inferno, must live up to American values.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: All Aboard the Economic Recovery Flier

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The merits of rail transportation, substantial compared with highways, have been overlooked in coverage of President Clinton's strategy of infrastructure investment for economic recovery. Our dependence on road transport exemplifies the inefficient use of resources in the United States. 
 Rail transport requires half the energy to carry a given number of people, needs one-eighth the space road transportation needs and costs one-sixteenth as much. Because rail can transport more people to a place, buildings can be built taller and less spread out, and the need for private parking is drastically reduced.
The research of David Alan Aschauer, an economist at Bates College, shows the net benefits of railroad investment are twice as large as highway investment and accrue positive results three times faster.
More than 72 percent of Americans support increased investment in public transportation options.
Budget makers in state houses and city halls should also redirect transportation investment from highways to railroads.
 
DANIEL CONVISSOR
Board Member
Transportation Alternatives
New York, Jan. 28, 1993

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Lost $7.4 Billion Last Year

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 10

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company posted an $840.3 million fourth-quarter loss today and a $7.4 billion loss for the year, largely reflecting accounting changes and one-time charges against earnings.
Without the special charges, however, Ford's yearly results were an improvement over 1991, when the nation's No. 2 auto maker also posted huge losses. 
 Still, Ford's loss was the largest ever reported by an American company, exceeding the record $5 billion annual loss posted by I.B.M. last month. On Thursday, however, the General Motors Corporation will break the record again. It is expected to report a 1992 loss estimated at $24 billion, also mostly caused by the changes in accounting standards.
Ford's yearly loss came on revenue of $100.1 billion and compared with a $2.3 billion loss in 1991 on revenue of $88.3 billion. An accounting change for retiree health benefits caused a one-time charge against 1992 earnings of $7.5 billion, and a new accounting standard for income tax resulted in a credit of $657 million. Excluding these changes, Ford lost $502 million for the year.
The loss in the fourth quarter of 1992 came on revenue of $25.4 billion and compared with a loss of $476 million in the fourth quarter of 1991 on revenue of $22 billion. The loss in the 1992 quarter included charges of $105 million for the accounting change and $419 million for a restructuring in Europe.
"We've had a big improvement in operating results from last year," said David N. McCammon, vice president for finance. He prediced that 1993 would be profitable.
Harold A. Poling, Ford's chairman, said in a statement, "We were encouraged by the substantial improvement in the profitability of U.S. automotive operations and a record profit from the financial services group." He blamed the recession in Europe for the company's poor financial results there.
Wall Street found encouragement in Ford's results, and the stock rose 87.5 cents today, to $49.75 on the Big Board.
Ford's worldwide automotive operations, excluding the accounting changes, lost $1.5 billion last year, compared with $3.2 billion in 1991. The company said it lost $405 million in American automotive operations and $1.1 billion in foreign auto operations in 1992.
Profits from financial services in the fourth quarter were $196.6 million, a drop from $236.6 million last year. But for 1992, financial services earned $1.03 billion, excluding accounting changes, up from $927.5 million in 1991. Ford's financial services consist of the Ford Motor Credit Company; the Associates, a consumer finance company, and First Nationwide savings and loans.
David Healy, automotive analyst for S. G. Warburg & Company in New York, said Ford's fourth-quarter operating loss, minus the accounting changes, was about a third greater than he had predicted because of large reserves to cover car warranties and other unexpected items. Another analysts saw problems ahead.
"Ford's gross profit margin actually declined in the fourth quarter" on a 24 percent increase in volume, said Wendy Needham of Smith Barney, Harris Upham in New York. Costs associated with the race between the Ford Taurus and Honda Accord for the leadership in car sales had contributed to the erosion of profit margin, she said.
With auto demand in the United States gaining strength and Ford preparing to introduce a promising new midsize car, the Mondeo, in Europe, 1993 will be profitable, Mr. McCammon, the Ford vice president, said.
But Europe's economy remains doubtful. Ford expects sales on the Continent to drop to 13.7 million vehicles this year, compared with 14.9 million last year. Ford is forecasting sales of 13.5 million cars and trucks in the United States this year, up from 13.1 million last year.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 12, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A table in Business Day yesterday showing the Ford Motor Company's quarterly earnings provided incomplete data. The results for the first three quarters of 1992 should have been adjusted for the effects of accounting changes and extraordinary charges announced on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: TAIWANESE NAMED ISLAND'S PREMIER

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Taiwan's provincial Governor, Lien Chan, was nominated to be Prime Minister today, marking a major shift of power in the ruling Nationalist Party in the wake of democratic reforms.
President Lee Teng-hui nominated Mr. Lien at a meeting of the party's 31-member Central Standing Committee, which approved the decision. Parliament is scheduled to vote on Mr. Lien's confirmation this month. 
 Prime Minister Hau Pei-tsun, 73, a conservative Nationalist leader accused by the opposition of blocking democratic reforms, was forced to resign last week after losing a fierce battle between liberal and conservative factions in the ruling party.
Mr. Lien, 56, a liberal politician who heads the provincial government apparatus, would be the first member of the island's native Taiwanese majority to become Prime Minister. Mr. Hau and his predecessors were born in China and fled to Taiwan after Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Government lost the civil war to the Communists in 1949.
Democratic reforms that began with the lifting of martial law in 1987 are gradually shifting power into the hands of native Taiwanese. President Lee became the island's first native President in 1988.
 
Vows His Loyalty
 Mr. Lien, in a gesture of reconciliation toward the conservatives, said after his nomination that he would "loyally follow in Premier Hau's footsteps.'
Mr. Lien is expected to support President Lee's policies of democratic reform and the use of Taiwan's economic power to break out of the international isolation caused by its diplomatic rivalry with the Beijing Government.
He has affirmed his commitment to the ruling party's official goal of reunification with China, although many native Taiwanese leaders place less emphasis on this goal than do mainland Chinese like Prime Minister Hau.
Mr. Lien was Foreign Minister from 1988 to 1990 and has served as Vice Prime Minister, Communications Minister and deputy secretary general of the Nationalist Party.
He holds a doctorate in political science from the University of Chicago and was an assistant professor at the University of Wisconsin and the University of Connecticut in the 1960's. He comes from one of Taiwan's wealthiest families and is a millionaire.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 6, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article by Reuters on Feb. 11 about the nomination of the Provincial Governor of Taiwan, Lien Chan, to be Prime Minister referred to his background imprecisely. Although he is considered part of the native Taiwanese majority because his ancestors were born in Taiwan, he was born in mainland China and moved to Taiwan as a child.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed as Investors Await Trade Talk Resolution

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against other leading currencies in light, technically driven trading yesterday as investors awaited the outcome of a standoff in trade talks between the United States and Japan.
Gold prices fell in New York after rising in Europe. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery, the most actively traded futures contract, lost $2, settling at $383.70 an ounce. 
 The dollar settled into a narrow range against the Japanese yen as traders awaited news on bilateral talks to narrow the nearly $60 billion United States trade deficit with Japan. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 108.30 yen, unchanged from Wednesday.
Japan's Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, is scheduled to meet President Clinton in Washington today. Mr. Clinton had set today as a deadline for reaching agreements to further open the Japanese market to American products.
"At this stage, the market's very undecided about what's going to happen," said Brian Halligan, yen trader at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. in New York. "Everyone's reading headlines and just reacting."
 
Sanctions Possible
 In recent weeks, the dollar has fallen against the yen on suspicion that the United States Government might try to drive up the Japanese currency to force the trade gap to shrink. But traders said yesterday that the United States Government might instead impose sanctions if the trade talks failed.
Sanctions could further batter the ailing Japanese economy and hurt the yen.
The dollar fell against the German mark after failing to top the 1.7650-mark level. The dollar's drop from the 1.7560-mark level, to 1.7530 marks, was "a very quick and violent move," as it set off prearranged orders to sell dollars, said Matt Porio, a vice president of Chase Manhattan.
The market was also awaiting the release today of the Producer Price Index for January from the Government.
"This is kind of critical because of all the inflation chatter going on," said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at Mellon Bank. An unexpected surge in inflation at the producer level could point to higher interest rates, thus strengthening the dollar.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADERS URGED BY CLINTON TO BACK TAX PLAN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton told business executives and their lobbyists face to face today that next week he would propose an increase in the top corporate income tax rate and a limit on the tax breaks that companies could take for their executives' salaries.
The proposals themselves were not completely new, but this was the first time since Mr. Clinton took office -- and probably the first time since he began his campaign -- that he had looked people in the eye and told them in public that they would have to give up something specific for the sake of reducing the Federal budget deficit. Until now, Mr. Clinton has only spoken generally about shared sacrifice. 
 "I need your support and your contribution," the President told about 200 business executives and their Washington lobbyists whom he had invited to the White House. "Everyone will have to pay their fair share. But if you do, we will all be better off, and the business community will be stronger in the years ahead."
 
Attack on 'Excessive Pay'
 He said that the top corporate tax rate would have to be raised in line with the increase he plans to propose in the top rate for individuals and that "the tax code should no longer subsidize excessive pay of chief executives and other high executives."
Mr. Clinton received a standing ovation at the beginning and the end of his speech, which was attended by many Cabinet members and was open to reporters. But afterward, some business leaders expressed their concern, and many others were reserved in their response.
Dirk Van Dongen, president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, an organization of small businesses, said: "I came out with many more questions than answers, and many strong concerns. We are very, very disturbed with this initiative with regard to corporate rates."
But others, especially those with Democratic connections, said that the President had been courageous and that they would back him. One was Barbara Davis Blum, chief executive of the Adams National Bank here, who was deputy administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in the Carter Administration.
"It's a bitter pill for people to swallow," she said. "It's a bitter pill for me to swallow. But what a gutsy thing for him to do -- telling the ones who would least like it."
At an earlier private meeting with a few of the most prominent executives, Mr. Clinton said he would propose some form of a tax on energy, according to John Sculley, chairman of Apple Computer and a strong Clinton supporter. The President's top advisers have said publicly that an energy tax is in the cards, but this was the first time Mr. Clinton himself acknowledged it.
 
Program in Final Stage
 The 25-minute speech in the East Room was part of a drive by the President and his staff to build support for the economic program he plans to announce to Congress on Feb. 17.
Administration officials said the program was in the final stage of development and would probably be completed over the weekend. In an interview, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said the "job impact" of every idea was being weighed before it was included or excluded.
At a televised "town meeting" in a Detroit suburb on Wednesday night, Mr. Clinton began to prepare the ground for the sacrifices he would ask from ordinary Americans. He suggested more directly than he ever had before that rather than offer a tax cut, as he promised in his campaign, he would propose higher taxes on the middle class and would cut spending for popular programs.
 
Superfund Called a 'Disaster'
 In his speech today the President emphasized his intention to improve Government programs, and singled out the Superfund program for cleaning up toxic wastes as one that does not work. Under the program, which began in 1980 and is one of the largest environmental public works projects, the Government pays to clean up toxic waste dumps and then tries to get reimbursed by businesses that caused the problem.
"The Superfund has been a disaster," Mr. Clinton said. "All the money goes to the lawyers, and none of the money goes to clean up the problems that it was designed to clean up."
But what made today's speech most unusual was the directness with which the President spoke. He began by discussing the nation's long-term economic problems, saying that deficit reduction was "a critical part of a strategy to build jobs and growth for America today and in the long run."
He accused the Bush Administration of understating the size of the deficit and added: "I can sort of deny the problem and finesse the numbers, or I can tell you what I think is the truth. I think I should follow the latter course."
Then he addressed the business executives specifically. "We must ask your contribution to bringing the deficit down," he said, almost pointing his finger at his audience. "If the business community leads the way, Congress will follow. I need your help. I hope you'll be there."
Mr. Clinton, who wants to raise the top individual income tax rate, said he had been told by his Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, that there would have to be "a corresponding increase in the corporate tax rate to avoid tax shifting."
What that means is that if the top individual rate and the top corporate rate get too far out of line, tax lawyers and accountants will figure out ways for wealthy people to move income from one side of the ledger to the other to gain a tax advantage.
The top corporate rate, paid by all but the smallest profitable companies, is now 34 percent, compared with a top rate for individuals of 31 percent. The President's comments suggest that if he fulfills his campaign promise to propose raising the top individual rate on families with incomes above $200,000 to 36 percent, then he might also propose lifting the corporate rate to that level.
The idea of limiting the tax deductibility of executives' salaries is more amorphous. Now, companies can write off the entire cost of all salaries as a business expense. Mr. Clinton suggested during the campaign last year that salaries above $1 million should not be deductible.
 
'Excessive' Executives' Pay
 But today he added a new fillip, saying that "excessive" pay should not be deductible, and defining excessive as "unrelated to the productivity of the enterprise."
Mr. Clinton has never been specific about whether he considered stock options and other kinds of compensation in the same realm as salaries.
Several executives at the meeting were critical of the proposal on deductions of salaries, and wondered how the Government could possibly have a fair rule to gauge the productivity of a company.
"He's going to have a very difficult time selling that," said William B. Blount, chairman of an investment banking company in Alabama. "It's not a good idea, the Federal Government regulating corporate America."
Mr. Blount, incidentally, is chairman of the Democratic Party in Alabama.

HEADLINE: Older Cities Relying More on Suburbs' Taxes

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Lighted letters still shout this old factory city's historic boast from a bridge over the Delaware River: "Trenton Makes, The World Takes." But these days Trenton, like most of the other big, once-rich cities in the region, is the taker, not the maker, when it comes to paying for its municipal budget.
As investment has fled to the suburbs or to more newly developed parts of the country, cities have begun relying less on their own tax receipts and more on tax revenue raised in the suburbs and redirected as state aid. (New York City, helped by an economic rebound in the 1980's, became an exception to the trend.) At the same time, outside aid is making up an ever smaller part of the budgets of the newer metropolitan areas that have grown up at former suburban crossroads. 
 And though President Clinton may be more sympathetic than his predecessors to urban needs, what he can actually do collides with the reality of Federal budget deficits.
The tug-of-war, reflecting the fact that older cities retain political clout, if not economic, has carried a price for both the aging urban communities and the emerging satellite cities.
"In the small cities, local taxpayers are paying a bigger and bigger portion of the cost of their government and more and more of the taxes that go to other cities, but less and less is coming back to us," said Eileen M. Earl, budget director for White Plains.
 
City Against City
 White Plains derived 7.5 percent of its $40 million budget from state aid in 1980, but 5.5 percent in 1990. Meanwhile, Buffalo, the state's second largest city, increased the aid-provided share of its budget to 69 percent from 66.4 percent.
Ms. Earl calls that unfair, arguing that White Plains is not exempt from urban problems. For example, she said, it has a shelter for homeless people, financed by Westchester County, that requires frequent attention from the city's police and fire departments without compensation.
But older cities also pay for the shift in aid, with an erosion of local autonomy, as decisions affecting a housing project, a new school building or a health program are increasingly being made in state legislatures or Federal offices instead of City Hall. In New Haven, where state and Federal aid pays 53.4 percent of the bills, officials grumble about the strings attached to outside aid, but feel they have to lobby for it anyway.
"Our property tax base is so overburdened that we take what is offered," said Jane Ciarleglio, director of intergovernmental affairs. "But the requirements can be so demanding and so full of rules of the things we can and can't do, that there are times when we do say to ourselves, maybe we just shouldn't take it."
 
Greenwich Can Afford 'No'
 Rich towns have that choice: this winter, Greenwich, Conn., decided not to apply for Federal disaster relief to repair storm-damaged beaches. The town feared that Federal help would also mean Federal rules opening the beaches to nonresidents.
Greenwich received 16 percent of its revenues in state and Federal funds in 1980; today the figure is 7 percent, said William J. Bliss, the Town Comptroller.
A reliance on outside aid also opens city administrations to outside scrutiny. In the 1970's, Mayor Hugh Ad donizio of Newark campaigned for extensive state aid to the city's schools. The legislative debate focused attention on longstanding reports of corruption, which eventually led to Mayor Addonizio's conviction.
Perhaps no two cities better reflect the way the fiscal balance can shift than New Haven, a historic manufacturing city, and its neighbor down the coast, Stamford. Both cities are about the same size, with New Haven slightly larger; both have manufacturing pasts that provided early wealth, and both have their shares of urban problems. In 1970, each derived about a quarter of its income in aid.
 
Tale of 2 Tax Bases
 But over the next two decades, Stamford was more successful than New Haven in riding the corporate office boom, rebuilding its downtown and adding millions to its tax base. In 1990, as a result, New Haven's reliance on outside aid more than doubled, to 53 percent of total revenues, while Stamford's share fell to half its former level, to about 13 percent.
Similarly, Trenton derived just 9.5 percent of its general revenues from state and Federal aid in 1960, when it was still a steel and ceramics center for the Delaware Valley, but 64.4 percent from outside its borders in 1990, after most of its big factories closed.
In New York City, a brush with bankruptcy in the 1970's raised the level of outside aid for the city to 46 percent of revenues. But the city's long stretch of prosperity during the 1980's dropped its 1990 aid share to 38 percent, far below Buffalo's 69 percent and Syracuse's 62 percent.
Still, from universities to hospitals, New York City is a huge consumer of aid: the $12.3 billion it received from state and Federal coffers in 1990 was 27 percent of all aid given to all municipalities nationally that year, according to Census Bureau figures.
Aid levels are not directly comparable among cities because in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, aid figures do not always include welfare payments. Welfare is a county and state responsibility, so public assistance payments are reflected in New York City's aid budget, but not for Trenton, White Plains or New Haven, which are part of larger counties. If a direct comparison of aid levels is attempted, New York City is getting an even smaller percentage than, say, New Haven, because New York's 38 percent includes outside welfare contributions while New Haven's 53 percent does not.
Some experts on urban affairs implicitly criticize the cities as becoming too reliant on outside money.
"In the years between the end of the Civil War and the First World War, New York City built its massive subway system, a water system which is one of the world's wonders, without Federal aid or subsidy or even much borrowing," said Roger Starr, editor of The City Journal, a quarterly of the Manhattan Institute. "We built it, but now we can't run the subways without 40 or 50 cents for every dollar coming from the state or the Federal Government."
Others regard the reliance of the older cities on the states as an inevitable result of the flight of investment from cities and the corresponding concentration of the poor behind the city line.
Peter Salins, chairman of the urban planning department at Hunter College, argues that the flow of suburban taxes to the cities marks a necessary and desirable integration.
"I want to change the lexicon," he said. "Newark may have in some earlier time been independent, but today it is functionally the same as Brooklyn, a part of the greater New York City urban area, and it is under no more obligation to be self-reliant today than Brooklyn is."
 
Suburbs' Protection Money
 Mr. Salins regards the tax transfer from suburb to city as a form of protection payment against the ills of the city.
"If the cities were once the economic locomotives, why then are we now tolerating them as cabooses?" he asked. "Because they are the poorhouses, quite simply, and if the poor were not living in these older decaying satellite cities, where will they live?
"They will not vanish, they will not disappear into thin air, they will not go to Ohio. So the suburbanites and the more affluent residents of the central cities are content to pay the additional taxes to keep the undesired households and the undesired activities, the warehouses and so on, where they are."
His theory is small comfort to Bridgeport, Newark and other cities starved for money. Urban interest groups do have some hope that the Clinton White House will at least make it possible for them to struggle for pieces of a slightly bigger aid pie. Since President Clinton's inauguration, appeals for more urban aid have come from the National League of Cities, the United States Conference of Mayors and the Urban League.
 
A System of Boundaries
 John Yinger, an economist at Syracuse University, argues that since the state and Federal governments created a system of boundaries that lets jobs and investment abandon impoverished sections for more prosperous ones, then the state and Federal governments should help maintain services for the people left behind.
"I don't think of it as dependency, because that suggests that they have alternatives," he said. "The old cities are not in this position because they are screwing up; it's because they are facing very harsh conditions."
In fact, said Mayor Douglas H. Palmer of Trenton, the region's cities already put a heavier tax burden on their property owners than the suburbs, and yet need still higher levels of state and Federal aid.
"Our homeowners are already very heavily taxed, and we just had a revaluation that hit many people even harder," he said after announcing a campaign to wrest more aid from the State Legislature.
Beyond the education budget, 65 percent of Trenton's city budget is for police and fire protection, Mayor Palmer said. "If you want to lay people off, that's where the big bucks are, and in this day and age, who can talk about cutting back on public safety?" he said. "So we are stuck between the rock of cutting services and the hard place of raising taxes, and we can't really do either."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Plan for Close-Up Images of Earth From Space

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11

 BODY:
A small California company formed by a scientist who worked on the military's so-called Star Wars program has been licensed by the Government to launch a series of photo satellites that will make it possible for customers to directly dial up high-resolution images of earth and view them on their personal computers.
The new system, even though capable of producing the highest-quality commercially available images from space, will not approach the close-up power of military spy satellites, which is why the Department of Defense agreed to permit the license for the relatively weaker system. Military satellites can discern objects as small as one foot in diameter, civilian experts say. The permit is the first granted under a law passed last year by Congress.
 
Political and Economic Impact
 Readily and widely available high-resolution images of the earth could have a significant political and economic impact, according to business experts and Government officials. Besides making it harder for the world's military powers to launch surprise attacks, the pictures might be used for purposes like corporate espionage or news gathering. 
 The Worldview Imaging Corporation, an Oakland, Calif., start-up venture with Silicon Valley financing, received approval for the project from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in January.
The company was founded early last year by Walter Scott, a computer scientist who until the end of 1991 was the head of the controversial Lawrence Livermore Laboratories projects "Brilliant Pebbles" and "Brilliant Eyes," which are part of the Strategic Defense Initiative -- the formal name for the Star Wars program. His co-founder was Doug Gerull, an executive at the Intergraph Corporation, the leading company in the geographic information systems market.
"If the imagines are cheap and available quickly, this will change a lot of things," said Mr. Gerull, Worldview's chief executive. "You could sit at your desk and get an image from anywhere on the earth."
The resolution of the Worldview system is still nowhere near what the United States Government spy satellites can obtain. Those systems can take pictures that clearly show objects as small as footballs, while the Worldview system would show objects of "under three meters," according to several people familiar with the project. Still, that would be enough resolution to distinguish objects the size of cars and military vehicles.
Moreover, it would be significantly more resolution than is currently possible from Government public systems like the United States Landsat satellites used for map making and other data gathering, or the French Spot system used for similar purposes. Spot can resolve images up to about 10 meters while Landsat's resolution is about 30 meters.
The Worldview project is certain to generate interest -- and controversy. High-resolution images have been a closely protected technology by the nations that are space powers because of the crucial military and economic information the pictures contain. Currently the United States, France and the Soviet Union are selling only lower-resolution images to a variety of commercial concerns, ranging from agribusiness and petroleum companies to environmental organizations searching for evidence of pollution.
If all goes as planned, the company will begin supplying satellite photos in 1996 from a single small satellite and gradually add additional satellites to make it possible to get quicker turnaround time on a photo request from a customer.
Industry analysts said that Mr. Gerull had been a significant force in turning Intergraph into the leading player in the geographic information systems, or G.I.S., market. This computer hardware and software is increasingly being used by both corporations and local government planners in sophisticated data-analysis applications.
Last year the G.I.S. market was $2 billion, according to Kathy Hale, a market researcher at Dataquest in San Jose, Calif. Ms. Hale said that she expected the market to double by 1996 and that growth of G.I.S. would be fueled in part by the availability of cheap satellite imagery such as Worldview's.
"It's really a Government monopoly and this will provide some healthy free-market competition," she said.
One of the most influential backers of Worldview, and a member of its advisory board, is Edward Teller, the architect of the hydrogen bomb. Mr. Teller has been a vocal proponent of a global satellite observation system for military, economic and environmental applications.

HEADLINE: Experts See Tax Curbs on Executives' Pay as More Political Than Fiscal

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The effects of President Clinton's plan to limit corporate tax deductions for paying seven-figure salaries would probably be more political than economic, some experts on executive compensation said yesterday.
The plan could hit hard at high-salary industries like Wall Street, Hollywood and big time sports, which might make it easier for middle-class people to swallow a tax increase, these experts said. 
 But the money raised for the Treasury could be relatively inconsequential, perhaps several hundred million dollars, which would be only a ripple in a multibillion-dollar ocean of debt.
 
End of a Subsidy?
 Reviving an idea he raised during last year's campaign, Mr. Clinton said corporate taxes would have to rise so the tax code would "no longer subsidize excessive pay for chief executives and other high executives."
Companies have been able to write off the entire cost of salaries as a business expense. Mr. Clinton suggested during the campaign that salaries above $1 million should not be deductible. He never specified whether he considered stock options and other kinds of compensation in the same realm as salaries.
Jude T. Rich, chairman of Sibson & Company, a consulting firm based in Princeton, N.J., said the effects of the change would be fairly widespread among large corporations, especially if stock option gains were included. "That's where the big money is," he said.
He said that the average chief executive's pay at the 20 largest companies last year was $4 million to $5 million and that a majority of chief executives in Fortune 500 companies received more than $1 million. But he said the benefit for the Treasury would be "just peanuts: a couple of hundred millions."
 
'Where All the People Are'
 He added, "It's purely a gesture to the middle class," because they will have to pay through tax increases or Social Security cuts if the President wants more revenue. "That's where all the people are."
The proposal quickly drew criticism on Wall Street, where not only the most senior executives, but scores of others, are paid more than $1 million a year.
But few on Wall Street are likely to be immediately concerned, at least while the times are good. While calling on changing the tax code for excessive compensation, Mr. Clinton specifically defined such excess as any payments "unrelated to the productivity of the enterprise."
At first blush, that could leave Wall Street at least partly off the hook. After all, the majority of the money in a Wall Street executive's annual pay comes from the year-end bonuses. The bonuses come from a pool of capital funded during the year, and each executive's amount is set by a committee at the firm, arguably linking the whole process to the firm's productivity.
 
Good Pay in Bad Times
 But Wall Street has never been known for containing itself, and has been known to keep paying hefty amounts even when times are bad. In 1990, for example, the entire industry posted a loss, which analysts said would not have happened if compensation levels had fallen to the degree the business had.
"Wall Street goes up on the upside, but they dont go down when things are tough," said John Keefe, president of Keefe Worldwide Information Services, a consulting firm to the financial services industry. "This kind of plan will cause Wall Street to rethink its compensation scheme."
In the sports world, the Clinton plan was viewed as potentially having "a disastrous impact" on major league baseball, said an official in a league office who asked that his name not be used.
Currently, player contracts are regarded as depreciating expenses by owners of the 28 teams. Last year, 265 players made more than $1 million, to bring the average salary in the major leagues to "well above" that figure, the official said. "Without those tax deductions, he added, "we would have to drastically alter the structure of our game."
While he declined to speculate on what changes might be required if the proposal became law, he said the effect would be different on different teams because of the way player contracts are structured by team owners. Some owners amortize the contracts over longer periods.
Hollywood executives, reached last night, said they would need to see details of the Clinton plan. "It is too early to comment and I'm not sure what it means," said a senior executive at one studio who also insisted on not being identified.

HEADLINE: With Jeers for the West, Iran Cheers 14 Years of Revolution

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Hundreds of thousands of Iranians accompanied by battalions of the armed forces converged on Freedom Square in Teheran today in a Government-sponsored rally marking the day the military capitulated to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, bringing the fall of the monarchy 14 years ago.
While President Hashemi Rafsanjani said in a speech today that the West must reassess its attitude toward Iran, marchers labeled the United States "the mother of all corruption." 
 Huge crowds waved framed photographs of senior Iranian clerics, as the voice of Mr. Rafsanjani, broadcast over towering loudspeakers, declared that the Iranian "people are quite happy and love their revolution."
"Western analysts must reassess their attitude about Iran," Mr. Rafsanjani said. "Don't label us fundamentalist or terrorist."
Mr. Rafsanjani said that the sheer appeal of the Islamic revolution ruled out emulating Western models of the multiparty system.
"Our struggle against the West is not a war," said Hamid Shariatpour, a 22-year-old Teheran cleric. "It's a cultural struggle in which we must replace the negative with something positive."
In recent weeks, while the state-run media and senior Iranian leaders made accusations of Western ploys "to reflect a negative image of Iran" according to a commentary on Iranian television, few have dealt with economic pressures and Iran's damaged international creditworthiness.
Since last March, the late payments on short-term loans due to the Central Bank of Iran's indiscriminate opening of letters of credit have provoked concern in foreign banks.
Mr. Rafsanjani told a gathering of foreign diplomats in Teheran yesterday that Iran "as a member of the world community understands the need for peaceful cooperation." "In the second half of this year, we had some difficulty in paying our short-term credit," he said. "This is being eliminated."
But even though Mr. Rafsanjani adopted a more conciliatory tone yesterday, marchers publicly condemned the United States.
Massoumeh Robatjazi, 13, described walking in the annual rally as "a family tradition."
"I just repeat the slogans the other people give to show our unity," Miss Robatjazi said. "My favorite is, 'Death to America' ."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury's Auction Sets Off a Rally

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury's auction of 30-year bonds went well yesterday and sparked a rally that turned a so-so three-day quarterly auction into a better one, traders said. President Clinton also helped, as the yield on the new 30-year bond dropped to 7.15 percent.
The $35.5 billion three-day sale of Treasury notes and bonds was the first quarterly auction under Mr. Clinton. Coming after a strong rally since January and ahead of the disclosure of the President's economic plan next week, it could have been a perfect excuse for a big correction. 
 But after it was all over yesterday, the market had only moved a little above the low yields for the year reached last Friday. And Mr. Clinton, in his appearance in suburban Detroit Wednesday night and in comments to businessmen at the White House yesterday, was still saying the things that have made many investors and traders believe that he is serious about reducing the record Federal budget deficit.
 
 
'Did Himself Proud'
 "Mr. Clinton did himself proud over the last 24 hours by focusing people back on deficit reduction," said Joseph Liro, the chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company.
By late in the day, those who bought the 30-year bond at its average yield of 7.22 percent were well into the black as the yield dropped to 7.15 percent, which is down from the 7.21 percent in the when-issued, or pre-auction, market Wednesday and from 7.25 percent on the old 30-year bond.
The successful sale of $9.33 billion of 30-year bonds, which was at the lowest yield since the 30-year bond began to be regularly auctioned in February 1977, sets the stage for a another test of the 7.1 percent closing low for the 30-year bond that was reached in April 1986. Before yesterday, the lowest yield reached since 1986 was the 7.15 last Friday. The new bond has a 7.125 percent coupon, also the lowest since 1977.
Whether the 7.1 percent level can be broken will depend a lot on the deficit-cutting plan that Mr. Clinton outlines next week. Many traders and investors have been buying the 30-year bond in part because they are expecting the President to be able to cut the budget deficit.
The 30-year bond auction also touched off a rally in the rest of the market that helped improve the fortunes of buyers of the three-year notes and 10-year notes in the first two parts of the Treasury's quarterly auction Tuesday and Wednesday.
 
 
'No More Worries'
 "Once it was over there was no more paper and no more worries and we had a relief rally," said Jay Goldinger, a bond trader at Capital Insight in Los Angeles.
The three-year note was back in the black as the yield dropped to 4.7 percent, below the 4.73 percent average at the auction and well below the 4.78 percent it jumped to after Wednesday's selloff.
The new 10-year bond, whose poor auction set off selling Wednesday, was still in the red, but much better off. The new note was auctioned at a average yield of 6.33 percent but jumped to 6.41 percent by the end of Wednesday trading. Yesterday the yield worked its way back down to 6.36 percent.
Traders said that there were several factors that made the 30-year auction go well. One was that the 10-year auction went so poorly Wednesday and the selloff that followed pushed up the yield on the new 30-year bond, making it cheaper and more likely that buyers could count on some profits.
 
 
Speculation on Further Reduction
 In addition, many traders are still speculating that the Treasury will make a further reduction in the regular size of the 30-year auction at the next quarterly sale in May. The Treasury cut the size of this auction by $1 billion.
There was also speculation that some speculators were making bets yesterday that the spread between the yields on long-term securities and shorter-term securities would narrow. To make this bet an investor buys bonds and sells shorter-term securities. There was also talk that Goldman, Sachs & Company was an especially large buyer of bonds.
The report that retail sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent in January gave a little support to the market in the morning because the increase was a littler less than expected. There seemed to be little impact from the decline of 12,000 in initial jobless claims, to 340,000, in the week ending Jan. 30.

HEADLINE: Casino Owner Offers Lure: $140 Million in New Taxes

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Steve Wynn, the Las Vegas casino owner, said today that his company, Mirage Resorts, would guarantee the state at least $140 million a year in tax revenue, about 1.6 percent of the entire 1993 state budget, if casinos were legalized for Hartford and Bridgeport.
The total, which Mr. Wynn told a legislative committee would be backed by the "full faith and credit" of his company, was far more than the $50 million that Mirage officials had mentioned in past lobbying efforts, and reflects the heights to which Connecticut's debate over gambling have climbed in just the last few weeks. 
 
 
The Pequot Pact
 Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, which operates the state's only casino, in Ledyard, signed an agreement last month under which the tribe pledged $100 million a year to the state in exchange for the right to operate slot machines. Under that agreement, which was intended by Mr. Weicker to short-circuit the casino movement, the tribe would be released from any obligation to make payments if the Legislature were to legalize slot machines anywhere else in the state.
Apparently by coincidence, the State Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, issued a long-delayed legal opinion today concluding that the agreement was legal and binding upon both parties and was not, as some state lawmakers had charged, a usurpation of legislative authority by the Governor.
Mr. Blumenthal, who was not consulted by the administration in negotiating with the tribe, said he believed the agreement could not be overturned by the Legislature, and did not require any approval by Federal authorities either.
He said he thought that the agreement could not be overturned by anyone, ever, without the consent of both parties. What that means, he said, is that Mr. Weicker has committed the state in perpetuity; even if future governors or legislatures wanted to withdraw from the pact with the Pequots, they could not do so unless the tribe consented. Connecticut can refuse to take the tribe's money, but the slot machines are there to stay, Mr. Blumenthal said.
 
Fairness Concerns
 Mr. Weicker's pact with the tribe, while praised by lawmakers as a deft political maneuver, has been criticized by some municipal leaders, who say the $100 million in proceeds is not being fairly distributed around the state. Bridgeport, for example, the state's largest city and one of the poorest, would get only $1.8 million, while Farmington, a wealthy suburb of Hartford, would get $3.2 million.
Mr. Wynn, who was testifying at the Capitol at the very moment that Mr. Blumenthal was issuing his opinion on the Pequot pact, also said he disagreed with the Attorney General's interpretation, and said he thought the tribe could stop payments at any time and the state would be unable to do anything about it.
 
The Social Effects
 But money is only part of the issue. Some legislators questioned Mr. Wynn sharply about the effects his casinos might have on crime rates and gambling addictions, and what guarantees he could make that the residents of the cities where casinos would be built would benefit.
Mr. Wynn said that large crowds always produce higher levels of crimes like pocket picking and purse snatching that have nothing to do with gambling, and that gambling addicts are more prone to bet on horses and state lotteries than at casinos.
For Mr. Weicker, however, Mr. Wynn had only kind words. He said the Governor's deal with the tribe -- by giving the state a cut of the profits in gambling at Ledyard -- had transformed the debate from one of policy and politics to one centering on the economy and jobs.
"He got it down to the terms we thought it ought to be," Mr. Wynn said. Mr. Blumenthal said in his opinion that the pact between the Pequots and the state did not forestall any legislative action on the gambling bills before the General Assembly, including a proposal to authorize slot machines at off-track betting parlors and jai-alai frontons.
But he said he agreed with the administration's position that any such action, if it legalized slot machines, would release the tribe from its financial obligation to the state.
