HEADLINE: Unicef Director Recommends It Stay Where It Is

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
The executive director of Unicef has recommended that the relief agency keep its headquarters in Manhattan rather than moving to Westchester County or elsewhere.
Under a proposal by the Dinkins administration and a city-state agency, the rent that Unicef pays for its current headquarters at 3 United Nations Plaza would be cut, and Unicef would be given ownership of the building in 2026. 
 Unicef, formally called the United Nation's Children's Fund, has 950 employees in New York City. Mayor Timothy C. Idoni of New Rochelle, which had been courting the agency, vowed not to give up the fight, but New York officials said the recommendation announced yesterday made it highly unlikely that Unicef would move.
The current owner of the 203,000-square-foot building at 3 United Nations Plaza, between First and Second Avenues on a renamed section of 44th Street, is the city-state agency, the United Nations Development Corporation. It expects the bonds issued to pay for the building's construction to be paid off in 2026, after which it would transfer ownership to Unicef. The city, which owns the land at the site, would give that to Unicef.
In addition, the Development Corporation is negotiating to buy an additional 200,000 square feet of space for Unicef Unicef or the United Nations would also similarly be able to obtain ownership of the new space eventually and it, too, would be exempt from real estate taxes.
Unicef's executive board has the final say on where Unicef goes, but city officials were confident that the major hurdle had been overcome when they obtained the backing of Unicef's executive director, James P. Grant. "I think we're the majority of the way there," said Barry F. Sullivan, Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development.
Mr. Grant said alternatives to Manhattan would be less costly, but the statement said the "paramount considerations for the basis of his decision" were location: He decided that there would be "major disadvantages" to not being very close to the United Nations headquarters and the Permanent Missions to the United Nations.

HEADLINE: U.S. Panel Urges Setting Export Target Levels

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The chairmen of some of the nation's largest corporations said today that Federal trade officials should establish temporary market-share targets for American exports.
In a report, the executives, members of the Government's top advisory panel on trade, said the targets were needed because Japan still imports a smaller percentage of its manufactured goods than any other major industrial nation, despite the removal through negotiations of many regulatory trade barriers in Japan. 
 These persistently low purchases from abroad, the report said, reflect the existence of "invisible barriers" to trade in Japan. As evidence, they cited that nation's system of interlocking ownership among companies.
But the panel also said that a failure by Tokyo to meet targets should not be enough, by itself, to justify retaliation against Japanese exports.
 
Guarantee of Market Share
 Under a system of market-share targets, a government -- for instance, the United States -- obtains agreement that a set percentage of a product used in the other country be foreign-made. A big chunk of that foreign share would presumably be American. The idea is controversial because some free-trade proponents argue that any such arrangement represents managed trade.
The release of the report today coincided with the arrival here of Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe, who met briefly with President Clinton at the White House.
After the meeting, Mr. Clinton said they had agreed that "we shouldn't be protectionist in our relationship." But he said he also told the Japanese official that he would press efforts to bring down the trade deficit, "and that I would be working with him on it very firmly."
A Japanese official here with Mr. Watanabe said Tokyo opposed specific market-share targets. "It would be highly surprising," the official said, "if we accepted the existence of invisible barriers, and therefore it would be highly surprising if we would accept" such targets.
 
Stability or Monopoly?
 But former American trade negotiators have said that Japanese officials have in fact been receptive to such arrangements, which tend to produce a more stable market but can also encourage the development of industrial cartels that charge high prices to consumers.
The panel that issued today's report is formally the Advisory Committee for Trade Policy and Negotiations. It was created by Congress in 1974 and includes the heads of I.B.M., A.T. & T., American International Group, Boeing, Dow Chemical,Eastman Kodak and Chase Manhattan, along with 37 other top officials from corporations, trade associations, academia and labor.
Their report shows the extent to which large American corporations like to have the Government take their side in trade disputes, even though many of them say they are strong advocates of free trade.
The use of specific market-share targets, besides evoking the managed-trade argument, would have the effect, critics say, of insulting a valuable ally like Japan by trying to dictate economic policy.
But Timothy J. Regan, a vice president at Corning Inc., who helped draft the report, said the use of targets did not represent managed trade because the targets would not be directly linked to any reductions in American imports from Japan if they were not met. Equating targets with managed trade, he said, "is like saying if you have a tariff, you're protectionist -- it's simplistic."
He added that the panel had made a similar if less specific recommendation of market-share targets in 1989.
 
Accord on Semiconductors
 The semiconductor industry is one cited by people on both sides of the argument. The Bush Administration's 1991 agreement with Japan noted the two Governments' "expectation" that foreign semiconductors would make up 20 percent of the Japanese market by the end of 1992.
But it did not say what would happen if the target were not met. Final figures are scheduled to be released on March 17, and are widely expected to fall short of 20 percent.
Tokyo officials contend that the Americans' market share has not risen as planned because the Japanese recession has stunted the market and encouraged Japanese electronics companies to stick with their longtime domestic suppliers.
But the American share did not grow in the late 1980's, when Japan's economy was thriving. Japanese officials argued then that demand was growing so rapidly that their electronics manufacturers could not be expected to buy foreign semiconductors at the faster rate required to enable other nations' market share to grow.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Gained 0.3% Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Consumers kept on spending in January, pushing retail sales up three-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today. Department stores and automotive dealers recorded the biggest gains.
While the overall increase was a bit shy of expectations -- and was accompanied by a downward revision for December -- analysts said they were not worried that the economic rebound was losing momentum. Rather they saw the results, based as usual on partial data, as continuing an upward trend that has generated six increases in seven months. 
 "It's doing fine," said John E. Silvia, an analyst for Kemper Financial Services, referring to the one-third of the economy accounted for by retailing. "It's not a boom -- but we don't want a boom."
 
 
Jobless Claims
 In a separate report, the Labor Department said first-time claims for unemployment insurance fell 12,000 in the last week of January, to 340,000, the second straight decline after three consecutive increases.
The latest doses of favorable economic news came as the Clinton Administration began to make the remaining final decisions about the legislative package the President is to introduce formally on Wednesday. It is to consist of short-term stimulus on the order of $25 billion to $30 billion and a four-year strategy for reducing the budget deficit through spending cuts and tax increases.
Consumers pushed $167.4 billion across retail counters last month, with a 1.1 percent jump in sales of durable goods more than offsetting a slight decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in the nondurables sector. Durable goods are expensive items from home appliances to autos that are expected to last at least three years; nondurables are less costly items like food and clothing.
 
 
'Even Growth Track'
 This was enough to show the economy remains on an "even growth track," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers. He said he found little evidence in the latest data -- including a recalculation of December's gain to eight-tenths of 1 percent from 1.2 percent -- that consumers had retrenched to pay off holiday debt or in anticipation of smaller income-tax refunds.
Tracy Mullin, president of the the National Retail Federation, the largest trade group, hailed the January results, the third consecutive monthly gain. "This upward trend is continuing, and it proves that the industry is well on the way to a solid recovery," she said.
The $62.1 billion in sales of durable goods last month included gains in all major categories -- 1.1 percent for automotive dealers, eight-tenths of 1 percent for merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes, and six-tenths of 1 percent for those selling furniture and home furnishings.
The retail figures are adjusted for normal seasonal variations and for holiday and trading-day differences. They are not adjusted for price changes, however, so they do not reflect either inflation or discounts.
Sales of nondurables totaled $105.3 billion last month, a flat performance that followed an advance in December of six-tenths of 1 percent.
 
 
Department Store Sales
 A 2.4 percent jump for department stores drove the overall general merchandise sector up 1.9 percent. Gasoline service stations chalked up a 1.4 percent gain.
But these were completely offset by declines of eight-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars, seven-tenths of 1 percent at drug and proprietary stores, six-tenths of 1 percent at grocery and other food stores and four-tenths of 1 percent at stores selling clothes and accessories.
Compared with January 1992, the report also showed, retail sales were ahead by 6.6 percent with no adjustment for inflation. In the latest three-month period -- from November through January -- the gain was 7.2 percent.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Art, Texas Style
The Dallas Museum of Art has been thinking in true Texan scale, with a $30 million, 140,000-square-foot addition that is to open in September. The three-story Nancy and Jake Hamon Building was financed in part by a $20 million gift from Mrs. Hamon, the widow of Jake Hamon, a Dallas oil tycoon who died six years ago. Mrs. Hamon stipulated that the money go toward building a new wing rather than increasing the museum's endowment.
The addition was designed by the New York architect Edward Larrabee Barnes, who designed the museum's existing building in 1984. In addition to office and storage space, the wing provides 14,000 square feet for 7,000 American objects, including the museum's extensive assortment of Pre-Columbian gold. There will also be a 32,000-square-foot education center for the museum, half of whose visitors participate in some kind of educational program.
But with so many museums struggling just to survive, and the city of Dallas's having reduced its financial contributions to the museum, the new wing is viewed with some skepticism in the art world. But there are also those who believe the addition could help pull in potential donors.
"It may seem brash from a distance but it's the classic Texas attitude," said Harry S. Parker 3d, a former director of the Dallas Museum who is now the director of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco. "Texas has a long tradition of building real-estate projects on-the-come. And being leveraged is a part of the thinking."
 
Against the Tide
 Peter C. Marzio, the director of the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, said that while most museums were pulling in their horns, Dallas was acting aggressively. "But sometimes going against the tide works," he said. "The question is do they have sufficient money to operate?"
Richard Brettell, a former director of the museum who is the consulting director for the Hamon expansion, said he was "very sanguine about the museum's financial future." But he added, "That's not to say it's going to be easy."
When the museum was founded 90 years ago, the city owned all the art as well as the building. When the museum moved to its new site in 1984 it established itself as a separate legal entity. The city of Dallas owns the present museum's buildings and what now amounts to about half its collection. While last year the city cut its funds to the museum by 17 percent, Dr. Brettell said that two years ago the city had extended for 20 years its contract to pay the museum's operating costs based on a percentage of the city-owned art, and that this new contract included the cost of operating the new addition. The city has also agreed to make a one-year increase of 50 percent in its financing to help with the opening year of the new addition.
"We're building the addition to the city's specifications," Dr. Brettell said. "But the city's collection will remain static and ours is growing, which means that over time the city will be giving less money." He said the museum hoped that income from its endowment would be able to cover the difference.
 
80% of FundsEighty Percent in Hand
 The addition is part of a $55 million expansion. Meg Hanlon, who heads the museum's press office, said 80 percent of the funds had been raised.
The wing will become the centerpiece of a totally reorganized museum, housing what the institution calls its Museum of the Americas. In time, the remainder of the collection will be divided among a Museum of Europe, a Museum of African and Asian Art and a Museum of Contemporary Art. The philosophy behind the thematic reorganization reflects the museum's desire to be sensitive to its location, in a state that borders Mexico, and to put non-Western art on an equal footing with European art.
"When we analyzed the collection we began thinking about making a definition for each building," Dr. Brettell said, "so that rather than simply being a cultural maze, like most museums, ours will be organized into geographical and historical units."
On April 17, the institution will reopen a portion of the second and third floors of its existing building to house the Museum of Europe. The Museum of African and Asian Art and the Museum of Contemporary Art are to open in successive years, beginning in 1994.
 
Dispute Over Picasso Print
 A lawsuit is proceeding between two of the world's leading print experts: David P. Tunick, a Manhattan dealer, and Eberhard Kornfeld, the owner of Galerie Kornfeld, a well-respected auction house in Bern, Switzerland. Last week, Judge David N. Edelstein of Federal District Court in Manhattan denied a request from Mr. Kornfeld to dismiss the case.
The court had ordered Mr. Kornfeld to produce by Feb. 1 documents relating to the Picasso print that is at the center of the dispute. Mr. Tunick's lawyer, William M. Barron of Walter, Conston, Alexander & Green in Manhattan, said Mr. Kornfeld had failed to do so. Now Judge Edelstein has ordered Mr. Kornfeld to appear in court next week for a deposition.
At the heart of the dispute are issues of authenticity and money. In June 1990, Mr. Tunick paid $1.68 million for an impression of Picasso's famous 1935 print "The Minotauromachie" at an auction at Galerie Kornfeld in Bern. Mr. Barron says that at the time of the sale both men had agreed that Mr. Tunick would pay for the print in installments. The dealer exhibited the print at the annual Art Show in Manhattan in February 1991, where it was the centerpiece of his booth and was priced at $2 million. The work failed to sell at the show.
 
Offer of an Exchange
 Sixteen months after his purchase, and eight months after the Art Show, Mr. Tunick said experts who had seen the signature questioned its authenticity. Mr. Kornfeld, a Picasso expert himself, insists the work is genuine. He offered to exchange it for a copy of the same print in his private collection that had once belonged to Nelson Rockefeller and had for years been on loan to the Museum of Modern Art in New York. Mr. Tunick refused to make the swap.
"He refused the offer when he heard he would have to pay in 30 days," said Mr. Kornfeld in a telephone interview earlier this week. "He said it would not be possible."
Last October, nine days after Mr. Tunick said he discovered that the print's signature was fake, he filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan, citing fraud, misrepresentation, breach of duty, honesty and good faith in fair dealing, and breach of fiduciary duty. He asked for his money back -- the $426,254 paid in cash as well as artwork he consigned to the Swiss auction house valued at $974,000 -- and punitive damages of $20 million.
At the end of November, Mr. Kornfeld filed a lawsuit in Switzerland for the money he was still owed. Two months ago the case was thrown out of the Swiss courts on jurisdictional grounds, a decision Mr. Kornfeld is appealing.
 
Change of Venue Denied
 Judge Edelstein ruled that the case is to proceed in New York because the disputed print is here, as are the several experts who believe the signature is a forgery. In a pretrial motion, Mr. Kornfeld maintained that the dispute should be heard in Switzerland because he is a Swiss citizen and because his auction house had specified that any court proceedings must take place in Bern. The judge denied the motion to dismiss the case.
Faxes that went back and forth between the two men for 15 months reflect, for the most part, a verbal tug of war concerning the payment. In one fax, dated July 24, 1991, and submitted to the court, Mr. Tunick wrote to Mr. Kornfeld: "While we see some signs of business beginning to turn around, our cash position remains difficult for now, and we simply are not able to continue with any sort of payment schedule at the moment."
Mr. Barron, Mr. Tunick's lawyer, said, "This was the beginning of the worst part of the recession and Tunick simply could not divert monies and change his business plans to accommodate Kornfeld." The lawyer added that "as of the time David discovered the forgery he had paid $1.4 million in monies and in kind, so that his ability to pay simply cannot be questioned."
Mr. Barron said that Mr. Kornfeld changed the terms of the deal, at first agreeing to accept extended payment but then wanting money immediately.
 
A Different Estimate
 Matthew C. Kesten, a lawyer with Kantor, Davidoff, Wolfe, Rabbino & Kass in Manhattan, who is representing Mr. Kornfeld, said Mr. Tunick's payments do not add up to $1.4 million. So far, Mr. Tunick has made three cash payments totaling $350,000, according to documents filed with the court. He has also consigned six prints to Mr. Kornfeld to auction, two of which, Mr. Kesten said, have been sold for a total of about $29,000. Mr. Kesten estimates this leaves a balance of $1.3 million.
Among the prints Mr. Tunick sent to Mr. Kornfeld was Edvard Munch's "Madonna." According to court documents, Mr. Kornfeld put the print up for sale and his firm's published sales results indicated that it sold for about $500,000. But after questioning in court, Mr. Kornfeld admitted that the piece had in fact not been sold at all. "Mr. Kornfeld published the highest bid, he never said the print had sold," said Mr. Kesten.
Mr. Barron said: "Mr. Kornfeld has been struggling to avoid taking the case to trial in New York. He has lost in Bern and here. This case will now proceed with pre-trial discovery and we hope for a prompt trial, where Mr. Tunick will prevail and very likely recover substantial punitive damages."
Mr. Kesten sees things differently: "If we are ultimately allowed by the judge to get to the merits of the case, I think we will be able to show that the signature is correct. The piece was only questioned 16 months after Tunick bought it and conceded that he could not pay for it."

HEADLINE: Fiscal Prudence in Trenton

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio has yet to announce he's running for re-election in November, but his budget love-in with the Republicans who control New Jersey's Legislature says he is looking to minimize confrontations that might upset his plans or rattle voters. His cautious stance may be smart politics, but it is also smart governance after years of fiscal stress.
The Republican leadership greeted the Democratic Governor's budget message this week with approval. The two Republican contenders for Mr. Florio's job denounced it. And the Senate Democratic leader complained that Mr. Florio should be fighting to restore homeowner tax rebates that the Republicans cut last year. 
 Who's in charge? Until November it won't be clear. Republicans snatched control of both houses from Democrats two years ago, with veto-proof majorities, after Mr. Florio snatched the governorship from Republicans two years earlier and bulled through the biggest tax increase ever.
Last year most of his vetoes were overridden, including his veto of the Republican budget, which cut the state sales tax. This year he has apparently decided it's wiser to accept the inevitable. He even consulted the Republicans in preparing the budget and, smartly, removed contentious school aid issues from the docket altogether by resolving them separately two months ago.
The Governor's $15.6 billion plan for the coming year is as notable for omissions as for what's proposed. Above all, there are no new taxes, no new fees and no increases in transit fares.
Remarkably, Mr. Florio nonetheless foresees enough revenue to earmark $100 million for a "rainy day" fund. That's a far more responsible move than racing to cut taxes again, which some Republican leaders have mentioned.
New Jersey may be in somewhat better economic shape than other Northeastern states, but it would be foolhardy for any state to lapse so soon into the bad old budget habits of the 1980's.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The President Can Do It

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL; Anthony Lewis is on vacation.

 BODY:
Now that everybody is totally alert to the national danger from alien nannies, perhaps Americans and their new Administration will find a little more time and thought to deal with an even greater threat to our society.
Drugs. You do remember drugs? 
 Drugs, as in crack babies doomed to a misty, stumbling life, as in gangs spraying bullets into passers-by, as in jammed jails and emergency rooms, hundreds of billions lost in production, the spread of AIDS, mentally disturbed homeless driven to madness, as in 10-year-old pushers.
Many Americans do not remember, as long as it is not their street corner, their grandchild in an AIDS pediatric ward.
But maybe this new President will give the fight against drugs what it has lacked most -- leadership, direction, passion, energy from the Oval Office. Maybe -- no guarantees. During the campaign, all the candidates yawned their way past it. The polls did not care -- why should candidates, right?
President Bush had increased the anti-drug budget. But as for anti-drug leadership and energy, well, no. Ross Perot -- the mouth of the South told us he had a great anti-drug plan. He just never came up with it.
Candidate Clinton said a few of the right things, briefly. But it was economic statistics that made his eyes sparkle -- as if the U.S. could ever get off its knees without getting the monkey off its back.
Since Election Day, Clinton people seem startled when it is mentioned: "I'll get back to you on that."
Now President Clinton has cut the staff of the coordinator of anti-drug policy, once laughingly known as the drug czar, to about 25 from 146.
Too small, even though the office was comatose under a Bush appointee, a defeated Republican politician whose name I forget.
But President Clinton has taken one potentially useful step -- to give cabinet rank to whomever he appoints as director.
Potentially -- if the President tells the Cabinet that on drug issues the director speaks for him, so listen. Potentially -- if the director gets a voice in Federal anti-drug spending.
Most experts in the anti-drug field agree that trying to stop drugs from coming into the country will not work by itself. But enforcement and interdiction will always be part of the job and the new director will need a top law person as deputy.
The key is reducing America's craving for drugs through education and hard therapy. 
That will not happen unless President Clinton puts his own back and brain into it, to lead, lead.
Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal, head of the 15 therapeutic communities known as Phoenix House, has been pleading vainly that the military turn buildings in abandoned or underused military camps over for yearlong drug therapy. Now there is barely a tenth of the 100,000 beds needed for that intensive treatment.
The President could do it. He could also help build mandatory therapy into the prison time of every person convicted of a drug-related crime, as proposed by Representative Charles E. Schumer of New York.
The struggle against drugs cannot be set apart, as it is now. It has to be woven into planning and operation of health care, criminal justice, anti-AIDS work, job training, education. The President could do that.
James Burke, the business executive who heads the energetic and effective Partnership for a Drug-Free America, asks for a drug summit meeting. The President could do that.
The drug coordinator has to be a person of deep experience and reputation. The appointment of Dr. Rosenthal would be Presidential emphasis of the importance of the job. Other top candidates would be Mr. Burke, former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop or Mathea Falco, author of the recent, valuable book on community and business action, "The Making of a Drug-Free America."
The President will find Democrats in Congress who give their energies to the drug war. One of them is Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York. But Mr. Rangel's committee on narcotics is threatened by Congressional budget cutting. That would destroy an anti-drug watchdog to save less money than a drug gang can earn in a month. The President might help stop that.
No, the drug war cannot be won by any President alone. But one thing we have seen: It can't be won without him.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
HERBERT ZOHN, a retired art dealer, has been a lifelong admirer of Eleanor Roosevelt, and several years ago he was struck with an idea: to put up a sculpture of her in what he described the other day as "a shabby corner of Riverside Park at 72d Street."
Mr. Zohn wrote to the New York City Parks Department and learned that the work would have to be done by a private organization, so he formed the Eleanor Roosevelt Monument Fund. He recruited her grandson Dr. FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT 3D, a professor of economics at Sarah Lawrence College, to be his co-chairman and organized a sculpture competition. 
 On Feb. 21, the First Lady, HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON, is to speak at a benefit for the project titled "First Ladies of Song" at Alice Tully Hall. Proceeds will help pay for a eight-foot-high bronze sculpture by the competition winner, PENELOPE JENCKS of Boston, and for the landscaping of the two surrounding acres in the park.
The performers are to include Joanne Woodward, Barbara Cook, Judy Collins, Lena Horne, Marilyn Horne, Julie Wilson, Rosemary Clooney, Kitty Carlisle Hart and Shirley Verrett.
Dr. Roosevelt, who arranged for Mrs. Clinton's appearance, said, "Once she got my letter summarizing the project, she expressed her enthusiasm and made her commitment early on."
"People are always comparing Mrs. Clinton with my grandmother," he added. "In the January-February issue of Mother Jones magazine, there is an article called something like 'Advice From Eleanor to Hillary," and they did something with a photo of Mrs. Clinton sitting in a chair and Eleanor Roosevelt sitting in a chair so that it looks like one photo."

HEADLINE: Remaking U.N. for a Changed World Means End to Veto Power;
Look to Moscow's Role

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher has said that it is "time for some reorganization of the United Nations," including permanent membership for Japan and Germany. His remarks prompted a curt response from Britain, whose Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, argued, "If it ain't broke, don't fix it." 
 But until only a few years ago, the Council was handcuffed by permanent member use of the right to veto and was in this sense quite broke.
The veto hasn't been used for a while, but the apparent consensus among permanent members can in no way be taken for granted. Signs of change are emerging from Moscow, where hard-liners are gaining influence over the Government's decision-making machinery. Russia's finger-pointing at Croatia, in response to that country's violation of the United Nations peace agreement, has ruled out the possibility of the Council's taking action soon against Serbia. And Vice President Aleksander Rutskoi's recent threat to use the veto to "halt ill-conceived United States attacks on Iraq" is perhaps the most disturbing reminder that dissent at the Security Council is anything but a thing of the past.
Mr. Christopher's reference to the need to reorganize the Security Council reflects the Clinton Administration's aspirations for a more effective United Nations, able to imbue Washington's actions with multilateral support. Mr. Christopher would do well to look more closely at the negative implications that Russia's rightward shift has for the Council's smooth functioning. That this shift is fueled in part by frustration with the reforms advocated by President Boris N. Yeltsin should encourage the United States and other G-7 countries to bolster reformist influence, particularly Mr. Yeltsin's, through more sincere -- and more visible -- economic and political support.
If Moscow's reformers are allowed to fall, the world, and the United States in particular, will have lost the chance to establish the multilateral channel for settling international disputes.
 
DOUGLAS KEH
Vienna, Feb. 1, 1993
 
The writer is with the United Nations International Drug Control Program.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Household Help

Can someone who belatedly paid Social Security taxes for household help now amend his or her income tax return to claim the child-care credit?
EVELYN MILLER, MANHATTAN
Yes you can, but any interest or late-filing penalties are nondeductible, said Julian Block, a Larchmont, N.Y., tax lawyer. "To amend your return, file Form 1040X, accompanied by Form 2441, for each year in which you claim the credit," he said. The maximum child-care credit each year is $480 for the care of one child and $960 for the care of two or more children. 
 There is a deadline for amending a return, Mr. Block added. In most instances it is three years from the return's due date. Thus a return for 1989 with a due date, for most people, of April 15, 1990, has a deadline of April 15, 1993. Further information is contained in Internal Revenue Service Publications 503 and 556, available free by calling 800-TAX FORM.

Buying Stock on Margin

What are the advantages and disadvantages of buying stock on margin?
MICHAEL WATINS, FLORAL PARK, L.I.
A margin account lets an investor borrow money from a brokerage firm to purchase additional securities and is a double-edged sword. "The primary advantage is that it offers the opportunity to increase the overall return on your investment portfolio, if the amount you earn on the investments bought with this borrowed money exceeds the interest rate charged by your broker on the loan," said Jonathan D. Pond, author of the "New Century Family Money Book." That rate is usually the prime lending rate plus 1 to 3 percentage points.
But if your investments decline significantly in value, "you may then be subject to margin calls, typically a forced sale to meet the requirements of your margin agreement," Mr. Pond noted. "This happened to a lot of margin investors right after the 1987 crash who were forced to sell stocks to offset their paper losses."

Being an Angel

I've been thinking about investing in an Off Broadway show. How does it work?
MIKE SOMMER, LEE, MASS.
According to Frederic B. Vogel, executive director of the Commercial Theater Institute, "putting money in a theatrical show is a very high risk and you should not invest unless you are prepared to lose it all."
There are 100 percentage points, known as points, in the ownership of a show that are sold to investors, with the amount of each point based on the total capitalization.
"Limited partners put up all the capitalization, for which they get 50 percent of the net profits," Mr. Vogel said. "General partners, who do all of the work and generally do not put up any capital, get the other 50 percent."
Limited partners have limited liability, generally with no responsibility for any financing beyond their initial investment. "All or part of their investment is returned to the limited partners if the production has an operating profit, prior to any net profits being distributed," Mr. Vogel said.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Bakers Find Anger Is the Mother of Invention

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN

 BODY:
As a starting point, hatred can be positive. Take the case of the 400 workers who lost their jobs when Stroehmann's shut down its Taystee Bread bakery in Queens seven months ago. When they started to hold their weekly meetings, it was mostly to vent their anger at bosses who had fled the city and abandoned them. They cursed their old employers. They dreamed of vengeful boycotts. They are still meeting, only now, what they talk about is setting up their own big bakery in two years time.
"O.K., listen up," said Lynn Bell, addressing 35 of the unemployed workers who turned up at the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Flushing. The 40-year-old former machinery cleaner and union representative was both giving news and shoring up hopes. 
 "We've gotten some more grant money," she said. "We're going to be meeting with the association of Chinese bankers. We got some resumes from people answering our ad for a bakery manager. Our site committee is looking at 15 possible locations.
"And, oh yes, the advertising agency that's working with us wants to hear from you with any ideas about what we should call our bread. It ought to be a name that signifies what we are all about."
A visitor who had spent the afternoon with Ms. Bell and her associates thought they should call it something like Honest Bread, Real Tough Bread, Righteous Bread. In fact, though, they are not going to call it anything anytime soon, because, as Ms. Bell repeatedly made clear, it will be a long time before any dough rises. Still, that they had come this far, that they had bankers and an advertising agency and that they were still staying in touch with each other was clearly remarkable.
"You've got to understand that all this started when we were just a bunch of loudmouthed complainers meeting in the Maplecrest bar across the street from the plant," said Jennie Call, who worked for Taystee for eight years as a packer. Before that, she had worked for a printing compa
ny that relocated to New Jersey and another bakery that moved upstate. "At first, there were just four or five us meeting at the bar, but it grew when the closing date got nearer."
Back when the bakery was still running, John Diaz, who is 59, had been in management. As assistant superintendent, he had been Ms. Bell's supervisor and for years hisdealings with the union representative were not the warmest. Now they are good friends and allies in a fight for jobs, brought together by the bakery's closing.
"What Stroehmann's did -- the way they did it -- well, betrayal is too nice a word," said Mr. Diaz, who had worked at the bakery for 20 years. "We all felt violated. They never asked for concessions from the union or the workers. They never offered relocation possibilities. They never discussed things or negotiated. They just left, thinking they could maintain quality and production by paying less wages at bakeries in Pennsylvania. I think that was their plan ever since they bought Taystee Bread four years earlier. They thought they could buy in to the metropolitan market for sales and run away from production."
Joseph Chaffee, another former manager, added: "You know what the severance was? It was 30 hours pay for each year of work after three years."
For Edouard Archange, a 49-year-old father of five, that worked out to about $1,500. Just like most of the Taystee workers, Mr. Archange has not found a job and has been living on his savings and unemployment benefits. "There are no jobs," he said. "All we can do is to start our own bakery."
That idea first came up at the Maplecrest when Ms. Bell said she had heard that in Pittsburgh, bakery workers had somehow managed to put together their own company after their employers moved away. By this time, the angry Taystee workers were spending most of their time trying to organize a boycott of their former employer's products. A group of 30 visited Pittsburgh and learned how the workers there had battled for three years to set up a bakery called City Pride, with equity shared by workers and investors.
"We saw we had a model to work with," said Ms. Bell. She is an exceedingly polite woman, deferring to others, eager to bring everyone into the discussion, but she is clearly a catalyst who combines a marathoner's energy with the enthusiastic hopes of a crap shooter.
They set up the Community-Labor Campaign to Save Taystee Jobs, renting an office at 32-17 College Point Boulevard, not far from the old bakery. They quickly received $121,000 in grants from the New York State Urban Development Council, banks and private foundations to be used as seed money. They commissioned a study from a consulting group in Boston to determine whether a bakery based in New York City could effectively compete in a market dominated by producers who, for the most part, truck in baked goods from plants elsewhere. The study showed that, yes, such a bakery could do well.
A Brooklyn-based nonprofit organization called Leap became the project's sponsor, seeking $10 million to set up the bakery, which, like the one in Pittsburgh, is to be owned by investors and workers. City officials informed the group that they were pressuring Stroehmann's, which still does business in the city, to return $780,000 in tax benefits that were forfeited when Taystee closed. The officials added that the money had been earmarked as an investment in the new bakery. At the moment, plans call for production to begin by the end of 1994.
"It's a long time to wait," said Mr. Archange, "but what can we do?"
Someone said that unemployment benefits would run out by then. Someone else noted that unemployment in the area was twice that of the nation.
"It's our kind of jobs that are disappearing," said Ms. Bell.
Ms. Call said: "We're fighting for our jobs by what we're doing, and if we succeed, it'll lead others to try."
The visitor noted that the effort seemed like a labor of love.
"No, that's where you're wrong," said Mr. Chaffee, laughing. "With the way we were treated, it's more like a labor of hate."

HEADLINE: Another Surge of Refinancings Sweeps Over Mortgage Lenders

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
American homeowners, who last year pared billions of dollars in interest payments off personal balance sheets by refinancing their mortgages, are at it again.
Fueled by a rally in the bond market that has pushed long-term mortgage interest rates to 20-year lows, the latest surge in refinancing activity began right around Christmas, mortgage bankers said, and has intensified in the last few weeks. 
 "Our call volume has gone from 50 to 60 an hour to 150 an hour in the last week," said Laura Lippman,a spokeswoman at Countrywide Credit, based in Pasadena, Calif., the nation's largest originator of mortgage loans. "Throughout the company, we are probably getting close to 10,000 calls a day on refinancing mortgages."
If it continues, the latest refinancing wave will free huge amounts of money that might otherwise have gone to lenders each month. That money could give added lift to an economy that is already looking increasingly healthy. Unlike other refinancing frenzies in the last year, this one comes as consumers' spirits are relatively high, having risen steadily since the Presidential election.
Mortgage bankers, who have lived through two years of initially hectic and then frenetic refinancing activity, sound somewhat blase about the latest pickup. What is interesting at the moment, they say, is that mortgage applications for new purchases have been rising for six weeks.
 
Contrast to Last Year
 "Last year there was a tremendous volcano of refinancing activity," said Howard Culang, managing director for Prudential Home Mortgage, the nation's second-largest originator of home mortgages. "Now it is growing, but it is more measured."
Still, analysts point out that the bond market, made up of a jittery bunch of traders, could bring mortgage refinancings to an abrupt halt if it does not like the components of the economic program President Clinton is to outline on Wednesday or if it is troubled by the way Congress deals with the package.
Interest rates on 30-year Treasury bonds, which influence mortgage rates, fell to 7.12 percent yesterday, a seven-year low.
At the moment it is not clear which mortgage products homeowners are favoring as they refinance. Last year, for example, many chose to move out of 30-year mortgages and into 15-year loans. Although monthly payments are higher on shorter-term loans, homeowners can pay down debt faster.
The rush to refinance "does not necessarily imply greater spending," said Alan Sinai, president of the Boston Company Economic Advisors Inc. "But it does help the economy."
Yesterday the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, which buys pools of mortgages from lenders, reported that the average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell for the eighth week in a row, to 7.75 percent, from 7.80 percent a week ago. The 7.75 percent is the lowest average rate since June 15, 1973, when the rate was 7.73 percent.
At 7.75 percent, the monthly principal and interest payment is $707.23 on a 30-year loan of $100,000. That compares with $834 a month for a similar loan at 9.5 percent.
Average rates on one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, which are often favored by first-time home buyers because of the low initial rate, fell to 5.04 percent, Freddie Mac said, from 5.06 percent a week ago.
Each week the Mortgage Bankers Association puts out separate indexes tracking mortgage applications for refinancings and for purchases.
In the period from late December to Feb. 5, the refinancing index rose 116 percent, said David Lereah, chief economist at the association, but the index, which is at 719, remains well below the peak of 1,354 it hit last July 24.
The association's purchase index has risen 69 percent in the same period, to its highest level since the measure was first published in 1990.
 
One Lender's Outlook
 "We have been doing more purchase business than other business," said Pete Wissinger, an executive vice president at Norwest Mortgage Bank in Des Moines, a mortgage lender that does business in 49 states and originated more than $21 billion in mortgages last year. "But we could see a very robust refinancing market this year if rates stay at these levels or go lower."
It is difficult to imagine that refinancing activity in 1993 will match what took place in the last two years.
In 1991 and 1992, years when the Federal Reserve Board steadily pushed down short-term interest rates to help stimulate the economy, nearly half a trillion dollars in mortgages were refinanced, according to estimates by the mortgage bankers group.
Those refinancings, in turn, pushed down debt service costs by nearly $10 billion, the association estimated.
Nevertheless, bankers said the pool of mortgage loans that have not yet been refinanced remained huge.
 
Still Haven't Acted
 Mr. Lereah said that in August he identified $2.4 trillion worth of mortgages that were candidates for refinancing. "There is a very large pool of mortgage holders out there paying anywhere from 9.5 percent to 10 percent that still have not refinanced," he said. "It may take two or three refinancing booms in a row before these people wake up."
Mr. Sinai, the analyst, said that unless President Clinton's economic address offered serious proposals to cut the Federal budget deficit, and Congress responded to his policies in a credible way, those who had delayed refinancing their mortgages might have missed the boat.
"Those who are grabbing the window of opportunity here are very wise," he said. "The bond market has already improved some on the belief that the President is serious about cutting the deficit. If he really presents a really bona fide deficit reduction program, the bond market will fly. If he doesn't, long-term interest rates are probably going to move higher."

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ASSAILS 'SHOCKING' PRICES OF DRUG INDUSTRY

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., Feb. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton criticized the powerful drug industry today for pursuing "profits at the expense of our children" as he sought to assign blame for soaring health care costs and to enlist public support for his own health program.
Mr. Clinton's blunt words came as he announced a proposal to spend $300 million next year to increase the number of American infants and children who get vaccines. White House officials said the effort would lead to the immunization of one million more infants and children beginning this summer. 
 "Our prices are shocking," Mr. Clinton said. "The pharmaceutical industry is spending $1 billion more each year on advertising and lobbying than it does on developing new and better drugs. Meanwhile, its profits are rising at four times the rate of the average Fortune 500 company."
 
Push for Lower Prices
 The President's criticism of the drug industry echoed a similar attack on Thursday by Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is in charge of developing the Administration's health-care policy. Defending themselves, several drug companies, whose stock prices declined modestly today, said the President had been misled by statistics in asserting that vaccine makers were profiteering. Four companies said they would send representatives to a White House meeting next week to discuss prices with Mr. Clinton. [Page 8.]
While the President said Federal spending on immunizations at public clinics would rise sharply, he made it clear that he wanted drug companies to lower their prices. He said he had directed Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to begin negotiating immediately with drug companies on the price of childhood vaccines against polio, measles and diphtheria.
 
Vaccinating All Children
 He also pledged to deliver a proposal to Congress that would guarantee the immunization of every child. Fewer than than half of all 2-year-olds in the United States are fully vaccinated, White House officials said.
Mr. Clinton's comments were the opening salvo of a campaign to try to drive down the cost of drugs and to sell the Administration's health plan to the public.
Administration officials said James Carville, an architect of Mr. Clinton's election victory last year, would be the political strategist for a nationwide effort to win support for the health plan. Mr. Carville also managed the Senate campaign of Harris Wofford, whose upset victory over Dick Thornburgh was widely attributed to its emphasis on health care reform.
A day after Mrs. Clinton traveled to Pennsylvania to single out the pharmaceutical industry as a target for the public's discontent, Mr. Clinton went to a health clinic across the Potomac River to rebuke the manufacturers even more harshly.
 
Backing From Top Democrats
 Asked whether members of Congress, who are lobbied heavily by the pharmaceutical industry, would be behind his effort, Mr. Clinton told reporters: "Whether they are or not is up to them. But this is unconscionable. We are running the risk of new epidemics spreading out in this country. We cannot do it."
Making no secret of his goal to win over the public, he added, "I think the public outpouring on this is going to be so strong that they'll come along and do it."
Although major makers of vaccines complained that Mr. Clinton had singled them out unfairly, leading Democrats praised the President. "It is appropriate for the President to insist that drug companies do their part as well," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee. He added that "the laissez-faire attitude of the past Administration meant that business too often was not asked to participate in meeting urgent national needs."
Mr. Clinton's appearance today at the health clinic at the Fenwick Center here, where children get free shots, was also a public relations prelude to his economic address to a joint session of Congress next week. The visit had the feel of a campaign event. Mr. Clinton hugged babies and worked the crowds of hundreds of children and parents, and he halted the motorcade and jumped out of his Cadillac limousine as he was leaving the center to mix with more people lining the street.
Mr. Clinton said the vaccine program would be included in the economic plan he would announce to Congress on Wednesday. The program, he said, would create an increase in medical clinics' working hours and thus provide a small boost to the economy.
Administration officials said they were still considering a plan that would have the Government buy the entire supply of children's vaccines and distribute them free.
President Clinton has said he will submit legislation to Congress by May 1 to control health costs and guarantee access to health care for all Americans. Thirty-five million people do not have health insurance.
 
Opposition Is Expected
 But the Clintons say they expect fierce opposition from businesses and health care providers that get large amounts of income and profits from the current system. That is why the White House is enlisting Mr. Carville. "I'm sewing on my chevrons, polishing my weapons and getting ready to go out and do battle," Mr. Carville said today.
Mr. Clinton said that while 10 states had negotiated agreements with vaccine manufacturers to get cheaper vaccines, others had been turned away.
"Today, we must tell the drug companies to change those priorities," he said. "We cannot have profits at the expense of our children." The President said he had specifically instructed Ms. Shalala, in her talks with the manufacturers, to assure that states could buy vaccines at affordable prices.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, acknowledged that the Administration, in seeking to persuade drug companies to reduce prices, could threaten to remove their tax advantages for research and development. But, he said, he hoped for "good negotiations," adding, "I don't know that we have to presume, necessarily, a completely adversarial relationship."
 
Jump in Prices
 The average costs of vaccinating children have risen for several reasons, including the fact that more shots are recommended nowadays, prices have gone up, and there was a Federal excise tax on the vaccinations from 1988 to 1992.
In 1982, the average cost of a complete series of vaccines for a child, purchased by private doctors, was $23.29. By 1992 the cost was $243.90. In that same period the cost for an average vaccine purchased under Federal contract rose from $6.69 to $128.79. Those figures are based on calculations by the Department of Health and Human Services and American Academy of Pediatrics.
The cost for a vaccination from a private doctor for diphtheria, tetanus or pertussis went from 19 cents in 1977 to $9.97 in 1992. For an oral polio vaccination, the price rose from a dollar to $9.91. And for measles, mumps and rubella, the price jumped from $6.01 to $25.29.

U.N. PLANS PULLOUT OF U.S. TROOPS
The U.N. Secretary General plans to bring most American troops home from Somalia by April and replace them with a multinational corps of 15,000 to 20,000 soldiers under the command of a Turkish general. The plan would leave 3,000 to 5,000 American troops under the command of a foreign officer, a departure from long-standing U.S. policy. 1
 
BOSNIA TO BAR U.N. AID
The Bosnian Government announced that it would refuse to accept any further deliveries of U.N. food and medical aid to Sarajevo until United Nations relief convoys begin regular deliveries to besieged Muslims in eastern Bosnia. The move appeared to have been prompted by the Clinton Administration's policy statement on the war in Bosnia. 1
 
U.N. DECISION BACKS ISRAEL
The U.N. Security Council, closing the book on the dispute over Israel's deportation of 400 Palestinians more than six weeks ago, again urged Israel to take back the deportees and called on the Palestinian delegation to return to the stalled Middle East peace talks. 3
 
WHAT'S IN STORE FOR ITALY?
After the resignation of Bettino Craxi as leader of the Socialist Party in Italy, one of the country's more perplexing questions is this: Where will the new leaders be found in a political system that is seen by many Italians as utterly discredited? 4
 
ARGENTINA AND U.S. IN PACT
Broadly opening its technology to a Latin American country for the first time, the U.S. signed an accord with Argentina that will permit it to buy some of the most advanced computers, nuclear technology and aeronautical guidance systems. 4
 
UZBEKISTAN TESTS THE FUTURE

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

Companies

HEADLINE: In Nervous Uzbekistan, It's a New Day but With the Same Old Hard Line

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan

 BODY:
Here in the heart of Central Asia, Uzbekistan challenges the fond hopes and assumptions that a collection of newly independent countries would cast off the immense burden of the past and emerge as democracies from the wreckage of the Soviet Union.
Stunned by ethnic strife and the rise of the religious right next door, Uzbekistan is engaged in a sweeping political crackdown on dissent, banning demonstrations and arresting opposition leaders on charges ranging from treason to slandering President Islam Karimov. 
 In neighboring Tajikistan, a civil war along clan and religious lines has displaced a tenth of the population. With the help of Uzbekistan and Russia, and worried about Iranian influence and the intervention of Afghan Tajiks, the former Communists are back in power.
In Turkmenistan, the Communist system has scarcely changed at all. Even in Kazakhstan, potentially the richest country of the region, the leadership is putting economic development far ahead of political change, trying to keep the lid on ethnic tensions.
But in Uzbekistan, the largest country of Sunni Muslim, Turkic-speaking Central Asia, open repression is the order of the day.
Western and Asian diplomats here consider the crackdown a puzzling overreaction by Mr. Karimov, who ran Uzbekistan under the Soviet Union and who won a carefully orchestrated election in December 1991.
"It's fair to say that the Karimov Government is out to do in the political opposition," said a senior diplomat. "There's nothing subtle about it."
 
For Clinton, A Sticky Issue
 The crackdown presents the new Clinton Administration with the problem of figuring out how to press a Soviet-style authoritarian state on human rights without angering its leaders and cutting off dialogue altogether.
Mr. Karimov, president of Uzbekistan since March 1990, did not favor the breakup of the Soviet Union. He has tried to preserve the old system while edging gingerly toward a freer market. Washington moved quickly to open an embassy in Tashkent, seeing Uzbekistan as a bulwark against Iran-style Islamic rule, which seems to have replaced Communism as the West's nightmare of choice.
But Mr. Karimov has presented Washington with considerable difficulties. An American human rights report cited arbitrary arrests, press censorship, long detentions without charges, surveillance, phone-tapping and the dismissal and beating of opposition political figures as "a calculated attempt by the Government to intimidate and silence the opposition."
Uzbekistan faces severe economic problems. The Soviet Union required Uzbekistan to concentrate on growing cotton, which has ravaged its environment and distorted its agricultural balance. Uzbekistan remains the world's fourth-largest cotton producer, though more land is reverting now to fruits and vegetables. It also mines gold and uranium and produces natural gas. Last March, some oil was discovered.
But the economy is worsening. The conversion to private property and ownership that has started fitfully in Russia has barely begun here, and Western investors are wary of what they regard as a rich country with an unstable political environment.
Prices are inevitably rising, despite Government subsidies on bread, butter, rice, cooking oil and other items. But a system of rationing through neighborhood stores has produced inevitable shortages. Pensioners live mostly on bread and tea.
The problems can be seen in the huge central market of Tashkent, where there are lines to buy the savory grilled shashlik with onions on the fresh flat bread called nam and the prices are cheaper than in Moscow.
 
Meat Is a Luxury On Worker's Pay

But a construction worker in the market, who said to call him Uncle Misha, is supporting his wife and four children on 6,000 rubles a month, about $10. A kilo of meat costs nearly 12 percent of his monthly salary.
"I don't know if we'll make it," he said, looking over bruised apples.
Compounding these problems, the government is facing a severe budget crunch and has started to lay off workers.
Uzbek officials will not talk openly about the crackdown, but they say Mr. Karimov's foremost aim is political stability in a time of economic transition and regional tensions.
They say Uzbekistan has taken an object lesson from Tajikistan and cannot allow Islamic "fundamentalists" and naive democrats to inflame tensions. They imply the Uzbek opposition has close ties to proponents of Islamic rule, which the opposition denies.
Religion does indeed play a major part in the lives of the people here, and a focus for opposition to the government. At the Tellah Shakh mosque, services are full, with the shoes of the faithful in racks outside the door.
Men in the national robe-like coat, or chupan, and the embroidered, four-sided cap, or tyubeteyka, mingle on the street, looking at religious books for sale or listening to tapes of foreign mullahs. Rashid Hassanov, a pensioner, said religion was freer now.
Nearby, at the Shaik Zainuddin mosque, some 1,000 men worshiped inside and another 500 were outside.
"Of course Karimov is afraid of such strong religious power as in Iran or Tajikistan," said a 54-year-old carpenter who declined to give his name. "They're still Communists. If you say something against them, they'll grab you by the throat." He thought for a moment and said: "But we can pray, that's the main thing."
 
Trying to Separate Religion and Politics
 Mr. Karimov says he is trying to draw a sharp line between religion and politics. Any religious-based party is banned, including the Islamic Renaissance Party, which was active in Tajikistan and works underground here. Its leader, Abdullah Utayev, and as many as 20 others are already in jail.
Last spring, in the Fergana Valley, where religion is strong, Mr. Karimov moved to crush an organization called Adolat, or Justice, which organized vigilante groups to stop official corruption, and there were many arrests.
Deputy Prime Minister Bakhtiar S. Khamidov said that the opposition has "no real economic or political program." The Tajik events "quite clearly show that the fundamentalists do not represent the majority there," he said.
There have been persistent reports, confirmed by Tajik officials, that Uzbekistan sent military aid to the former Communists in Tajikistan. But Uzbek officials say Tashkent has provided only humanitarian aid.
Akhmadzhon Lukmanov, an Uzbek Foreign Ministry spokesman, said that Uzbekistan, with 1.5 million ethnic Tajiks in a population of about 19.9 million and the same number of ethnic Uzbeks in Tajikistan out of 5.1 million, could not help but be nervous over a religious and clan war next door.
"Certain groups there with fundamentalist goals just wanted to take power, and at the same time they covered their activities with talk of democracy," he said.
 
Court Used to Stifle Opposition Voice
 The court cases against opposition groups seem to proceed from the assumption that they are power-hungry dupes of the Islamic right. On Jan. 19, for example, after a brief case, the activities of the main opposition movement, Birlik, or Unity, were suspended for three months in what the official newspaper, Voice of the People, called "a last chance."
Calling Birlik leaders "puppets in the hands of forces that seek anarchy and chaos," the paper, with Stalinist echoes, said: "It's impossible to stop the locomotive of history. They tried by putting a rotten log across the tracks."
Two days later, the trial began of a Birlik leader, Abdumannob Pulatov, who was kidnapped by Uzbek Interior Ministry police from Kyrgyzstan in early December after attending a human-rights conference.
Young men wielding steel pipes cracked the skull of Mr. Pulatov's brother, Abdurahim, Birlik's chairman, outside the Interior Ministry after he was questioned June 29. He is now in exile.
Abdumannob Pulatov, a 41-year-old physicist and chairman of the Uzbek Human Rights Committee, was convicted for "offending the honor and dignity of the President." He was charged with creating and causing to have carried a poster of Mr. Karimov a year ago, after three students died in price riots, with the caption: "There is a beast that eats its children."
The case against Mr. Pulatov had significant inconsistencies. Uzbek police intermittently prevented an American diplomat, a reporter and other foreigners from entering the trial, despite the judge's permission. On Jan. 29, Mr. Pulatov received a sentence of three years, but was immediately pardoned by the judge, who invoked a prior presidential amnesty.
Mr. Pulatov thanked Western diplomats and human-rights organizations. "I'm free because our President decided to reach a compromise with the West," he said.
There are many more such trials on the docket. The secretary of Birlik, Vasiliya Inoyatova, is facing similar charges of defaming the President because of a poem. Four people are currently under arrest on charges of trying to overthrow the Government.
At least 11 Birlik members have been arrested for a time and then released, and many have been fired from their university jobs, including Shukhrat Ismatulayev and Marat Zakhidov, both mathematicians, the co-chairmen of Birlik.
Talib Yakubov, 53, a Birlik founder, was fired from the Pedagogical Institute on Nov. 30. The dean told him he could remain only if he promised to quit his political activity.
"The K.G.B. has a free hand," he said, speaking in a darkened car under a weak street lamp. "It's like wolf hunting. The dogs are pushing us to the place where we can be killed."
 
Strong Convictions, Stronger Reaction
 The registered opposition party, Erk, or Freedom, has faced considerable pressure. Its bank accounts and cars have been seized, its newspaper shut, its building partly requisitioned.
Its chairman, Mohammed Salikh, 43, said bluntly: "Sometimes I think we're acting too openly. Our people are being arrested; there are provocations; they are threatened by telephone, with arms; some are hit by cars or beaten in the street. It strengthens our convictions, but with every hour this regime is getting stronger and more obvious. Freedom is being strangled here."
Asked whether he was concerned about the power of his comments, Mr. Salikh shrugged. "Karimov has a hot temper," he said. "If someone tells him Salikh gave an interview to The New York Times and said something bad, he could just call a general and say, 'Get rid of him.' He's very thin-skinned. Look at the Pulatov case."
Diplomats from secular Islamic countries counsel patience and suggest that because there is no democratic tradition here, the West must not hold Mr. Karimov to impossible standards. "This has never been a democracy and may never be one," one diplomat said. "It's important, in a list of 10 vital issues, not to overemphasize one or two."
"I know the Uzbeks," he said. "If you shout too loudly, they'll slam the door, and they'll keep it shut for a long time."

HEADLINE: U.N. Council Calls on Palestinians to Resume Talks

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 12

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council, closing the book on the dispute over Israel's deportation of 400 Palestinians more than six weeks ago, again urged Israel today to take back the deportees and called on the Palestinian delegation to return to the stalled Middle East peace talks.
Under a complicated agreement worked out over the last few weeks, the Council told Israel that it welcomed its decision to readmit 101 of the Palestinians deported to a barren strip of land in Lebanon separating the Israeli and Lebanese frontiers. But the Council said it expected Israel to comply fully with its order to take all of them back. 
 In a victory for Israel, the Council has also agreed to drop any consideration of an earlier demand by the Palestinian Liberation Organization for economic sanctions against Israel and is not now expected even to debate Israel's failure to comply fully with its orders.
 
Peace Talks a Priority
 The action reflects the efforts by the Clinton Administration, with the backing of all other Council members, including its three Muslim members, to give top priority to restarting the stalled Middle East peace negotiations after the Palestinians withdrew from those talks to protest the deportations.
The United States made it clear that it wanted the dispute over the deported Palestinians to be resolved at the United Nations before the departure of Secretary of State Warren Christopher for Israel on Wednesday on his first trip to the Middle East.
Some senior Israeli officials say they believe that as a result of today's compromise the Palestinians will return to the talks after Mr. Christopher completes his trip in about two weeks time. Several other Council members expressed a hope for that outcome but cautioned that they had no hard evidence of a behind-the-scenes deal.
The P.L.O. spokesmen here denied that their organization had made any commitment to re-enter the Middle East peace talks and said they had not agreed to today's action. "We are not a party to what was agreed today," said the P.L.O.'s chief representative, Nasser Al Kidwa, calling it "meaningless."
"My instructions are that our terms for returning to the peace talks remain the same, the full and safe return of all the Palestinian deportees," he added.
 
'Step in the Right Direction'
 Under today's arrangement, this month's Council President, Ahmed Snoussi of Morocco, explained the Council's views to Israel's United Nations representative, Gad Yaacobi, at a private meeting here this evening.
Afterward, he said the Council had reaffirmed its decision to demand the return of all the deportees but felt the readmission of 101 represented "a step in the right direction." The Council urged Israel to "advance expeditiously" toward full compliance with its demands. And it urged "all concerned" to seek to "reinvigorate the Middle East peace process."
The Israeli representative then restated his Government's position, that the expulsions represent a temporary and exceptional measure that is not a part of Israel's normal policy. Israel also says that all the temporary deportation orders will be reviewed by special boards regardless of whether an individual has lodged an appeal.
The reviews raises the possibility that many more deportees could be offered readmission well before their expulsion orders lapse at the end of this year. But Israeli officials deny having given the Clinton Administration any secret assurances that they would soon be offering to take back the remaining deportees.
After the meeting Mr. Yaacobi said he believed "this issue is now finally off the agenda of the Security Council." He urged all parties to return to the peace talks but gave no promise that the deportees would be allowed back before the end of the year.
The Security Council reacted to the original expulsions by voting on Dec. 18 to "strongly condemn" Israel's action as a breach of international law and demand that it immediately readmit all those who were deported into Lebanon but who were subsequently refused permission to enter that country.
The P.L.O. then asked the Council to impose a variety of mandatory sanctions on Israel when Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali reported on Jan. 26 that the special envoy he had sent to Jerusalem had failed to persuade Israel to bow to the Council's demands.
But the Clinton Administration came down firmly against any further Security Council action against Israel, saying its top priority was to get the peace talks started again. Britain, France, Russia and other Western members gave broad support.
The P.L.O.'s demand for sanctions also won little support from the Council's six third-world members, which include three Muslim countries: Morocco, Pakistan and Djibouti.
All opponents argued that any move to sanction Israel would certainly be vetoed by the United States and perhaps other permanent members too. Such a veto, they said, would only damage the Middle East peace negotiations further by giving a propaganda victory to Muslim fundamentalists opposed to any negotiations with Israel.
As this month's President, diplomats say, Morocco played a critical role in fashioning today's compromise, with King Hassan anxious to resolve the issue during his country's presidency as a sign of support for the peace talks.
 
An Impossible Goal
 An additional argument against attracting an American veto was that it would would end a two-and-half-year period during which the five permanent members of the Council -- the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China -- have refrained from using their vetoes and tried instead to settle disagreements by compromise.
Had a veto been used, many members feared that other permanent members would be tempted to veto actions that they found distasteful, and that Russia in particular might start using its veto to protect Yugoslavia's Serbian Government from further Council pressure on it to cooperate in ending the Bosnian civil war.
Once Israel bowed to American pressure and agreed to take back 101 deportees, the P.L.O. apparently concluded that sanctions had become an impossible goal.
Instead, it called for a resolution that would have done little more than urge Israel to comply fully with the Council's earlier orders. And when the major powers objected, it suggested that the Security Council should just hold a public debate on the whole issue so that it and its Arab supporters could air their views. But that idea was also rejected.
At a breakfast meeting with journalists in Washington, the Palestinian delegation's spokeswoman, Hanan Ashrawi, expressed a willingness to compromise with Israel to break the impasse.
"We will be willing to deal with whatever the Security Council decides," Mrs. Ashrawi said.

HEADLINE: Dow Ends at 3,392.43; Off for Day and Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday amid concern about President Clinton's State of the Union Message next week, especially over the possibility that tax increases will be part of a deficit-cutting package. The week ended very much the way it started, with the broad market retreating across its full breadth.
Analysts also cited some programmed selling, early weakness in bond prices and the three-day holiday weekend as factors in the decline.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 30.26 points, to 3,392.43. For the week, the Dow lost 49.71 points from its all-time record closing high of 3,442.14 at the end of last week.
 
Trading Tails Off
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the lightest of the week, at 216.8 million shares, down from 257.2 million on Thursday. The equity markets will be closed on Monday for the Washington's Birthday holiday. 
 "The Presidential attack on high drug prices, however valid, didn't help the already extended market and bore an uncomfortable resemblance to John Kennedy's 1962 attack on the steel industry that resulted in a bear market drop of 50 percent," said Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president and market analyst at Tucker Anthony.
"And because of the market's susceptibility to such high-level knocking," he added, "investors might be wise to take protective measures against a possible repetition."
Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst at Kidder, Peabody, noted that the brief swoon in the bond market after the release yesterday morning of the January producer price data was enough to take the heart out of the market.
"Trading-oriented investors usually shy away from holding long positions ahead of a three-day holiday, preferring instead to have their books a little balanced," he said.
Anther factor, Mr. Jarrett added, was the snowy weather in New York, which kept a lot of analysts away from the market.
ARCO fell 3/4, to 117 3/8, and Amerada Hess dropped 1 1/2, to 49 3/4, after a Paine Webber analyst cut his ratings on the companies to unattractive, advising investors to shift into overseas oil companies.
 
Boost for Big Airlines
 Stocks prices of the three largest domestic airlines were up after Merrill Lynch analysts lifted their rating for the group, citing an improved industry outlook. UAL, parent of United Airlines, rose 1 1/2, to 126; AMR, parent of American Airlines, rose 7/8, to 63, and Delta Air Lines, gained 3/4, to 51 3/8.
Netrix, a manufacturer of computer networking products, sank 6 3/4, to 12 1/4, after the company said fourth-quarter earnings had doubled to 10 cents a share, which was below its expectations. The company said economic sluggishness had slowed orders from Europe.
Sears rose 1 1/8, to 52 5/8. On Thursday, the retailer outlined a $4 billion, five-year program to upgrade its stores; Merrill Lynch raised its rating on the company to above average.
