HEADLINE: U.S. Details Careful Plan Of Hijacker

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
The Ethiopian who commandeered a German jetliner to New York carefully planned the hijacking for some time because he had been refused entry to the United States and had "personal and family problems" that required his presence here, Federal authorities said yesterday.
The nature of the problems was not disclosed, but the suspect, Nebiu Demeke, who had lived in Germany since last August and is the son of an Ethiopian father who is an economist and a Moroccan mother, said he had brothers in Minnesota and Indiana and a sister, Selamawit Demeke, at Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania.
 
Bail Hearing in Court
 Mr. Demeke also told the authorities how he had deftly smuggled a harmless starter's pistol aboard the Africa-bound jet over Austria on Wednesday, hiding the gun under an Indiana Jones-style hat and then using it repeatedly to threaten pilots and flight attendants. As his arrest loomed, he swapped it for the pilot's sunglasses. 
 As most of the hijacked passengers returned to Europe and German authorities focused anew on security at Frankfurt, Europe's largest and busiest air hub, the pilot of the Lufthansa jet described the ordeal at a news conference and the hijacking moved from a sky-and-runway drama into the courts yesterday.
Alternately brooding and smiling, a thin, small man who looked more like 12 than 20 years old, Mr. Demeke appeared before United States Magistrate Allyne Ross in Brooklyn for a bail hearing on Federal charges of air piracy carrying penalties of 20 years to life in prison.
In a Federal complaint that provided many new details of the episode, he was accused of seizing Lufthansa Flight 592 with 94 passengers and 10 crew members after it left Frankfurt, bound for Cairo and Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, and of commandeering it to New York by threatening to kill crew members with what looked like a semiautomatic pistol but actually fired only blanks.
During the 11 1/2-hour, 5,600-mile odyssey, the complaint said, the hijacker put the gun to the head of the pilot, Capt. Gerhard Goebel, and threatened to shoot a flight attendant every five minutes during a refueling stop in Hanover, but surrendered without a struggle when the wide-bodied, twin-engine Airbus 310 landed at Kennedy International Airport at midafternoon.
The complaint said Mr. Demeke "admitted his involvement in the hijacking" and told Federal agents that he "planned the hijacking because he had been unable to enter the United States lawfully" and because he had "personal and family problems which required his presence in the United States."
Clad in blue jeans, a turquoise paisley shirt and a blue ski sweater under a large black parka, the defendant stood silently beside his court-appointed lawyer, Marcia Levy, during the 15-minute hearing. Mr. Demeke entered no plea to the charges, and the hearing focused on the question of bail.
 
Held Without Bail
 Thomas H. Roche, associate United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, asked that Mr. Demeke be held without bail and told the court the defendant had confessed to a premeditated hijacking, had endangered the lives of all on board the jetliner, had no job or apparent means of support and might flee if he was released.
Ms. Levy did not comment on most of these assertions or on the substance of the charges, but denied that her client might flee. "He has a strong desire to be exactly where he is," she said. "There is no risk of flight." But the magistrate ordered Mr. Demeke held without bail for a hearing on Feb. 26.
German authorities said Mr. Demeke, a former student in Morocco, had arrived in Germany last August and had applied for political asylum. But he withdrew the application this month and decided to return to his native Ethiopia. As is customary in such cases, the German Government paid for his ticket.
While security at Frankfurt Airport was under review, the complaint against Mr. Demeke said he had smuggled his starter's pistol aboard with a simple trick -- putting it under his Indiana Jones-style hat. At the security checkpoint, it said, he was scanned with a hand-held metal detector, but only from the shoulders down.
"The defendant was then asked to remove his hat, which he did, thereby concealing the pistol from the security officer," the complaint said, implying that he had pinched the pistol in the crown of the wide-brimmed fedora in a slick conjurer's move.
 
Threats to Kill
 Once on board, the complaint said, Mr. Demeke entered a lavatory, donned a ski mask, drew his pistol and emerged to seize a flight attendant as a hostage. In the cockpit, he "placed the pistol against the head of the captain" and ordered him to fly to New York.
But a refueling was needed, and Mr. Demeke, impatient during 90 minutes on the ground in Hanover, threatened to kill a flight attendant every five minutes unless the refueling was speeded up, the complaint said. Later, over the ocean, he told Captain Goebel that he had "planned this for a long time."
The captain, at a news conference in Frankfurt yesterday, said: "I told him that he had planned very well. I praised him. He was proud of what he had accomplished. At first, he was hyper-nervous, threatening. Things loosened up with time, and we developed a kind of collegial relationship."
Federal officials acknowledged, meantime, that they had misidentified the hijacker and misstated his possible motives in Wednesday's swirl of confusion. Officials here and in Germany mistakenly named Ferah Siyad Shuriye, a 31-year-old Somali living in Norway, as the hijacker, and said he had demanded American intervention in the war in Bosnia.
Mischance, a bizarre anonymous call and a progression of rumors apparently accounted for the gaffes. Mr. Shuriye was aboard, seated just in front of the hijacker, and a boarding pass with his name on it was found on the floor. Since the hijacker never gave his name to the crew, the pass was thought to be his.

HEADLINE: ARGENTINA SIGNS TECHNOLOGY PACT

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Broadly opening its technology to a Latin American country for the first time, the United States signed an agreement with Argentina today that will permit this country to buy some of the most advanced computer equipment, nuclear technology and aeronautical guidance systems.
In a memorandum of understanding signed in the ornate San Martin Palace in downtown Buenos Aires, Argentina agreed to a broad range of controls over technology it develops and any technology it receives from the United States. 
 It is the first time the United States has nudged a Latin American country into an agreement that effectively controls the transfer of missile and nuclear technology, as well as technology that could lead to the manufacturing of chemical and biological weapons, to potentially hostile third countries.
For Argentina, the agreement means the flow of more sophisticated computer equipment and greater acceptance among industrialized Western countries as a significant international player toward global stability.
 
Argentina Reliability Noted
 "Basically it shows that we think this country is reliable and responsible in handling the use of potentially dangerous technology," said a United States official who asked not to be identified. "This country has come a long way."
Just a decade ago, after the Falkland Islands war, Argentina was one of the most bellicose countries criticizing the dominant presence of the United States. But under President Carlos Saul Menem, the country's political orientation has been reversed.
Not only did Argentina restore ties to Britain and renounce the use of force in seeking the return of the Falklands, but at the request of the United States it has nearly abolished its medium-range ballistic missile program, called the Condor II, which it developed in the early 1980's with Egyptian and Iraqi financing.
The demise of the Condor II was critical in the United States' decision to sign the memorandum of understanding on the control of strategic exports today. For years Washington maintained that the Condor II was a potential technology that would add to the arsenals of hostile Middle East countries, especially that of Iraq. The missile, more accurate than the Scud, was capable of carrying nuclear payloads.
The United States has been trying to conclude a similar agreement with Brazil, but those talks have stalled, a United States official said.
American officials said Argentina was on its way to becoming a member the Coordinating Committee on Export Controls, or Cocom, an informal group of 17 countries aimed at keeping out of the hands of hostile countries technology that could be used in the making of weapons of mass destruction.
 
A First Step
 Today's agreement is considered Argentina's first step toward membership, which could be still several years off. United States officials said the key was for a country like Argentina to show a track record of abiding by the export restrictions.
In addition to ending the Condor II program, the country enacted a law last year that greatly restricted the export of its technology.
The new agreement permits this country, which has been struggling to modernize its economy and industry, to acquire computers, munitions, nuclear reactor technology and chemical technology that is likely to speed its development.
After suffering decades of high inflation, military governments and persistent corruption scandals, Argentina is longing to be considered part of the industrialized world and not of the third world. Mr. Menem frequently tries to persuade Argentines that the country is either part of the first world or just on the doorstep.

HEADLINE: From Intel, the Thinking Machine's Chip

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation has begun shipping samples of a computer chip that imitates the circuitry of the human brain.
The chip is the largest and fastest neural network processor yet built, and computer designers and scientists say the new technology is the most promising approach toward building intelligent machines that mimic hearing, seeing and thinking -- functions today's computers do poorly. 
 The project is still a gamble for the world's leading maker of the microprocessors that form the core of popular desktop computers. Researchers have been experimenting with systems that simulate "biological computers" for more than a decade. Yet beyond some promising niche applications, Intel has not yet found a widespread use for these chips.
Developed in partnership with Nestor Inc., a Providence, R.I., computer development company, and with only about $1.6 million from the Pentagon, the new chip is designed to recognize patterns of information quickly and precisely. It is structured as an array of 1,024 silicon "neurons," each with a tremendous amount of memory to store and retrieve data.
Artificial neural networks are modeled on the human brain's biological network of hundreds of billions of special cells, or neurons, that transmit information back and forth, making possible behavior like learning and recognition.
The computerized neural networks may one day be able to perform tasks like recognizing objects and understanding speech, which have so far stymied conventional computers. Moreover, with the ability to learn by themselves, such machines would not require the laborious programming of rules and procedures now required to allow computers to work.
"Neural nets offer a whole new way of viewing how computing can be done," Gordon Moore, Intel's chairman and the company's co-founder, said this week. "This represents a significant step toward the mainstream."
The designers of the chip said it was capable of performing 20 billion simple operations a second, a favorable rate when compared with that of today's most powerful supercomputers. Moreover, the new chip, known as the Ni1000, contains 3.7 million transistors, a larger number than Intel's new Pentium personal computer microprocessor, which is yet to be introduced.
In addition, the neural network processor is expected to be more resilient than its conventional microprocessor counterparts, Intel's designers said. Because it is based on a network of separate neurons, a single or even dozens of processing elements can fail and the chip's performance will not be harmed. In contrast, in a conventional microchip, the failure of a single transistor can be fatal.
A number of small start-up companies, as well as large electronics companies like Intel, Motorola, A.T.& T. and Ricoh, are all pursuing neural network systems. But many researchers in the field are skeptical about the economic viability of taking experimental designs and freezing them in silicon chip designs.
"This gives the researchers less freedom to change their particular design," said Ronjon Naj, a neural network expert who is the head of Lexicus Inc., a Palo Alto, Calif., pen software recognition company. "Even if you do use them, the cost of putting them into a machine may limit the application."
But another industry analyst said it was possible that Intel might find a profitable business for its new chip.
"There is a lot of attention being given to fuzzy logic chips in home appliances and cruise controls in cars," said Sanjiv Varma, an artificial intelligence expert at New Science Associates in Mountain View, Calif. "Some entrepreneur might come up with an embedded application for Intel's neural processor that is not high-tech but is more mundane."
Because it is based largely on technology initially developed by Intel's memory division, the neural processor took only a fraction of the resources needed to developed the Pentium. A team of five circuit designers laid out the chip, and it was produced with $1.6 million from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency and the Office of Naval Research. Intel invested an additional $1.1 million, and Nestor put up $400,000.
The Pentagon has been investing heavily in smart weapons and a generation of automated battlefield control systems.
A number of researchers said the most interesting feature of Intel's new Ni1000 is the tremendous amount of memory, more than 330 kilobytes on each chip. Memory is increasingly being viewed as more important than raw speed in determining the power of neural networks. Memory provides the context that is thought to be vital to recognition in advanced systems.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Rise 0.2%, Easing Inflation Concerns

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Wholesale prices remained under control in January and business sales jumped sharply in December, the Government said today in two more economic reports suggesting continued gradual economic improvement.
"The expansion is solidly in place," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting service. "It's just going to remain quite moderate." 
 The Labor Department said its Producer Price Index edged up two-tenths of a percent in January after a one-tenth of a percent advance a month earlier and one-tenth of a percent declines in October and November.
"We're moving in the right direction," said Ron Schriebman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler Distributors. "We just need to pedal faster and create some more jobs."
The wholesale prices report showed that much of the increase was in energy products and automobiles. Food prices were down. At an annual rate, wholesale inflation was running at 2 percent, just slightly more than the 1.6 percent in 1992.
The Commerce Department said business sales at the manufacturing, wholesale and retail level shot up 1.9 percent in December, outpacing the four-tenths of a percent buildup in inventories, including a 1.7 percent jump in retail stockpiles.
Analysts were unable to explain the surge in the retail backlog, which took place at the same time stores were reporting an eight-tenths of a percent increase in sales during the strongest holiday shopping season in four years.
Still, the overall inventories-to-sales ratio fell to 1.46, the lowest level in at least 10 years. That means that it would take 1.46 months to exhaust backlogs at the December sales pace.
Slim inventories often mean increased production and more jobs as businesses try to meet increased demand as the economy picks up.
In the wholesale price report, the Labor Department said food prices dropped nine-tenths of a percent in January after jumping 1.3 percent a month earlier. Vegetable prices, which shot up 48.4 percent in December, fell back 19.2 percent last month.
Energy prices, on the other hand, rose nine-tenths of a percent, including a 2.9 percent jump in gasoline prices. The cost of energy products fell 2.3 percent in December.
Excluding the often-volatile food and energy components, the core rate of wholesale inflation rose four-tenths of a percent, partly because of what analysts said were one-time increases of 1.2 percent in automobile prices and 2.6 percent in tobacco products.
 
Inflation Front Calm
 Mr. Schriebman of the wholesale distributors association said the report showed that wholesale inflation began 1993 where it left off last year.
"There's no volatility in producer prices and hasn't been for two years now," he said. "There's just too much slack in the economy, too much idle capacity, to rile up inflationary pressures."
In the food component, beef prices were down three-tenths of a percent while chicken prices dropped 3.9 percent. Dairy products declined five-tenths of a percent and fresh fruit, 6.6 percent.
These declines were partly offset by an 8.3 percent jump in fish prices and a 1.3 percent increase in pork prices.
Electricity was up seven-tenths of a percent. But natural gas prices edged down one-tenth of a percent and fuel oil dropped by half a percent.
The 1.2 percent rise in auto prices wiped out a two-tenths of a percent decline a month earlier. Economists at the Mitsubishi Bank in New York attributed the increase in car prices to lower price-tag incentives.
 
Clothing Prices Mixed
 Women's apparel prices increased two-tenths of a percent, but men's and boy's clothing dropped half a percent. Girls' and infants' apparel prices were down seven-tenths of a percent. Footwear was down one-tenth of a percent.
Prescription drug prices dipped five-tenths of a percent after December's 1.4 percent advance. Magazine prices jumped 1.4 percent.
Tobacco product prices were up 2.6 percent in January, more than twice as much as in December. Alcoholic beverage prices fell three-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed While Gold Prices Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday, rising against the German mark and Japanese yen amid positive economic news.
Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery traded late at $329.60 a troy ounce, down $2.60 from late Thursday. The Republic National Bank of New York said gold fell $2.45 an ounce, to a late bid price of $328.80 an ounce. 
 Zlatko Glamuzina, chief currency dealer at Banco di Sicilia, said positive economic news announced yesterday had driven the dollar higher against the mark as the trading day progressed.
Also influencing the market was a report that the University of Michigan's February index for consumer expectations remained unchanged. Mr. Glamuzina said the index had been expected to fall, so this was positive news.
Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 120.45 yen, down 1.07 yen from Wednesday's close. Japanese financial markets were closed Thursday for a national holiday. Later in London, the dollar finished at a higher rate of 120.78 yen. In New York, the dollar traded at 120.65 yen, up from 121.175 yen late Thursday.
In New York, it cost $1.4205 to buy one British pound, compared with $1.4180 late Thursday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.4180, from $1.4190 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.6615 German marks, up from 1.6577; 1.5415 Swiss francs, up from 1.5355; 5.6225 French francs, up from 5.6050; 1.8705 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8650; 1,547.00 Italian lire, up from 1,543.00, and 1.2551 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2563.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $328.35 a troy ounce, compared with $331.80 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, it fell to a late bid of $328.50, compared with $331.90 bid late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 55 cents an ounce to close at $331.10.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cattle Prices Continue Rise As Storms Muddy Feedlots

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Live cattle futures prices hit a record high yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as foul weather threatened to further constrict tight supplies of slaughter-ready animals. Other cattle and pork futures finished mixed in Chicago.
On other commodity markets, oil futures fell, lumber futures rose, and grains and soybeans ended mixed. 
 Live cattle futures rose in response to continued strength in the cash market yesterday after a winter storm dumped snow on sodden feed yards in Nebraska and western Kansas.
Analysts said the precipitation worsened the condition of mucky feedlots that had begun to dry out after a series of storms from late November through January.
Deep mud drains body heat from cattle, slowing their rate of weight gain and forcing feeders to either hold back animals or sell them to meatpackers at subnormal weights.
Cattle carcasses have averaged 685 to 686 pounds since December, about 10 pounds below weights a year ago, said Joe Kropf, commodity analyst with Bill Helming Consulting Services in Shawnee, Kan.
"The feedlot conditions at the end of this week are better than they were at the first of December or the first of January but not as good as they were a week or so ago," he said.
 
Oil Futures Fall
 Crude oil and other energy futures fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Light sweet crude oil for March delivery sank 28 cents, to $19.98 a barrel. March heating oil tumbled 1.02 cents, to 55.63 cents a gallon. March unleaded gasoline fell 1.58 cents, to 53.58 cents a gallon. March natural gas fell 3.5 cents, to $1.71 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Spruce 2-by-4's for March delivery posted a sharp $7.20 gain to $395.70 for 1,000 board feet, the 15th straight record high. Lumber has been supported by tight supplies and rising demand as the economy strengthens.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, March wheat fell 2 3/4 cents, to $3.64 3/4 a bushel. March corn slipped 1/4 cent, to $2.12 1/4 a bushel. March oats fell 1/2 cent, to $1.40 1/4 a bushel. March soybeans rose 3 1/2 cents, to $5.70 1/2 a bushel.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
3 New Offerings: Bond, Stock and Mixed

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Tax-conscious investors with a conservative bent might consider the new T. Rowe Price Tax-Free Insured Intermediate Bond Fund from T. Rowe Price Associates of Baltimore.
Owning bonds that mature in 5 to 10 years reduces the volatility of the fund's share price by about a third, which is a plus should interest rates begin to rise. 
 The insurance, which guarantees payment of the bonds' principal and interest in the event of default (but does not guarantee the share price will not fall), reduces the fund's yield by about two-tenths of 1 percent now, the company estimates. The fund's 30-day yield is 4.98 percent.
Another new offering is the Mutual Discovery Fund, the fourth entrant in a series of funds managed by Michael Price and sponsored by Mutual Series Fund Inc. of Short Hills, N.J.
Discovery will invest in small-capitalization stocks in the United States and overseas and may buy bonds or securities of companies involved in mergers or reorganizations.
Mr. Price, who has a good long-term record, uses a value approach to stock picking, which is now in vogue. "Value" managers buy companies they think are undervalued while "growth" managers buy companies whose earnings are expected to outpace the average.
Oakmark International Fund is a new overseas stock fund managed by the Chicago-based Harris Associates, whose Oakmark Fund was the top-performing fund last year.
Like Oakmark, the overseas fund uses a value approach to stock picking. Overseas investments may be good bets now because they have lagged behind domestic investments for four consecutive years.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Albertville Learning To Turn Gold, Silver And Bronze Into Green

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBERTVILLE, France

 BODY:
For any American television viewer who overdosed on luge last February, Ray Leblanc and 16 days of snow-capped, tape-delayed Winter Olympic scenery from the French Alps, a return to the Savoy region one year later reveals an area indelibly marked by the Olympic experience.
The enormous Olympic rings are still painted on the highway in the workaday outskirts of Albertville. Windows full of Magique-the-mascot dolls and "Albertville '92" duffel bags at 40 percent off still fill the stores on the city's main street. 
 At the edge of town, past signs for "Le Parc Olympique," stands the Ice Hall, where Kristi Yamaguchi's combination of artistry and athleticism carried her to a gold medal in ladies figure skating. Now, anyone can rent a pair of skates, open a door and lurch gamely onto the ice. Only this is no longer quite the same arena where Yamaguchi starred. Although the hall's interior shell is unchanged, only 1,200 of the original 9,000 seats remain. It is as if someone has laid out a Little League stadium in a space shuttle hangar.
 
Gone to Barcelona
 Across a two-lane road from the Ice Hall, the site of the whimsical and memorable opening ceremonies bears little resemblance to the place where 1,808 athletes from 64 nations paraded on Feb. 8, 1992. The 30,000-seat stadium is gone, shipped off piecemeal to Barcelona to accommodate Summer Olympic fans. In its place is a huge dirt lot that contains only one vestige of its former function: the elaborate steel mast that served as an axis for the imaginative choreography of the young ceremonies director, Philippe Decoufle.
Across the lot at the speed skating oval where Bonnie Blair once again warmed middle America's collective heart, the stadium has been left untouched, but the ice has been replaced by a rubberized, all-weather track.
"Before the Olympics, the foreigners never stopped in Albertville," said Nathalie Miege, who works in a souvenir shop. "They all come through now and take their pictures, but I think they're a little disappointed because there's not much left anymore. Not in Albertville anyway."
Up the serpentine roads that lead to the ski resorts, the evidence is more plentiful. In Courchevel, the two ski jumps still tower over their wooded surroundings. In Val d'Isere, the men's downhill run, La Face de Bellevarde, is now open to recreational skiers. In Meribel, the hockey rink is home to junior tournaments and figure skating exhibitions.
 
'A Good Source of Income'
 Even the bobsled and luge track, which gave organizers such fits because of environmental safety concerns, has finally resumed operation in the hamlet of La Roche, offering bold tourists the chance to glide top to bottom with a driver for 400 francs (about $75).
"We see this is a good source of income," said Andre Broche, the track's director, who must balance the track's books over the next three years to keep it open.
Money remains an everyday topic in the Savoy. The good news is that the $52 million deficit run up by the Olympic Organizing Committee was quickly covered by the federal government and the Savoy Regional Council. The troubling news is that some small communities who viewed the Games as an excuse to think big continue to struggle.
Brides-les-Bains, site of the principal Olympic village, is still searching for financing to underwrite a deficit that exceeds $11 million. Pralognan, which was host to the demonstration sport of curling, ended up paying $2 million (about $3,400 for each of its 600 inhabitants) to cover its share of constructing an ice rink. Les Saisies, site of the cross-country events, has reportedly been ordered by the Government to spend no more on infrastructure improvements until 1997 because of its financial difficulties.
Local taxes are up in many areas of the region, even in the tony commune of Meribel/Les Allues.
"My taxes have increased about 15 percent," said Jean-Marie Choffel, Meribel's director of tourism. "Of course everybody resents it, but it's the price you pay. There aren't many places who have the chance to hold the Olympics. There is a cost, and the hope is that you will benefit in the long term."
 
Strong Start to Season
 Some short-term benefits have already become apparent. Tourism was up significantly in the Olympic region throughout the summer, and with some help from an early snowfall, the first month of the winter season produced record occupancy rates.
"We have never started a season like this; the lifts in the Three Valleys have seen their receipts go up 60 percent," said Michel Barnier, the president of the Savoie General Council who was a co-president of the organizing committee with Jean-Claude Killy. "It will be a very good season, but I want to be prudent. I won't say we've really succeeded until I see the same sort of numbers after two or three seasons."
The pre-Olympic improvements made in local transportation have certainly played a role in the early success. New and improved roads have cut traveling times from Lyons to the high-altitude stations by as much as a third during peak periods. But the fact remains that nearly 25 percent of the Savoy's visitors this winter have been first-time visitors, and the majority of those have been foreigners who discovered the Savoy last February.
The optimism over tourism has helped soften the psychological blow to an area that in the last year has seen unemployment rise from a relatively low 7.5 percent to 10 percent, which is near the national average.
Despite the difficulties, it is no easy task to find someone who regrets embarking on the Olympic adventure.
"We miss the Olympics here," said Daniel Marret, an Albertville bartender. "For five years before the Games, it was like people dared to dream. They worked toward a common goal and forgot some of their petty differences. Now, Albertville is becoming again just another small town. I guess it's inevitable. You only live an experience like that once in your life."
 
'We Made It to the End'
 Although Barnier can wax nostalgic about the lighting and extinguishing of the flame, it is clearly his relationship with Killy that marked him the most.
"We started together on this project 10 years ago, and we made it to the end," he said. "I was very happy to show that two different men could live such an adventure together and come away friends."
In June, Killy was named president of Amaury Sports, a Paris-based organization that among other tasks, negotiates television rights for the Tour de France and the Paris-Dakar automobile rally. Barnier, a Neo-Gaullist member of Parliament, recently authored a book on environmental trouble spots and is preparing to stand for re-election in March.
He plans to make his second trip to Lillehammer, Norway, this summer to meet with the next Olympic organizers.
"I don't want to give them too much advice," Barnier said. "I will go see them out of friendship because we have always had a good relationship. All I would say is not to lose a minute. The last year goes very quickly."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A road sign welcoming visitors to Albertville now only points to a largely deserted town a year after the Winter Games. (Pascal Rondeau/Allsport for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1231 words

HEADLINE: Seattle, City of Future, Finds It's a Company Town

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Over the last seven years, during one of the worst economic periods in modern times, few cities in America added jobs as quickly as Seattle did. This Pacific Rim port has been held up as the city of the future: an economy free of smokestack industries, producing things the world wants to buy, from airplanes and computer software to biotechnology and exotic coffee.
On Jan. 26, a day some here are calling "Black Tuesday," the city of the future was told it might lose 50,000 jobs in the next 18 months -- nearly 5 percent of the area's work force. The Boeing Company, this city's old partner in civic destiny, said hard times in the world airline industry were forcing it to cut production by 35 percent. 
 The move is very likely to result in up to 20,000 layoffs at Boeing plants in the Puget Sound area and tens of thousands more at businesses here that depend on the Boeing payroll. Boeing is also laying off 5,000 or so workers at plants in Wichita, Kan.
When Pittsburgh lost its steel mills, or Flint, Mich., lost its auto plants, the cities were said to be rust belt relics clinging to dinosaur industries. Seattle's story is different, making it all the more troubling to business and Government leaders trying to build the nation's manufacturing base.
 
Clinton Pledges Help
 For one thing, Boeing is no dinosaur. Even with its recent contraction, it is the nation's leading exporter, building nearly 60 percent of the world's airplanes. Last year its profits were $1.6 billion. It has orders stretching to the 21st century. The jobs are high paying and mostly high technology.
On Wednesday, responding to a question from a Boeing worker at his televised "town meeting," President Clinton said the Government intended to take forceful measures to keep Boeing and the rest of the aerospace industry healthy.
"I am not going to roll over and play dead," Mr. Clinton said. "Seven technologies are going to shape the high-wage jobs of the future. And one of the biggest is commercial aviation. The United States has a lead there. We are losing it because we have not fought to maintain it."
But while political leaders may be able to shore up the domestic air industry, those measures are not likely to help the world economy. And Boeing, more than virtually any other major American company, has hitched its fortunes to world commerce.
 
Dangers of Dependency
 Seattle coasted above the last major recession in large part because it had an economy based on world trade. What the layoff announcements have demonstrated to many business leaders here is that no city, no matter how forward-looking and global its economic base, should be so dependent on a single company.
"When everybody else was singing its praises, I thought the Seattle economy was a train wreck waiting to happen because it was so dependent on Boeing," said Joel Kotkin, a Los Angeles writer who specializes in Pacific Rim trends and is a senior fellow at the Center for the New West in Denver.
From 1984 to 1990, Boeing doubled its Seattle-area payroll to a high of 106,000. In those years, the Puget Sound region added more than 300,000 jobs, growing at three times the national average. At one point, Boeing was hiring 500 people a week. Now the company employs 98,000 people in the metropolitan area, which has a population of 2 million.
Mike Wills moved to Seattle in 1987, bought a house, then began a family with his wife. He was hired by Boeing two years ago but was notified last month that he would soon be laid off. "I chose Seattle over other cities because it seemed like there would be more opportunity," he said. "I'm optimistic I'll land on my feet. But the short-term fear from something like this puts a lot of stress on the family."
 
The Envy of Other Cities
 The recent Boeing boom may have produced a false sense of security, what Glenn Pascall, a local economist and writer, called "an absolute sense of superiority because of the dominance of Boeing."
"Seattle is what every city is trying to become," said Mr. Pascall. "It is already a high-tech center, competing globally. But then something like these massive layoffs come along and it makes you wonder."
Perhaps no major city in the nation is more attached to a single employer. Even General Motors employs far fewer people in the Detroit area, about 50,000, than Boeing does in Seattle.
"People who've been in Seattle long enough are really afraid of Boeing, because they've been hammered before by these busts," said Charles Royer, the former Mayor, now director of the Institute of Politics at Harvard University. "It's like San Franciscans who have been through an earthquake. You walk around on eggshells, even during the good times."
The city has shaken some of its dependence on the aerospace giant. In 1970, after a collapse of major orders for new planes, the company shed 64,000 jobs, two-thirds of the payroll, and the famous sign appeared: "Will the last person leaving Seattle please turn out the lights?" Unemployment reached 13 percent, the highest of any city in the nation.
 
Buoyed by Microsoft
 Virtually no one is predicting such a gloomy scene this time around. Twenty years ago, 1 in 5 jobs in the Seattle area was at Boeing. Today the figure is 1 in 10, and the region supports more than 200,000 high-tech jobs, many at Microsoft, where the average salary is $81,000 a year. It is also a national leader in biotechnology, fisheries and container-ship port activity.
Dick Conway, who makes the economic forecasts for several Seattle-area government agencies, says the city may still escape a recession, even with the loss of 50,000 jobs. Boeing, he said, is the only drag on an otherwise healthy economy.
"The reason we've done better than most states is because through Boeing and others, we are more dependent on world trade than any other state," Mr. Conway said. "Over the long run, I'd say if you have to be dependent on someone, you couldn't pick a better company to be dependent on than Boeing."
Still, the drag is a big one. Because Boeing workers are paid so much more than they were 20 years ago and are far more productive, the layoffs will affect virtually every part of the region's economy, he said.
 
Both Loved and Loathed
 There is talk in Washington, D.C., about providing some sort of legislative relief for Boeing and the airlines. One proposal, backed by Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, would change bankruptcy laws so that airlines operating under such restrictions could not start fare wars, thereby dragging down the healthy carriers. Over the last three years the nation's airlines have lost more than $9 billion, which is more than they made in profit in the previous 44 years.
Seattle residents have long been ambivalent about Boeing. "Most of us regard Boeing the way Indians once thought of Mount Rainier -- a cloudy, mysterious place about which nothing much can be known," David Brewster, editor of The Seattle Weekly, a newspaper focusing on the news and the arts, wrote in a recent column.
Paul Schell, dean of the School of Architecture at the University of Washington and a Seattle Port commissioner, calls Boeing the "company people love to hate."
"If there's a good side to these layoffs, it is that this will stir us out of a complacency that comes from having a Boeing in your backyard," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: In Seattle, a city whose fortunes grew even during recent times of economic slowdown, the Boeing Company's announcement last month of its intention to lay off workers has made city leaders rethink the soundness of being so dependent on a single company. (Photographs by Therese Frare for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
A Lawyerly Search for a Good Lawyer

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Maybe Shakespeare, Dickens and Dan Quayle were right.
Recent events in Washington have only reinforced the arguments of those who would "kill all the lawyers," or at least curb them, or at the very least not let a lot of them get into a room and make important decisions affecting the country. 
 The Clinton Administration's tortuous search for an Attorney General, which may have ended with the selection of Janet Reno, the Miami prosecutor, must seem strange to most Americans.
How could Judge Kimba M. Wood have been interviewed by a President who is a lawyer, a First Lady who is a lawyer, a White House counsel and half a dozen others who are lawyers -- and still everyone comes out of these talks without the answer to their most important question?
How could these high-powered lawyers have never realized that there would be a political problem with Zoe Baird when she told them at the start that she had broken the law? And how could they have failed to see that because one woman did something illegal and the other did not, that their stories might play differently with the public?
 
Friends and Strangers
 And as Rush Limbaugh, the conservative talk show host, put it, "Why has it taken so long for a bunch of lawyers to find a good lawyer?"
It seems strange that the First and Second Lawyer always seemed to have been picking people recommended by others but strangers to them, even with their vast network of lawyer friends. Indeed, Mr. Clinton seemed to have a hard time explaining just how he had failed to notice Ms. Reno, even though she was a friend of his brother-in-law.
Res ipsa loquitur, as lawyers like to say: The matter speaks for itself.
Charles Peters, the editor of The Washington Monthly, said the cases of Ms. Baird and Judge Wood are instructive: "In both instances, you had a tremendous number of lawyers who fooled around and missed the main point. Isn't that a symbol of what happens when you've got all these lawyers running things?"
Mr. Peters says the tone of the Clinton Administration so far has been more lawyerly and elitist than populist. In the campaign last year, many Americans were drawn to the plain-spoken Ross Perot, who promised to run the Government like a business. Mr. Clinton, by contrast, has an Administration that comes across like a high-powered law firm.
Even by the standards of a capital accustomed to a glut of lawyers, this President has surrounded himself with a lot of lawyers, many in top jobs that require no legal training. He has also conducted the opening weeks of his Presidency in a lawyerly way, getting bogged down in technicalities, loopholes, caveats and flyspecking.
Robert Altman, the movie director who lives in New York, finds Washington these days all too reminiscent of his 1975 movie, "Nashville," in which a folksy, blunt character named Hal Phillip Walker (a presage of Ross Perot) began a third-party campaign for President with a pledge to eliminate all the lawyers from Congress, because, as he said: "A lawyer is trained for two things and two things only -- to clarify, that's one. And to confuse."
In an interview, Mr. Altman said: "The basic philosophy of lawyers is that there is no morality, only legality. My own lawyer, who is one of my very best friends, drives me crazy with his endorsement that anything legal is acceptable, even if it isn't moral. My feeling about lawyers is, Wait a minute, I have to call my lawyer and find out if I can say this."
In the case of Judge Wood, two cultures collided semantically. Using political culture shorthand, Mr. Clinton asked the judge if she had "a Zoe Baird problem." She answered, in narrow legalese, that she did not have a problem exactly like Ms. Baird's, but she did not answer the broader political aspect that was clearly included in the President's question.
And it was ironic that Mr. Clinton did not recognize the narrowly worded escape clause approach, since he used it himself during the campaign to fudge issues on the draft, taxes, marijuana and his personal life.
In the campaign, George Bush and Dan Quayle lambasted Mr. Clinton for being "in the tank" with a special-interest group wearing "tasseled loafers."
"Sharp lawyers are running wild," Mr. Bush said, with "crazy lawsuits."
But once in office, Mr. Clinton cleaved to his roots as a lawyer. The New Republic recently noted that while his Cabinet has four women, four African-Americans and two Hispanics, "in a more meaningful sense Clinton has chosen one of the least diverse Cabinets in memory; of its 18 members, 13 are lawyers, and those include all four top economic officials."
The President could have tried to cut through some of the legal red tape entangling his opening weeks by standing up and saying that the current laws about illegal aliens and Social Security taxes on domestic workers are perceived as overly complicated, and perhaps need some simplification to encourage compliance. But that did not happen.
Rather, the Administration began jettisoning any candidate with even the slightest perceived problem on the subject, and pleading no contest on the officials already in place who have problems -- a move that has caused even greater confusion about what is allowable.
William Kristol, Mr. Quayle's former chief of staff who was the architect of the Vice President's campaign against excessive litigation, predicted that Mr. Clinton would be hurt if his Administration continued "to be dominated by lawyerly thinking."
 
'The Party of Lawyers'
 "The Democrats were once the party of working men and women and union leaders and political bosses and farmers and ethnic groups," Mr. Kristol said. "Now they've become the party of lawyers and interest groups who use the legal system to advance their goals and argue about 'rights.' Lawyers don't produce anything. They just feed off of and encourage other people's problems."
The best description of the law's tendency to feed on itself, which the new President might take as a cautionary tale, comes at the beginning of "Bleak House," when Charles Dickens describes a case in the Lord Chancellor's court called "Jarndyce and Jarndyce":
"This scarecrow of a suit has, in course of time, become so complicated that no man alive knows what it means. The parties to it understand it least; but it has been observed that no two Chancery lawyers can talk about it for five minutes without coming to a total disagreement as to all the premises.
"Innumerable children have been born into the cause; innumerable young people have married into it; innumerable old people have died out of it. Scores of persons have deliriously found themselves made parties in Jarndyce and Jarndyce, without knowing how or why. . . . There are not three Jarndyces left upon the earth perhaps, since old Tom Jarndyce in despair blew his brains out at a coffeehouse in Chancery Lane; but Jarndyce and Jarndyce still drags its dreary length before the Court, perennially hopeless."

HEADLINE: Jabs and Plenty of Pitches In Perot Visit to 'Tonight'

 BODY:
Ross Perot traded jokes and jabs with a master of the form, Jay Leno, on Thursday night as he expanded his political fund-raising drive to the "Tonight" show's huge television audience.
If the lusty response of the crowd was any indication, the sometime Presidential candidate was a hit. 
 The NBC studio sounded like the setting for a basketball game or a professional wrestling match when Mr. Perot walked on stage, lugging a valise stuffed with his trademark economic charts and graphs. The roar of approval was punctuated with many boisterous, and mostly male, shouts of encouragement, in the "Go get 'em Ross!" vein.
In his appearance, Mr. Perot kidded about his closely cropped haircut and his "full-blooded Sioux Indian" barber, about Dan Quayle, about Dana Carvey's impersonations, and about himself.
All the while, he managed to weave in references to his toll-free number and the post office box through which Americans can join his political organization, United We Stand, America, for $15.
Mr. Leno remarked, "People say, 'Sending Ross Perot $15, isn't that sort of like bringing goldfish to Sea World or something?' "
Mr. Leno prodded Mr. Perot to take credit for the idea of televised "town meetings," like the one President Clinton staged on Wednesday night, but Mr. Perot declined, correctly. While Mr. Perot popularized the term "electronic town hall" in the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton had held several such forums in the New Hampshire primary campaign.
Mr. Perot said he called Mr. Carvey about his impersonations on "Saturday Night Live" and told the comedian that he was so good that "my family feels you are better than I am" and that "if you would go on the campaign trail," Mr. Perot could be twice as effective.
Chatting about a sandwich that a restaurant in Maine created in his honor, Mr. Perot said there was also a "Dan Quayle sandwich, which is two slices of white bread with nothing inside."
"What's in your sandwich?" Mr. Leno replied. "Any tongue in your sandwich?"

HEADLINE: It Isn't 'Yankee, Go Home' Anymore

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is senior columnist of The New York Times; Russell Baker is on vacation.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
The message to Washington from the mammoth gathering of leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, was loud and clear. Reversing the hostile graffiti of a generation ago when America was seen as determined to dominate, it was, "Ami, don't go home."
From East and West, North and South, the plea was for the U.S. to stay actively engaged in the world's economic and security affairs. Raymond Barre, France's former and possibly future Prime Minister, put it flatly, saying the U.S. bears "first responsibility" for restoring economic confidence and pulling everyone back into a new period of growth. Others need to do better on their monetary, fiscal and wages policy mix, he said, but the key is to make sure there is no U.S. "economic decoupling" and a convincing U.S. start on deficit reduction. 
 Virtually every participant insisted that only new U.S. initiatives can revive effective cooperation among world leaders, not only on trade, exchange rates and finance but also on coordinating aid to the East and the dangerously frayed Russian society, stopping war from spreading through the Balkans and restoring enough order to enable the world to get on with its business.
There is a sense of helpless, fearful drift among the nations so sure of themselves not long ago, and a nostalgia for the days when America could be counted on to command, enabling everybody else to indulge in carping. The pleasure of America-bashing has vanished. There is a risk of schadenfreude, of finding some satisfaction in these new perceptions, while America tries to focus on attending to its own needs. It is a trap. Too much is at stake for the U.S. as well for it to turn aside and let the others stew a while.
Nationalism is rising everywhere, even in stable countries. The new enemy to replace the reliably thick ice of the cold war is disorder. It can be faced only by cooperative policies and will be faced only if Washington provides the impulse and sets the terms for coordination.
Fred Bergsten, a Washington economist, points out that the Group of Seven industrial countries control 75 percent of the world economy, but he says "the G-7 is dead." That is, the minimum of joint management that it had been providing hasn't been functioning in the last couple of years. He wisely calls for an urgent, special meeting in the spring before the regularly scheduled photo-op summit in Tokyo this summer.
Two trends going in opposite directions have created a sharp strain in relations among states. Economies are being globalized; regardless of where decisions are made, they operate transnationally. But politics are being renationalized, turning inward, with a loss of awareness of the superseding common interest and the need for mutual reinforcement that the cold war imposed.
The need hasn't diminished with the dissolution of blocs. If anything, it has increased, but so has uncertainty, and it undercuts what efforts there are to keep things on track.
President Clinton is right to think carefully: the message from America does need to be renewed and revised. But he is wrong if he thinks there's no hurry and others can be left to fill the void. The new voice needs to speak firmly, with great clarity, on America's response to the uneasy world: the U.S. doesn't want out and it doesn't want to take over. Responsibility must be shared. Mr. Clinton should say America recognizes the menace of disorder and it's not the kind of world we want to live in, but the rest of you have as much or more to lose than we do if you block or fail to join a concerted effort to keep it moving steadily. Everybody's listening hard. He would be heard.

HEADLINE: Classical Music in Review

BYLINE: By ALEX ROSS

 BODY:

Jupiter SymphonyChrist and St. Stephen's Church
Manhattan
 After temporarily succumbing to financial crisis last spring, the Jupiter Symphony has moved a few blocks north of Alice Tully Hall, which was its home for many years. This chamber orchestra, whose repertory derives largely from the Classical era, has revived itself on the basis of individual donations, including some from members of the New York Philharmonic.
 Monday night's concert began with Handel's Concerto Grosso No. 1 in B flat and then Haydn's Symphony No. 18 in G. While the ensemble was not always completely tidy, it had an attractive, well-rounded sound; Jens Nygaard conducted gracefully and with a lyrical bias. Robert Ingliss was an able oboe soloist in the Handel. 
 The program note promised a "special surprise" after intermission, and this arrived in the person of Jerome Lowenthal, the always surprising and sometimes incredible pianist who specializes in forgotten Romantic fireworks. Mr. Lowenthal began with a stirring declamation of Paul Verlaine's poem "Clair de Lune" in French, then played the Debussy piece of the same name; Scriabin's Nocturne in D flat, for the left hand alone, closed his segment brilliantly.
 Grieg's "At the Cradle" and Mozart's Violin Concerto No. 2 followed, with Pamela Frank as soloist in the latter. Ms. Frank, who has already given two acclaimed recitals this year, has become a major presence among younger violinists; this Mozart displayed in good measure the lyrical and dramatic intensity that characterizes her work.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Bakers Find Anger Is the Mother of Invention

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN

 BODY:
As a starting point, hatred can be positive. Take the case of the 400 workers who lost their jobs when Stroehmann's shut down its Taystee Bread bakery in Queens seven months ago. When they started to hold their weekly meetings, it was mostly to vent their anger at bosses who had fled the city and abandoned them. They cursed their old employers. They dreamed of vengeful boycotts. They are still meeting, only now, what they talk about is setting up their own big bakery in two years time.
"O.K., listen up," said Lynn Bell, addressing 35 of the unemployed workers who turned up at the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Flushing. The 40-year-old former machinery cleaner and union representative was both giving news and shoring up hopes. 
 "We've gotten some more grant money," she said. "We're going to be meeting with the association of Chinese bankers. We got some resumes from people answering our ad for a bakery manager. Our site committee is looking at 15 possible locations.
"And, oh yes, the advertising agency that's working with us wants to hear from you with any ideas about what we should call our bread. It ought to be a name that signifies what we are all about."
A visitor who had spent the afternoon with Ms. Bell and her associates thought they should call it something like Honest Bread, Real Tough Bread, Righteous Bread. In fact, though, they are not going to call it anything anytime soon, because, as Ms. Bell repeatedly made clear, it will be a long time before any dough rises. Still, that they had come this far, that they had bankers and an advertising agency and that they were still staying in touch with each other was clearly remarkable.
"You've got to understand that all this started when we were just a bunch of loudmouthed complainers meeting in the Maplecrest bar across the street from the plant," said Jennie Call, who worked for Taystee for eight years as a packer. Before that, she had worked for a printing compa
ny that relocated to New Jersey and another bakery that moved upstate. "At first, there were just four or five us meeting at the bar, but it grew when the closing date got nearer."
Back when the bakery was still running, John Diaz, who is 59, had been in management. As assistant superintendent, he had been Ms. Bell's supervisor and for years hisdealings with the union representative were not the warmest. Now they are good friends and allies in a fight for jobs, brought together by the bakery's closing.
"What Stroehmann's did -- the way they did it -- well, betrayal is too nice a word," said Mr. Diaz, who had worked at the bakery for 20 years. "We all felt violated. They never asked for concessions from the union or the workers. They never offered relocation possibilities. They never discussed things or negotiated. They just left, thinking they could maintain quality and production by paying less wages at bakeries in Pennsylvania. I think that was their plan ever since they bought Taystee Bread four years earlier. They thought they could buy in to the metropolitan market for sales and run away from production."
Joseph Chaffee, another former manager, added: "You know what the severance was? It was 30 hours pay for each year of work after three years."
For Edouard Archange, a 49-year-old father of five, that worked out to about $1,500. Just like most of the Taystee workers, Mr. Archange has not found a job and has been living on his savings and unemployment benefits. "There are no jobs," he said. "All we can do is to start our own bakery."
That idea first came up at the Maplecrest when Ms. Bell said she had heard that in Pittsburgh, bakery workers had somehow managed to put together their own company after their employers moved away. By this time, the angry Taystee workers were spending most of their time trying to organize a boycott of their former employer's products. A group of 30 visited Pittsburgh and learned how the workers there had battled for three years to set up a bakery called City Pride, with equity shared by workers and investors.
"We saw we had a model to work with," said Ms. Bell. She is an exceedingly polite woman, deferring to others, eager to bring everyone into the discussion, but she is clearly a catalyst who combines a marathoner's energy with the enthusiastic hopes of a crap shooter.
They set up the Community-Labor Campaign to Save Taystee Jobs, renting an office at 32-17 College Point Boulevard, not far from the old bakery. They quickly received $121,000 in grants from the New York State Urban Development Council, banks and private foundations to be used as seed money. They commissioned a study from a consulting group in Boston to determine whether a bakery based in New York City could effectively compete in a market dominated by producers who, for the most part, truck in baked goods from plants elsewhere. The study showed that, yes, such a bakery could do well.
A Brooklyn-based nonprofit organization called Leap became the project's sponsor, seeking $10 million to set up the bakery, which, like the one in Pittsburgh, is to be owned by investors and workers. City officials informed the group that they were pressuring Stroehmann's, which still does business in the city, to return $780,000 in tax benefits that were forfeited when Taystee closed. The officials added that the money had been earmarked as an investment in the new bakery. At the moment, plans call for production to begin by the end of 1994.
"It's a long time to wait," said Mr. Archange, "but what can we do?"
Someone said that unemployment benefits would run out by then. Someone else noted that unemployment in the area was twice that of the nation.
"It's our kind of jobs that are disappearing," said Ms. Bell.
Ms. Call said: "We're fighting for our jobs by what we're doing, and if we succeed, it'll lead others to try."
The visitor noted that the effort seemed like a labor of love.
"No, that's where you're wrong," said Mr. Chaffee, laughing. "With the way we were treated, it's more like a labor of hate."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 17, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: Another Surge of Refinancings Sweeps Over Mortgage Lenders

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
American homeowners, who last year pared billions of dollars in interest payments off personal balance sheets by refinancing their mortgages, are at it again.
Fueled by a rally in the bond market that has pushed long-term mortgage interest rates to 20-year lows, the latest surge in refinancing activity began right around Christmas, mortgage bankers said, and has intensified in the last few weeks. 
 "Our call volume has gone from 50 to 60 an hour to 150 an hour in the last week," said Laura Lippman,a spokeswoman at Countrywide Credit, based in Pasadena, Calif., the nation's largest originator of mortgage loans. "Throughout the company, we are probably getting close to 10,000 calls a day on refinancing mortgages."
If it continues, the latest refinancing wave will free huge amounts of money that might otherwise have gone to lenders each month. That money could give added lift to an economy that is already looking increasingly healthy. Unlike other refinancing frenzies in the last year, this one comes as consumers' spirits are relatively high, having risen steadily since the Presidential election.
Mortgage bankers, who have lived through two years of initially hectic and then frenetic refinancing activity, sound somewhat blase about the latest pickup. What is interesting at the moment, they say, is that mortgage applications for new purchases have been rising for six weeks.
 
Contrast to Last Year
 "Last year there was a tremendous volcano of refinancing activity," said Howard Culang, managing director for Prudential Home Mortgage, the nation's second-largest originator of home mortgages. "Now it is growing, but it is more measured."
Still, analysts point out that the bond market, made up of a jittery bunch of traders, could bring mortgage refinancings to an abrupt halt if it does not like the components of the economic program President Clinton is to outline on Wednesday or if it is troubled by the way Congress deals with the package.
Interest rates on 30-year Treasury bonds, which influence mortgage rates, fell to 7.12 percent yesterday, a seven-year low.
At the moment it is not clear which mortgage products homeowners are favoring as they refinance. Last year, for example, many chose to move out of 30-year mortgages and into 15-year loans. Although monthly payments are higher on shorter-term loans, homeowners can pay down debt faster.
The rush to refinance "does not necessarily imply greater spending," said Alan Sinai, president of the Boston Company Economic Advisors Inc. "But it does help the economy."
Yesterday the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, which buys pools of mortgages from lenders, reported that the average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell for the eighth week in a row, to 7.75 percent, from 7.80 percent a week ago. The 7.75 percent is the lowest average rate since June 15, 1973, when the rate was 7.73 percent.
At 7.75 percent, the monthly principal and interest payment is $707.23 on a 30-year loan of $100,000. That compares with $834 a month for a similar loan at 9.5 percent.
Average rates on one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, which are often favored by first-time home buyers because of the low initial rate, fell to 5.04 percent, Freddie Mac said, from 5.06 percent a week ago.
Each week the Mortgage Bankers Association puts out separate indexes tracking mortgage applications for refinancings and for purchases.
In the period from late December to Feb. 5, the refinancing index rose 116 percent, said David Lereah, chief economist at the association, but the index, which is at 719, remains well below the peak of 1,354 it hit last July 24.
The association's purchase index has risen 69 percent in the same period, to its highest level since the measure was first published in 1990.
 
One Lender's Outlook
 "We have been doing more purchase business than other business," said Pete Wissinger, an executive vice president at Norwest Mortgage Bank in Des Moines, a mortgage lender that does business in 49 states and originated more than $21 billion in mortgages last year. "But we could see a very robust refinancing market this year if rates stay at these levels or go lower."
It is difficult to imagine that refinancing activity in 1993 will match what took place in the last two years.
In 1991 and 1992, years when the Federal Reserve Board steadily pushed down short-term interest rates to help stimulate the economy, nearly half a trillion dollars in mortgages were refinanced, according to estimates by the mortgage bankers group.
Those refinancings, in turn, pushed down debt service costs by nearly $10 billion, the association estimated.
Nevertheless, bankers said the pool of mortgage loans that have not yet been refinanced remained huge.
 
Still Haven't Acted
 Mr. Lereah said that in August he identified $2.4 trillion worth of mortgages that were candidates for refinancing. "There is a very large pool of mortgage holders out there paying anywhere from 9.5 percent to 10 percent that still have not refinanced," he said. "It may take two or three refinancing booms in a row before these people wake up."
Mr. Sinai, the analyst, said that unless President Clinton's economic address offered serious proposals to cut the Federal budget deficit, and Congress responded to his policies in a credible way, those who had delayed refinancing their mortgages might have missed the boat.
"Those who are grabbing the window of opportunity here are very wise," he said. "The bond market has already improved some on the belief that the President is serious about cutting the deficit. If he really presents a really bona fide deficit reduction program, the bond market will fly. If he doesn't, long-term interest rates are probably going to move higher."

HEADLINE: A Jolt for the Student Loan Stocks

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
Wall Street received a quick education on the student loan business yesterday, and it did not like what it learned.
The once-hot stocks of the Student Loan Marketing Corporation, known as Sallie Mae, and the Student Loan Corporation fell sharply as some analysts issued warnings to investors about possible changes in the student loan program. 
 President Clinton, who made universal access to Government loans for education a centerpiece of his campaign, is expected to call for a revision of insured lending to college students that would bypass banks and eliminate the need for a secondary market, like the one served by Sallie Mae.
 
'An Uncomfortable Feeling'
 "It's an uncomfortable period," said Jack Morris, a spokesman for Citicorp, which owns 80 percent of Student Loan. "The business in itself is sound. But any business can be affected by outside events."
Only about a month ago, the stocks of Sallie Mae and Student Loan were surging, buoyed by reports that the Clinton Administration was planning no immediate action. In addition, declining interest rates were expected to push up the companies' profits.
Student Loan's shares traded as high as $30.50 last month, up sharply from its initial offering price of $16.75 when Citicorp sold a 20 percent stake to the public in December. But yesterday, Student Loan plunged $3.50, to $18.625, and was the Big Board's biggest percentage loser, with a 15.8 percent decline.
Sallie Mae's stock fell $4.50 yesterday, or 7.1 percent, closing at $58.625 in heavy trading. Last month, it had traded as high as $75.25.
 
Leaders in Industry
 Sallie Mae and Student Loan hold and service insured student loans. Sallie Mae is a publicly traded Government-sponsored enterprise, buying loans made by private lenders. It is the largest holder of student loans. And Student Loan is the nation's leading student lender.
At least four Wall Street analysts, David Hilder of First Boston, Robert G. Hottensen of Goldman, Sachs, Peter Treadway of Smith Barney and Gary Gordon of Paine Webber, have cautioned investors about the stocks in recent days.
Mr. Treadway and Mr. Hottensen changed their recommendations from "buy" to "hold."
Mr. Gordon and Mr. Hilder, while continuing to recommend the stocks, warned investors of "heightened uncertainty" and "volatility." Both noted that an actual decision on the issue was probably months away.
Direct lending by the Government could save taxpayers from $4.8 billion to $6 billion over five years, according to separate estimates issued by the General Accounting Office and the Congressional Budget Office last November.
Sallie Mae and other interested parties dispute the savings estimates and have already begun a counterattack. They hired KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm, which called the agencies' findings flawed.
"They're making a $100 billion bet that they can efficiently run and manage a lending program using taxpayer money," said Gisela Vallandigham, a spokeswoman for Sallie Mae. "They presume there will be a cost savings."
Sallie Mae, the 700-member Consumer Bankers Association and the National Council of Higher Education Loan Programs, a group of state guarantee agencies, paid for the Peat Marwick study. Their report said the Government overlooked administrative costs of direct lending or the cost of dismantling the current student loan program.
 
Awaiting the Details
 Details about the breadth of the Clinton Administration's proposal may come as early as next week during Mr. Clinton's State of the Union address or during testimony by Education Secretary Richard Riley before a March 2 House Budget Committee hearing. Mr. Riley has expressed no opinion so far about the proposal, a department spokesman said.
Industrywide, about 7,800 lenders issued $15 billion in student loans last year. Sallie Mae, which issues few loans, held about $24 billion in insured student loans at the end of the year. The company generally issues short-term floating notes on a monthly basis to raise funds to buy student loans from financial institutions. Last year, Sallie Mae raised $11.3 billion from the capital markets.
Student Loan holds $3.2 billion in insured student loans and originated $909 million last year.
As a Government-sponsored agency, Sallie Mae can sell debt at yields just above those of the Treasury. On Feb. 8, the company sold $500 million of six-month notes at a yield just 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above the three-month Treasury bill. Holders of insured student loans receive a so-called special allowance payment of 3.1 percent.
Under direct lending, the expected savings would come from the Treasury's ability to borrow money at the Goverment's cost of funds and from eliminating the special allowance payments.
Student loan volume is growing because of the increasing costs of education, higher enrollment and cutbacks in grant aid.

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
A Time of Guarded Optimism

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
The trucks emptying dealers' booths on the night the Winter Antiques Show closed two weeks ago left with far less than they brought. Crediting the mini sales boom to the recent surge in the economy and President Clinton's election, dealers in most categories said they had bettered last year's figures, despite an attendance lag in the second half of the nine-day event.
Long viewed internationally as the golden calf of all antiques fairs, the show had lost its pre-eminence in recent years, partly due to controversy over what some saw as mismanagement. Hurt by the recession, the event also faced competition from the International Antique and Fine Art Dealers Show held here in October. Now, with the winter show's luster somewhat restored, and the economy eased, sales are improving in American, Oriental and European artifacts as well as in silver and jewelry. 
 "Business was terrific," said the show's manager, N. Pendergast Jones. "We had close to 9,000 people on the first weekend."
Though dealers continued to sell for the next five days, ticket sales were slower. In all, nearly 24,000 people attended the show and the preview, which was about 850 fewer than last year and 10,000 under the 1985 total. The fair was sponsored by the East Side House Settlement, a Bronx-based charity.
"There's nothing left at Marguerite Riordan's," Mrs. Jones said. "We're sending her home with a shopping bag."
Mrs. Riordan, a folk-art dealer from Stonington, Conn., smiled. "That's not quite true," she said. "We've had a very strong show -- half of what was on view on opening night was sold. Our second batch didn't do as well." Among the most admired of Mrs. Riordan's items that found buyers were an 18th-century Massachusetts tea table at $85,000 and a tiger-maple linen cupboard at $65,000. "We sold something every day," she said. "But business was not quite what it was in the late 1980's."
Directly across the aisle, Leigh Keno, another Americana furniture dealer, was nearly as busy. The fashion designer Bill Blass bought a wall clock priced at $14,500. Mr. Keno also sold a serpentine-front 18th-century desk, with an asking price of $220,000.
"The art market has finally turned," said Michael Goedhuis, a London dealer who was showcasing ancient Chinese bronzes from the Warring States period. As the fair was about to end, just before the Super Bowl kickoff, a Manhattan collector bought a pair of bronze lions that had been guarding the entrance to Mr. Goedhuis's booth. The massive, snarling beasts, from an early-19th-century Japanese temple, weighed a ton. Although they had one of the highest price tags at the show, $475,000, the sum was well below the million-dollar offerings at this fair in the late 1980's.
"We changed one wall four times" as objects were sold, said Milly McGehee of Colwill-McGehee, Americana dealers based in Baltimore. Gone from that wall were two hooked rugs, one in a tiger pattern ($6,500), the other covered with hearts ($10,000), and a drum-shaped Hepplewhite wine cabinet made in Maryland ($55,000). "Our most popular item was the pair of log-cabin andirons," Ms. McGehee said. "We could have sold them two dozen times on opening night." The price was $6,800.
Joel Kopp, of America Hurrah in Manhattan, was more cautious. "There's no boom yet," he said, "but people are buying again." Nevertheless, he did sell quilts, paintings and American Indian artifacts. A collector bought the Kopps' $38,000 18th-century quilt, with a center square by John Hewson, a pioneer printer.
European antiques also did well. During the first two days, Karl Kemp, a Greenwich Village dealer, sold 15 pieces of European furniture and decorations, including an 1820's ebony-inlaid Biedermeier writing table from Vienna, which was priced at $16,000. The SoHo dealer Elizabeth Street sold an 18th-century Italian well head of white Istrian stone. Priced at $24,000, it weighed 1,500 pounds and was shipped to Pennsylvania.
Shirley Day, a London dealer in Oriental art, sold eight important items. The costliest -- $90,000 -- was a 10th-century Khmer figure, almost five feet tall.
"We've done better here than at any other fair," Ms. Day said, adding, "including Grosvenor House in London and the Biennale in Paris and the International show."
Rare 18th-century silver changed hands swiftly during the January show. Jonathan Trace of Putnam Valley, N.Y., sold a rococo coffeepot made by Wilmington's Bancroft Woodcock with an asking price of $80,000. And at the booth of the New York dealer Eric Shrubsole, the $45,000 pair of 1752 candlesticks by Edward Wakelan of London was bought by a New York collector.
Jewelry dealers were also satisfied. The most expensive object sold by Peter Schaffer of A La Vieille Russie was an 18th-century English brooch, priced at $29,000. Edward Munves of James Robinson, another Manhattan dealer, said jewelry sales were the best ever in his six years at this show.
"Business improved dramatically on Wednesday, Nov. 4," Mr. Munves said. "Ever since Election Day, our sales have soared."

(Colwill-McGehee); A serpentine-front Chippendale desk in mahogany, with an asking price of $220,000, found a buyer. (Leigh Keno)
