HEADLINE: A Balancing Act for TriBeCa Zoning

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
IN TriBeCa, city planners have seen the present. And they think it may work.
They are trying to reconcile zoning policy with the realities of the existing neighborhood. Also, in something of a departure, they are trying to coordinate their work with simultaneous designations by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. "I thought it was important to see if we could have zoning and historic district designation complementary," said Richard L. Schaffer, director of the City Planning Department and chairman of the City Planning Commission. 
 "That's a major breakthrough," said Marla G. Simpson, director of land-use planning for Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan. "It's not that anybody has been working against that direction but I think it takes a lot of willpower on the part of agencies to bring their agendas into sync. It's really encouraging that they did that."
Not everyone is encouraged, however. "The worry at our end is that preservation is determining what planning goals should be," said Michael Slattery, a senior vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York. "They've got things upside down."
As it stands today, much of the zoning in TriBeCa seems upside down, at least in its relation to the streetscape. Where five-story structures predominate, zoning allows skyscrapers like the financially troubled 52-story Tribeca Tower apartment building at 105 Duane Street, west of Broadway. Where zoning is meant to retain manufacturers and wholesalers, these industries are drying up and departing.
TriBeCa -- the triangle below Canal Street -- was for many years home to the wholesale butter, cheese and egg markets; dealers in textiles and dry groceries; graphic-arts concerns; warehousers and manufacturers of shoes, electrical goods and machinery.
Planners once called it the "Northwest Goods Handling Area" (although the acronym NoGoHa was never coined). A 1966 plan described the area as one of "small businesses in older buildings, declining employment and an increasingly unattractive environment."
Then something happened that planners had not foreseen. The residential population exploded. Loft dwellers, artists and entrepreneurs were drawn to TriBeCa by the 19th-century scale, by little architectural gems that lined its small streets and by the mix of tranquility and grittiness in the old quarter.
On the other hand were landlords who had held, purchased or assembled properties against the plausible assumption that Wall Street firms might migrate north and city bureaucracies might shift to the west.
As the number of residents increased, so did their concern that the very qualities that attracted them to TriBeCa in the first place would be jeopardized by high-intensity development. But owners feared that preservation or rezoning would greatly limit their ability to exploit these trends, leaving them saddled with antiquated, decrepit structures.
Two years ago, the Landmarks Preservation Commission created the first of four historic districts in TriBeCa. The remaining three were designated in December. A month later, the Planning Department recommended rules to reduce density and preserve the "street wall" formed by buildings in eastern TriBeCa. For the western blocks, planners recommended an increase in density and the removal of some restrictions on residential construction and commercial development.
"What we tried to do was make zoning much more sensitive to the existing fabric of the community," Mr. Schaffer said.
The Planning Commission underscored this aim Monday, when it endorsed the new historic districts, 11 to 1. In its report to the City Council, which can modify or even deny the designations, the Planning Commission concluded that each district "will help sustain the physical and economic revitalization already under way in the area" and is "consistent with plans for the area's future development and improvement."
IF the fate of TriBeCa West is a reliable guide, the Council may remove some properties but otherwise leave the areas alone. The zoning recommendations are now being circulated for comment and are not likely to reach the Council until next year.
The chairwoman of the TriBeCa-Washington Market committee of Community Board 1, Madelyn Wils, said, "The whole idea that the Planning Commission has accepted the fact that preservation makes for good economics is a very big step for the city."
"I believe this is a precedent," she said, "to actually look at a community which is presently in the process of being landmarked and to look at zoning at the same time, and work hand in hand."
City planners noted the 34-page "TriBeCa West Historic District Manual," by the landmarks commission, New York Landmarks Conservancy and Ehrenkrantz & Eckstut Architects, and urged that similar handbooks be prepared for the other districts.
The manual describes building characteristics and materials -- sidewalks, entrances, walls, windows, fire escapes, cornices, parapets -- indicating the contribution made by each to the overall quality of the district.
Metal awnings, for example, are noted as being "significant features in the TriBeCa West district" that "should be retained."
The manual also suggests areas in which owners have some leeway. Since sign bands are a typical feature of upper stories on buildings in the district, painted or applied signs may be found not only appropriate but "in keeping with this historic tradition."
There are even guidelines offered for new construction, giving a prospective builder some idea of what the commission is looking for and what it would probably not accept.
"If you read this, you'll be able to get a sense of what you can do," said Laurie Beckelman, chairwoman of the landmarks agency. "If you're willing to come to the table and follow the rules, you'll get through the system very, very quickly."
Such assurances are not enough to assuage major business and real estate leaders who believe that historic districts -- where any construction, demolition or exterior alteration is subject to approval from the landmarks agency -- seriously inhibit economic development by discouraging large-scale building and forcing owners to go through a time-consuming regulatory maze.
"We are not against preservation per se," said Dr. Barbara L. Christen, president of the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association. "But we do become concerned that there be a balance between preservation and the potential for growth and development. The unique nature of the downtown community as the economic engine of the region makes it that much more important that you consider maintenance of that balance."
"The proximity of TriBeCa to lower Manhattan is an asset of great potential," she continued. "The intense concentration of financial services is a very attractive resource to the rest of the world. One direction in which it might expand is TriBeCa."
For that reason, she said, the association opposed the "blanket designation" of historic districts and favored individual landmark status where warranted.
Mr. Slattery of the Real Estate Board of New York also said that land-use policy must balance preservation against other needs.
"What's in the best interest of the city includes where growth should take place, what's the acceptable level, what role the neighborhood character should have," he said. "What about these other planning needs? They certainly haven't gotten equal time."
But Mr. Schaffer said that was exactly the point of the new recommendations. "The overall notion was to have balanced zoning for preservation and growth," he said.
On the growth side, he cited the proposal to change zoning in those parts of the Lower Manhattan Mixed-Use District from Murray to Warren Street and from Reade to North Moore Street.
This special manufacturing district was created in 1976 to retain industry, while permitting the conversion of existing buildings into loft dwellings. Within the district, new residential construction is prohibited and prospective commercial tenants are required to get a special permit from the Planning Commission.
CITY planners would allow new residential construction with a floor-area ratio (F.A.R.) of 5, meaning that a building could have 5 times as much floor space as the lot it occupies. Restrictions would be eliminated on the commercial use of ground-floor and second-floor space.
On the preservation side, Mr. Schaffer noted the proposals for Broadway, from Chambers to Walker Street, and Church Street, from Reade to Thomas Street and from Worth to Walker Street.
Zoning now permits towers with a floor-area ratio of 10, but a developer can get a 20 percent bonus for providing a plaza. That yields a floor-area ratio of 12. And the plaza squeezes the building bulk onto a smaller site, therefore pushing the tower higher.
On Broadway, planners recommended eliminating the plaza bonus, to encourage buildings that more closely resemble those around them. Commercial structures would be limited to a floor-area ratio of 10. Residential developers could still build at a ratio of 12 if they also provided lower-income housing.
On Church Street, planners recommended cutting the maximum bulk in half, to a floor-area ratio of 6.
Chambers Street is mixed. The western part of the street is zoned with a floor-area ratio of 5, while the eastern part has a ratio of 10. Planners would even that out to a ratio of 7.5 for most of the stretch between Broadway and Greenwich Street.
The city has not completely retreated from the 1980's vision of TriBeCa as Wall Street North. One major, government-sponsored project still in the pipeline is the New York Exchanges Headquarters proposal on a city-owned site bounded by Greenwich and West Streets, Warren and Murray Streets.
Since it was proposed in 1990, the project has gone through several transformations, shrinking as it went -- but not enough to satisfy its opponents, who do not want the structure built at all.
It was originally to have been a 47-story, 1.2 million-square-foot structure, costing $450 million, to house the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange; Commodity Exchange; New York Mercantile Exchange; New York Cotton Exchange and New York Futures Exchange. Public subsidies and benefits were to amount to about $142.5 million.
The Mercantile Exchange has since split from the group and is now negotiating independently for 260,000 square feet of space in Shearson Lehman Brothers' Faulkner Center, at Greenwich and Hubert Streets.
To accommodate the exchange, substantial interior reconstruction would be necessary. For example, an existing floor slab would have to be removed to create a new trading floor. The city and state are providing about $80 million in capital contributions and tax incentives, said Anthony Mannarino, first executive vice president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
Some $95 million in public benefits are earmarked for the revised Exchanges Headquarters project, which will cost about $160 million, Mr. Mannarino said. These include a $75 million contribution toward construction, $22 million of which would be recouped through payments in lieu of taxes; $25 million in property tax abatements and $17 million in ground-rent savings, sales-tax savings and low-cost power.
As revised, the Exchanges Headquarters would have about 500,000 square feet, including a 50,000-square-foot trading floor. It would have 10 stories but, at about 170 feet, would be equal in height to a 14-story office building. It is not yet clear whether or how the project will be affected by the prospective merger of the Commodity Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade. "We need to sit down with the Comex group very soon to understand precisely where they are," Mr. Mannarino said.
The director of exchange relations for Comex, Alan Hanson, said that if the merger is approved by the two bodies, the Board of Trade "fully supports the need of the exchanges here to go forward with the new trading facility."
A lawsuit has been filed against the project by several groups and individuals, including the TriBeCa Community Association. The suit challenges the legality of the benefits and subsidies, the adequacy of the environmental impact assessment and the standing of public agencies in the project. An officer of the community association, Nancy Page, said the exchanges "could go into existing space, like the Merc has, and it would be a much better deal for everybody."

HEADLINE: Talking: Subleasing;
Defying The Rules In Co-ops

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
TOUGH economic times can tempt otherwise law-abiding people into questionable dealings. Symptomatic of this has been a rise in the number of shareholders in New York City co-ops who have been subletting without their board's approval.
"Nowadays, whenever anyone calls me to say they have a 'discreet' sublet to offer, I know exactly what they mean," said John Griffin, president of Griffin Realty Group, rental specialists in Manhattan. 
 The shareholder, he said, may offer the doorman several hundred dollars to help maintain confidentiality. At other times, he said, a subtenant is brought in ostensibly as a relative. Mr. Griffin said he refuses to get involved in such dealings.
Deborah Davis, a Manhattan lawyer specializing in co-op litigation, said there had been an increase in the number of shareholders "who are just moving people in."
Experts say the regulations are most likely to be defied when boards drag their heels on requests for approval. The climate of defiance is heightened if the building has a reputation for requiring excessive documentation and then rejecting worthy applicants. And some buildings have made their sublet surcharges so onerous that a shareholder may flout the rules just to avoid the fees.
"I had one woman call me who wanted to know if we could make it all very 'discreet' because if the board found out they would charge her $4,500," said Mr. Griffin. "And that was just for a five-month tenancy."
Board members have been defending their position by arguing that such anarchy chips at the very core of co-op ownership, that one of the primary attractions of a co-op apartment -- in contrast to a condominium -- is the chance to enjoy an enhanced quality of life, in part by retaining veto powers over who can live in the building through screening prospective subtenants.
Boards see other needs for the exercise of those powers. Wilma Gottlieb, president of the 333-unit co-op at 2 Tudor City Place, said that her board was concerned that total freedom for sublets could discourage shareholders from making bona fide efforts to sell.
"And if an apartment is occupied it's also more difficult to sell," she maintained. As a result, she added, the building could eventually "take on a transient nature."
Boards may need to make such views more widely understood. This may be so even if they have made great strides in liberalizing and streamlining sublet policies over the last three years, which may have been done in response to the weaker market and the financial difficulty many shareholders have been facing.
For example, the Tudor Place co-op will now consider a four- or even a five-year sublet if a shareholder can show real hardship or has made a good-faith effort to sell without success, said Ms. Gottlieb. Subletting used to be limited at Tudor Place to one year and was permitted only if the shareholder intended to return.
Many boards, already walking a tightrope between protection and compassion, are unwilling to accept that some shareholders would have the audacity to bypass even a liberalized policy. Thus more and more of them are threatening recalcitrant shareholders with eviction.
But those powers are in jeopardy. In Lincoln Guild Housing Corporation v. Stuckelman, Judge Peter Wendt of New York Housing Court ruled in November that Anna Stuckelman, a shareholder at 303 West 66th Street, had the right to let her grandniece occupy her apartment without board approval.
Judge Wendt based his decision on an interpretation of the state's 1983 Roommate Law, which gave a primary tenant the right to bring one other person to live in the unit without the landlord's approval. Shareholders are frequently classified as primary tenants by the courts because they are, in essence, tenants of the co-op corporation.
THUS, argued Judge Wendt, the customary language in a co-op proprietary lease restricting occupancy to the shareholder's immediate family is contrary to the intention of the roommate law and cannot be upheld. The Lincoln Guild co-op had argued that the grandniece was an illegal subtenant since Mrs. Stuckelman had been in a nursing home at the time.
"This could mean that any shareholder can now put anyone into an apartment at any time," warned Howard Schechter, the lawyer who represented the Lincoln Guild co-op. Indeed, the decision is already being cited as a defense in a similar case involving a co-op at 345 East 93d Street -- Mill Rock Owners Corp. v. Timothy McEvoy.
Moreover, there is now the fear that the decision might embolden even more shareholders to slip unauthorized subtenants into their apartments. Thus, both the Council of New York Cooperatives and the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives have filed amicus briefs with the New York State Supeme Court's Appellate Term, First Department, where the Lincoln Guild case is being reviewed.
"It could result in overcrowding and over-utilization of a co-op's facilities," said Charles Rappaport, the federation's president. "And then everyone's maintenance will go up. What about security? Soon it won't be safe to live in a co-op anymore."
How should a board proceed in the meantime?
In December, Richard Siegler, a New York City lawyer specializing in co-ops, sent a bulletin to 105 client boards urging them not to feel pressured into even greater liberalization because of the Lincoln Guild decision. He maintains, as do most co-op lawyers, that it will be reversed on appeal.
Assuming Lincoln Guild is reversed, careful monitoring plus compromise could become the most appropriate response. Ms. Davis said that when a nonauthorized sublet came to the attention of her client boards "we normally start by sending out a notice to cure what is essentially a lease violation."
Often this is enough, she said, for both sides to reach a settlement allowing the shareholder to retain the subtenant, provided the subtenant gains retroactive board approval.
If, however, the Lincoln Guild decision is upheld, a board should at least try to keep a current a list of all residents, said Marc Luxemburg, president of the council, "and not allow anyone in who isn't authorized by a shareholder."
But he added that the appeals court might instead only partially reverse the decision. At the very least, this would let a board limit the number of additional occupants and require the shareholder to be using the apartment as a primary residence while the other person was there.

HEADLINE: Gains Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The recently issued advisory opinion referred to in your Jan. 10 Perspectives column about the New York gains tax superficially appears to be an effort by the Department of Taxation and Finance to recognize the reality of a depressed market. 
 The opinion permits foreclosing lenders to calculate gains-tax liability based on current fair-market value of the foreclosed property instead of the amount foreclosed upon, provided the lender acquires a controlling interest in the defaulted company instead of direct ownership of the defaulted property.
Foreclosing lenders are supposed to take heart from this bureaucratic palliative.
Rather than being a road map away from an often artificial gains-tax liability for foreclosing lenders, the advisory opinion may actually lead into a minefield. First, it will not work in the case of an individual, who obviously cannot transfer a controlling interest in himself or herself. Second, acquiring a controlling interest in a corporation or partnership carries with it all of the acquired entity's liabilities, disclosed and undisclosed. Third, it cannot be used if the defaulted entity also owns other real property that is not the subject of the default. Fourth, if the property is owned by a limited partnership whose investors are shielded from personal liability for the gains tax, they would have little incentive to transfer their interests to the lender.
While certain foreclosing lenders may benefit from this advisory opinion, we submit that it is inapplicable in the vast majority of instances. The fairer course would be to implement a uniform rule that, in any foreclosure, gains tax is to be calculated based upon the lesser of current fair market value or the amount foreclosed upon. Fairness could also be enhanced by permitting the basis to be increased by the real costs incurred by defaulted developers. In this way, what in reality is a substantial economic loss that undoubtedly led to the lender's takeover will not be artificially transformed into a tax-generating "gain."
Finally, now that net gains-tax revenues are one-eighth of what they were at their zenith, has New York reduced the gains-tax bureaucracy by a corresponding percentage?
 
MARC J. LUXEMBERG, MARK S. BORTEN
Manhattan
 
The writers are partners in the law firm of Snow Becker Krauss.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: ENGAGEMENTS;
Patricia Durner, Stephen Verdesca

 BODY:
Mr. and Mrs. Richard Durner of Allentown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Kay Durner to Dr. Stephen Arthur Verdesca, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Verdesca of Morristown, N.J. A May wedding is planned.
Ms. Durner, 29, graduated from Hamilton College. She is an editor of Bank Securities Journal and Bank Insurance Marketing, magazines published by I.D.D., financial publishers in New York. Her father is an accountant in Allentown, where her mother, Marilyn M. Durner, teaches home economics at Springhouse Junior High School. 
 Dr. Verdesca, also 29, graduated from Columbia University and received an M.D. from New Jersey Medical School. He is a third-year resident at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia. His father is the corporate medical director at the American International Group, an insurance company, in New York.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Chase Reynolds, Charles Ewald

 BODY:
Deborah Chase Reynolds, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell S. Reynolds Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Charles Ross Ewald, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William B. Ewald Jr., also of Greenwich. The Rev. John Bishop officiated at Christ Episcopal Church. The Rev. Neely Towe, a Congregational minister, took part in the ceremony.
The bride is known as Chase. She is a freelance writer and photographer in Cody, Wyo., where she also is the director of the Breteche Creek Foundation, a nonprofit educational guest ranch. She graduated cum laude from Yale University and received a master's degree in journalism from the University of California at Berkeley. 
 Her father is the founder and chairman of Russell Reynolds Associates, the executive-recruiting company in New York.
Mr. Ewald is a corporate acquisitions specialist in New York and a principal in Investcorp International Inc., a merchant bank based in Manama, Bahrain. He graduated from Harvard University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He received a master's degree in philosophy, politics and economics from Oxford University and an M.B.A. from Stanford University.
His mother, Mary Ewald, is a poet. His father, a former speech writer for President Dwight D. Eisenhower, is an author.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2981 words

HEADLINE: Effective? Maybe. Profitable? Clearly.

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif.

 BODY:
THE Tokos Medical Corporation, which sells a service that detects early labor in pregnant women, recently started a program to reward obstetricians who ordered it for their patients.
In its files the company called the program "Dr. Deal." The deal: earn up to $20,000 annually on an investment of $1,000. 
 The program, in which 300 to 400 obstetricians nationwide are participating, works like this: The doctors put up $1,000 each to become shareholders in a company set up by Tokos that typically exists only on paper. In return, the doctors pocket 15 percent of the payment for any Tokos services prescribed by members of the physician-owned company. Tokos says participating physicians currently average about $5,000 a year from the arrangement; literature from one Tokos subsidiary boasted that annual earnings could reach $22,500.
When doctors do prescribe it, Tokos's home-monitoring service is not cheap. It costs $100 to $300 a day, or about $5,000 a pregnancy. That's a hard sell among cost-conscious insurers, so Tokos has 20 employees who make the company's case -- and they have had increasing success in persuading insurers to pay.
But a debate is growing about the effectiveness of the home uterine monitor that is the keystone of Tokos's service. The Food and Drug Administration is also investigating Tokos's marketing claims. Separately, there is a scientific controversy about the safety of the drugs Tokos sells to prolong pregnancy.
Some doctors are concerned about not only Tokos's marketing practices but also the willingness of some physicians to take part in its investment plans. "It is a sad day for medicine," said Dr. Benjamin Sachs, chief of obstetrics and gynecology at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston.
A look at Tokos's marketing efforts highlights one of the most troubling issues in health care: Medical companies often go to great lengths to encourage doctors to use their products, and to persuade insurers to pay for them. And they can succeed even when significant questions exist about a product's efficacy and safety.
Health-care experts say that nothing will change -- and medical costs will never be satisfactorily controlled -- without a systematic effort, whether by the Government or the private sector, to study medical technologies and identify who will most benefit from them.
"This is an extraordinarily pervasive problem," said Dr. Robert H. Brook, director of the health sciences program at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif. "The Government has to step in to help resolve the risks and benefits of these practices and then decide what is going to be used in basic medical care."
 
A Warning for Clinton
 Some experts think the problem so great that the Clinton Administration's effort to reform the health-care system by managing competition among insurers will fail unless it identifies which competing treatments and technologies are most effective. "Managed competition does not have the ability to deal with this problem," said Dr. Mark Chassin, Commissioner of the New York State Department of Health.
Pressure is also growing to crack down on financial-incentive programs that may affect the way physicians treat patients.
Tokos's chairman and chief executive, Robert F. Byrnes, said in an interview last week that his company's investment plan for physicians was both legal and ethical because it compensated doctors for paperwork and other chores for which insurers do not pay. He added that Tokos was helping to reduce the medical catastrophes associated with premature birth, and in the process holding down medical costs by keeping women out of the hospital.
"We have raised everyone's consciousness about the problem of prematurity," he said. "And we are very proud of our system because it works."
But Kirk Johnson, an attorney for the American Medical Association, said his group was investigating possible conflicts of interest posed by physician investment plans like those offered by Tokos. And three weeks ago, a Federal task force recommended an end to plans under which physicians refer patients to businesses that they own but in which they don't participate directly.
"This is a very murky area that we are very concerned about," Mr. Johnson said.
Founded in 1983, Tokos is the leading company in a burgeoning industry that has sprung up to prevent premature births, a leading cause of birth defects and infant mortality.
It is by no means alone in its aggressive efforts to gain acceptance of its product among physicians and insurers. Its two largest competitors, Healthdyne Inc. and Caremark International Inc., also provide financial incentives to physicians to use similar services. And there are many other technologies, new and old, whose efficacy remains unproven. Two examples: positron emission tomography for cardiac imaging, and the use of antigens for detection of ovarian cancer.
The need to prevent premature births is a compelling one. Each year 6 to 8 percent of infants are born prematurely (defined as before the 37th week of gestation), some so early that they die or suffer crippling defects. A troubled pregnancy can be devastating. And associated medical costs can reach $1 million.
Doctors cannot predict early delivery, though women carrying more than one fetus or having a history of early labor are considered to be at greatest risk. And though women can be trained to recognize some signs of early labor, home monitoring detects contractions a woman may not feel. Also, a physician who might have hospitalized a woman for early labor -- at $500 a day -- now may have a cheaper choice.
It is a choice most patients prefer. "If the patient knows about monitoring, God forbid you if you don't provide it," said Dr. J. Joshua Kopelman, an obstetrician in Aurora, Colo.
 
A Growing Acceptance
 The use of home monitoring of pregnancies is growing sharply. Last year, Tokos, which controls about 65 percent of the market, treated about 25,000 patients, a 25 percent increase from 1991. Through the first nine months of 1992, the company had revenues of $124 million.
To use the Tokos monitor, a woman straps around her abdomen a belt containing a sensor that detects uterine contractions. The hourlong reading is made one or more times a day and is transmitted by telephone lines to one of 60 Tokos offices staffed by nurses who analyze the data. Should the data suggest that the woman is experiencing early labor, a Tokos nurse calls her physician, who may prescribe terbutaline or ritodrine, medications dispensed by Tokos in a home-infusion kit, to relax the uterus.
A single monitor reading is $100 a day; additional readings and drugs raise that to $300. Visits by a Tokos nurse, required in the most serious cases, cost extra.
As for the company's profitability, Mr. Byrnes, interviewed at Tokos's headquarters in this city south of Los Angeles, said it had a profit margin of 15 to 17 percent of revenues.
While the company's service is expensive, many people think it worth the price. Deborah Jones, of Wayne, N.J., lost a child after going into labor early. In her most recent pregnancy, her physician prescribed Tokos monitoring and she had a healthy girl. "I found great relief and security in the monitor," she said.
Even many of the company's critics agree that intensive contact between a nurse and an expectant mother, part of Tokos's regimen, may help prolong a pregnancy.
 
But Does It Work?
 But does the Tokos technology itself -- the devices that transmit data on uterine activity to the nurses -- have any benefit beyond a psychological one in producing healthier babies? That is the nub of the dispute.
Some scientists argue that educating the patient to recognize symptoms or simply putting her in daily contact with a nurse would be just as helpful -- and less expensive. Some insurers say they could provide nursing more cheaply than Tokos.
In the mid-1980's, studies by researchers including Dr. Michael Katz, chief of perinatology at the California Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco, and Dr. John C. Morrison of the University of Mississippi appeared to support the value of the monitoring. But in 1988, Dr. Jay Iams of Ohio State University published a study that set the battle lines.
Dr. Iams said he initially assumed that his study would prove monitoring's benefits by showing that it extended more pregnancies than did simple daily telephone contact between a patient and a nurse. Instead, he found no difference. "I think everyone was shocked," Dr. Iams said.
But in recent years, much of the research both pro and con has come under attack as scientifically flawed. And, lacking a definitive study, the scientists involved in the debate have only dug in their heels.
Those opposing the growing use of the Tokos service, including Dr. Sachs of Beth Israel in Boston, see it as consuming money that might be better used for patient education. But advocates, like Dr. Morrison, who is now a paid Tokos consultant, say it helps a nurse do her job better.
"I think the literature is clear that you need the whole system," he said.
Last year, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, a professional group, declined for the second time to recommend the routine use of home pregnancy monitoring for high-risk patients. The group cited, among other things, a lack of clear research showing benefits.
Also, a study by a Canadian team published last year in The New England Journal of Medicine suggested that ritodrine is not effective and in fact can cause health problems like maternal heart arrythmia, and, in rare instances, death. The other drug used by Tokos, terbutaline, is chemically similar to ritodrine.
It is a dispute that has left insurers frustrated over what to do. While a majority of the nation's 73 Blue Cross and Blue Shield programs do pay for Tokos claims, about 20 plans do not. State Medicaid plans are also divided.
But efforts by Tokos's team of 20 people who visit insurers appear to be paying off. The company is getting about 80 percent of its orders approved by insurers, up from about 65 percent in 1990, Mr. Byrnes said.
The company's weapons have been studies like a 1990 report by Dr. Thomas S. Kosasa of the John A. Burns School of Medicine in Hawaii that found that home monitoring of 79 patients reduced insurance costs by $11,500 a patient.
Some insurers agreed that monitoring might avert catastrophic health problems associated with premature infants. "It is less costly to have 10 patients monitored -- even if only one may need it -- than to have one patient with a perinatal disaster and have that baby in the hospital with brain damage for months or for the rest of its life," said Dr. Marvin Blitz, the vice president for medical policy and research at Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in New York.
Other insurance executives, like Dr. Wade Aubry, medical director of Blue Shield of California, have looked at the data and reached a different conclusion: that there's no evidence that the monitoring -- as opposed to educating the patient or offering counseling -- makes a difference.
No matter who's right, investment plans like Tokos's are coming under increased scrutiny. In the past year alone, Tokos has set up about 40 physician-owned companies nationwide. Some of the groups were set up by a company known as Women's Homecare, a joint venture between Tokos and T<2> Medical Inc., a concern in Alpharetta, Ga., that pioneered doctor-owned companies in the home-care field.
The plans appear to be part of a high-stakes battle for physicians' loyalty. Victor J. Weinstein, an obstetrician in Charleston, S.C., who is a member of the Tokos plan, recalled his initial encounter with company officials. "We said to them, 'Why are you doing this?' " he said. "They said they were afraid of losing market share to competitors. They said, 'We want to make you a part of us.' "
The major concern with such plans is that physicians will prescribe unnecessary services so they can make more money. Another problem: doctors may form loyalties to companies like Tokos and so overlook more innovative or cost-effective treatments.
Federal law bars physicians from referring Medicare and Medicaid patients to companies in which they have a financial interest. But it does not cover private patients. The Tokos plan involves only private patients.
 
Doctors Are Divided
 Doctors who use Tokos's services are of two minds on the compensation. Dr. Weinstein, the Charleston obstetrician, said the investment plan was a way of compensating him for added time spent on home-care patients. But Dr. Kopelman, the Colorado obstetrician, said he and his partner decided last year to turn down Tokos's offer of fees to "supervise" cases. "We did not feel it represented any additional time so we did not feel that we needed any additional compensation," he said.
For his part, Mr. Byrnes said he was comfortable with the plans and was checking to make sure doctors were not overprescribing just to make more money. "We invite anyone to come in and look at our books."
He may soon find a taker. "The kind of returns these plans are offering physicians seem way out of line with the investment at stake," said Mr. Johnson of the A.M.A. He said that he had been unaware of the details of the Tokos plan and that the company had not sought an ethics ruling from the A.M.A. on the plan.
Ironically, Tokos may have pushed its monitor so aggressively because of insurers' reimbursement policies. Typically, insurers will pay only for drugs and devices, not nursing services alone, Mr. Byrnes said. And insurers like Mr. Blitz said that if the Tokos monitor proved ineffective, they would use their own nurses, not Tokos's, to talk with patients.
The company's claims in support of its own service have concerned some insurers. "The device was approved in a very narrow way but that is not the way it is necessarily marketed," said Dr. Gerald Silverstein, vice president for the Celtic Life Insurance Company in Chicago, which does pay for some Tokos claims.
Indeed, the company may have overreached in some of its claims. It promotes its service -- the monitor, nursing and drugs -- as effective in reducing premature births. But the F.D.A. has approved only the use of the monitor, not the service as a whole, and only then to detect early labor in the small group of women who have a history of early delivery. Also, the Government has never approved terbutaline as a birth-delaying drug or Tokos's claim that its system can reduce early births.
While it is legal and common for physicians to prescribe drugs and devices for unapproved uses, a company may not market its products for such uses or making unapproved claims for those products.
An F.D.A. spokeswoman declined to comment on her agency's inquiry into Tokos's claims. But Tokos officials said they have recently moved to separate their claims about the monitor and the service.
Mr. Byrnes said the debate surrounding his company had been caused by a small group of scientists opposed to monitoring and by short sellers. The stock, which was trading at $46.25 a share in December 1991, closed at $14 a share on Friday.
 
A Call for Research
 For all the debate, the question of whether Tokos's monitor is worth the price may never be adequately answered. What is needed, many people say, is studies that separate the benefits provided by the monitor from those offered by talking with a nurse.
In recent months, the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, a Federal agency, has tried to raise $6 million to finance such a study. But both Tokos and Healthdyne officials turned down a request to help underwrite the research, said Dr. Donald McNellis, the institute's special assistant for obstetrics. (Caremark, the smallest of the three home-care providers, has expressed interest.)
Mr. Byrnes said it was time to move beyond the monitoring debate and finance studies to better identify women at risk of premature delivery.
Dr. Iams said he could understand why there was so little interest among the home-monitoring companies. "They are out marketing their services and making money," he said. "The only thing that this study can do is hurt them."

 
 
SOME QUESTIONS RAISED IN CANADA
 LAST YEAR, Canadian researchers stirred further controversy about Tokos's home-care service. They reported in The New England Journal of Medicine that the drug ritodrine, used to delay delivery, did not appear effective and could cause health problems like heart arrhythmias and, in a small number of cases, death.
In its home-care regimen, Tokos uses both ritodrine and terbutaline, a chemically similar drug, as prescribed by a patient's physician. Terbutaline is not approved by the Food and Drug Administration as a treatment for early labor, but obstetricians use it widely.
The drugs, which are also asthma medications, work by relaxing the uterus. Initially, they are given to a woman orally, sometimes as early as the 24th week of pregnancy. But if a woman has an episode of early labor, Tokos will use a home infusion kit to deliver the drugs by injection.
In October, an F.D.A. advisory panel met to review the Canadian study. It found that ritodrine was effective when used intravenously, but expressed concerns about the drug's safety and recommended that the drug be used only in pregnancies of 33 weeks or less. In terms of oral usage, the panel found that ritodrine was of little benefit at current dosage levels and that further study was needed to see if an effective dose could be found.
As for terbutaline, the panel said that it was "concerned" about its growing unapproved use and asked the agency to look into how it might be best controlled and whether patients should be warned about its dangers.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Labor Takes a Happy Breath

SERIES: Next Week: The third in a series of articles about research in work and family issues.

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
THE labor movement, represented by the leaders of its 33 largest unions, is gathering this week on the sands of sunny Florida for its annual winter meeting. For the first time in more than a decade, it may not actually need the refuge that the swank of Bal Harbour provides. For 12 years, in labor's view, the arriviste and the aristocrat stood shoulder to shoulder against the working person.
Now Citizen Clinton is in the White House and, labor would say, finally a few things are right with the world. Mr. Clinton has signed two executive orders reversing Reagan-Bush Administration positions on rules at Federal work sites and on the use of union dues. He is considering amnesty for the striking air traffic controllers fired by Ronald Reagan. He has appointed Robert Reich to resurrect the Labor Department from the near-death experience it has suffered under 12 years of Republican stewardship. 
 And if Mr. Reich's favorite song is not "Look for the Union Label," he is at least on the same wavelength as the unions and has already put many of organized labor's issues on the top of his priority pile. "We are delighted with Robert Reich," said Rex Hardesty, a spokesman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "We've always said that economic policy was what mattered."
When Mr. Reich meets with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council at Bal Harbour on Tuesday, he is certain to be received more warmly than the most recent Labor Secretary, Lynn Martin, who came and repeatedly stuffed statistics on the decline of the unionized work force into the face of Lane Kirkland, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president.
But, if Secretary Martin was not as polite as the irate council would have liked about labor's numerical strength, the fact remains that the unions have a problem. In 1992, the percent of unionized workers in the private labor force dropped to 11.5, from 16.8 in 1983, the first year for which there are comparable figures. The percent of unionized workers is lower now than at any time since the National Labor Relations Act was passed in 1935,according to Greg Tarpinian, executive director of the Labor Research Association, a labor group in New York.
"If the current rate of decline continues," Mr. Tarpinian said, "5 percent of the private labor force will be unionized by the year 2000." Growth is occurring mostly in public employee unions, which operate under a different set of rules than do private-sector labor organizations.
There is the obvious problem of whether labor can drum up support at the White House and in Congress for a legislative agenda that includes, in the immediate future, a striker replacement bill and modifications to the North American Free Trade Agreement. In the longer term, some labor leaders would like to see on the table such apparently utopian goals as universal health care, labor law reform -- current labor law imposes restrictions on organizing unlike those in any other industrialized country -- and paid family leave.
There is the less obvious problem of drumming up support among the 177 million people in the work force. Mr. Clinton's election, and with it the dispensing of leadership by the generation of the 40's, has made even more conspicuous the fact that the torch has not, by and large, been passed to a new generation of labor leaders.
No one who remembers an elderly John L. Lewis thundering at his foes is likely to criticize the leadership on grounds of age alone. But labor seems to expend little on image management and the sophisticated technology and techniques by which it occurs -- technology and techniques young political consultants and public relations people, for example, take for granted. "You are not going to get the rank and file motivated without using modern tools of communications," Mr. Tarpinian argues.
Some of labor's problems are rooted in American attitudes, especially middle-class, white-collar attitudes. "It's a difficult hurdle for many Americans," said Gary Hubbard, a spokesman for the United Steelworkers of America. "They think they're independent and can take care of themselves."
But America -- the part that's at the mercy of downsizing, restructuring and revamping -- may be catching up with the union movement. Labor is worried about global competition and the loss of high-paying jobs, about the lack of affordable health care, about the decline in the middle-class standard of living and the lack of job security, about the viability of pension funds. Sound familiar, white-collar America?
 
 
 
WHAT THE WOMEN ARE CALLING FOR
 ALONG with many people around the country in the last few weeks, Joyce Miller believes she has been watching the appointment of the Attorney General turn into a women's issue. The woeful Zoe Baird-Kimba Wood interlude, she says, helped highlight a key issue: the lack of adequate child care for all working women. "Women have to reach out to whoever they can to take care of their children," said Ms. Miller, a member of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council and president of the Coalition of Labor Union Women.
Though Ms. Miller is loyal to labor at large, it is her professional duty to serve the interests of union women, not always an easy job in a movement still dominated by men. Though C.L.U.W. is almost 20 years old, only two women serve on the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council. Ms. Miller says women are gradually working their way up the pipeline. They serve now as secretary-treasurers, department heads and high-level assistants.
The pool feeding the pipeline is growing in size and influence. The International Labor Organization reported recently that the number of female union members doubled between 1960 and 1990, to 6.2 million from 3.1 million. The issues? Among others, "Increasing the minimum wage," said Ms. Miller. "Getting more women into the higher paying nontraditional jobs."
She favors paid family and medical leaves. She agrees that possibility was precisely what business objected to during debates about the Family and Medical Leave Act, which grants 12 weeks of unpaid leave. "It will not be nearly the nightmare they're trying to make it," she argues. "Other countries have done this and survived. Look at Germany. They are thriving."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: The Clinton Economic Plan's Winners and Losers

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE economic plan that President Clinton unveils this week will be the biggest earthquake to hit the nation's economy since President Reagan took office 12 years ago, turning many industries topsy-turvy, leaving some badly damaged and some better-off.
The plan will reshape the economic landscape, the President's aides say, by creating a tax credit for business investment, establishing a broad-based energy tax, cutting capital gains taxes for new businesses and seriously attacking the budget deficit. 
 While Mr. Clinton vows that the plan will make the American economy stand tall again, many businesses spent last week greasing their powerful Washington lobbying machines in the hope of knocking down whatever parts of the Clinton program would hurt them, and there should be plenty.
Retailers worry that an increase in the corporate income tax would hit them broadside. Computer makers are terrified that the tax credit for business investment may not include computer purchases. And big energy users, like chemical companies, airlines and metal producers, fear that they would be battered by a new energy tax.
Some executives point out that if the plan hits them too hard, economic sense will drive them to hit Mr. Clinton where it hurts: they would open new plants and create new jobs overseas, rather than in the United States.
"If the Administration decides that it's going to make it more difficult for us to compete by raising the cost of doing business, then new investments are not going to be made in this country," said Paul H. O'Neill, chairman of Alcoa, the nation's largest aluminum company.
While the broad outline of Mr. Clinton's plan is known, many details remain under wraps, with industries struggling to figure out whether they will be winners or losers. There will certainly be some last-minute changes and surprises as the Clinton team rummages around to find $145 billion in annual deficit cuts.
To be sure, Mr. Clinton will sprinkle plenty of goodies into his package. The biggest will be an investment tax credit, which will be manna for the nation's machinery producers. Paving companies and producers of railroad cars are delighted by the prospect of increased infrastructure spending. And plans to slash capital gains taxes for investors in start-up businesses should prove a gold mine for venture capitalists.
At the moment, many business executives feel off balance anticipating Mr. Clinton's economic package, worried about proposals that would hurt their bottom lines, but sharing the President's goal of cutting the deficit. Many question the wisdom of mounting an all-out offensive against specific parts of the plan when the President's credo is shared sacrifice to slay the deficit dragon.
"Everyone will have to pay their fair share," Mr. Clinton told business lobbyists on Thursday. "But if you do, we will all be better off, and the business community will be stronger in the years ahead."
Who knows better than executives that slashing the deficit is vital to reduce long-term interest rates and free up more money for private investment. Indeed, there is a palpable sense among some business leaders that tearing down the Clinton plan would make the nation's long-term economic prospects dimmer than ever.
"No increase in our taxes or costs is welcome," said Arnold M. Nemirow, chief executive of the Wisconsin-based Wausau Paper Mills Company. "However, if it's applied fairly and is necessary to help reduce the deficit long-term, we'll all be better off."
 
Investment Tax Credit
 For business, the investment tax credit will be the sweetener that makes the package's bitter medicine palatable. Administration officials talked last week about a a 10 percent credit on investments in equipment, but noted that the percent could still change. They say the credit will probably be incremental, meaning companies would receive the credits only on investments above a certain level of investment in recent years.
Administration policymakers see such a credit as the most powerful tool for speeding up growth, and some economists say it can produce $10 billion to $15 billion extra in equipment spending this year. The biggest winners will be producers of capital equipment, like machinery makers, and capital-intensive industries, like chemicals and metals. "It's very important for us to have a good investment tax credit," said Milton Deaner, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Despite the broad business support for such a credit, lobbyists sound like screeching alley cats in arguing over what the details should be. The Administration favors a temporary credit to get a quick burst of investment over the next year or two, but Allen Lenz, chief economist for the Chemical Manufacturers Association, said, "It should be a permanent thing because if it's temporary, you just get a little extra puff of investment for a minute."
Fortune 500 companies fear the credit will be aimed at small business, and small companies seem allergic to the complexity of an incremental credit.
"The incremental credit being designed is not small-business friendly," said John Motley, vice president at the National Federation of Independent Business. "Incremental credits are complicated. You need good professional help or computer programs to figure them out, and that costs a lot for our members."
Detroit's Big Three fear the credit will not include fleet sales of cars, and Silicon Valley frets that computers will be excluded. "We are working with Administration officials and folks on the Hill to make sure that computers are included," said Ted Heydinger, director of government relations for the Computer and Business Equipment Manufacturers Association.
The question of what time period to use as the base of past investment will certainly lead to heavy-duty lobbying. For example, investment by the aircraft and glass industries was especially strong last year, so those industries might be penalized because it would be hard for them to exceed those levels. "I worry that they'll define it in a way that punishes manufacturers who have invested a lot recently while giving the greatest benefits to those who haven't invested much," said Albert W. Moore, president of the Association for Manufacturing Technology, a group of machine tool makers. "That doesn't make sense."
Not surprisingly, many businesses prefer a broad credit rewarding them for every dollar of new investment.
 
Energy Taxes
 For years, many executives supported a gasoline tax to cut the deficit because it would sock consumers while hardly laying a hand on most businesses. Administration officials, however, have signaled that they favor a broad tax on all energy, because drivers would find a gasoline tax unfair.
In addition to raising revenue, such a tax could conserve energy and reduce pollution. The Administration is leaning toward either an ad valorem tax, a fixed tax on all energy use, or a B.T.U. tax levied on the heat value of different energy sources. Either tax is expected to increase the nation's annual energy bill, now $475 billion, by at least $20 billion.
Manufacturers are fuming, contending that such a tax would greatly harm export-oriented companies. "You're going to have a hell of a fight on any energy tax that significantly increases the cost of production," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "We can't afford that with everything else going on."
Take the steel industry. Energy accounts for about $100 of the $450 cost of a ton of flat-rolled steel, and an energy tax could increase costs by $10 a ton. Mr. Deaner, president of the Iron and Steel Institute, said, "The industry lost $3 billion in the last two years, or about $15 a ton, so if you add another $5 to $10 to costs, it really hurts."
Perhaps the hardest hit industry would be aluminum because of the huge amounts of energy used in smelting. "To the degree that there is a differential tax impact on energy-intensive industries like aluminum, the ultimate consequence is going to be the most energy-intensive parts of the industry are going to stop being done in the U.S.," Mr. O'Neill, Alcoa's chairman, said. "They will relocate to places with hydroelectric power or other cheap sources, like Venezuela, Brazil or Australia."
Noting that a B.T.U. tax would hurt his company eight times as much as a gasoline tax, Mr. O'Neill urged a gasoline tax or broad-based consumption tax. Many manufacturers favor a broad consumption tax, like a national sales tax, contending it would encourage investment.
Underlining executives' fundamental differences over taxes, Tracy Mullin, president of the National Retail Federation, attacked a consumption tax. "Our industry is very opposed to a broad-based consumption tax," she said. "It's regressive. It would dampen consumption, and that would send negative ripples through an already fragile economy."
 
Raising Corporate Taxes
 Few businesses are happy about President Clinton's plan to increase the corporate income tax from its current 34 percent level.
Treasury officials have told him that if he goes through with his campaign pledge to increase personal income taxes on the rich to 36 percent from 31 percent, then the corporate rate should rise to the same level. Otherwise, partnerships, whose members pay the personal income tax rate, would incorporate to qualify for the lower corporate rate.
"We are very, very disturbed with this initiative on corporate rates," said Dirk Van Dongen, co-chairman of the Tax Reform Action Coalition, an association representing scores of trade associations and companies. "Corporations create jobs. Implicit in that is you don't take resources away from them."
The corporate tax rise might hurt capital-intensive companies, like chemicals or machinery, least because they can write off their equipment and would now benefit from investment credits. In painful contrast, financial service companies and retailers would feel the full brunt of this increase.
"We pay a very high effective tax rate," said Ms. Mullin of the retail federation. "We have tiny profit margins, maybe 2 percent of sales in a good year. Anything that increases the corporate rate will hurt us immediately."
Administration officials, eager not to alienate the middle class, say that it is more equitable to raise corporate and personal income taxes than payroll or consumption taxes.
But many companies seem ready to wage an all-out battle against the corporate tax increase, arguing that it clashes with the Administration's plan to encourage investment rather than consumption. That means embracing consumption taxes, rather than higher income taxes.
"Everyone else in the world is moving to consumption taxes, and we're talking about higher income taxes," said Roger E. Brinner, chief economist for DRI/McGraw-Hill. "That's terrible international strategy."
 
Infrastructure
 When President Clinton surveys the nation's infrastructure, he sees not America the Beautiful, but America the Bruised and Battered. Thus he plans to increase investment spending by $10 billion to $20 billion annually over the next four years to repair and renovate crumbling highways, rusting bridges and packed airports.
The Administration is also planning to shower money on high-tech projects, like high-speed rail, a nationwide computer highway and a new generation of pollution-control equipment. All this aims to show an America on the mend, one ready to leap into the 21st Century.
Hearing all this, construction firms and transportation equipment companies think they are about to enter heaven.
Mr. Clinton's ambitious infrastructure plans could increase spending on public investment by 10 percent a year. The CMI Corporation, an Oklahoma-based producer of $500,000 highway-paving machines, expects its orders to jump by 20 percent because of the infrastructure frenzy.
"We see a lot of work resurfacing, rehabilitating and widening highways and roads," said John Lillywhite, a director of project development for the Bechtel Group, the San Francisco-based construction giant. "There should also be a lot of opportunity in light rail and high-speed rail."
Mr. Clinton's infrastructure program has two objectives: to give the fragile economy a short-term shot in the arm and to enable American industry to compete better long-term by making transportation and communications faster and cheaper.
"This program is seeking to speed up the recovery and that means cyclical industries would benefit the most," said Laurence H. Meyer, who runs an economics consulting firm in St. Louis.
The cyclical winners are expected to include machinery and metal companies, truck manufacturers and construction firms.
 
Capital Gains Tax Cuts For Small Businesses
 Tearing a page out of the Reagan playbook, the Administration wants to unleash entrepreneurs, but in a scaled-down Democratic way: slashing capital gains taxes for investments in start-up businesses only. Clinton aides say the President will propose some version of a bill sponsored by Senator Dale Bumpers, another Arkansas Democrat, that would eliminate capital gains taxes for investments held for 10 years in companies with $5 million or less in capital. Investors in companies with capital of $100 million or less would receive a 50 percent capital gains tax cut for stock held at least five years.
Venture capitalists -- who are lobbying to increase the threshold to $200 million -- say such a proposal would encourage mom-and-pop start-ups and create tens of thousands of jobs. "If you have a start-up company with no track record, you don't rush to lend it $100 million," said Barry Rogstad, president of the American Business Conference, an association of fast-growing mid-sized companies. "This proposal helps because it will really reduce the cost of capital."
While preferring this proposal to the across-the-board cuts in capital gains taxes favored by former President Bush, some Democrats fear the proposal will serve mainly as a tax break for venture capitalists.
"Not too many moms and pops are lobbying for this proposal, but a lot of venture capitalists are," said Alan Auerbach, an economics professor at the University of Pennsylvania. One fear is that corporations with capital of more than $100 million would exploit this tax break by dividing themselves into smaller units.
Venture capitalists insist the tax break would help the economy at large. "This is much bigger than the venture capital industry; this is about job creation," said Richard Kramlich, managing partner of New Enterprise Associates, a venture capital firm.
 
Conclusion
 By no means does the above list cover all of the President's proposals that will affect business. Mr. Clinton's vow to increase income taxes on rich Americans will unquestionably hurt Neiman-Marcus and the Four Seasons more than Wal-Mart and Pizza Hut. Then, the President's plan to limit the deductibility for excessive executive pay will anger company chairmen whose boards may rethink astronomical compensation plans.
For months, Mr. Clinton has pledged to make the research and development tax credit permanent, and that should be a shot in the arm to high-tech companies. His plan to beef up the nation's mediocre job training efforts should also help manufacturers.
Like the public at large, the business community runs the risk of focusing on just the proposals that cause immediate pain without stopping to look at Mr. Clinton's big picture -- a picture that includes deficit reduction, a better workforce, and, the President hopes, lower interest rates and higher profits and living standards.
Last week President Clinton warned business lobbyists to get on board, rather than fight his economic plan. "We have got to change," he exhorted them. "The short-term pain of making changes now is so much less than the long-term costs of continuing to do things the way we're doing them."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
With Volatility Rising, Traders Are Twitching

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
AS details leak out regarding President Clinton's economic plan, the financial markets are getting nervous. Not necessarily scared, but jerky.
There are good reasons for such concerns. While public attention in Washington focused on nannies and gay soldiers, the emerging Clinton economic strategy appears to be based on lessons learned from Ronald Reagan: A President's power is greatest at the beginning of an Administration, while the economic statistics are most important in the last year of a term. 
 The economy was horrible early in Mr. Reagan's first term, a fact that did not prevent his re-election. It was just fine early in George Bush's administration, a fact that did him little good in 1992.
It appears that Mr. Clinton hopes to push through unpopular tax increases, including a broader tax on Social Security benefits, while cutting at least a few spending programs. In the longer term, such a budget-control strategy has a lot to recommend it. But the more immediate impact will probably be negative, as tighter fiscal policy slows a recovery that already is the weakest in memory.
The stock market's current high multiples assume that corporate profits will grow at a good clip. But a weak-recovery strategy would tend to hold down profits, as would an increase in corporate income taxes. The idea of using the tax law to penalize companies whose executives are paid in the millions might not bring in much revenue, but it would set a negative tone in Wall Street-Washington relations. Nervousness related to such talk helped give the Nasdaq composite its worst week since last September, down 1.5 percent.
The Treasury bond market ought to like such talk, but even it had its moments of nervousness last week. Buyers balked at the new 10-year Treasury bond, and for a day it appeared the brokers had bid too high and might suffer big losses. But Clinton tax talk helped push rates back down, producing sighs of relief around Wall Street.
Perhaps the most intriguing indications of nervousness are in the commodities markets. The sudden bull market in lumber -- in which the price of boards for delivery next month has risen from 22 cents a board foot last fall to more than 39 cents now -- took almost everyone by surprise. James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, suggests it could be heralding a renewal of inflation, but the conventional wisdom is that lumber prices will soon subside.
Even long-dormant precious metals came to life for a couple of days last week. The markets clearly suspect that something is about to change, but are not sure just what.
The increased volatility makes life more interesting for traders -- Nasdaq brokers now discuss the "disaster du jour" -- but does not necessarily encourage investors. Perhaps things will settle down soon, but it is at least as likely that the President's proposals will just set off a long round of congressional haggling, keeping outcomes uncertain and markets unsettled.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
PC Buyers Will Soon Face Choices Among Work Stations

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
PERSONAL computers and work stations, two of the fastest-growing areas of the computer industry, have been on a collision course for several years. This may be the year of impact.
Sometime later in 1993, the two companies that have set the pace in recent years for PC hardware and software will climb to higher realms of performance. The Intel Corporation is expected to introduce its Pentium microprocessor (nee the 586, successor to the 286, 386 and 486). The Microsoft Corporation will introduce Windows NT, its first operating system designed specifically to take advantage of the power of the Pentium and other powerful microprocessors. 
 At the same time, the companies that dominate the market for powerful work stations are driving down prices, moving ever closer to the realm of personal computers that use the Intel chips. It is now possible to buy a low-end work station for less than $5,000 -- a machine that would have cost at least $15,000 not so long ago.
But the huge corporate market is not likely to switch en masse to work stations, because software, not hardware, is the biggest investment a company makes. Most businesses have already made substantial investments in PC software, and far more software is available for PC's than for work stations, especially for routine work like word processing and spreadsheet calculations. But as even routine business applications demand more processing power, work stations are increasingly attractive.
Sun Microsystems Inc. is the leader in the work station market, followed by Hewlett-Packard, International Business Machines, Digital Equipment and Silicon Graphics. Each is vowing to provide mainstream business customers with work stations that cost less than $5,000.
Most of those work station makers, with Digital in the lead, are also exploring the possibility of creating even lower-cost systems to run Microsoft Windows NT and other operating systems as well as Unix, a powerful if somewhat cumbersome program that is well-suited to tasks like computer-aided design and engineering, data-base management, electronic publishing, software development, video teleconferencing and scientific modeling.
"Digital has kind of beat them to the punch, but H-P and Sun are kicking NT's tires," said Bill Bluestein, a senior analyst for Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
Planning a counterattack, several PC makers are in the process of creating entirely new systems using reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. Later this year, the first efforts of the much-ballyhooed alliance of I.B.M., Apple and Motorola will yield its first computer products, generically known as the Power PC family. The Power PC chip is expected to yield performance equal to or slightly better than Intel's Pentium.
As the line of demarcation between personal computers and work stations blurs, businesses will find they have new choices for managing information. And choice, many executives have learned, is a decidedly mixed blessing: confusion may be heaped upon confusion.
Most work stations already employ RISC processors, which use a simple, highly optimized set of commands to achieve high performance at relatively low cost. Work stations also traditionally use variations of the Unix.
But Windows NT may prove to be Microsoft's wild card. The program is expected to have features that rival those in Unix, and Microsoft is a formidable competitor, with nearly 100 million PC's flying its flag.
A delicious twist to the operating system maneuvering occurred recently when the Novell Corporation, the leading maker of operating systems for networked personal computers, acquired Unix Systems Laboratories Inc., the standard-bearer for unifying the Unix world.
The idea of a Unix in every box, from the desktop to the supercomputer, is not new. "It's a war cry that has been heard so long that Rip Van Winkle was probably the first to shout it," said John R. Logan, vice president of the Aberdeen Group Inc., a market research and consulting firm in Boston.
But Novell does have the ears of many corporate PC managers. And the war cry "allows Novell to go head-to-head with Microsoft NT, with the argument that NT is merely a desktop or low-end system," Mr. Logan said. Unix, on the other hand, works on big systems as well as small, he said.
The latest maneuvering in the work station business came last week from I.B.M., whose advanced work station and systems division rolled out a series of new RS/6000 machines, ranging from one with supercomputer power at a cost of $300,000 to a low-end color model that sells for $3,995. (The price for the low-end model, however, does not include a disk drive, which can add a few hundreds to a few thousand dollars.)
"It's an exciting price point, even though they know full well that nobody will buy it that way," said Terry D. Bennett, director of technical systems research in the Beaverton, Ore., office of Infocorp, a market research firm.
"I.B.M. is becoming more aggressive in many ways, and one of the ways is that they're willing to do some of the marketing and positioning games that others did." Even when the disk drive is added, he said, the I.B.M. machines are attractive.
I.B.M.'s history in the work station business is a tale of contrasts. The company invented RISC technology in 1975 but failed to exploit it commercially until three years ago.
In February 1990, I.B.M. brought out the RS/6000 product line as a replacement for its ill-conceived and short-lived I.B.M. PC-RT (for RISC Technology, or Really a Turkey, depending on whom you ask).
In less than a year, the RS/6000 generated $1 billion in sales, and it remains one of the fastest-growing segments of I.B.M.'s business "although things have slowed down a bit," said Nancy E. Battey, director of work station research at the International Data Corporation in Mountain View, Calif. She added, "The arrival of the Power PC in the second half of the year will help I.B.M. get down into the lower cost range."
When I.B.M. reported its disastrous financial results for 1992 last month, the soon-to-be replaced chief executive, John F. Akers, tried to soften the blow by pointing to technologies that he said were the key to the company's recovery strategy. Among those he specifically cited were client-server computing, networking, RISC technology and multimedia, all of which have some relationship to the work station business.
The advanced work station and systems division is one of I.B.M.'s bright spots, and it is expected to become increasingly important as the computer industry in general, and I.B.M. in particular, shifts its focus away from mainframes and supercomputers and toward smaller but increasingly powerful systems.
