HEADLINE: Business Diary/February 7-12

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring
 
 
COMPANIES

 
And Now, the News: G.M., G.M., Then a Word on G.M.

 BODY:

Even with the battering it's taken in recent years, General Motors remains larger than life. And last week, true to form, it dominated the news -- a public-relations bull's-eye one day, a mind-boggling loss the next. First, refusing to just lick its wounds after a jury held it responsible for a teen-ager's death in a G.M. pickup, the company roared onto the offensive, suing NBC for tampering with a truck in a news report. It scored a direct hit, as NBC -- to settle the suit -- issued a stunningly long (three-and-a-half-minute) on-air apology. Then, with no qualms about kicking the downed network, the auto maker suspended advertising on all NBC News programs. (After just a day, however, saying it was satisfied with the apology, it rescinded that ban.) And to thicken the plot, a judge dealt G.M. a setback in its grand plan to close numerous plants -- and gave at least a temporary reprieve to 2,500 auto workers whose jobs are threatened. Saying that by accepting tax abatements G.M. had effectively promised to keep its Willow Run plant, in Ypsilanti, Mich., open through the 1990's, the judge blocked it from closing the plant. G.M. had planned to close it this summer and consolidate operations in Arlington, Tex. Calling the ruling "unprecedented and contrary to both the facts and the law," G.M. said it would appeal. The company had tried to forfeit the tax breaks, but Doug Winters, the Ypsilanti city attorney, said, "We want the jobs, not the money. G.M. is not above the law."
 
Sprinting for the Red
 
Has Carl Lewis gone into accounting? He must have, the way records are getting broken. But corporate America surely hopes these records will last. First, Ford reported a $7.4 billion loss for 1992, mainly because of its retiree accounting, erasing I.B.M.'s recent record for the nation's largest loss. But its title lasted just a day, as General Motors came in with a stunning $23.5 billion figure. Without the special charges, though, there were signs of improving operations. G.M. stock did well, ending the week at $40.625, while Ford shares slipped to $49.25.
 
A Poorer Sears, a New Sears
 
Another fixture of the corporate landscape dumped some hefty numbers onto its balance sheet last week. In reporting a $3.9 billion deficit, Sears, Roebuck cited hurricane-related losses at its Allstate Insurance unit and the costs of scrapping its catalogue. Not to mention its charge for retiree benefits -- $1.87 billion. Later in the week, after pausing to let the news sink in, the retailer looked squarely at the future, vowing to spend $4 billion to give its stores face lifts.
 
More Shrinkage at I.B.M.
 
It may have to rename itself I.B. if it gets any smaller. I.B.M. only recently said it would cut its work force by 25,000, but word spread last week that it could be more like 40,000. The numbers tell the tale of the incredible shrinking company. Workers: 407,000 in 1986, 300,000 at the end of '92 . . . and 260,000 at the end of '93? Stock price: over $100 last summer, $50.75 on Friday.

Short Chapter at Random House
 
Joni Evans has had a bumpy ride at Random House. In 1987 she was recruited to start her own imprint. Then she was named to head the adult trade division. That lasted just a few years, and she then created Turtle Bay Books. But now Turtle Bay is no more. Ms. Evans said she always thought "it would be three to four years before we broke even, and I thought he did, too." But "he" -- Alberto Vitale, Random House chairman -- said, "Conditions have changed."
 
Survival of the Techiest
 
It makes the head spin. You're slogging through the evening's cable offerings -- the 12 talk shows, the 15 football games -- when some long-distance company calls to explain its convoluted advantages. Now it's all getting mixed up together; the cable and phone businesses are cross-breeding, embarking on an odd Darwinian struggle. Last week, in the first deal of its kind, Southwestern Bell agreed to buy two cable systems from Hauser Communications -- the onset of a race to deliver all manner of communications services, like more cable offerings than you'll ever keep track of. Soon, perhaps, you'll reach for the phone to turn on a movie, or turn on the set to call Aunt Nellie -- or finally, in low-tech despair, sit down and read a book.

Hello, Phone -- Get Me Rewrite
 
Meanwhile, phone technology moves relentlessly on. In Nynex's latest bid to improve the human lot, you can say "Mom" and the phone calls your mom. And only yours, mind you. Other voices get other moms. In the system Nynex will soon begin testing, each household member compiles a separate voice directory of dozens of names. Is the system perfect? Well, no. Nynex officials concede that if Dana Carvey barked out "Barbara," the former First Lady's phone could easily ring.
 
HB>THE ECONOMY

 
Clinton Works the Crowd
 
President Clinton laid it out succinctly. "With all these economic improvements, we aren't generating new jobs," he said at his "town meeting." And the deficit, he said, "is about $50 billion a year bigger than I was told." Questioners veered to other topics, but Mr. Clinton kept steering back to the economy. On Wednesday he will propose higher taxes and painful budget cuts, and he wanted to soften up his audience -- to assure them his plan would be "fair to all Americans." He did offer one specific: he will seek to raise the corporate tax rate -- a message he then gave to 200 executives and lobbyists at the White House.
 
Read Their Lips: 'Don't Touch'
 
In casting about for a billion here, a billion there, to hack from the deficit, Mr. Clinton will have to look hard at many sacred items. But some things are more sacred than others -- like Social Security cost-of-living increases. His budget director, Leon Panetta, had proposed a one-year freeze, but Mr. Clinton -- possibly with visions of irate retirees at the White House barricades -- put his machete away. A freeze, falling hardest on the poor, is a far cry from soaking the rich. But he has not ruled out increasing taxes on benefits, since that would not affect low-income people.
 
Inflation Stays in Check
 
 Inflation is well under control even as economic growth gains momentum. Prices at the wholesale level rose a modest 0.2 percent in January. Over the past year the Producer Price Index has risen just 1.8 percent -- a minor gain for an expanding economy.
 
Detroit vs. Japan: No Contest
 
Detroit was armed for battle. Thinking the time was right and the new Administration sympathetic, it had spent serious money preparing to file complaints seeking steep duties on imported cars. But once its plans leaked out, the rock-throwing started. Cries of protectionism filled the air, foreign auto makers and governments trained their heavy lobbying guns on Detroit, and even Mickey Kantor, the top American trade official, voiced qualms. The final blow came when General Motors, bombarded by Japanese pressure, defected. The auto makers, while insisting they had a strong case, saw that without a united front they had no chance and backed off. The move was a reprieve for the Administration, which would have been forced to resolve this sticky issue quickly.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Speed. Freedom. . . . Tolls?
 
Autobahn. The very word spits out images of untamed horsepower, foot to the Porsche floor, the ultimate open road -- in short, freedom. With no tolls, and long stretches with no speed limits, the network of superhighways has deep resonance for Germany, and the world. But again, yesterday's sacred cow becomes today's hamburger. The realities: severe congestion and a German economy whose horsepower is dwindling. So Bonn plans the unthinkable: charging user fees on the Autobahn and eventually privatizing it. Well, there are still video games.
 
Bonjour, Vietnam
 
On the first visit by a Western leader since 1975, Francois Mitterrand promised to double aid to Vietnam -- if human rights improve -- and urged Washington to end its economic embargo. Local radio said the visit showed that the West saw Vietnam's "will to join the mainstream economy."
 
Tax the Other Guy, Not Saudi Oil
 
Saudi Arabia is worried. There's a lot of talk about taxes to cut oil use. And now that Saudi Arabia has replaced Russia as the largest oil producer, the Saudis have the most to lose. This threat also comes just as Saudi Arabia is trying to pare OPEC output to push prices higher. So the Saudi oil minister, Hisham M. Nazer, in Houston last week, pulled out all the stops. Citing "constant discrimination against oil," he called environmentalists' policies "alarming." Oil import fees "defy the logic of geology and economics." And, citing the crying need for global economic growth, he said, "Abject poverty is indeed the worst environmental pollutant."

HEADLINE: VOWS;
Martha Evans and Geoffrey Morris

BYLINE: By Lois Smith Brady

 BODY:
THESE days, when Geoffrey Morris tells people what he does, they often respond by starting a Crossfire-style political debate with him.
Mr. Morris, 27, is the executive editor of National Review, a conservative journal that publishes everything from articles about America's moral decline to ads for Slick Willie T-shirts. Recently, he's been invited to quite a few of what he calls "cocktail parties for the embattled." 
 His courtship of Martha Evans, 25, the assistant to the marketing director of Library of America in New York, a nonprofit publisher of American classics, was thoroughly conservative.
Until their wedding, she lived on the Upper East Side and he lived downtown. "We didn't want to live together without being married," said Mr. Morris, who described the conservative view of marriage this way: "You date for a while and then you find that it's right and then you get married and live together happily ever after, but not before. I think people ideally want marriage to be that way, but economic concerns and other things force them to live together. We tried to get close to the ideal."
Though Ms. Evans and Mr. Morris rarely vote alike -- she's a liberal and a supporter of President Clinton -- on the subject of relationships and marriage, they agree. "You don't have to be conservative to have these views of commitment and responsibility," she said.
While the couple did not share an apartment before the wedding (the bride said she was looking forward to fighting over private space with Mr. Morris) they took many sailing trips together, a true test of compatibility.
In June 1991, when they took a weeklong trip off the New England coast, Sheila Evans, the bride's mother, worried how the couple would fare together on a small boat. She recalled: "We all wondered, 'How is their relationship going to be after such a long, tough sail?' They still liked each other, probably better than before."
He proposed in July, sitting on the sea wall outside her family's house in Cohasset, Mass. "We sat down on the wall," she recalled, "and he started saying things like, 'We've been coming here a lot in the past few years.' Then he said, 'Well, would you take care of me if I was sick?' That's when I knew it was serious."
They went apartment hunting only a few weeks before the wedding. "When we were looking for apartments on the West Side," Mr. Morris said, "one of the brokers looked at me like: 'I've never seen one of you guys in person. You're a conservative and you live in New York?' "
Last Saturday, a layer of new snow covered the roofs and rocky coves of Cohasset. Snow continued to fall as Ms. Evans arrived at St. Anthony's Church, in a white sleeveless gown, long white gloves and a tulle veil as thin and transparent as frost.
The 180 guests, many of them rugged sailors like the bride and bridegroom, didn't seem to mind the storm. One said he was glad to be on dry land.
William F. Buckley Jr., the editor at large of National Review and a sailing partner of the bridegroom, missed the wedding, but responding to a request for comment he sent a fax a few days later from Rougemont, Switzerland. In it he said: "Sailing on the midnight watch to Nova Scotia a couple of years ago, Geoff Morris commented -- mind you, this was 18 full months before the defeat of George Bush -- that there weren't enough conservatives in America. I urged him to do something about that and lo! he discovered the fair Martha." He added, "To be sure, the first job is to bring her around."

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Saturn Adds a Wagon to the Line

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
FOR a while there, I thought I had figured it out, figured the easy way to get through the winter. Two years ago, I had shelled out 400 bucks for a snowblower, and Long Island hadn't had more than a dusting of snow since that day.
Alas, the magic seemed to be gone, I thought, flailing my way through what was indeed a surprise snowstorm over the Northeast, which unfortunately included the Long Island Expressway. Weaving through pileup after pileup, I was feeling particularly sorry about the two expensively crumpled Mercedes-Benzes at the side of the road. 
 I had time to ruminate, because I was nicely secure in an inexpensive little Saturn with front-wheel drive, traction-control and antilock brakes. The car just threaded its way through the morass of fender-benders and showed again why it has been one of the major successes of recent years.
By now, of course, even casual observers are probably aware of at least part of the Saturn story: How General Motors created a new corporation in Spring Hill, Tenn., to build a world-class car. How a new dealer network of fancy showrooms was created. And how customer satisfaction has skyrocketed as a result of a serious attempt to do everything right.
True, it might be asked why an organization with the resources of G.M. felt that it was necessary to create a subsidiary to do everything right. But the question has been asked, and the answer, after a bit of harumphing, seems to be that the sheer size of the corporation, along with its not always excellent tradition, were getting in the way. By starting with a clean sheet of paper, Saturn was able to do exactly what was needed.
The penciling on that clean sheet started in the early 80's with a planned introduction of Saturn's little import-fighter in 1988. As it turned out, the first car didn't roll off of a showroom floor until the 1991 model year, the delay resulting from concerns for quality that frequently staunched the creative juices and even held down production.
Eventually, though, Saturn came to be. And, according to The Power Report, a generally respected publication put out by the consultancy of J.D. Power and Associates of California, Saturn's distribution methods and customer satisfaction triumphs are being analyzed by nearly every manufacturer in the world.
"Dealers of competing makes are looking for ways to 'Saturnize' their operations in hope of improving dealer profits and customer satisfaction," the publication says.
Within General Motors, the troubled Oldsmobile division has been the first to pay serious attention to the way Saturn is doing business, and John Rock, the division's general manager, has said that he is going to turn Olds into the place to which Saturn buyers will graduate.
Those buyers right now have seven possible choices, including the sedans and coupes and -- new for 1993 -- a pair of station wagons.
Like the rest of the line, the wagons have plastic body panels that are hung on a steel "space-frame," a la the late and occasionally lamented Pontiac Fiero. The polymer panels, which resist dings and dents, are said by Saturn spokesmen to be one reason that buyers are so satisfied.
While the sedan and coupe use plastic side panels, the wagon models also incorporate the lightweight material into the roof and the top-hinged tailgate. In the new wagon, the hood is the sole exterior panel that is stamped from steel.
Under that hood, the two standard Saturn powerplants are mounted sideways and drive the front wheels. The wagons are designated simply SW1 and SW2, with the first being logically more basic than the second.
As such, my maroon SW1 carried the low-level 85-horsepower four. The SW2, which uses the same basic 1.9-liter engine, adds considerable oomph, having four valves per cylinder and producing 124 horsepower. And, given the test vehicle's somewhat emphysemic performance, the more powerful version is probably the way to go.
Fuel economy is good with either engine, ranging from 24 miles per gallon, city, to 37, highway, depending on the configuration. Both engines also can be ordered with a five-speed manual transmission or a computer-controlled four-speed automatic, and the maroon wagon had the automatic. It also had Saturn's optional ABS and traction-control system ($645), which is new this year.
New, too, is a revision in the automatic transmission's shift pattern in the computer, reducing back-and-forth shifts between gears when the vehicle is going up a hill.
The "powertrain control module" monitors vehicle speed in relation to accelerator pedal input. And, when speed drops and more throttle is applied, the computer extends the time in gear or keeps the transmission from shifting. That means that the automatic feels much like the manual.
The full-time traction-control, meanwhile, uses the same computer, along with the antilock brake system and engine controls to prevent the drive wheels from slipping. If the system senses that the front wheels are turning faster than those at the rear, it adjusts the amount of power needed for traction.
Inside, the is also something new in the form of a driver's air bag, which is all to the good. The air bag was a surprising omission in earlier models, particularly after the Saturn's long gestation.
What is not all to the good, however, is the fact that the car also has motorized seatbelts, those annoying and dangerous snakes that slither up and over you whenever the ignition is on and a front door is opened or closed.
That said, the test car was nicely done, with a gray interior in cloth and plastic, and comfortable reclining buckets up front. In back, the wagons have a split bench, and while room is not immense, it is reasonable for a small car. With the seatbacks in the up position, cargo space measures 28.8 cubic feet. Folding them flat increases that to 56.3 cubic feet.
Storage includes a small bin between the buckets, and there is a medium-sized glovebox. The console between the seats holds a reasonably good ashtray and buttons for the power windows, the power sideview mirrors and the power window in the tailgate.
On the road, the ride is good, and the car handles well. But the nicest part might be the price.
The SW1 has a base of $10,895, while the SW2 with its bigger engine begins at $12,195. As tested and fully optioned, the maroon wagon had a sticker of $14,275, not bad for a comfortable -- and comforting -- little vehicle. For taming winter, in fact, it's the next best thing to a snowblower.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The plastic-bodied wagon comes in two versions, the basic SW1, below, and the more powerful SW2, at left. (Saturn Corporation)

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
From Seed, the Journey to the Perfect Plant

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
THOSE who grow their own plants from seed find there is something rather special in the doing. Of course, many gardeners would rather wait until late spring and buy the few vegetable or annual seedlings they need. But just as many delight in growing their own plants from seed.
The greatest advantage in growing your own is the selection possibilities. Many times some of the more unusual flowers or vegetables are not available from garden centers. Also, seed sharing is one of the strongest binds in gardening friendships. 
 There is also the economic side. One packet of seed will yield many, many plants whereas buying several six-packs or pots of seedlings can ruin a modest garden budget. Don't forget, come spring there will be many other expenses: tools to buy, mowers to sharpen, fences to fix, fertilizers to add.
Those who do grow their own seedlings enter into a garden adventure that is difficult to equal, particularly when a special plant is known to be difficult. Many a gardener has boasted to a summer visitor that a particular plant was raised "from a pup."
A novice will often make a mistake of timing, that is planting the seed either too late or too soon. Only through trial and error can this lesson be learned.
The object should be to have the seedlings strong and actively growing so that they can settle in quickly when planted outdoors. Their root systems must be sturdy, for strong active roots will be the basis of the plant's quick establishment.
When seed is planted too soon, the result usually is a lanky bunch of seedlings that flop all over the place. The stems are weak and there are few leaves. Some seedlings even perish before they are ready to go outdoors. Tomato seedlings are a prime example of a rush to have the first ones on the block.
By contrast, seed that is slow to germinate needs a head start if the young plants are to be large enough to handle and settle in when planted outdoors. Snapdragons and petunias are examples.
Some seed does not even need to be started indoors but can be planted directly in the garden as soon as the soil is ready. Others need a cold period or stratification. Some will germinate immediately upon sowing, some seed must be covered to germinate. Still other seed is not covered because it must have light to germinate.
The best way to find the proper method for a particular plant is through study of the seed catalogues, the seed packets or garden books. Once the seed is sown, keep the seed pans moist and warm until germination. Then comes the important step of transplanting. When the seedlings have germinated, they will start to grow rather quickly. Their root systems will begin to fan out in the soil and will need room to stretch.
The soil mixture in which the seedlings will be transplanted is vital, for it will be the mixture that will nurture the developing root system and give the seedlings stem support for growing.
There has been much use of peat moss for potting mixtures, but geologists and soil scientists have begun to question whether this is sound judgment since using up the peat moss destroys a natural process of nature that has taken thousands of years to develop.
Far more practical for home gardeners is the use of a commodity from their own yards, a natural peat replacement: compost. When screened and mixed into the potting mixture, it has similar qualities of peat. Compost retains moisture, contains nutrients and provides a loose quality for root vitality.
Coarse sand can also be mixed with the compost, or a lightweight vermiculite can be substituted. This is a spongy product, derived from mica, that absorbs water.
Perlite, another lightweight porous ingredient, is also mixed in with soils. It is the white globular substance often seen in potting mixtures and seed flats because it tends to rise to the surface. Many ingredients for a mix-your-own potting mixture can be found at garden centers along with the bags already mixed.
The old rule about transplanting seedlings when their second set of true leaves appears is still valid. The seedling leaves usually do not look anything like those of the adult plant. As soon as the plant has grown enough to put out a second set, it is ready to be on its own. For this pricking or transplanting process one important reminder: Never handle the seedling by its stem as it may succumb to the heat of the fingers.
On the other hand, a seedling will always have two leaves, and if one leaf is damaged in the process, there will be a second leaf to grow.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Japan Fears the U.S. Is Its Postwar Pal No More

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
ODDLY enough, one reason Japan worries about Bill Clinton is that unlike John F. Kennedy he never captained a boat that was sliced in half by a Japanese warship, and unlike George Bush he was never shot down over the Pacific. In the iconography of American Presidents as seen from Tokyo, the World War II veterans who went on to occupy the Oval Office never bore a grudge. Instead, they were magnanimous victors who, after vanquishing the old Japan, took an almost fatherly pride in its reconstruction. They remembered the occupation, and regarded the Japanese as a bright, industrious ward who grew into America's strongest ally in the Pacific. Most important, they were usually indulgent of the country's mercantilist tendencies, viewing them as a problem that should not be allowed to threaten the relationship.
The new President, as Japanese have reminded themselves time and again, grew up with a very different Japan. He was a boy in Arkansas when Akio Morita began putting Sony radios into American homes. By the time Mr. Clinton reached law school, Nissans and Toyotas were beginning to jam the streets. As a governor, he frequently took the red-eye to Tokyo in search of Japanese investments and factories for his state. His Japan is first and foremost an economic competitor, hardly in need of America's help. 
 "In the eyes of many Japanese, it seems like a very big generational leap," said Yukio Satoh, who heads North American affairs for Japan's Foreign Ministry. Another senior Government official was more blunt, suggesting that for people of Mr. Clinton's generation, Japan was no longer a "special country."
That alone may explain why, even before Mr. Clinton has said much about trade and economic policy, the Japanese are rushing to redefine their relationship with the United States. They think they have to move fast.
The problem is that visions of what the relationship should look like -- especially in the sudden absence of a common enemy lurking out of Vladivostok -- are being churned out faster than Hondas, and in as many models.
Everyone wants America to remember that, as Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe said in an interview last week, "trade is not the only relationship we have." But on Thursday, no sooner had Mr. Watanabe settled into a chair in the Oval Office than Mr. Clinton started a pointed discussion about cutting Japan's newly ballooning trade surplus with the United States and said removing more trade barriers is to be the first order of business. "That is my job," Mr. Clinton said. Not exactly the warm words about unshakable alliances that Japan had in mind for the first meeting.
Like England, Japan has always spoken enthusiastically about its "special relationship" with the United States. But it is one that was forged first by the occupation and later by mutual economic dependence, rather than by shared culture or even much of a deeply felt meeting of minds. In fact, the United States first promoted Japan's industrial accomplishments largely to channel its energies into something other than militarism. And Japan's role as a vital military base meant security always took precedence over the economic costs.
 
Reversing Priorities
 That began to erode in the late 1980's, during disputes like the one over Congress' attempt to restrict the transfer of aviation technology to Japan. With a President in office who now talks about seven strategic technologies America must preserve, Tokyo is bracing for more of that. While Mr. Clinton seems unlikely to tinker much with the American troop presence here, especially now that Japanese contributions make it cheaper to station soldiers here than at home, there is little question the old priorities are being reversed.
That leaves Japan with some tough choices: Whether to veer harder toward Asia -- a trend that has to some extent begun already with new overtures to China, Vietnam and the rest of Southeast Asia -- and whether to try to mollify or modify its old mentor. In recent months, Japanese officials have been trying them all out, tentatively sketching three different faces of their country:
The Thin-Skinned Retaliator In public, few politicians or diplomats will admit to advocating a don't-push-me policy with the new Administration. But privately, some senior officials say Japan is frustrated that it has grown big but earned insufficient respect. This is the Japan that wants to remind Mr. Clinton of his campaign observation that three-quarters of America's competitive problems must be fixed at home. At their most extreme, such views seem nationalistic. But in the mainstream, they are reflected in recommendations, like one from Japan's biggest business group in December, that Japan prepare to retaliate if the United States unilaterally moves to restrict imports. This is also the Japan that warns America not to be intoxicated by its military power. In an essay this month, Hisashi Owada, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs (and father of Japan's soon-to-be princess) noted Japan's $13 billion contribution during the Gulf crisis and said "it is perfectly clear that the United States could not have fought the gulf war without assistance of this kind."
The Reluctant Superpower This is the Japan that finally lives up to its talk of being America's equal partner, even though its citizenry seems allergic to taking action that might single Japan out. Advocates of this approach say the first examples have come in places like Cambodia, where Japan has sponsored peace talks and has sent troops to rebuild roads but not disarm factions. The problem is that eventually this Japan has to decide whether to be a regular superpower, with a larger military, or continue what Mr. Owada termed "an extremely unnatural existence," that would have to be balanced by extraordinary contributions to the world in non-military fields.
The Reformer This is the Japan that no longer waits for American pressure before opening its markets, building better housing, taking more vacations and turning into what Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa calls a "lifestyle superpower." All this, of course, also increases imports. Few doubt the benefits of putting an end to the cycle of American demands, Japanese refusals and then grudging change that has embittered all sides. But the timing for reform is poor. The ruling Liberal Democratic Party, scandal-ridden and divided, seems more terrified than ever of taking the initiative. The business community, after drinking more than its share during a terrific party in the 1980's, will take the better part of the 90's just getting the poisons out of its system.
This is not to say that Japan will not change in response to the challenges of a new team in Washington; after all, an American named Akebono just became the first foreigner ever to be named a sumo grand champion. But it took 2,000 years.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S RANGE;
Doing More Than Bush, Less Than Advertised

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TRACKING President Clinton's latest pronouncements on Bosnia, the economy and domestic policy, it is possible to divine the parameters within which he seems to be operating early in his term. You can tune the Clinton Administration in on your political dial somewhere between the prudence of George Bush and the boldness of Mr. Clinton's own campaign book, "Putting People First." The sound you will hear is something more than Muzak but less than John Philip Sousa.
And don't go fiddling with the volume control; it's set that way for a reason. "Because Clinton was not elected by a majority he needs to be cautious, and because he needs to be re-elected by a majority he needs to be bold," said Kathleen H. Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania. "And that is his dilemma." 
 The balancing act was apparent last week in both foreign and domestic policy. Consider the moment when Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher announced the Administration's new policy on Bosnia. "Serbian ethnic cleansing has been pursued through mass murders, systematic beatings, and the rapes of Muslims," he said. "Our conscience revolts at the idea of passively accepting such brutality." But after this lion-like roar, the policy he then articulated was more befitting a cub: an initiative aimed at demonstrating that Mr. Clinton was doing something more than Mr. Bush -- not just dumping the whole thing in Europe's lap -- but not so much as to entangle G.I.'s in an ethnic quagmire.
Washington would name a special envoy, Reginald Bartholomew, to take part in the negotiations between the warring factions and the international mediators Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen. But Mr. Bartholomew "will not necessarily be at the table," said Mr. Christopher. No American weapons would be offered to Bosnia's Muslims, but Washington would try to team up with Moscow to use leverage to gain Serb concessions. America would contribute to a peacekeeping operation, but only after a settlement.
This approach might be called high-octane Bush, or prudence plus. Sometimes such a calibrated approach is exactly what is called for in diplomacy, and only the next few months will make clear whether it fits the realities in Bosnia. It certainly fits the mood at home, though. Yes, the public says, it is shameful that at the twilight of the 20th century such barbarism still stalks Europe, but if that problem were addressed with all the boldness Mr. Clinton promised during the election campaign, the price could be prohibitive.
On the domestic front a similar balancing act is going on. The President is preparing to send Congress on Wednesday a package of short-term spending programs to stimulate growth, long-term programs to restructure the economy, and new taxes and spending cuts to reduce the deficit. On paper, it will be nothing if not bold. Whether that boldness survives into the final legislation, however, will depend on the interaction of three moods: the country's, the President's, and that of Congress.
Mr. Clinton's economic advisers remain convinced he won the election because most Americans believed that they were not living as well as their parents, and that people are ready to sacrifice for a turnaround, provided the plan is serious and fair. The problem, though, is that in the campaign Mr. Clinton addressed that anxiety with a plan that was serious and disingenuous -- based on a pretense that it could be carried off without pain to the vast middle class.
 
Promises to Keep
 At last week's town hall meeting in Detroit a woman asked Mr. Clinton if he would break his promise not to sock it to the middle class. His answer: "I have said that before I ask the middle class to pay, I am going to ask the wealthiest Americans and companies to pay their fair share and I am going to cut more Government spending. But I cannot tell you that I won't ask you to make any contribution to the changes we have to make." The real question is: What will that woman, and people like her, feel after reading Mr. Clinton's whole plan? Obviously, some people will be unhappy. So how will Mr. Clinton respond when the screaming starts?
Some officials worry aloud that Mr. Clinton is not mean enough -- that members of Congress already do not fear him, and that he does not evince that L.B.J. spirit: "Cross me and you die." But others say such an approach is unrealistic. Of the Democrats in Congress, fewer than 30 percent have worked with a Democratic President. They are not used to following the leader; they have been suckled on adversarial politics in Republican Administrations.
Therefore, Mr. Clinton's strategy will be to persuade them that he will go out and sell those cuts personally to help create a political shield for some very tough votes, and that he will make the Democratic Congress part of the process of shaping his legislative package. He has already given lawmakers a chance to shoot some things down in advance so they will feel part of the process.
How much boldness will survive such a political skeet shoot? "We can't accommodate everybody's concerns, but maybe we can do 80 percent," said one Clinton aide. "If our supporters in Congress at least feel they were part of that 80 percent it is a lot more likely they will vote with us. You just can't send messages down from the mountaintop anymore. Clinton himself went up to Capitol Hill twice last week, and his wife, too. It's a different era."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Housing And Fear Upend Integration

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
LIKE a family secret that will not stay hidden, the reality of school segregation keeps forcing itself into the light, exposing the unresolved and politically explosive issues of race, class and poverty in American life.
Two current cases raise difficult questions in the long battle to integrate schools. In a civil trial under way in Hartford, Conn., the plaintiffs are arguing that linking city and suburban schools is the only way to produce true economic and racial integration. In Richmond, Va., a judge recently delayed an order to end the practice of "clustering" white students in a few classes at a mostly black school. 
 The cases touch upon desegregation's thorniest issues -- the huge gaps in spending between rich and poor school districts, the connection between segregated housing and segregated schools, the consequences of suburbanization and a backlash against integration by some blacks as well as whites.
These are questions, for the most part, that the Supreme Court has left to lower courts to decide. As a result, the hardest-fought, highest-stakes battles these days are mostly in state courts like Hartford's or Richmond's, over issues that are less blatant than the early fights against racial segregation enshrined in law.
The new cases, over segregation by housing and class, question a fundamental premise -- whether families have the right to leave behind urban problems, schools they consider unsafe, and in many cases, integration, by moving to the suburbs and, in effect, buying better public education.
"I am more convinced than ever that if we're talking about providing really equal educational opportunity, then we have to confront the issue of racial and economic isolation," said William L. Taylor, a veteran school desegregation lawyer.
Both in Hartford and Richmond, courts confronted urban schools that were segregated largely because better-off whites had moved to the suburbs where their property taxes were directly apportioned for schools. In these cases and others around the country, desegregation advocates have pushed to link city and suburban schools, forcing integration and closing huge gaps in spending.
In Richmond, the United States Supreme Court decided in 1973 not to merge the city's school districts with those of two surrounding counties, leaving the schools largely black. As an incentive to keep the remaining white families, two schools put all the white children in a few classrooms, as if to create a "comfort zone" for them, leaving other classrooms all-black. Mr. Taylor believes that the solution was illegal and morally wrong because it resegregates children within schools. When the school board ordered the children to be reassigned, some white parents went to court to block the action.
 
The South's Progress
 But Gary Orfield, a desegregation expert and professor at Harvard University, said that, paradoxically, the grouping of white children could be more likely to promote real integration than the school board's plan to scatter isolated students across overwhelmingly black classrooms. "What you're really looking for is not a school with a few visitors sprinkled around," he said. "You're looking for each group to make some contribution, to be taken seriously."
These dilemmas are nationwide. In a desegregation study published last year, Professor Orfield found that southern schools were far more integrated than those in the
North and West, where segregated schools were actually on the rise. Professor Orfield also found that even when minority parents moved to suburbs, their children's schools remained segregated because segregated housing patterns persisted.
The fuss in Richmond, and on a much larger scale over the past 20 years in cities from Boston to Oklahoma City, also illustrates the political complexities of hammering out a desegregation plan acceptable to parents of all races. Over the last dozen years courts have moved away from ordering busing, aiming instead for a mix of certain required desegregation goals and incentives like specialized magnet schools.
 
The St. Louis Plan
 One possible model for Hartford, where the trial began on Dec. 16, is St. Louis. A settlement there gave inner-city children the right to attend suburban schools, and, since the mid-1980's, about one-third of those eligible, some 14,000 children, have ventured into suburbia, according to Mr. Taylor, who argued the case. Because white parents did not have to bus their children into the inner city, the plan won acceptance. But it also raises certain troubling questions, according to Amy Stuart Wells of the University of California at Los Angeles, who is writing a book about the case.
Black parents had to choose to send their children into a largely alien world, and Professor Wells found that the ones most likely to choose were better-educated, more aggressive, more self-confident families, leaving children of some of the most troubled families behind in the worst schools.
"There are a lot of trade-offs," Professor Orfield said. "If you want to minimize political conflict, the more choice you give, the happier middle-class families are. If you want to make the most desegregation possible, you need a much more coercive mandate, but then there is more initial student flight."
In the Hartford case, lawyers who are suing the state want to assemble a team of experts to determine which plans have worked best. Despite years of negative publicity about busing, desegregation has worked well in dozens of small and middle-sized cities, J.S. Fuerst and Roy Petty argue in a study published last year in The American Prospect.
One answer, said Ronald L. Ellis of the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, a lawyer in the Hartford case, is to make sure that all schools are good ones. "If you have uniformity of excellence," he said, "you won't have people leaving."
The open questions are whether such excellence is inseparable from integration -- and whether the ultimate goal is desegregation. Because blacks in many cities have borne most of the burden of busing, and because when all-black schools were closed, many black principals and teachers were reassigned and lost their status, some black parents now argue that they would rather have all-black schools that they can oversee than have a chance to participate in integration. Several recent Supreme Court cases have raised the question, too, of just how extensive desegregation remedies should be.
In Oklahoma City and DeKalb County, Ga., the Supreme Court has left these questions to lower courts. Having resigned themselves to Supreme Court inaction, many desegregation advocates are looking to President Clinton. Professor Orfield hopes that the Federal Government will give desegregation efforts a huge boost simply by ending 12 years of siding largely with those who would halt further desegregation and by spreading the word when integration works.
But President Clinton also faces the risk that shining the light on these murky and passionate issues could provoke a backlash from the very group he courted during the election -- the middle-class suburbanites who have long voted Republican and whose interests are at stake in cases like Hartford's.

HEADLINE: CLINTON PROPOSES ALTERING MEDICARE TO SAVE $35 BILLION

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton will seek at least $35 billion in savings from Medicare over the next four years by limiting payments to doctors and hospitals and by trying to increase premiums for elderly people with high incomes, Administration officials said today.
The proposed savings, three times what President George Bush sought unsuccessfully in 1992, are part of what Mr. Clinton describes as a bold program to reduce the deficit and its long-term burden on the American economy. He will announce the outlines of that program in a speech to Congress on Wednesday, but the details may still be modified. 
 Taken together, the proposed tax increases and budget cuts in various Federal programs will save $500 billion to $550 billion over five years, Administration officials said. The last such exercise in austerity, the 1990 budget deal, was expected to save $496 billion over five years.
 
No Expansion in Benefits
 The savings in the Medicare program, which finances health care for 35 million elderly and disabled people, would, at first, be used mainly to reduce the budget deficit rather than to expand health benefits for those without insurance, Administration officials said. Proposals for expanding coverage will be made as part of the President's national health-care plan, which he has promised to send Congress by May 1.
Administration officials say that Medicare and Medicaid, the health program for low-income people, must be part of any deficit-reduction plan because they account for nearly half of the projected increase in Federal spending over the next five years. The Government expects to spend $146 billion on Medicare this year and $80 billion on Medicaid, which are two of the biggest and fastest-growing programs in the budget.
 
Doubling Spending
 In the 1980's, Congress set standard Medicare rates for hospitals, and it established a national fee schedule for doctors, starting in 1992. But it did not stem the growth of Federal spending on health care. And without any change in current law or policy, the Congressional Budget Office estimates, spending for Medicare will double over the next several years, from $129 billion in 1992 to $259 billion in 1998. Under the Clinton proposals, outlays for the program would still increase, but at a slower rate than otherwise.
Another proposal being considered by the Administration would prevent doctors and hospitals from increasing charges to private patients to make up for income lost as a result of the new Medicare limits, officials said.
If Mr. Clinton seeks Medicare savings of the magnitude now envisioned by the White House, he will most likely face opposition from a small army of lobbyists for doctors, hospitals and the health-care industry. The President seems prepared for such a confrontation and may welcome it for political reasons. In separate appearances this week, he and his wife, Hillary, assailed the drug industry, complaining that companies had made excessive profits from the production of vaccine for children.
 
Asking for Sacrifices
 Mr. Clinton has been laying the groundwork for his economic program by declaring that Americans need to make sacrifices for the common good. He will ask farmers, veterans, college students, middle-income families and corporations to share the sacrifice by paying higher taxes or giving up some of the Government largess they receive.
Mr. Clinton will unveil his economic plan and some of his deficit-reduction proposals when he addresses a joint session of Congress on Wednesday. He will provide more details of his budget proposals in late March. The proposed tax increases are the biggest sought by a President in decades.
The likely Medicare proposals include spending limits on doctors and hospitals, an increase in premiums charged to higher-income elderly people and restrictions on doctors' ability to raise charges to private patients to compensate for a reduction or freeze in payments under Medicare.
In addition, Federal health officials said they wanted to prevent doctors and hospitals from raising their charges in expectation of cost controls to be imposed as part of Mr. Clinton's national health-care plan. It was not clear how the Government could control what doctors charge their private patients.
Representative Pete Stark, chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said he saw "no problem" with judiciously limiting Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals.
Doctors have average income of more than $160,000 a year, he said, and some underused hospitals should be closed. But Mr. Stark, a California Democrat, said the savings from such cutbacks should be used to expand Medicare benefits, not just to reduce the budget deficit.
 
Limiting Reform?
 When Mr. Clinton discussed his plans to control health costs as a Presidential candidate in September, he said, "We will dedicate Federal savings from cost controls to expanding coverage to all." But there is no evidence that the initial savings from his proposals next week will be used for any purpose other than to reduce the deficit, which he says is bigger than he realized.
Martin A. Corry, director of Federal affairs at the American Association of Retired Persons, voiced concern about the change in emphasis. "The Administration will narrow its options for health-care reform if it uses all the Medicare savings for deficit reduction," he said.
Federal officials refused to say exactly how Medicare premiums might be raised for affluent elderly people, or what income levels would be affected. Lawmakers will undoubtedly be cautious in view of their experience with a law to provide insurance against catastrophic illnesses in 1988. After Congress imposed extra premiums and a surtax to pay for that program, elderly people rebelled, forcing Congress to repeal it a year later.
Mr. Clinton has conceded that he probably cannot fulfill his campaign promise to cut the deficit in half within four years. But he says he wants to shave $145 billion from the expected 1997 deficit. With no change in current law or policy, the Congressional Budget Office estimates, the 1997 deficit will be $319 billion.
 
Congressional Efforts
 In January 1992, Mr. Bush asked for Medicare changes intended to save $10 billion over four years, but Congress rejected most of them. Aides to Mr. Clinton say he has a better chance of winning Congressional approval because his party has a majority in Congress and he is offering a balanced package of spending changes and tax increases.
In its own efforts to slow the growth of Medicare, Congress ordered that hospitals be paid a flat amount, set in advance, for each patient, starting in late 1983, and it established a national fee schedule for doctors, starting in 1992.
Nevertheless, with rising medical prices, a growing elderly population and the proliferation of potentially useful medical technology, Medicare continues to grow.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that spending for Medicare will double, from $129 billion in 1992 to $259 billion in 1998. It estimates that Federal spending for Medicaid will soar to $146 billion in 1998, from $68 billion last year. Together the two health programs account for 46 percent of the projected increase in Federal spending from 1992 to 1998.
In the last fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, the deficit was $290.2 billion, a record. Some Democrats say they believe that a failure to reduce the deficit this year will substantially increase pressure for a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget.
 
Using Different Statistics
 In their battles with Republican Administrations over the deficits, Congressional Democrats repeatedly accused President Ronald Reagan and Mr. Bush of basing their budgets on unrealistic economic assumptions, which overstated economic growth. This, in turn, often led the Republicans to overestimate Federal revenues and to underestimate Federal spending and deficits. Like their predecessors, Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush obtained their economic forecasts from three agencies: the Council of Economic Advisers, the Treasury and the Office of Management and Budget.
In contrast, President Clinton and his budget director, Leon E. Panetta, intend to use the economic assumptions of the Congressional Budget Office, which forecasts economic growth at an annual rate of 2.8 percent this year and 3 percent in 1994. The outlook of the Congressional Budget Office is slightly more pessimistic than the forecast of many leading private economists.
By adopting the economic forecast of the Congressional Budget Office, Mr. Clinton wants to show that he is serious about reducing the deficit and has no desire to use gimmicks to minimize the problem, White House officials said.
Cabinet officers customarily ask for bigger budgets than the White House allows. Budget officials said that Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, had unsuccessfully tried to persuade Mr. Clinton to forgo a few of the cutbacks being proposed in Medicare.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Hope: Hostility;
Oddly Enough, if Everybody Finds a Fault In the Deficit Plan, the Better Its Chances

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
When President Clinton drops his economic plan on Congress and the American public next week, the first sounds you hear will be the potshots.
The hostile fire will come from every which way -- industries that would have their taxes increased, people who would lose Government benefits, communities where military bases would be jeopardized, conservatives who want lower taxes and less Government spending, and liberals who want higher taxes so spending can be increased. Cutting the budget deficit is so difficult that almost everyone will have a beef. 
 But the overwhelmingly negative instant reaction should not be taken as evidence that the plan will fail. Just the opposite, in fact. It is another example of the ways of Washington, and it may be a healthy sign for the program.
 
Formula for Success
 In an odd way, the greater the pain and the more widely it is spread, the better Mr. Clinton's chances of success. Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has told the White House that it is politically crucial to create such a large universe of sacrifice that it is difficult for people to say they should be outside it.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, has repeatedly cautioned his troops to reserve judgment, to avoid being swayed by the early opposition, to study Mr. Clinton's entire package carefully before taking a stand.
"People who are offended by some particular thing are likely to communicate," Mr. Gephardt said in an interview. "The people who generally think it's a good idea will be quiet at first."
 
All Ideas Under Attack
 Ted Van Dyk, a Democratic strategist, said he would be more concerned if the opposition was muted. "The far greater peril," he said, "would be to have a program at which potshots weren't taken. That would mean it wasn't bold enough. It wouldn't work. Congress and the public would lose their respect for the President, and his Presidency could unravel."
The early indications are that Mr. Van Dyk has little to worry about. Almost every idea that has been floated in the last couple of weeks, even those that stood no chance of making the final cut, has been sharply attacked. That is one reason the White House is keeping its final decisions so private as it puts the finishing touches on the plan.
Long after top Administration officials had said that Mr. Clinton would not propose a gasoline tax, the American Trucking Associations and several other organizations held a joint news conference this week to denounce such a tax.
After a long opening statement in which he maintained that a gasoline tax would bring the world as we know it to an end, Thomas J. Donahue, the president of the trucking associations, opened the session to questions.
 
The first Question
 This was the first question: "Isn't this press conference a perfect example of why it is nearly impossible for any President to propose anything for reduction of the deficit? How would you cut the deficit?"
This was the guts of Mr. Donahue's answer: "We all stand ready to participate in the solution of the deficit. We all call first for some reasonable reductions in spending that has exploded across this country, and we would all have our own views on how to fairly and broadly increase taxes in a way that would not call on one group of users, highway users, to pay for everybody else's deficit.
"The Constitution encourages and guarantees in this country the right to petition the Government, and we are taking advantage of that opportunity on behalf of tens of millions of Americans, real Americans, that get up every day and go to work and are creating the jobs and earning the payroll checks in this country. And, quite frankly, the suggestion for the purposes of politics that people that would take issue with the Government's decisions on how to tax us are not real Americans makes me mad."
Russell B. Long, the former Senator from Louisiana, used to characterize that kind of lobbying with a ditty:
 
 Don't tax you.
 Don't tax me.
 Tax the fellow
 Behind the tree.
 On another matter, word had no sooner got out that Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, was advocating a freeze in cost-of-living increases in Social Security payments than Congressional offices were besieged with telephone calls from retirees. And several leading Democratic Senators threatened to hold their breath until they turned blue.
Mr. Clinton almost certainly never looked favorably on the idea of a freeze, and a few days after the news broke the White House said so publicly.
Protests then arose over suggestions that the space station and the superconducting supercollider might be cut back or even killed, that money for reserve and National Guard units might be trimmed and that corporate tax deductions might be abolished for "excessive" salaries paid to executives.
After Mr. Clinton told about 200 business executives and their Washington lobbyists at the White House on Thursday that he planned to propose an increase in the corporate tax rate, the adverse reaction was instantaneous. The Tax Reform Action Coalition, a lobbying group whose hundreds of members range from Procter & Gamble and International Business Machines to the Beauty and Barber Supply Institute and Elmer Buchta Trucking Inc., fired off a letter of opposition to the President.
Alan Kranowitz, a White House lobbyist in the Reagan Administration who now works for the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, said, "We will definitely shoot as hard as we can at the tax rate increases."
 
Changes in Pressures
 Junior lawmakers may be swayed by this kind of pressure, but more experienced ones have become inured to it, recognizing that it does not represent the full views of their constituents.
Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, one of the most influential liberal Democrats in Congress, said the nature of lobbying and constituent pressure had changed since he took office 24 years ago.
"You can see it in the mail," he said. "When I came here, most of my mail was from individuals back home who cared about their individual problems. Today, a huge amount of the mail comes from the fact that you have all kinds of associations, councils, organizations, etc., who will send information bulletins to their membership crying with alarm, ringing the bells from the rooftops, saying please descend on Washington and protect your interests or you'll never see Day 3."

HEADLINE: Vaccinations Are Often Free, But Many Children Miss Out

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
Long after the hour of her scheduled appointment had passed, Michele Bryant sat with her 2-year-old son in the waiting room of the New York City Department of Health clinic in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. She had little choice but to wait it out in the dreary room on a snowy Saturday: As a single mother with a full-time job that offered no health benefits, she had neither the time nor the money to go to a private pediatrician to get her son vaccinated.
"I got up this morning at 6:30 to bring him here," Ms. Bryant said, as her son, Taurean, scurried along the rows of plastic seats, restless after two and a half hours in the clinic. "This is what you have to do. If you love your child, you want them to have the best care you can get."
 
Struggling With Bureaucracy
 Vaccines are free and readily available in public health clinics in New York and many other states. 
 But for every parent like Ms. Bryant, who tries to have her child vaccinated, thousands of others do not try at all or give up after struggling with the public-health bureaucracy. Some, facing a multitude of economic and family pressures, do not think it is worth the trouble. Some are not aware of the importance of vaccinations. And some, in this country illegally, are afraid to bring their children for shots.
To encourage immunization by making it more affordable, President Clinton announced on Friday a plan to spend $300 million next year to increase the number of American children who are vaccinated. White House officials said that as a result, a million more youngsters would be immunized starting this summer, most at public clinics.
The President strongly criticized drug manufacturers for failing to lower their prices on vaccines and for what he called spending on advertising and lobbying at the expense of developing new and better drugs.
Administration officials said they were still considering a plan for the Government to buy the entire supply of children's vaccines and distribute them free. Drug manufacturers dispute President Clinton's assertion that they are to blame for the rising costs of immunization, and argue that they offer substantial discounts on vaccines sold to government programs. The real problem, they say, lies in educating the public about how and where vaccines are available.
Many doctors and health-care experts say free vaccine will not solve the country's immunization problem. They say the lack of a centralized record-keeping system and a concerted educational campaign is partly to blame for the low immunization rate. Those functions are left up to a patchwork of clinics, doctors, hospital emergency rooms and charities. In some cases, record keeping is so abysmal that some children never get vaccinated and others receive the same vaccines over and over.
 
From Pioneer to Laggard
 The failure to vaccinate is so widespread in this country that many health officials speak of an "immunization crisis" in a nation that pioneered the use of vaccines to fight childhood diseases. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, less than half of all children in the country between 2 months and 2 years old are properly vaccinated. In the inner cities and rural areas, proportions are even smaller. In New York City, the Department of Health reports that only 38 percent of schoolchildren have completed the full series of recommended vaccines by the time they are 2, the benchmark age for immunization because the natural immunity a baby receives from his or her mother has dissipated.
According to the American Academy of Pediatrics, the United States ranks 17th in the world in the percentage of infants vaccinated against polio. Health experts say immunization rates are higher in industrialized countries with a nationalized system for primary health care, like Britain.
"This is one of the true national disgraces we're dealing with," said Dr. Irwin Redlener, president of the Children's Health Fund, a nonprofit group that offers health care to children at New York City homeless shelters. "Immunization is a fundamental marker of access to health care for children. The lack of it puts kids at a fantastic level of vulnerability."
Dr. Bruce Siegel, the New Jersey health commissioner-designate, said: "Immunization is one of the areas where we are seeing a step backward 50 years. Children should not be dying of measles in this day and age."
In responding to President Clinton's criticism of drug manufacturers, David J. Williams, president of Connaught Laboratories Inc. of Swiftwater, Pa., blamed lawsuits for driving up vaccine prices.
"The only profiteers in vaccine pricing have been the lawyers who launched hundreds of product liability lawsuits," Mr. Williams said. "If we were to distribute vaccine free to everyone, whether rich or poor, it would drive up the cost of immunization to the Federal Government. It doesn't make any sense to increase spending on buying a product that is in abundant supply when the money could be better used in eliminating the barriers that obstruct access."
 
The Connecticut Experience
 Although Connecticut has a longstanding program to buy and distribute vaccine to doctors and clinics. Dr. James Hadler, the state epidemiologist, said that only 63 percent of Connecticut children receive the full complement of vaccines by age 2 -- only marginally more than in New York and New Jersey, which do not provide all the vaccines doctors need.
"Universal distribution is just a component of what needs to be done," Dr. Hadler said.
Besides Connecticut, 12 states -- Alabama, Colorado, Idaho, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, North Dakota, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Vermont, Washington and Wyoming -- buy vaccine and distribute it free to doctors and clinics. The doctors are allowed to charge a nominal fee, usually $5 to $10, to administer the drugs. Since 1920, Massachusetts has manufactured its own diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis, or whooping cough, vaccine, but most other states buy their vaccines.
Thirty years ago, when the measles vaccine was licensed, health officials predicted that the childhood disease would be eradicated within a few years. But after years of decline, measles made a comeback from 1989 to 1991, with 4,000 cases and 23 deaths in New York State alone. State epidemiologists found that more than half the cases were among preschool children, most of whom had never received the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine, known as M.M.R.
At the height of the outbreak, health officials gave the M.M.R. vaccine to 6-month-old children, even though it is normally administered to 1-year-olds. When outbreaks subsided, administration at age 1 was resumed. Although few comprehensive statistics on underimmunization are kept, medical experts are convinced it remains so widespread among preschool children that there will be future outbreaks. "Where parents are not having their children immunized, diseases we thought we had under control are going to be popping up all over the country," said Dr. John Lee Clowe, president of the American Medical Association.
Health organizations say that to be properly immunized, all 2-year-olds should have had four shots of diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis, or whooping cough; three of polio and one of M.M.R. In recent years, two new vaccines, for hepatitis B and Haemophilus influenza type B, have been added to the recommended program.
Because most public and private schools require that children are completely immunized before they enter kindergarten, doctors say that many parents do not realize how critical it is for them to receive all the shots by the time they are 2 years old.
Conversely, doctors and health officials report, a much smaller proportion of children receive too many vaccines. Parents are issued immunization cards to keep track of their children's vaccinations. But Dr. Redlener said that because there is no national registry, children whose cards have been lost or misplaced get the same shots over and over as they move from doctor's office to clinic to emergency room.
For parents like Ms. Bryant, the problem is one of access as much as economics. Commuting two hours each way to a receptionist's job in White Plains from her home in East Flatbush, she has little time during the week to respond to a medical crisis, let alone to visit a doctor for preventive care. She is torn between her need to earn a living and her desire to care for Taurean. "My younger sister takes care of him while I'm at work," said the 20-year-old Ms. Bryant. "But I want to be the one to take him to the doctor. He's going to hurt and cry."
Several months ago, she had an appointment for her son at a city health clinic in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and took a day off from work to keep it. But when she showed up late, she was told she had to reschedule. It was not until she learned of the child health-care clinic in Fort Greene, which recently expanded its hours on Thursday nights and Saturdays, that Taurean was immunized. He was already six months behind. Before his visit, he had never been inoculated against polio and diphtheria.
 
Feeling of Failure
 Health officials say that with costs rising and most insurers refusing to cover vaccinations, more and more middle-class families are going to public clinics for immunization -- or are not having vaccinations at all. Still, the problem is most acute for lower-income and minority parents.
Dana Fort, a 25-year-old single mother, lives with her five young children in a homeless shelter in the Bronx. Some of them are fully immunized, she said, while others are missing several shots. Her youngest child, she said, did not get any vaccinations until he was 9 months old. She said that her frustration over what she believed was her inability to get adequate treatment for herself and her children at local hospitals and clinics sometimes made her reluctant to take her children to doctors.
"It hurts me," she said. "I have cried lots of times because I feel like I've failed my children."
To reach people like Ms. Fort, hospitals and community organizations in inner cities have been trying new ways of coaxing people into clinics and mobile immunization units. Three months ago, Bellevue Hospital Center started a program in which two nurses screen children in the pediatrics emergency room to determine if any vaccinations are needed; of 450 children who have been screened, 72 were immunized. In Jersey City, the State Department of Health set up a satellite clinic in March 1991 next to a local welfare office to find children who did not have all their shots. Since then, 7,000 children have been vaccinated.
But the obstacles to immunization remain daunting. At the Richard Allen Center on Life, a nonprofit child- and foster-care organization in Harlem, immunization outreach workers Danilda Abreu and Pamela Jones say that they would like to go door to door to find the underimmunized, but that they are afraid to enter many of the buildings. Instead, they go to trade schools and churches and community groups, handing out fliers and singing the praises of diphtheria shots.
"A lot of people say to me, it's the wait," Ms. Jones said. "A lot of people don't want to wait. I say, it's better to take one day out for your child than not to have that child at all."

HEADLINE: North Korea Spurns Nuclear Agency Demand

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 14

 BODY:
North Korea, in a growing challenge to the International Atomic Energy Agency, said late on Saturday that it would reject a demand to inspect two sites believed linked to its suspected nuclear weapons project. If the effort is pressed, it warned, it will take a "countermeasure for self-defense."
In a defiantly worded dispatch issued by the Korean Central News Agency, the Communist regime of President Kim Il Sung accused the United States of "trying to attain its sinister purpose" by manipulating the Atomic Energy Agency, a United Nations affiliate, to spy on "military objects" that are not part of what it insists is a civilian nuclear power project. 
 The installations that the agency demanded to see in a cablegram to the North Korean leadership on Thursday "are not liable to inspection by the I.A.E.A.," the press agency account said.
On Thursday, the Atomic Energy Agency's director general, Hans Blix, demanded that inspectors be given access to two buildings at Yongbyon under a procedure called a "special inspection." The agency has never before used a special inspection to compel the opening of a site that a country has not declared part of its nuclear programs.
Unless North Korea reverses itself, the rejection of the demand appears to set the stage for a confrontation that could soon be referred to the United Nations Security Council. If asked by the agency, the Council has the right to enforce a special inspection, though it is unclear that economic embargoes or other techniques to isolate the country would be effective against a country already as isolated as North Korea.
Last week, agency officials said that if their demand for a special inspection was rejected or simply ignored, Mr. Blix would most likely call an emergency meeting this week of the agency's board of governors in Vienna to determine the next step. Determining whether North Korea is on the verge of becoming a nuclear power is considered a critical test of the agency's competence, especially because of criticism that its inspectors failed to detect Iraq's nuclear weapons program in the years leading up to the Persian Gulf war.
North Korea has permitted six inspections of its installations at Yongbyon, 60 miles north of the capital, Pyongyang, since Mr. Blix visited North Korea last May. But it has consistently rejected requests to see two buildings that the agency, based on Western intelligence reports, believe have been used as a dump for nuclear wastes. Samples of those wastes, they believe, could indicate whether North Korea has extracted enough plutonium from its nuclear reactors to produce crude atomic weapons.
In its rejection of the special inspection today, the North Korean Government said: "The allegation that we have 'suspicious facilities' related to the nuclear problem is a sheer lie. We have no other nuclear facilities than those we have reported to the International Atomic Energy Agency," it said.
The report added, "If we accepted inspection of 'suspicious objects' as demanded by the United States, it would be the beginning of the exposure of all our military objects and bases and would become a precedent of permission for the opening of military bases of all nonnuclear states."
It also said that the agency had "no right to use 'information' offered by a third country" to call for a special inspection. Agency officials said last week, when North Korea made the same charge, that under the guidelines approved by member nations of the agency it had the right to use any intelligence that it viewed as reliable.
In fact, nuclear experts say, they are uncertain what, if anything, they will find if inspectors are ever permitted into the buildings. There have been enough delays since the first requests to open the sites in November for North Korea to move the waste elsewhere.
Because many of the buildings in the Yongbyon area are reportedly connected by a vast array of underground tunnels, such an effort might not be detected by satellites or by high-flying reconnaissance aircraft.
