LENGTH: 1215 words

HEADLINE: Making a Go of It the Old-Fashioned Way, Through Bartering

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
AMONG the things Finn Dankilde, owner of the Pampered Pet, in Fishkill, has acquired during the last three years are a second-hand Audi for his daughter at college, the services of an accountant for his business and his personal tax returns, dental care for all four members of his family, tickets to the Virginia Slims tennis finals at Madison Square Garden and meals at good Manhattan restaurants for his wife and himself.
Yet no money changed hands in any of the transactions. Instead, Mr. Dankilde paid for everything with credit, the "trade dollars" he gets from barter exchange. Mr. Dankilde is a member of the International Trade Exchange, a publicly held barter company with 74 offices and 16,000 members nationwide, known as ITEX.
 
Increased Purchasing Power
 "In terms of volume of business, Westchester is in the top seven nationally," said Bruce Kamm, the head of the New York/Westchester office of ITEX. Mr. Kamm recently completed plans to build a Westchester office in Bedford, not for cash but by bartering for building materials and the services of architects and contractors. 
 A former computer executive who developed on-line services for various companies, Mr. Kamm became a member of ITEX with the intent of bartering his services.
"The system worked so well for me -- among other things, I got a car -- that I decided to leave the computer business, which was overcrowded, and become an ITEX barter broker," he said. "My rationale was that with the recession, a lot of business owners and professionals would be even more receptive to the barter concept in order to stimulate their businesses and move inventories and conserve cash. Most people aren't aware that today 30 percent of all business transactions in the country involve some type of trade or barter. And by the end of the century, it's expected to increase to 50 percent."
On completion of a training course at the corporate training center in Portland, Ore., Mr. Kamm became a trade director with an office in Manhattan. In 11 months he expanded in Westchester.
"The concept of barter exchange is simple," he said, explaining how the system works: businesses profit from bartering by increasing their purchasing power and by finding new customers; members receive credits for what they sell. In order to join, they pay a one-time, $295 membership fee and a commission of 5 percent cash on every barter transaction, plus a yearly $15 cash fee and a yearly $15 fee in trade dollars for association dues and a newsletter. "In return, they get our nationwide list of products and services, which range from accountants and acupuncturists to video productions and well drillers, and everything in between," Mr. Kamm said.
By selling goods and services through the exchange, members earn trade dollars, which are credited to their account, similar to a bank account, Mr. Kamm said. They use their trade dollars to buy from other members. Purchases are made using "trade drafts," which look like bank checks.
"ITEX does all the accounting and record keeping for the exchange," Mr. Kamm said. "Regular account statements are issued to all our members showing them the activity in their account." Members set their own prices on the goods and services they offer for barter.
Bartering, which was once perceived as a slightly shady practice, part of the underground economy that avoided paying taxes, gained respectability with the passage of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1984, which, Mr. Kamm said, required all barter groups to report the value of all transactions to the Internal Revenue Service. Barter transactions are subject to the same taxes as cash transactions.
 
'Barter Can Move Inventories'
 "We're the only public company in the barter business," Mr. Kamm said. "We file regular financial reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Although everything is bartered today, it's particularly useful in a recession when businesses are cash poor or when the demand for business in a particular product is slow. Barter can move inventories. And if a customer wants something very special and unique, part of my job is to help him find it."
For one customer, Mr. Kamm said, a contractor who wanted a luxurious boat in exchange for the trade dollars he earned from doing contracting work for other members, Mr. Kamm found a seller with a $95,000 yacht. "The contractor got the yacht, air fare to London and a trip on the Orient Express for two in return for building an addition on a home for another customer."
Another member wanted to trade a lion; still another bartered two racehorses worth $15,000 apiece.
"Barter transactions aren't always small," Mr. Kamm said. "Some interesting tradeabilities that just came in last week were a brand-new $160,000 sports car, $10.5 million worth of mining equipment and $23 million in medical equipment."
 
A Willingness to Work Is Needed
 Recently, Mr. Dankilde bartered a poodle puppy worth $500 plus another $200 for supplies and $500 for training, housebreaking and an obedience course to a couple who, in turn, sell bridal gowns and prom dresses. In another transaction, he said, he bartered two fish-tank setups totaling $1,700.
"But you have to be willing to work at bartering; unless you use it and understand the system, you will be out of cash -- which is the last thing you want," Mr. Dankilde said. "You have to be a good shopper. But once you understand the process, it can be extremely advantageous. I know it's helped me save cash and move stock, and while it doesn't pay the bills -- you still need cash for that -- you do get opportunities to use your trade dollars for something that can be sold and converted into cash. For instance, if you buy a car with trade dollars and sell it for cash, you end up with cash."
Marilyn Goldberg, the owner of Mari Hube, an art and museum giftware shop on Manhattan's East Side, frequently goes on buying trips and attends trade shows here and abroad.
"We barter a lot of travel, hotel accommodations, magazine advertisements and art supplies," Ms. Goldberg said. "We manufacture and sell original art pieces for museum stores and because we frequently have to have new inventories for our museum customers, we barter our excess stock. It's a good way to lower our inventories and save cash. As far as I'm concerned, I think barter exchange is the wave of the future. We will be seeing more of it."
 
A Half-Cash, Half-Barter Job
 Thomas Honahan is a contractor in Middletown, N.Y. Recently, Mr. Honahan installed skylights and renovated the exterior of the Casalone restaurant in Manhattan.
"The total cost for the job was $25,000, half for cash and half for barter credit," Mr. Honahan said. "I figure barter accounts for 20 percent of my overall business. In exchange for my contracting work, I have acquired a fax machine, air tickets to Aruba, and I'm working on bartering hotel accommodations now. Bartering has helped me keep busy during the recession."
Dr. Jan Gross, who is Mr. Kamm's wife, is a periodontist.
"I've already bartered my professional services for building supplies that were used for the construction of our new house in Bedford, and now I am working on getting the appliances through barter," Dr. Gross said.

HEADLINE: Clinic Lends a Hand in Rocking the Cradle

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON recently described the effects of her first few weeks in the White House.
"There has been so much to do initially," Mrs. Clinton said in a report in The New York Times. "Sleep has taken a back seat. I told Bill we have a budget deficit, an investment deficit and a sleep deficit." 
 If the Clintons want the White House to look like America, they are on the right track -- at least when it comes to sleep deprivation. Like other busy Americans for whom there do not seem to be enough hours in the day, sleep has been put low on their list of priorities.
But viewing sleep as an expendable luxury is a misperception -- and one that is potentially dangerous, say doctors who study sleep.
 
A Price to Pay
 "People have somewhat vague ideas about the nature of sleep," said Dr. Charles Pollak, a neurologist and the medical director of the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center at the Westchester division of New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center here.
"They have the idea that sleep is essentially a waste of time and that nothing useful is being accomplished," Dr. Pollak said. "What they don't understand about sleep is that it is a bodily function that is as necessary as breathing."
The need for sleep will eventually manifest itself, Dr. Pollak added. While a person can get along on a short-term basis with less sleep, over time there will be a price to pay in reduced cognitive function.
And if the brain is short on sleep, the result can be irritability, confusion and depression. The consequences include troubled interpersonal relationships, difficulty on the job and the kind of clouded judgment that leads to serious accidents.
According to a report released last month by the National Commission on Sleep Disorders Research, several of the nation's major accidents, including the near meltdown at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant as well as numerous rail, airplane and automobile accidents, share a common basis: human error related to excessive fatigue. Several doctors at the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center contributed to the report.
There are a variety of reasons why people don't get enough sleep, say the experts who study sleep. In some cases it may simply be a condition of modern life in a difficult economy -- many people working two jobs, enduring long commutes or performing shift work fail to get enough sleep.
But there are others for whom, no matter how much time they spend in bed, sleep seems an impossibility. The National Commission Report said that about 40 million Americans suffer from chronic disorders of sleep and wakefulness, such as narcolepsy, sleep apnea and insomnia. An additional 20 to 30 million people experience intermittent sleep-related problems.
According to the report, the vast majority of people affected remain undiagnosed and untreated. But doctors at the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center say that many people who suffer for years without enough sleep are doing so unnecessarily.
 
A Variety of Complaints
 "Most sleep disorders are treatable," said Dr. Margaret L. Moline, the director of the center. "Basically, the problem is that there is just not enough information in the general public and among health-care professionals about sleep -- what's normal and what is a disorder."
For instance, she said, "most people think snoring is laughable because the noise is funny." But, she added, "it may be caused by sleep apnea, which is a dangerous condition, and while we cannot cure it, there is a very effective treatment."
People who come to the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center for help have a variety of complaints, but most fall into three main categories.
First, there are those who complain of excessive daytime sleepiness. By this they do not mean occasional drowsiness that comes after one bad night of sleep.
This is sleepiness that occurs every day and is severe enough to be disabling -- causing errors at work, car accidents and a basic inability to take part in such simple pleasures as seeing a movie or a concert without falling asleep.
Sleepiness, of course, is caused by not sleeping well, and at the center doctors attempt to discover the root of the problem. One common diagnosis is sleep apnea -- a condition where a person has difficulty sleeping and breathing at the same time. People with sleep apnea snore heavily and can actually be waking up dozens of times a night in an effort to breathe. Sleep apnea can be treated with a machine that regulates breathing.
Another sleep disorder that causes excessive daytime fatigue is narcolepsy. People who have narcolepsy cannot stay awake and alert for 16 hours a day, which is what most people are able to endure. They need to take frequent naps throughout the day.
Not only is this disorder disabling, but it is also frequently misunderstood.
"The most poignant stories I hear are from people with narcolepsy," Dr. Pollak said.
"Often a person has grown up accepting other people's ideas about them as lazy people who are not motivated and not interested in what they are doing," Dr. Pollak said. "They come to believe it is a matter of character because they have no other explanation for why they are falling asleep all the time," he explained.
Narcolepsy can be treated with medication.
A second major category of complaints at the center is insomnia. Insomnia is not a disease but a group of conditions that may have different causes, Dr. Pollak said. The most prevalent is psychiatric -- depression is known to cause sleeplessness.
Long-term treatment means addressing the depression itself, either through medication, psychotherapy or a combination of the two.
 
The Biological Clock
 In other cases people who cannot fall asleep until 2 or 3 o'clock in the morning no matter what time they go to bed may have a problem with what doctors call the biological clock. Dr. Daniel Wagner, a staff neurologist at the center, said there is a clock in the brain that keeps track of time.
"The body clock is a relatively rigid function," Dr. Wagner said. "If you change time zones, you can reset your watch but not your brain. That's why you have the symptoms of jet lag."
Dr. Wagner said that research in trying to reset the brain clock includes exposure to bright lights and medication, but, he added, the research remains experimental.
 
Inappropriate Behavior
 People often attempt to medicate themselves for insomnia by using sleeping pills. Sleeping pills are the most widely prescribed type of drugs in the world, doctors at the clinic say. But they warn that prescription sleeping pills are both psychologically and physically addictive, and while pills may be effective for a short-term, specific problem, they are not advisable for chronic sleep disorders.
The third major source of complaints at the center is what doctors gingerly call "behavior inappropriate to sleep." This can include people who act out a dream and punch a bed partner, people who prepare a meal in their sleep and eat it without waking up and children sleep-walking out of bed, down the stairs and out the front door into the street.
Though some of the anecdotes seem amusing, the consequences are far from laughable; often they result in serious injury. The center has seen patients who have injured their spouses, walked through glass doors and been badly lacerated and children who have been hurt during their nighttime ramblings. Often, such conditions can be controlled with medication.
When patients come to the sleep-disorder center they are evaluated in several ways. Almost all patients complete sleep logs, so they can chart their patterns of sleep.
For some, though not all patients, it is useful to obtain sleep recordings, which measure the amount and quality of a person's sleep. The center has four private sleep rooms, each of which, in addition to having a bed, is equipped with infrared lights and a video camera.
Electrodes are attached to the patient, and as he or she sleeps, brain activity, eye movements, muscle tone and heart rhythms are measured. Results are charted on a 20-channel polygraph and can also appear on a computer screen.
When asked how anyone could possibly sleep under such conditions, Dr. Moline said: "Oftentimes, people who have come here have really reached the end of their ropes. They are exhausted."
 
Studies Under Way
 In addition to its treatment of patients with sleep disorders, the center is also involved in research. Three major studies are in progress: one studying methods to reduce the effects of shift work, another on age-related insomnia and a third studying the effects of antidepressant medication on sleep and wakefulness. Volunteers are needed for all three studies.
Doctors say that an occasional sleepless night is normal. For everyday stress, calming bedtime routines can be soothing. But over-worry about sleep problems can also cause additional difficulty in sleeping.
"Worrying about a sleep problem can make it real," Dr. Pollak said. "There are techniques that can help you relax. Drinking warm milk, sleeping on a comfortable mattress, anything that helps you feel confident, calm and relaxed is useful. If that helps you, fine. But an effort to relax can be anxiety-provoking in some people. And if they are suffering from a major sleep disorder, those techniques are usually not a powerful enough treatment."
 
 
 
TIPS ON GETTING A SOUND SLEEP
 Here are some suggestions for getting a good night's sleep from the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center.
*Sleep on a regular schedule seven days a week. ("You have to have a bedtime," said Dr. Daniel Wagner, a staff neurologist. "Bedtimes and wake times are not just for military barracks or children. They are useful for everyone in keeping sleep predictable.")
*Minimize anxiety-producing activities before bed. For instance, avoid arguments and do not pay bills at bedtime.
*Avoid alcohol and such stimulants as caffeine before bed.
*Do not exercise strenuously for several hours before bedtime.
*Do not eat a big meal right before bed.
*Do something relaxing in the hour or so before getting into bed.
*Consult a doctor if you still feel tired after practicing good sleep hygiene.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Margaret L. Moline, the director of the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center at the Westchester division of New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center, watching monitor, also at right, of a sleeping patient. (Photographs by Alan Zale for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 1; Styles of The Times

LENGTH: 3061 words

HEADLINE: Lost in the Name Game

BYLINE: By BETSY ISRAEL

 BODY:
WHAT do you call someone who is 23? (Or for that matter, someone 31 or 18 or possibly 12?)
Journalists, marketing executives -- many over-30's everywhere -- seem suddenly desperate to know. Each week brings a new round of cute, all-inclusive names, each guaranteed to be the generational logo. And with these pronouncements come handbooks and guides to this mysterious New Youth and many talk-show dissections of New Youth character, as well as polls, profiles, articles -- each offering up the definitive traits of the postboom, pre-millennium set. It's as if half the world had just noticed that many, many people were born during the 1960's and 70's. 
 Despite all the fuss, there's little agreement on who they are, except for this: these people have had it rough. They were the children of Watergate, one reads again and again, of newly employed mothers, absentee fathers and mass divorce. They grew up amid precocious sex and drug use, legalized abortion and possible nuclear annihilation, not to mention those "open" classrooms that may have produced the lowest SAT scores in history. And they emerged from childhood in time for AIDS, an unyielding recession and bad rock music. In their favor, it's generally agreed, they can do five things at once: channel-surf, eat, talk on the phone, listen to music and type resumes for nonexistent jobs. But they can't, determined namers say, concentrate on any one activity for more than five minutes.
The fill-in-the-blanks, we'll call them here. The only American generation without a name. Despite countless "This is it!" claims, they still don't have one.
Few, understandably, want to be known as baby busters (as in "from boom to bust") or baby boomerangs (for boomeranging home to one's parents, or worse, boomeranging back to rob or kill selfish, home-owning baby boomers). Time magazine did not exactly wrap things up with the New Lost Generation. And how excited is the average 30-year-old (minus 10) likely to get about twenty-somethings? Others favor the slightly mysterious Generation X, the title of a sardonic, "Here we are!" novel by Douglas Coupland. Or else slackers, from the Richard Linklater film about severely anomic (yet very witty) young Texans. There's been talk of Bradys, after the venerated television sit-com, and even 13ers, for the 13th generation to come of age since Benjamin Franklin's (advocates concede, however, that being named for a floor that elevators don't stop at might be discouraging -- worse even than being named for an antique television show.)
Gabe Doppelt, the editor in chief of the reconstituted, more youthful Mademoiselle, suggested "Cable Generation, perhaps -- because MTV is just one channel among many." The author Joan Kron wrote in a letter to Allure magazine that "Metamorphs" -- a term she devised with Dr. Grant McCracken -- "really best describes the 90's person who believes that he or she can and must change themselves in order to survive."
So the list drones on: latchkeys; technobabies; videos; boomers-nots; cyborgs; posties; protos (for proto-adults); borders; downbeats; mall rats; nowheres; burnouts; remotes; steroids; junks; "sparse," according to the National Journal, or to quote the columnist Russell Baker, "simply numb."
And there would seem to be as many definitions of whom these chilly labels purport to fit. Neil Howe, who wrote "13th Gen" with Bill Strauss, said, "We are talking here about the 80 million people born from 1961 to 1981 -- that's two related waves: the 60's Atari wave and the later 70's group, which we call the Nintendos."
Bret Easton Ellis, 28 and an occasional "Atari wave" spokesman, claims as peers those born between 1961 and 1971. Donna Gaines, the author of "Teenage Wasteland" -- a study of miserable, forgotten suburban "burnouts" -- defines the "bust" as the 37 million people born between 1965 and 1975. And Business Week has staked out the 46 million born between 1964 and 1975, a group of expert shoppers likely to spend some $125 billion this year.
In fairness to the blanks, a truly accurate group portrait will take years to complete. (By some estimates, the youngest members are now 12.) In the meantime, we can admire this rush to define as a marketing ploy on the scale of D-day. Or we can view it as a weird sort of national sport, a professional name game. Or as something deeper, perhaps what Michael Schudson, a professor of communications and sociology at the University of California at San Diego, called "a means of creating community between people who have lost other forms of identification."
"Definition by birth year," he continued, "is really a phenomenon of the past half century, a time in which people have moved around so rapidly that traditional community, familial or spiritual ties do not hold."
One 19-year-old student, who is (or isn't) blank, put it this way: "People without a name tag on are threatening, and so there's got to be a big push to get that tag. You say, 'Hi! I'm from the dog-bowl era!" They say, 'Fine. Here's your discount dog bone.' Is there some reason we can't just live?"
There is. Isolating and naming population segments help marketing executives and advertisers. Create the idea of a subculture defined by tokens of membership, and you sell more toys, movies and books. "No marketer on earth could have ignored those 75 million or whatever baby boomers," said Barbara Feigen, executive vice president at Grey Advertising. "Obviously that was one of the hugest marketing opportunities of the century. It was imperative to comprehend not only the shared chronological age but the mind-set, the common attitudes, sociology and psychology -- what values that unique group brought to the marketplace."
And the true legacy of the 1960's is the idea that the group is the young group, whether it's a New Generation or a Youth Quake or an Explosion or a New Voice.
Studies of spending patterns have shown that when a large number of people turn 25 simultaneously, sales of big-ticket items -- cars and houses, namely -- start to rise. A large number of American citizens will turn 25 during the next few years. And by "reaching out" to them, advertisers will suck up those at either end of the age spectrum, the too young or just too old. (Remember that the only ones who really said "groovy" in 1967 were either 12 or pushing 40.)
This business imperative intersects an odd cultural one: the need to have (or to prove) generational standing.
During the 1960's, the "core" baby boomers (born between 1946 and 1951), became that young generation largely by reviling the one just before them. And as they aged during the 1970's, and actually turned 30, they extended this generational apartheid in all directions. Consider for a moment the lives of the '58-to-'59 group (late boomers? boomettes? yuppies?), who faced countless loyalty tests: Did they really see the Beatles on "The Ed Sullivan Show," or did they just think they did? Where were they during the invasion of Cambodia? ("Seventh grade" was not, needless to say, an acceptable response.) Since that time, testifying to one's pop-cultural legacy -- a defensive litany of childhood television shows, historic rock concerts or political acts -- has become a competitive fact of life. Americans now carry with them an instant age resume, with the generational label as a sort of cover letter.
So why is it so hard to write one for the blanks? For one thing, because the generational markers, all the identifying cartoons and clothes and shoes, now seem to come and go with greater speed. In fact, as the daily tempo of life has accelerated -- and as advertisers have been forced to seek more finely segmented audiences -- the average ID-card "generation" seems to last as long as most sit-com runs. This high turnover rate has created a huge instant-nostalgia market (Great Love Ballads of the late 70's! Television show themes from the Summer of Love!). It has also made it hard for the blanks to set membership ground rules. There are factions within factions, internal tribes with their own identifying T-shirts. Being asked to wear the wrong one is cause for war.
This age egocentrism was summarized recently by two 30ish men on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times. In a tone of muted outrage, they denounced being dumped with the "twenty-somethings," the grungy miscreants they called the cuspers. Instead they claimed to represent a mini-cohort, born between 1960 and 1964, a "boomlet," inhabited now by boomer manques. Unlikely, as adults, to experience much in the way of "boom" -- the great houses and cars and casual sex -- they would settle, thank you, for a better-looking, slimmer demographic.
Which brings up a second labeling dilemma: who'd want to be part of an age group like Generation X or Baby Bust?
"We haven't done any naming of this group ourselves," said Ms. Feigen at Grey Advertising. "But if we do, it will be from a constructive marketing perspective. These names reflect what these people are not, or else they're a reference to some other group. It's insulting. It's shallow. The names don't show any thought given to who these people are, how they feel about themselves."
Under the circumstances, inclusion in this age cohort might reasonably be viewed less as an invitation, a call to comradeship, than as a punishment. (Labeling is always to some extent a hostile act. Yuppie, originally a socioeconomic designation, quickly became a moral slur, a weapon core boomers used to bash the late arrivals.) Just as no one was ever voluntarily "a yuppie" -- and no self-respecting over-50-year-old would admit to being from the Silent Generation -- few want to sign up to be blank.
"The 13er," said Mr. Howe, the author, "shares with his or her peers the collective sense that everything gets tired by the time it gets to them. There's the very real sense that the boomers -- who were the original 'found' generation -- sucked up too much of the oxygen and now there's not enough left." He continued, "Like the first World War I-era 'lost' generation, the 13ers are a sacrificial generation, a clean-up crew who will have to quietly, on their own, take on the messes previous generations couldn't handle." He added, "And they feel as if they will never get credit for it, that all the attention is going, out of guilt, to the generation after them -- the 'baby on board!' kids born post-'82."
IGNORED until last month or so, blanks seem to have a skeptical so-show-me approach to just about everything. And it's this reticence -- known also as a bad attitude -- that ultimately makes the search for an acceptable name so difficult. To the blank, the entire labeling process is transparent and insulting (imagine being the target audience for "Melrose Place.") In short, the 20- and 25- and 30-year-olds just won't buy it.
They make fun of it.
Playing anthropologists, reporters often cite "Generation X," a novel by the very funny, very blank Mr. Coupland, who is 32. What most quote, however, is not the prose itself but the marginalia -- a glossary of terms like "bleeding ponytail" and "legislated nostalgia" -- included to explain key "X" concepts. (His latest novel, "Shampoo Planet," includes an updated Table of the Elements -- PZ=prozac; OP=opinion poll, etc.)
Even the more serious statements of generational discontent sound like an angry parody of 60's rhetoric. "We are twenty-nothing," declared an unsigned piece in The Baffler, a literary journal published by graduates of the University of Chicago, "forever lost to your suburban platitudes; lost to the simple blather of your TV; deaf to your nonpolitics; hopelessly estranged from your cult of 'professionalism,' the brain-deadening architecture of your office complexes." It added, "Your best and your brightest want nothing to do with you."
This refusal to hold still and be tagged -- coupled with the inability to say exactly who is to be tagged -- has led some to conclude that there simply isn't a new generation out there. Perhaps, as Alexander Star wrote recently in The New Republic, the claim to blank generational status is "a myth -- an imaginary resolution of real contradictions." As Professor Schudson explained, "Most generations have a focal point, a traumatic national or political event or a war. Here, you might argue that the one defining cultural experience of people in their 20's is a splintering effect, a true multiculturalism that's nonbinding."
"What you have is commercials," said one 24-year-old woman. "Rollerblading-across-the-Grand-Canyon wish fulfillments. I don't see any organized role models or beliefs. I mean, 'Wayne's World'? Anyway, I think the idea of generations, as isolated organized groups, is obsolete."
What may be obsolete is the idea that one encompassing label can be applied. "Silent" and "G.I.," attached to generations, cover a lot of identifiable ground. "Hippie," "punk" and "yuppie" refer to increasingly smaller patches.
"The world has changed so much in 20 years," Ms. Doppelt at Mademoiselle said. "The state of flux that kids heard so much about in the late 60's is now pretty much permanent. And younger people have -- as we all have -- this information, all sorts of things, flung out at them, 24 hours a day. The mind has to work in a different way." She continued: "That doesn't make them completely different. At least two generations grew up with TV, so some similarities exist, but you have to be much quicker and direct. There's a different sensibility, both more sophisticated and more straightforward."
Richard Linklater, the director of "Slacker," has tried to describe that sensibility, to say what it is that unites and brands his co-blanks. It's not a political stance or a language or even a coherent fashion statement. As he writes in his book on the making of the film, it's experiencing an "incredible kind of -- what? Dissatisfaction, or total nonbelief in everything, but with an interesting sense of humor and irony about it all."
As generational tag lines go, "the Age of Aquarius" was a lot easier to work with.
 
 
 
A GENERATION DEFINES ITSELF
 "I honestly think that the principal experience of people in their 20's is of being caught behind a defining generation and having to settle for junk culture as a unifying symbol. We couldn't rebel against Vietnam, so we rebelled against disco. We missed the 80's boom and all the good jobs were taken, so we invented this slacker psyche, or in my case went to law school. We should call ourselves the late generation. That's really it. You had the generation of our parents that lived by things with which youth is inexorably associated: hippies and political agitation. History didn't leave us that symbolic youth, so all we got left with was 'The Brady Bunch.' "
Charles von Simson, 28, law student, Brooklyn.
 
"I feel, and most people I know feel, something big is about to happen, and we're excited. Especially coming from an African-American point of view, things are so bad that there is a change that has to take place. It can only go so low and people will take things into their own hands to make things happen. In the riots in Los Angeles, it was basically the young people who were outraged, who were fighting back. You didn't see many older people shouting and outraged. It was the older people who were talking about calm. It is exciting to be young right now because things are so critical. I was talking to a friend of mine who was saying that there is a whole new wave that is going to happen. It's a social wave. It's a new feeling of change, that young people who have seen what has happened to past generations are taking control over what they feel is wrong."
Stacy Highsmith, 21, student, North Carolina School of the Arts, Winston-Salem, N.C.
 
"AT least among my friends, we want to do something that is meaningful and fulfilling and something that we hope is going to make a difference. But at the same time, I think all of us have a desire for material comforts, and those two often don't go hand in hand. And I'm not sure that characteristic is confined to our generation. It may be a predominant characteristic of people in their 20's, in whatever era. I don't think there is a definite characteristic of people in their 20's except that they are trying to decide what to do with their lives, and that is going to cause a certain amount of confusion and angst no matter who you are and what you are doing. To say that my group, as people in their 20's living in the 90's, is somehow different strikes me as a massive overgeneralization."
Ed Yim, 25, assistant to the general manager of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Philadelphia.
 
"DOES slacker mean a good thing or a bad thing? For us, I don't think anyone would think that it is bad. Whereas for other people, the problem is to define us, and slacker just barely gets at what our generation is experiencing. I feel like we have seen people or know people who are disillusioned with the American dream and yet at the same time don't feel ready to give up on it. But they are not going to embrace it in its current state. That leaves us with the problem of change, but it seems like an enormous task to change the way our country works. I feel like we are not sure of what the answers are. And if you don't know the answer, how can you work toward a change? So we are sort of caught in a big muddle of trying to see every side of everything and not being able to move forward."
Rachael McNally, 24, high school teacher and drummer for a band calledSleepyhead, Manhattan.
 
"BARTENDING and substitute teaching are both things that you do when you are on your way to doing something else or you haven't decided what to do. By the time my dad was 27, he had started a family. That's a big step. I have mixed feelings about children, not because I don't like them, but I just feel like there are probably more than enough people on the planet and I don't know if they need one more. On the other hand, there are so many people who are screwed up, maybe you could make someone who could do something good. So there is always the contradiction about feeling good about things and feeling bad about things."
Geoffrey Hill, 27, bartender and substitute teacher, Austin, Tex.

HEADLINE: Volunteers Become Partners In Education

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
AS school budgets are cut and more teacher aides and library assistants are let go, schools are increasingly tapping a valuable source of free staffing: volunteers. Parents, elderly people, business executives and others are donating their time to fill the gaps left as budgets have been trimmed over the last few years.
In Norwalk, for instance, the number of parents participating in the Volunteers in Norwalk Schools program has grown from 1,600 four years ago to about 2,500 today. 
 The program coordinator, Jan L. Fiore, said the program began in 1966 with parents running bake sales and monitoring the lunch rooms. Today, the parents help in the library, run computer seminars and tutor children after schools.
"I think people are turning out in greater numbers because they've become aware that the more parent involvement there is in the schools, the better their children do," Ms. Fiore said. "The message keeps getting out that if you're involved, if you're at the P.T.O. meetings and part of school programs, you're doing your child a real favor." James A. Connelly, Bridgeport's superintendent of schools, said parents at four of the schools have donated their time and the materials to construct playgrounds, valued at about $20,000 each. They also help out in reading, writing and math classes, and after-school programs.
"Parents are becoming a partner in schooling," Mr. Connelly said. "We're feeling our way through the area of parent empowerment. The role for parents is no longer just as a helper, we're sharing decisions on policy and governance of the schools, and I think that's going to grow."
Thomas W. Murphy, a spokesman for the State Department of Education, said that even now, when taxpayers seemed to be scrutinizing every nickel spent in the schools, people were usually eager to help when they were asked. "The issue is not usually getting enough parents involved," Mr. Murphy said. "It's developing a program to use them effectively."
There are, however, a few pitfalls for a school district just starting a volunteer program, Mr. Murphy warned. Schools are required to have certified teachers in the classroom; there are insurance implications for parents or others on school grounds, and school boards must take care not to divert work from union members in violation of a contract. "But schools know enough not to place parents in an inappropriate situation," Mr. Murphy said. "We've had few complaints."
 
Corporate Involvement
 Mr. Murphy said no statistics were kept on the number of school volunteer programs statewide, but he agreed it was rising.
"It's not just parents who get involved in schools," Mr. Murphy said. "There are some enlightened companies that allow employees to get involved in school on the company's time."
Few towns with active volunteer programs calculate how much the volunteer services are worth. But in Madison, Schools Superintendent Peter A. Barile said that his board had asked him to estimate how much time had been donated. "Beyond the P.T.O. and associated activities, we found we averaged more than 5,000 hours at each of the six schools -- almost 30,000 hours in all," Dr. Barile said.
He said Madison has different programs that solicit involvement of parents, businesspeople and elderly people.
"We're trying to run a school without walls," Dr. Barile said. "We want the community in our schools, and we want to extend our schools out into the community. I've been here since 1987 and every year we've built the program up a little more. We've now got some people volunteering 20 hours a week."
 
Schools Return the Favor
 And the school attempts to give something back. Dr. Barile said the schools have, for instance, opened their halls to elderly people for walking during inclement weather. "That's saying to them, 'You help us out in the schools, and we'll help you out.' "
Robert E. McDonald ran a hardware store for 16 of the 20 years he lived in Madison. Now, working with George Greim, another retiree, he coordinates school volunteers.
"People seem to be perfectly willing to help if they're asked," Mr. McDonald said. "The problem is in a lot of areas they're just not asked."
Mr. McDonald said that thanks to older people, bar codes were put on the library books scattered through the Madison schools, in order to computerize the collection. Also, a speakers' bureau enlisted about 70 people available to talk to students on 150 topics.
"A lot of our volunteers are retired people who wouldn't normally come into contact with the school," Mr. McDonald said. "We're trying to broaden the expertise available in the schools. And everyone who volunteers gets a great deal of satisfaction from it as well."
Ellen G. Marano of Watertown agreed. "I get a feeling of accomplishment when I know the kids are doing a little better after I've helped them," Mrs. Marano said.
When 10 percent of the teaching staff was laid off in her hometown last year, Mrs. Marano, a nurse who is taking time off from her career to raise three children, began volunteering three days a week, helping students with English composition, spelling and reading. Some of the elementary school classes have more than 30 students.
"The children can't handle that," Mrs. Marano said. "Starting out, they could use a lot more guidance than one teacher can give to a class of 30 students."
And, she said, her help takes a little pressure off the teachers as well.
"They really need the help," Mrs. Marano said. "Actually, they need more teachers, that's what they need."
 
Checking the Eager Beavers
 Dr. Connelly, the Bridgeport superintendent, said the volunteer programs must be tightly controlled so the school did not encounter more problems than it was solving.
"When a parent volunteer comes into the schools, the administration needs to lay out a few rules," Dr. Connelly said. "There are times when parents try to become involved in areas that would be better left to a professional."
For instance, parents who are not education professionals should not be trying to offer remedial education or counseling, he said. But when parents overstep their bounds, it is usually just a matter of being overeager to help, not that they are intentionally taking on more authority than they should, Dr. Connelly said.
"Once you have a clear understanding of the roles, there isn't a problem," Dr. Connelly said.
In fact, so committed is Bridgeport to the concept of parent volunteers that it recently rented space from the University of Bridgeport to open a parent resource center, where parents can go to learn computer skills, receive literacy training or attend seminars on child rearing.
Even in affluent towns that are weathering the recession better than most, volunteers can be an important part of the school program. Brian A. Fagan, Fairfield's assistant superintendent for instruction, said volunteers were integral to the Fairfield Arts for Youth program. Volunteers also coordinate field trips for the science program.
"It extends what the district is able to deliver in terms of the scope and the richness of the program," Mr. Fagan said.
 
Business Provides Mentors
 Where parent volunteer programs have been successful, some school systems have started to branch out. Norwalk, building on the success of its volunteer program, started a mentoring program in 1986, relying on area businesses to allow employees to give up an hour a week to spend with a student.
Dr. Susan G. Weinberger, who coordinates the program, said it has grown by about 25 percent a year the last few years, and now includes 31 companies. It has been the model for similar programs in 16 other communities, including Las Vegas and one in Canada.
"It began before the budget problems but it's become more important since the problems began," Dr. Weinberger said. "You've got kids coming to school who are not prepared, who have no support at home, and who are ready to drop out socially and academically. We give them someone who's there for them, a positive role model, someone who can excite them about staying in school."
Maura E. Romaine, assistant director of community relations for Norwalk Hospital, coordinates a dozen mentors at the hospital, and is a mentor herself to a third-grade girl in one of the city's 19 schools.
"Some of these kids had such a poor self-image that they would stare at their feet while they talked to you," Ms. Romaine said. "You can see them gaining self-confidence as time goes by, and it gives you a wonderful feeling to be part of that."
Mentors encourage the students to do more of what they do well. The student Ms. Romaine works with draws, and after she came into the hospital to see the different jobs people do there, she became so enthusiastic that she drew cards for all the pediatric patients.
Some districts have used parents and other volunteers for a variety of jobs inside the schools. In Cromwell, where the schools were granted a 1.3 percent increase in the budget last year, the lowest on record, more than $400,000 had to be trimmed, and volunteers have helped the school keep many programs going that would otherwise have been eliminated.
 
Filling In the Gaps
 Jefferson L. Prestridge, the Cromwell superintendent, said the budget that passed, for instance, cut all financing for field trips.
"At the elementary school, parents have completely absorbed that activity, and they spend a lot more time at it than we would be able to do," Dr. Prestridge said. "Parents are very interested in filling the gaps. It's a very supportive community, it's just that financially it's very difficult to support the schools because so many people have lost their jobs. So the parents are looking for other ways to support the schools."
One parent comes in and works with a teacher on the track program, and others help with transportation, he said. "Otherwise, 20 kids would not be able to compete in track."
Another parent comes in early each day to run the chess club. One parent who is an engineer has come in to evaluate the energy management system in the schools, saving hundreds, if not thousands, of dollars in consulting fees, Dr. Prestridge said.
Cromwell also has an educational foundation. Each summer, parents park cars and shuttle people to the Greater Hartford Open golf tournament, and put the money in a fund used to make grants for teachers to set up special programs. The effort raised $15,000 last year, Dr. Prestridge said.
"In the past we looked on the foundation's grants as something extra, but now it's a vital part of the school program," he said.
 
Advertising for Tutors
 Taking a cue from the systems where it is working, several schools across the state are starting programs to attract volunteers. Paul Copes, Superintendent of Schools in Bloomfield, advertised in the local newspaper last month seeking volunteers to help with basic tutoring activities. Last year his budget was reduced by 10 percent, or $2.3 million, to below the level it was in 1989.
"I would want parent volunteers in the schools even if there had been no cuts," Dr. Copes said. "The motivation is not strictly financial. It's enriching, for both the students and the volunteers, for this interaction to take place. Parents and other adults provide a different perspective for students. They make the course work come alive, based on their life experiences."
For instance, the president of the employee benefits division of Cigna Insurance Company, which is in Bloomfield, agreed to help teach a course on applied economics. But he had to do it early, at 7:15 A.M., so he would not be late for work each day.
"The students had to get there on their own because our transportation system wasn't geared to getting them here that early," Dr. Copes said. "But we had more than 20 students sign up for the course."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Eugene C. Gavin;
Politics From the New Side of the Aisle

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHEN State Representative Eugene C. Gavin, a Republican of Westport, was sworn in recently, he became a member of the largest class of freshmen in the General Assembly in recent memory. One-third of the state legislators in Hartford this year are freshmen and, like most of the newcomers, Mr. Gavin won the seat of a longtime legislator who chose not to run for another term in 1992, Elinor F. Wilber, Republican of Fairfield.
Mr. Gavin, who is 39 years old and a native of West Haven, earned a master's degree in business administration and law degree at Rutgers University, and an advanced degree in taxation from New York University School of Law. He returned to Connecticut after college and, after having held accounting jobs with several large companies, became director of state and local taxes for the Coopers and Lybrand accounting firm. Mr. Gavin discussed issues faced by freshmen legislators in a recent interview in his office in the Legislative Office Building in Hartford. Here are some excerpts from the conversation. 
 Q. There are more new legislators this year than anyone can remember. Is that going to help, hinder or make no difference during the new legislative session?
A. I think it's going to help, and I say that for two reasons.
One is, we went through a big debate over the income tax two years ago. Notwithstanding the heat of that debate the mix of the legislature didn't change that much, didn't change at all vis-a-vis Republicans and Democrats. But many of the Democrats I've met so far have run on the same principles I did, which was to get spending under control, stimulating the economy and creating jobs. It seems to me that, philosophically, many of the freshmen are identical, no matter what their party affiliation.
No. 2, I don't think it's going to be business as usual. The electorate is fed up with politics. I think we're all here to help the State of Connecticut, and I think that's going to be the overriding principle.
Q. Are the freshmen meeting in an informal, nonpartisan way?
A. It's not in a caucus per se but freshmen from both parties are invited to various receptions. The House leader had one at his home, and there are other groups having receptions for freshmen. That gives us an opportunity to talk over ideas. Now, as the session gets underway, we get to see each other, have lunch together, and talk things over. It's a building process. We want to get to know each other. There's an openness, and that's important.
Q. What's the hardest part of being a freshman?
A. The hardest part is you're not used to getting as much mail as you do as a freshman. I normally get a lot of mail, but now I'm getting big boxes full of mail every day, at home and at the office. You really have to be very organized to deal with the mail situation -- it could be constituent questions, invitations to receptions, information on various issues, so you have to read it all.
And I don't think many people are aware of how many state agencies and how many state programs there are, or how many lobby groups there are, like college associations, and business associations. I've even heard from a soda association; I had no idea there was such a thing.
Q. Has there been any pressure by the party leadership to make the new members fall into line?
A. There've been some party caucuses already, and I think the leadership has demonstrated a genuine concern that each of us be able to express our viewpoints on different issues. There's really been no reeling in of anyone, if you will, at this point.
At the same time, I believe that in order to be effective you have to have certain party positions and you have to be loyal to those positions. So there's a balance there. But they haven't been hard-nosed about it, and they've been very helpful in fact.
There's a special caucus coming up, in fact, to unveil some of the mysteries confronting freshmen: What are "go lists?" How can a bill be introduced after the deadline has passed, that sort of thing. The leadership has been effective at helping us get acclimated to a very awe-inspiring environment.
Q. When did you first get into politics?
A. My first election involvement was for the mayoral race in West Haven. I was about 10 years old, and my mother was on the Republican Town Committee and my father was a councilman. I grew up in that political environment. They say politics is a disease, and I have it in my blood -- I just want to make sure it's not fatal to me. I even met my wife through politics. We ran against each other in student government at Fordham University.
Q. What do you think about proposals for term limits?
A. To tell the truth, I have a hard time with term limits. I think elections are the people's means to terminate someone. I have a great deal of faith in the electorate. If someone is doing their job they should be re-elected and if they're not doing their job they should be defeated. We've seen it happen.
I remember when Lowell Weicker was the United States Senator from Connecticut. There was a perception there, apparently, that he wasn't representing the state as well as he could. I guess the State of Connecticut is also forgiving, because he's now our Governor, but that seems to tell me that no elected official can go his merry way, either in a real way or in a perceived way, and not incur the wrath of the people.
Q. It's expected there will be a big fight between the big cities and other municipalities over state financing this year. How are freshmen lining up in that fight?
A. Part of the answer is the revitalization of Connecticut. The decline of our cities happened because the cities no longer remained competitive, competitive with the suburbs and competitive with other states. So the real answer, in my view, is the revitalization of the cities. I think the freshmen legislators are going to be very pro-business, and that's going to help the cities.
Once we bring businesses back to our cities, there will be new jobs, and cities will become more attractive places to live. It's not even comfortable driving through some of our cities, and we have to address it or the problems are going to grow and grow, into the areas around the cities. We have to stop thinking city versus suburbs, and realize the cities' problems are Connecticut's problems. As freshmen I think we have a real commitment to the cities, they've given us a lot, and now they're in trouble and we have to help them out.
Q. Casino gambling is expected to be another major issue this year. What will you bring to that debate as a freshman?
A. I think people want to look at it seriously. It's not a question of introducing casino gambling into the state, Connecticut already has casino gambling, in Ledyard.
And casino gambling is hurting taxpaying businesses like the dog track, jai alai and off-track betting. We have an individual willing to invest $350 million of his own money. Casino gambling could also help our tourism industry. We cannot lightly disregard these conditions.
What the focus of debate should be is, if we permit casino gambling in Bridgeport or Hartford, what are we going to do so we don't end up like Atlantic City, how can we structure it so we can be sure casino gambling gives a jump start to our cities. This might be the impetus to get that going.
The question is, how do we do that? I think, unlike Atlantic City, the revenues should be put right back into the city, to make Bridgeport vital again. We're talking about $340 million a year in revenues, 6,000 new jobs. Part of the plan should be specific designation of the revenues into the cities.
If we do it in Bridgeport, use the revenues from casino gambling to improve the port, to improve the airport, to improve the train system. If it's structured right, the restaurants and hotels outside the casino area will benefit, service businesses and retail stores could benefit. The Governor has said he will veto any proposal for casino gambling. But he's also said the cities are one of his priorities, and I think the case can be made for casino gambling, and if it's done right maybe he'll think differently.
Q. Is the legislature going to cooperate less with the Governor this year because he, as well as legislators, face election in two years?
A. The worst thing that could happen is that, simply because the Governor proposes something, we oppose it because he's the Governor and he's not in "my party." Being a freshman I think I'm a bit idealistic. If the Democrats come up with a proposal that makes sense, I'm going to support it.
Our one goal should be to make Connecticut better. Come 1994, I want to be able to say, "This is my record, here's what I fought for." Hopefully there will be some successes. Let's not go after something simply because of who introduced it. There are a lot of legislators who have different backgrounds this time around, there's a new commitment, they want to bring in a more objective approach as opposed to the party approach.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eugene C. Gavin of Westport is part of the largest class of freshman legislators in memory. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 13; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1493 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Drinking In Diluted Stanislavsky, Street People Make a Film

BYLINE: By ANDREW MEIER; Andrew Meier writes for Premiere.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Last year, 138 people without homes died on San Francisco's streets. One of them was a nomadic Vietnam vet who spoke fluent Sioux and called himself Buck. Though he never got the shrapnel out of his skull or the alcohol out of his blood, he did try to find direction in one of the city's more unorthodox recovery programs.
The program, known as the Tenderloin Action Group, was founded in August 1991 by Rob Nilsson, a local film maker, and it invited anyone to act his way off the streets. Within a year, it had grown into a grass-roots workshop that today is finishing a feature film, "Chalk," a smoky pool-hall drama about a small-time hustler set up for a game he cannot win. Mr. Nilsson hopes that the film, which will cost just under $100,000 to make, will be ready for release late this year. 
 With its unlikely ensemble of novices, "Chalk" is not merely a low-budget melange of "The Hustler," "The Color of Money" and "Mean Streets." Rather, it is a film wrought with detail from the biographies of its cast and dialogue in their own idiom. Mr. Nilsson and his co-writer, Don Bajema, created each character with a workshop member in mind, grafting material from their improvised scenes and their own lives.
The cast might seem a sampling from a census of America's dispossessed, including some people who once led stable, middle-class lives. But to Mr. Nilsson, 52, they are "drifters and dreamers who shared the same conundrums of heart and head that confront us all." Having veered away from home and family to face battles with drugs, alcohol and the streets, these actors discovered a sanctuary in the Tenderloin Group. True, few among them were ever mere bundles on the sidewalk, but fewer still required any make overs, costume changes or De Niroesque stints on skid row to assume their roles.
Mr. Nilsson, a graduate of Harvard and the Peace Corps, traveled his own odyssey to make "Chalk." Nearing 50 as the 1980's closed, he was no longer up and coming. His independent films had garnered praise from Francis Ford Coppola and John Cassavetes and awards in Cannes (for "Northern Lights" in 1979) and Park City, Utah (for "Heat and Sunlight" in 1988). Despite his early acclaim, the director was shunned by Hollywood and forced to distribute five of his six films on his own. (The exception was the 1985 drama "On the Edge," which starred Bruce Dern.) The decade had made him thinner and grayer, a sinewy cross between Chet Baker and Clint Eastwood.
Mr. Nilsson spent the 80's practicing his own guerrilla film making, which he calls direct action cinema. It is modeled, he confesses with obvious adulation, on the cinema verite of Cassavetes. Emphasizing improvisation and character over strict plot lines and big-budget effects, he had lionized the struggles of Norwegian farmers, San Francisco cabbies, a disgraced runner and lovers in the final hours of an affair. But he had yet to touch a subject that haunted him daily.
That subject was his younger brother, Greg. For 10 years he had searched for Greg, who had left the family's home in Marin County and begun wandering around the country. By the spring of 1989, the breadlines in the city's Tenderloin district, seething with the down and out, had filled its seamy sidewalks. Every morning, on his way to edit "Heat and Sunlight," Mr. Nilsson would scan the hungry faces in search of Greg's. "About twice a year," he recalls, "my dad would get a call from some hospital in South Carolina or somewhere: 'We've got your son here. What should we do?' " Mr. Nilsson, too, wondered what he could do.
On the set of "Chalk," it is obvious he has found his answer. "This film's not about homelessness," he makes clear, "but it evolved out of my desire to address the issue." In the summer of 1991 Mr. Nilsson moved across the bay from Berkeley, where he lives, into a transient hotel in the Tenderloin, where he spent months writing a script called "Hope for the Fourth Ace."
"It's about a Vietnam vet and his lottery card that has four scratch-off numbers. A game of reverse Russian roulette." Mr. Nilsson shopped it around furiously, even paying his own way to Cannes, only to be "killed with kindness, not offers." Realizing that the homeless were not likely to attract audiences in the recession, he recruited Danny Glover and Whoopi Goldberg to work for scale. "Then James Olmos, Sally Kirkland and Peter Coyote volunteered," he says. While still hunting for the $4 million needed for financing, Mr. Nilsson and his co-producers, Rand Crook and Ethan Sing, searched for an "auxiliary cast," advertising a free acting workshop for anyone in San Francisco shelters. Each workshop was videotaped.
"That raw footage was bottled lightning," Mr. Nilsson says. "It was a collective human cry. You know why you see guys screaming on the street? Because they're wound so tight. Give them a chemical twist, and a spigot opens." Offering nothing stronger than diluted Stanislavsky, Mr. Nilsson pulled together the makings of a film.
"It struck me one day," he recalls; " 'Don't wait for the money. Use video. Turn the warehouse into a pool hall and use these wonderful actors.' " And so, with four donated pool tables, a bar built by the cast, nearly $25,000 from benefits whose attractions were names like Tom Waits, Gregg Allman and Gena Rowlands, and a $6,500 check from a "local angel," shooting began last June.
Ten months earlier, the Tenderloin Action Group had met for the first time. "That night we were just a brave few, fresh from the streets," remembers Edwin Johnson, who plays Watson, the proprietor of the hustler's local pool hall. Strangers on the streets, they discovered in the workshop that they shared painful histories.
"We're all just folks who ran across hard times," says Sharon Jamieson, a thirtysomething graduate of the University of the District of Columbia who spent six months in shelters before joining the Tenderloin Group. Motivated mostly by curiosity, the homeless trickled down to the organization's headquarters, a leaky warehouse in the city's industrial area.
Once a week, nearly two dozen would-be thespians came together. Ms. Jamieson recalls her elation after the first workshop: "It nourished my soul. I'm not saying I'm gonna be another Whoopi in six months, but it gave incentive to wean myself of the streets."
Few of the participants had acted before. Destiny Costa, a 21-year-old with a history of both alcohol and drug abuse, had been a "witch slash tour guide" in a Salem, Mass., museum. Ms. Jamieson had been an extra in "White Men Can't Jump" and "The Mambo Kings."
Mr. Nilsson, it turned out, was spared searching the Tenderloin for his brother. Greg resurfaced and has a small role in "Chalk" as the pool hall's custodian.
Like Greg, many in the cast have found not only an audience but a family. "On the streets," explains Edwin Johnson, "you know a lot of people. But not one can you call a friend." Although their part-time work on "Chalk" is unpaid pending a distribution deal, many members of the Tenderloin Group have found their lives changed. Disdaining alcohol and drug abuse, and becoming accustomed to keeping a schedule, they have now managed to find jobs and, at the least, rooms of their own.
"Chalk" has also proved to be an esthetic adventure. "I wanted to let them mine their own experiences and emotions," Mr. Nilsson says. "There was a lot of kindergarten rote reading at first, so we just found another skein to travel along." The director was careful to guide his actors away from self-indulgence, toward self-exploration. "Rob's different with each of us," Ms. Costa says. "He may be teacher, mentor, brother or father. But he gets us all to open up."
Mr. Nilsson's evolving role falls uneasily on his shoulders. "I'm not an acting teacher," he says. "I trust feeling over acting. My job is just a bit of midwifery."
Yet with an anthropologist's allegiance to authenticity, he kept his writerly impulses out of the script. "People on the street talk like no one could ever write," Mr. Nilsson says with a laugh, quoting one of the Buck's mantras: "Ain't no woman gonna bleed my best thoughts."
The director concedes that in the move from the workshop to the film, "a few got away." One was Neil, by all accounts a natural leading man, but a heroin addict unable to shake the habit.
Though Neil remains in the film in a smaller role, his departure forced Mr. Nilsson and Mr. Bajema into a major rewrite. "I cast one of 'Chalk's' two professionals, Kelvin Han Yee; and our African-American lead suddenly became Asian," Mr. Nilsson says. And filming began on schedule.
Mr. Nilsson is determined to screen "Chalk" nationwide as a testament to his cast. (A New York distributor, Arrow Entertainment, has expressed interest in the rights.) For Mr. Nilsson, the workshop is not enough. "This is not about process," he insists. "I'm an artist. I believe in leaving an artifact behind."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The co-writer Don Bajema in "Chalk," a film about a small-time pool-hall hustler. (Ethan Sing)(pg. 13); Mr. Nilsson, right, with the three leads of "Chalk," Denise Cavaliere, Johnny Reese and Kelvin Han Yee -- On an esthetic adventure. (Janet Silva)(pg. 19)

TITLE: CHALK (MOVIE)
