HEADLINE: How Milosevic Stole the Election

BYLINE: By Douglas E. Schoen; Douglas E. Schoen, a partner in the New York polling firm of Penn & Schoen Associates, managed Milan Panic's campaign for the presidency of Serbia.

 BODY:
Milan panic, the American businessman turned Serbian politician, flew to Nis last December not knowing what to expect. He was coming to the town, an industrial center in the southern part of Serbia and a stronghold of President Slobodan Milosevic, for the first major rally of his campaign for President of Serbia. The hope was that at least a few thousand people would turn out.
Initial signs were not encouraging. The Mayor told him not to come, factory managers said they would not receive him and there had been too little time to organize supporters. But when Panic pulled up to the Ambassador Hotel at 3 P.M. he was speechless. There in the town's main square, chanting his name rhythmically and eagerly awaiting his appearance, was a crowd of more than 20,000. 
 "When I began this campaign I was not a politician," Panic told the crowd. "But with this enthusiasm, you can now consider me a professional politician." If he won on Dec. 20, he promised, he would end the stranglehold the Communist Party had held on the country for better than 40 years, work to end the civil war in Bosnia, promote democratization and implement free-market economic policies. He also promised higher taxes and greater unemployment, as state industries were privatized. His economic proposals, while unconventional and potentially disruptive, were greeted with thunderous applause -- in a country where unemployment exceeds 60 percent.
Three weeks before the Nis rally, I had come to Serbia at Panic's request to help develop strategies for the campaign. While I had spent the last 15 years advising candidates, including Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Mayor Edward I. Koch in New York, and worked in 18 different countries, nothing prepared me for what I ran into. In all my previous experience abroad, which included work in countries like the Philippines, Bolivia and Panama, there had always been some basic sense of fair play. Naively, I kept thinking Serbia would be the same, or close to it.
THE OUTPOURING OF support in Nis represented something of a vindication for me. I had told Panic three weeks earlier that he should run for President and that he could win. This put me in a distinct minority among his local advisers, who believed the incumbent Communists (they now call themselves Socialists) would never allow themselves to lose an election.
Panic had returned to his native land in July at the invitation of Milosevic to serve as Prime Minister of what was left of Yugoslavia (Serbia and the very much smaller Montenegro). Milosevic had clearly hoped that Panic would legitimize his Government and provide cover for the ethnic cleansing and territorial expansion the Serbs were supporting in Bosnia. But Panic, whose avowed goal was to end the fighting in 100 days, quickly came to believe that Milosevic was the principal obstacle to peace in the region. Panic repeatedly called on him to resign, both publicly and privately, but got no response. He concluded that his only recourse was to mobilize the opposition for the elections.
After reviewing what appeared to be credible poll evidence, I told Panic that Milosevic had lost the confidence of the Serbian people, that the electorate wanted change and that, despite his having returned to Yugoslavia only five months earlier, that he was more popular than the incumbent. I encouraged him to run and indicated that he had better than a 1-in-2 chance of winning the election.
If there were any bias in the polling, I assured him, I presumed it would tend to overstate support for the incumbent authoritarian Government and understate support for the powerless opposition. On the basis of this, Panic agreed to run if the necessary 10,000 petition signatures could be collected in the two days remaining before the filing deadline.
Having worked on petition drives in the United States, I was skeptical that this could be done. Nevertheless, an army of young volunteers -- looking like something out of central casting -- scurried around and gathered not 10,000 but 40,000 signatures before the deadline. I was ecstatic. I was convinced that Serbia would swing inexorably to us as Russia had to Boris Yeltsin, Poland to Lech Walesa and Czechoslovakia to Vaclav Havel.
Once again, the Serbs in the campaign were markedly less optimistic. In different ways, they warned me not to be too encouraged by the poll results. "Don't expect the Socialists to roll over and play dead," one former Tito associate said to me. "They will try every trick in the book."
I said sternly: "Look, I've worked in elections around the world. No leader whose resignation is supported by more than half his electorate can be re-elected. Milosevic is finished." The man smiled and walked away, shaking his head.
FOR PANIC'S RUN, WE DECIDED TO combine the best-remembered aspects of President Reagan's 1980 campaign and President Clinton's 1992 campaign. We asked Serbian voters if they were better off now than they were two years earlier, when Milosevic was elected, and we ran on the economy, with the slogan "Promena Sad" ("Change Now").
When Panic incorporated these elements into his announcement of his candidacy, I was convinced we were on a winning track. But immediately there were problems. The announcement got virtually no coverage on state-run Radio Television Belgrade, the only electronic-news organization that covers the entire country. Its 30-second voice-over report dwelled primarily on the fact that the declaration took place at the American-owned Hyatt Regency.
More ominously, state-run radio and television -- long notorious as instruments of the regime -- began an unremitting assault on Panic, describing him as a traitor to the Serbian people and an agent of the American Central Intelligence Agency. The attacks began the night of Nov. 30 and continued in one form or another for the entire campaign. Still, that night a tracking poll showed Panic with a comfortable lead of eight percentage points.
I brought the results to Panic's villa, expecting him to be pleased. Instead, he was raging about the television coverage. "R.T.B. has just spent 27 minutes attacking me," he said. "There is no way we can win if they keep doing this." I tried to reassure him that we were still leading substantially in the polls and predicted that we would pull further ahead when our own television commercials started. He just shook his head.
Again, I was overly optimistic. Radio Television Belgrade next told us it would broadcast our commercials only after Panic's candidacy was certified by the Serbian electoral commission, which naturally was controlled by the Socialists. Still, I assumed this would be a formality. After all, Panic was the Prime Minister of Yugoslavia, one of the most popular people in all of Serbia and a certifiable hero for making a fortune in pharmaceuticals in the United States.
But I was wrong.
Almost immediately, the commission declared Panic ineligible because he had not been a legal resident for a year prior to the election. The residency requirement had been tagged onto some legislation in early November.
It was not until Dec. 9, with half the 18-day campaign past, that the Supreme Court of Serbia overruled the commission, putting Panic on the ballot. In the meantime, he was subjected to scathing nightly attacks on Radio Television Belgrade, without the opportunity to respond.
Nor was that the end of the matter. The channel refused to run any Panic commercials until it received official notification of his certification. Moreover, the certification had to be received by 3 P.M. for that night's broadcasts. I was not really surprised when the paper work arrived at 3:30.
With the active campaign ending Dec. 17, we had only a week to make our case to the people. But still, I felt we had a powerful message. We produced an ad that started with a picture of Milosevic, asking whether he had really improved the quality of life and the economy. The commercial showed bread lines and gas lines, as well as shots of ordinary Serbs with looks of desperation. It concluded with footage of Panic promising voters a healthy economy, peace and a more democratic society.
The ad never ran. Radio Television Belgrade barred it as too critical of the incumbent regime. I was incensed and told our advertising representatives to do whatever was necessary to get the ad on the air. They removed all references to Milosevic, but kept the shots of bread lines and economic decay. Again, the channel's officials refused the ad. But they said they admired it, so much so that they believed Milosevic was certain to be defeated if it ran. For days, the only commercial we were able to run was a biographical spot on Panic.
Curiously, to me, my Serbian colleagues seemed relieved that the negative commercials did not run. "You have to understand," the finance chairman finally explained. "If we lose, you will not be here Dec. 21 to face the consequences, but we will."
Enough happened during the campaign to convince me that their fears were justified. We assumed every phone was bugged. Some campaign volunteers were just too good to be true. They spoke fluent English and Serbian, had professional degrees or training and had unlimited time to devote to the campaign. They sought no compensation for their efforts. A number of comely young women came forward eagerly volunteering to be my "personal assistant."
While I rejected all these offers, there still were serious leaks. One night, for example, a journalist with Radio Television Belgrade came to our table in one of Belgrade's most fashionable restaurants and complimented us for television spots that had not yet been produced. Panic said half-seriously that the channel probably reviewed the scripts before he did.
Given that there was no expectation of privacy or confidentiality, I conducted one phase of our campaign very differently from the way I normally would. Instead of holding poll results in confidence, I publicized them as widely as possible. We did this to assure voters that Panic was a serious candidate who could actually win.
This credibility was crucial. In every survey we conducted, Panic held a narrow lead over Milosevic. Yet when the pollsters asked voters who they thought would actually win the election, a 4-to-1 majority believed the incumbent would prevail. We needed to convince people they were not alone in supporting Panic.
Going into the last few days of the campaign, virtually every survey showed either a dead heat or a slight Panic lead. The technical end of survey research is relatively far advanced in Serbia and there was little reason to believe that the surveys were flawed. We concluded that, despite our extremely limited access to the press and the very short campaign, we would either win a clear majority on the first ballot or that there would be a runoff with Milosevic, if the minor candidates should siphon off enough votes.
On Dec. 17, the last day of campaigning, Radio Television Belgrade devoted close to four hours to Milosevic's final campaign rallies while making only passing reference to Panic's closing rally in Belgrade, which was attended by more than 150,000 people. Radio Television Belgrade actually pre-empted many of Panic's final paid pre-election commercials to give more free coverage to Milosevic, leaving the Panic campaign with a substantial credit after the election.
WHILE PANIC was encouraged by the enthusiastic support he received from the Serbian population, he was bitterly disappointed with the United States and other Western nations. While Panic could not afford to seem too close to the West, he at least needed a concrete declaration that sanctions would be lifted if he were elected. Yet, no support was offered.
The United States did take one step that, regardless of the merits, proved to be politically disastrous for Panic. Just as the campaign was ending, Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger labeled Milosevic a war criminal for his role in fostering ethnic cleansing in Bosnia. This comment served to isolate Serbia and to allow Milosevic to portray himself as a victim of Western aggression and the only figure strong enough to stand up to American imperialism.
Moreover, the Eagleburger comment -- which included the menacing words that someday, somewhere the United States would get Milosevic -- had to strengthen the dictator's resolve to win the election by any means necessary. The prospect of death by hanging is not something that will typically encourage a despotic leader to loosen up.
On top of that, there were pathetically few outside election observers. The absence of international pressure, particularly from the United States, allowed the Serbian authorities to bar European poll watchers until two days before the election, making observation of the voting very difficult. Milosevic responds to real pressure. That's what got him to the Geneva peace talks. So why didn't we insist on free and fair elections? Why did we stand by meekly while Milosevic stole the election?
The manipulations actually began before the election, when voters who had not participated in the spring elections were systematically purged from the rolls. Sounds innocent enough, until you consider that the opposition boycotted the spring elections. To be reinstated, voters had to go to a central location to check their status and then wait as long as three or four hours at state bureaucracies to register. Needless to say, thousands of people did not even bother to try.
On polling day, from 5 percent to 10 percent of all voters were turned away by state authorities, according to monitors from the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. This figure was confirmed by our exit polling. The interviewers agreed that the vast majority of those who were turned away were younger voters, whom polls showed to be strongly pro-Panic.
Students, who supported Panic overwhelmingly, were required to be at their universities on Dec. 20 in order to register for subsidized housing for the next term, thus making it difficult for them to get home to vote. Ethnic minorities, who make up about 20 percent of the Serbian electorate and many of whom are living with relatives outside Serbia, faced waits of four to eight hours at border crossings on election day. Pre-election polls showed that these voters favored Panic by a margin of better than 10 to 1.
Despite these obstacles, an exit poll of 1,371 voters interviewed at a randomly selected sample of 60 Serbian polling places showed Milosevic and Panic tied at 47 percent. In the capital, between 80 and 90 percent of the voters said they had voted for Panic. Nevertheless, early official projections showed Milosevic with more than 55 percent of the national vote and Panic with around 33. They also showed us losing virtually every polling place in Belgrade.
I could go on. The point is, the Serbian election was a fraud. The great tragedy is that, with a little outside pressure, Milan Panic could have won, possibly ending the most barbaric conflict Europe has seen in half a century. In this election, we were all losers.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
When Country Life Gets on Their Nerves

BYLINE: By Michael S. Malone; Michael S. Malone is a writer based in Los Altos, Calif.

 BODY:
THESE days, when successful executives grow tired of the corporate rat race and dream of retiring into a life of rustic simplicity, one of the places they eye most longingly is the Northwest, especially Oregon. Land's cheap. Traffic's almost non-existent. And the casual life style looks like an appealing break from the pin-striped boardroom world they know.
But for many of these newly minted country squires, retirement soon looks a lot like the work they left behind. 
 Take Georges C. St. Laurent Jr. In the late 1960's and 70's, he made his fortune through Longwood, Fla., holding companies that developed commercial properties and shopping centers and from his ownership of the Sterno Companies in Tenafly, N.J.
"My life," he recalls, "was one of shooting back and forth in the corporate jet all week long. I never stopped."
Then, in the early 80's, he did stop. Recognizing both that "the capital gains rate was the lowest I thought I'd see in this century and that income and commercial property in Florida was overpriced, I decided to sell as much of my property as I could." Coincidentally, as Mr. St. Laurent was conducting this liquidation, Colgate-Palmolive approached him about taking over Sterno.
Says Mr. St. Laurent, "All of this occurred within a period of 18 months. So here I am in 1985, have just turned 50, with a lot of liquid assets and nothing to do. My wife, Eleanor, and I decided to take a look at where we wanted to live and the life style we wanted to have. We liked Oregon especially, because during the period we were looking, the population was actually decreasing. We found a cattle ranch in the Rogue River Valley near Eagle Point, and moved."
Mr. St. Laurent didn't realize at the time that he was part of a trend. The small towns of the Oregon coast and the Rogue Valley, have become the home of numerous urban expatriates, most of whom are in regular contact with one another. Grants Pass, the nearest city of any size to the 4,000-acre St. Laurent ranch, even features its own little Left Bank of bohemian top execs.
Charles H. Newcomer (yes, he is sick to death of the jokes) is one of them. A former developer and retailer in Los Angeles, he moved to what had been his 200-acre summer home in 1989. "Yeah," he says, "we all know each other. St. Laurent was down here the other day. I guess there's probably more millionaires per capita here than in most cities. We love to swap war stories about the old days. We've all got a lot in common."
One of these shared experiences is the brevity of their retirements. "A lot of these people come to retire and get away from the hectic life style," says Jennifer Kong of the Oregon Economic Development Department. Then they realize it's a mistake.
That's certainly what happened to Mr. Newcomer: "I went fishing twice, walked in the woods 10 times -- and realized that retirement wasn't for me."
So he went back into business -- albeit with an Oregon flavor. His company, Northwest Precision Plastics, employs 100 people and makes specialty injected plastic products -- for electronics and medical equipment and toys. A recent offering is a water gun devised by two local bankers and a financial consultant who like to raft on the Rogue.
Mr. St. Laurent, meanwhile, first set out to avoid the winding mountain roads. "I hired a veteran helicopter pilot, bought a helicopter and spent the better part of the year getting myself rated," he said. "After that I started using the helicopter as my primary mode of getting around the state."
He had no plan of ever going back to work, but made a small deposit in his local bank, a Western Bank branch in Eagle Point, and, as was his custom, having been a board member of Sun Banks in Florida, he asked for a copy of the bank's balance sheet.
"It turned out to be a nice independent bank," he said. "It'd had financial difficulties in the early 1980's and its publicly traded over-the-counter stock was languishing at half of its book value. It struck me as a buying opportunity." Before long, Mr. St. Laurent owned 5 percent of Western Bank's stock. "Then I basically forgot about it."
Two years later, in 1987, while the St. Laurents were in London, Mr. St. Laurent learned that giant U.S. Bancorp wanted to gobble up Western. "I rushed back, studied the situation, and realized that I didn't want Western Bank to go away," he said. By the time of the shareholder vote, Mr. St. Laurent had 18 percent of the stock. He blocked the sale.
Soon thereafter, he was appointed to the bank's board, and within a year was chairman and chief executive -- "and asking myself what I'd gotten into." The bank was not very profitable, it had problem loans, assets were just $300 million. "But I wanted to see how I could be more productive . . . In other words, I was bored out of my mind and wanted to get back into action," Mr. St. Laurent said.
Six years later, Western Bank has assets of $600 million, 38 branches and capital of more than $50 million (up from $16 million). Non-performing loans have dropped from 6 percent outstanding to less than 0.2 percent. Last November, Forbes Magazine named it one of the 10 best small banks in the United States.
"I don't really work that hard," Mr. St. Laurent claims, and describes a typical day sounding like a different century: "I spend a fair amount of time at the ranch. I get the hands together in the morning for instructions and then head on down to the bank."
Like many of Oregon's other bucolic barons, Mr. St. Laurent has strong feelings about the world he left behind. "I see what's happening in the Northwest as the fifth major migration in U.S. history," he said, referring to the flight from cities and suburbia. "This time," he added, "it's technical people who can move their skills and capital to a place that is safe and comfortable."

HEADLINE: More and More Teen-Agers Crowd Shelters in New York

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TROY, N.Y.

 BODY:
It had been a busy night at the shelter; a suspected crack dealer and his family were asked to leave, a mentally ill woman announced that she had just miscarried, though she had not been pregnant, and a shelter worker had told a new arrival, just out of jail, that he could not carry a weapon during his stay.
Amid the confusion, two 16-year-olds sat at a table in the shelter discussing music, Red Hot Chili Peppers versus Tracy Chapman. At first glance, the teen-agers seemed out of place. But at Joseph's House in Rensselaer County and other shelters around the state, teen-agers, many of whom have been abused, have become an increasing presence. 
 Across the state, people who run homeless shelters said they have been slowly overwhelmed by a growing number of young people seeking shelter. Far needier than the classic rebellious runaways seeking adventure, these young people have put new and special burdens on a system that can barely handle the more common problems of homeless families and the mentally ill.
Some shelters that are open to all homeless people "are now almost 100 percent kids," said Shelly Nortz, who heads the New York State Coalition for the Homeless in Albany. "By far the most common thing we hear about homelessness in the recession is that kids are taking over shelters or living in cars and breaking into churches to keep warm."
Advocates for the homeless attribute the change not just to the added economic pressures on families but also to a more general failure of public policy to prevent the wholesale destruction of families and a new awareness among young people that they do not have to tolerate abuse.
While no statistics are available on the number of teen-agers now living on the street or in the state's patchwork of public and private shelters, the advocates say teen-agers are the fastest growing group of homeless people in both New York City and the state as a whole. Elsewhere across the country, shelter providers said they had also noticed an increase in the number of homeless teen-agers, but nothing like what is being seen in New York.
"There's a whole brand new devastating situation," said Richard Dina, executive director of Children's House Inc., in Mineola, L.I., which runs three youth shelters and has seen the number of homeless teen-agers it serves increase by 100 percent from about 225 to 450 over the last three years.
"A few years ago they came to us and you got them right back with mommy and daddy," he said. "Now a lot of them don't have a family base to go back to, so we can't work on getting them back to their families; we have to work on getting them on their own."
In both policy and practice, dozens of people who work with homeless teen-agers said, state government has failed to respond to the change. The state's Division for Youth Services, they point out, will spend $5.3 million on services for homeless teen-agers this year, the same amount it has spent every year since 1990.
And despite an official policy that foster children must have a safe place to go when they are discharged, a number of those working with teen-agers contend the reality is far different. Specifically, these advocates for children say, every time the state sends a child back to an untenable situation at home it is effectively putting the child on the street.
 
Denied Public Aid
 On a local level, a number of county welfare workers still operate under the assumption that these teen-agers can go home again, routinely denying them public assistance, the advocates say, particularly when they came from middle-class families.
Advocates fear that pending legislation supported by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would dissuade young people from applying for the meager help now available: The budget bill would require those under 21 who receive general assistance to live at home unless there is a specific finding of abuse, and then the state would be required to sue the parents to recover money spent on welfare payments.
Although runaways have traditionally flocked to New York City, smaller cities, suburbs and rural areas are now seeing large numbers of homeless teen-agers who have been abused or kicked out by parents who could no longer afford to support them. Most have not run far and are wholly unprepared for life on the streets.
One 16-year-old who has been at Joseph's House for a month said he still did not consider himself homeless, and he enthusiastically rattled off the names on the labels in the designer clothes he received through a local charity.
"I was thinking about going to Mexico, because I had enough money for a one-way ticket," he said. " I was going to just keep on walking and go to Belize and get robbed by gringos and just experience life in some dangerous places, and get a tan."
He is not the same teen-ager who left home five months ago after he said his mother tried to stab him with a letter opener and subsequently wore out his welcome with relatives and friends, and spent the $500 he had saved from a paper route on cheap hotels. Since then he said he has learned not to trust anyone.
Though he does not smoke, he carries cigarettes to avoid fights with people who ask him for one. He so fears catching a disease that he wears gloves when he shakes hands.
"I've proven I can take care of myself on my own," he insisted, but demurred when Sharon Svolos, Joseph's House program director, asked him when he would like to move into the apartment she had found for him. "I've been thinking, I'm going to be tired tomorrow," he told her. "Can I move on Monday?"
 
Sharing Lessons Learned
 As a 16-year-old girl at the shelter described her history of sexual abuse by her father and stepfather, she drew geometric figures in a notebook and chewed on a fingernail. But when an older shelter resident sat down and began to complain that he was unable to panhandle enough change to buy a pack of cigarettes, she sat up straight and shared a lesson learned.
"Never ask for money for cigarettes," she told him authoritatively. "Don't ask for food, either, or they'll take you out and make you eat." She said she left home because her mother tried to stop her from attending Alcoholics Anonymous meetings.
Over time, the business of surviving not only hardens the young, but also drains the life from them. Some already appear to have lost all hope for the future.
"Every county we go into is seeing a huge increase and saying, 'What do we do with these kids?' " said Tom Schmitz, director of human services for the Salvation Army's Empire State Division in Syracuse. "Most of them don't have programs."
Rather than sleeping in subways or on city streets, many of the young people in rural areas camp out in the woods, sleep in abandoned railroad cars or move in with friends.
"Across upstate New York, we see them banding together in what I call adolescent families, with four or five of them living together in a trailer as a way to cope, and maybe the oldest one working at a marginal job to pay the rent," said Joseph Walker, executive director of Catholic Charities of Delaware and Otsego Counties.
In suburban areas, they often hang out in malls until the stores close, then sleep in a car or a train station or spend the night with a friend, said John Harper, executive director of a Friend's House, a 13-bed shelter for teen-agers that opened 10 months ago in Middletown in Orange County.
Residents in a number of small towns have started noticing teen-agers sleeping in parks or walking the streets all night. In Norwich, a town of 8,000 in Chenango County, ministers and elected officials formed a committee and collected donations to help find a place for homeless teen-agers to stay. Because the area has no homeless shelter, the county houses some of them in its public nursing home.
But most of these teen-agers refuse that option. "It's not a place you would want to be," said Harry Grant, a retired sales manager who began volunteering full time with the teen-agers three years ago. Working out of the Broad Street United Methodist Church, he delivers food and furniture in his blue pickup truck, and visits youths who call to tell him they are lonely.
 
Problems of Being Too Young
 Even when teen-agers find their way to a homeless shelter, they have a difficult time finding their way out; they have trouble finding permanent housing because they are too young to sign a lease or qualify for public housing. Teen-agers have trouble qualifying for public assistance because welfare workers must first get in touch with their parents, who are still legally responsible for them.
"The first thing the caseworker's going to do is call mom or dad, even though the kid says they've been abusing them," said Colleen Pawling, a lawyer with Neighborhood Legal Services in Buffalo. "The parent is never going to tell a county official that Susie can't come home again, so they're denied" benefits. A successful application by a teen-ager, she said, can take as long as six months.
Deborah Adler, a spokeswoman for the New York state Department of Social Services, said that under state law, teen-agers receive benefits immediately if caseworkers find that their parents' home is unsafe.x
Middle-class teen-agers generally have an even harder time convincing county workers that their parents cannot provide a stable home, the advocates said.
After the percentage of teen-agers in their shelter climbed to about 85 percent, Joseph's House in Troy began a follow-up program last year to help young shelter residents apply for benefits and find permanent housing. In many cases, they lack the maturity and patience that a housing search requires, Ms. Neitzel said, and their past experiences have not made them particularly easy to help.
Not far from the shelter, in a downtown storefront that has been converted into a studio, four formerly homeless young people call their new home the "Hell House of Pain," because each has a history of abuse. But they said they had at least found housing and companionship, and they are Ms. Svolos's success story.
"We get along good in this house; we talk through our problems every day," said a 16-year-old girl who sleeps on a couch in the crowded studio she shares with a young man who is clinically depressed, his brother who has refused treatment for skin cancer and a young woman who until recently had been living in her car. "We're kind of like a family, I guess."

HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE HONES ALL-OUT CAMPAIGN TO SELL SACRIFICE

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Opening a week that his advisers say could be the most important in shaping his Presidency, Bill Clinton is seeking to sell his economic program with one of the most intensive public relations campaigns ever staged from the White House.
Mr. Clinton will deliver his first televised address from the Oval Office at 9 Monday night as part of an elaborate buildup intended to set the stage before he presents the package -- with its mix of unpopular spending cuts and tax increases -- to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday. 
 White House officials said they borrowed the idea of the Oval Office address from former President Ronald Reagan, who during his third week in office made a plain-spoken public appeal for his tax-cut plan before taking it to Congress.
 
Political Stakes Are High
 But they concede that Mr. Clinton, though his party controls Congress, has a harder sell than Mr. Reagan, who was championing tax cuts, not unpopular tax increases. The political stakes are particularly high for Mr. Clinton because he made the economy the centerpiece of his election campaign.
For much of the weekend, Mr. Clinton was closeted with his top economic advisers to fine-tune the plan. While the overall effort has engaged hundreds of people in the White House, Federal agencies and the Democratic National Committee, Mr. Clinton is as comfortable with economics as many experts in the field, and his advisers said he had not consulted much beyond his economic team and members of Congress.
His involvement in reviewing the plan line by line is strikingly different from that of Presidents Reagan and George Bush, who both left such details to their budget directors.
 
Limits on Health Spending
 Today, Administration officials confirmed reports that they would probably impose limits on health spending and medical prices. "Some kind of cost controls are going to have to be implemented in order to make health care reform work for every American," Leon E. Panetta, the Director of Management and Budget, said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation."
But Mr. Panetta backed down from his position during his confirmation hearings that $2 should be cut in spending for every $1 that taxes are increased. Saying "we recommended that as a target," Mr. Panetta added that the plan had "to be balanced between spending cuts and revenue increases."
The basic program will contain short-term measures to stimulate the economy and a long-term effort to trim the deficit. Officials said the stimulus package would probably include an increase in Federal spending this year by $16 billion and $15 billion in tax breaks for businesses.
To reduce the deficit, there is expected to be a broad-based energy tax; a tax on perhaps 85 percent of the Social Security benefits of the wealthiest retirees; an increase in the top individual tax rate to 36 percent from 31 percent, and an increase in the top corporate tax rate to 36 percent. Among other provisions will be cuts in the payments made to doctors and hospitals under Medicare and deep cuts in military spending.
Developing a political strategy to win public support for the plan is as critical as the policy itself, White House officials said. They said the public support was needed to counter the lobbyists who are already gearing up to fight elements of the plan.
 
'He Could Get Chewed Up'
 "It would be a tremendous embarrassment if he couldn't get this through because, theoretically, he has the partisan support in Congress," said Martin P. Wattenberg, a professor of political science at the University of California at Irvine. "But theory and practice don't always go together, and if there's not enough public pressure on this, he could get chewed up by interest groups."
Monday night's speech is to last about 10 minutes and will be a "scene setter," as one speech writer put it, at which the President will try to win over the public by explaining what happened to the American economy and why people should make sacrifices. The details will be saved for Wednesday. Monday's address will be carried live on the major television networks, including CNN and PBS, and on the ABC, CBS and NBC radio networks, National Public Radio and Mutual Radio.
This has been a week given over to both economic strategy and salesmanship. During one six-hour session at which they reviewed budget options last week, Mr. Clinton and his top aides did not take a dinner break and instead ordered several pizzas. The same group was back in the Roosevelt Room tonight, as they have been virtually every day this week.
 
Campaign-Style Tour
 While Mr. Clinton has already devoted speeches, two radio addresses, numerous meetings with Democratic lawmakers and his first televised town meeting last week in Southfield, Mich., to preparing the public for his economic plan, White House officials said his offensive was far more involved than anything the image-conscious Reagan Administration took on.
The President is expected to pitch the plan in interviews on television networks, to travel to the Midwest and West Coast in a campaign-style tour, and he has scheduled sessions this week with Republicans from the House and Senate to try to win their support.
Members of Mr. Clinton's Cabinet have also been enlisted; members will travel to their home states on Thursday to carry the message.
On "Face the Nation" today, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, offered a preview of what opponents will say about Mr. Clinton's package. "It's the same old tax and spend, not a new idea that I can think of, unless they're keeping something back until he gives his address to Congress," he said.
Anticipating such criticism, Mr. Clinton has summoned a constant stream of lawmakers to the White House for consultations. Though he seeks their advice, White House officials said the meetings were also intended to give the members the feeling that they have not been steamrolled.
 
'Will Shape His Presidency'
 "It's very smart," said Representative Dan Glickman, Democrat of Kansas, one of several members who met with Mr. Clinton on Saturday. "What he wants to do is avoid a situation where congressmen run out after the speech and say, 'We don't agree with X, Y and Z.' It was not a patronizing session at all. He was taking things down as we were talking."
White House advisers said that after an often bumpy start in office over the controversy about lifting the ban on homosexuals in the military and the disputes over his candidates for Attorney General, Mr. Clinton needs to convince the public and Congress that his biggest priority is the economy.
"What we're doing politically is to build the sense that this is big," said Rahm Emanuel, the White House political director. "You'll hear a thousand excuses and a thousand reasons from the special interests why it's good -- but . . . The only answer is that this is a challenge to change the status quo and the business as usual thinking."
Stanley Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker, called the address on Wednesday "the speech that will shape his Presidency." Saying that people want the President to succeed, he said, "I think people are desperate for a new direction and vision."
As part of the effort, the White House sent top economic officials to appear on the Sunday television news programs to deliver the same orchestrated message that has come from the Administration for days: that the plan will be fair, but will require sacrifice from all Americans.
 
Emphasizing the Cuts
 To convince the public that Mr. Clinton has done his part, his surrogates, whenever they can, are mentioning the cuts announced last week in the White House staff and at Federal agencies -- cuts that are minuscule in the scheme of the entire Federal budget.
The speech Wednesday night is also viewed as crucial in getting the public, and the Congress, to swallow the plan.
His advisers said the President believed that in order to appear credible he had to lay out many specifics in his speech Wednesday. "They want it to be specific," Mr. Greenberg said. "If it's smoke and mirrors, he's going to lose them."
At the center of the effort, of course, has been Mr. Clinton, who for the last several days has convened his top economic advisers around a long wooden conference table in the Roosevelt Room in the White House.
Several participants described the intensive meetings on the condition that they not be identified. Mr. Clinton presides over the sessions from the middle of the table, often drinking diet cola or decaffeinated coffee.
The group usually includes these people: Mr. Panetta, Vice President Al Gore; Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff; Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury Secretary; Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers; Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary; Alice M. Rivlin, the Deputy Budget Director; Robert E. Rubin, head of the National Economic Council; his deputy, Gene Sperling, and George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director.
Asked how important the package was, one official recalled the sign in the Clinton campaign headquarters that reminded workers that the economy was the central issue. "Remember that famous sign?" he said. "This is the promise to redeem it."

HEADLINE: CHRISTOPHER MAPS A LOW-KEY AGENDA FOR MIDEAST VISIT

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Warren Christopher will make his first trip as Secretary of State to the Middle East on Wednesday, carrying exceptionally modest "talking papers": he will propose neither a new negotiating framework nor a bold strategy to bridge differences, but he will do what he always does first and says he does best -- meet all parties face-to-face and listen to what they have to say.
Unlike James A. Baker 3d, who as Secretary of State in the Bush Administration initially saw the Middle East as a no-win proposition and let the parties come to him for the first two years, Mr. Christopher decided that it was crucial to reinvigorate the Middle East peace negotiations and that he should go to the region himself.
 
His Three Goals
 But if he does get the talks going again, he will be building on a foundation Mr. Baker laid after the Persian Gulf war reshaped the political landscape in the Middle East. 
 There are three reasons for the eight-day trip, senior Administration officials say: to establish personal relationships, to signal that Washington is serious about playing an active role in reviving the moribund peace talks and to assess the commitment of the parties to sustained and serious negotiations.
"The trip itself is really the first step in reinvigorating a process that has been in deep freeze since last summer, when the Bush Administration essentially stepped out," said one senior Administration official.
 
A Longtime Strategy
 Mr. Christopher has never hidden his negotiating strategy. "Careful listening may be the secret weapon," the 67-year-old lawyer who was Deputy Secretary of State during the Carter Administration, said in a 1981 speech, an approach he has displayed in his initial dealings with lawmakers and foreign officials in the last three weeks. "We all have to assess our own strengths and shortcomings, and I observed some time ago that I was better at listening than at talking."
Senior Administration officials say that the background music he will hear on this trip will be a lot sweeter because of a complicated diplomatic move in the United Nations Security Council on Friday.
They say proudly that behind the scenes, Mr. Christopher paved the way for a successful visit with a furious flurry of personal diplomacy to push aside the obstacle that stood in the way of serious talking: the fate of 400 Palestinians banished by Israel to Lebanon.
"We were quite frankly dead in the water as long as this situation was deadlocked," a senior official said.
First, Mr. Christopher persuaded Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel to agree to a complicated formula under which it would take back some deportees now. But that gesture was not enough to satisfy the Palestinians, who vowed to boycott the peace talks until a Security Council resolution demanding the immediate return of all the deportees was fulfilled.
 
A Lobbying Effort
 So Edward P. Djerejian, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, began 10 days of intensive meetings with Israeli and Palestinian officials, while Madeleine K. Albright, the United States delegate to the United Nations, worked the Security Council.
With Ahmed Snoussi, the chief delegate from Morocco and this month's president of the council, Mr. Christopher and his aides pressed the Security Council to put its stamp of approval on the United States-Israeli deal, and on Friday the council urged the Israelis to take back all 400 Palestinians and called on the Palestinian delegation to return to the peace table.
Prime Minister Rabin welcomed the resolution, not least because it has no enforcement provisions, and said on Saturday through a spokesman that the resolution brought the deportation issue "to its conclusion."
But Hanan Ashrawi, the spokeswoman for the Palestinian delegation to the peace talks, dismissed the resolution as "another attempt at bailing Israel out."
Even if the Palestinians do not agree to come back to the formal negotiations, Mr. Christopher will meet with their representatives during his trip, which will take him on its first leg to Israel, Egypt, Syria, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.
 
Stakes May Be Low
 In that sense, he may have nothing to lose by going. But he may not have much to gain either. The crucial test is not whether he is credited for getting the Israelis out of a muddle of their own making, but whether he can help bridge the fundamental gaps between the two sides.
There is one question officials do not seem eager to answer: with war in the Balkans, American troops still in Somalia, tension with Iraq, a possible trade war with Japan and a tinderbox in Russia, why the push now in the Middle East, which does not involve an immediate strategic interest?
During his Senate confirmation hearings, Mr. Christopher said "helping Russia demilitarize, privatize, invigorate its economy and develop representative political institutions" was the most important security challenge facing the United States in the 1990's. And last Friday, after his first meeting in Washington with Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe of Japan, he echoed what Mr. Clinton had said the day before and called Tokyo "the most important partner of the United States."
So why is it not more important to go first to Tokyo or Moscow?
In responding to this question, senior Administration officials say that after his tour of the Middle East, Mr. Christopher will stop briefly in Geneva to meet Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia to prepare for a summit between Mr. Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin. "Kozyrev was not just an add-on," one senior Administration official said, indicating the importance of that meeting.
On the way home, Mr. Christopher will meet North Atlantic Treaty Organization foreign ministers in Brussels, where war in the states that used to be Yugoslavia will top the agenda.
 
Seizing the Moment
 But scrape away the official explanations and officials acknowledge other factors at play. The Clinton Administration inherited the Arab-Israeli negotiations from its predecessor, and it would be blamed for missing a chance for peace if it allowed the talks to founder.
More important, they say, it gives Mr. Clinton a chance to display what he calls an "aggressive" style of preventive diplomacy to deal with problems before they blow up and engulf him. One paradox of his Administration's foreign policy is that the Middle East, long a caldron of seething tensions and hatreds, seems predictable, compared with Bosnia, Somalia, Haiti, Iraq and elsewhere.
"We were left with an awful lot of messes from the previous Administration that we had to get on top of," said one senior official. "We had to do an awful lot of cleanup. Now the Administration wants to look to put its imprint on foreign policy and get ahead of the issues. And if there is anywhere preventive diplomacy is called for, it's the Middle East."

HEADLINE: Commission Rejects Great Lakes Flood Plan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
A plan involving dredging and the construction of flood gates to control water levels on the Great Lakes would be too costly and do little to curb flooding and erosion, a report to a commission overseeing American and Canadian waterways said today.
The study for the International Joint Commission recommended instead that the governments buy shoreline property where possible, insure that new developments are outside flooding range and use existing water controls more effectively. 
 The report is expected to bring protests from property owners, particularly on the shores of Lake Erie and Lake Ontario, where water levels are near record highs. Residents have been demanding flood controls since 1985, when high water levels combined with severe storms to cause hundreds of millions of dollars in property damage. The commission will hold public hearings in several cities, including Buffalo, next month.
Levels of all five Great Lakes could be regulated, the report said, but that would cost as much as $3.6 billion, which, it said, would be "neither economically efficient nor environmentally acceptable."
The flow from Lakes Ontario and Superior can be controlled now, but there are no controls on the middle three lakes -- Huron, Michigan and Erie. Property owners support a proposal to blast rocks to increase the flow from Lake Erie.

HEADLINE: For Foreigners, Pitfalls Abound

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: QINGYUAN, China

 BODY:
Despite a surge in investment and optimism about its economic prospects, China remains a difficult place for foreigners to do business.
American Standard, which made the Chinese President's whirlpool bathtub, says it is now making money at its joint venture in this small southern city, 40 miles north of Guangzhou. But in its first few years it lost money, and like other American ventures it faced an army of unexpected challenges. 
 Transporting goods is a constant headache in China, for trains and ships are often booked up and roads are jammed with trucks. It can take up to six weeks to ship toilets the 700 miles to Shanghai from Qingyuan, which is near Guangzhou.
Banks in this city do not know what traveler's checks are, so they don't accept them. When company executives first inquired about opening a letter of credit, a routine form of payment, the bank had never heard of such a thing. Another problem is the current shortage in the supply of dollars at the official swap centers. This may crimp imports and make it costly for companies to convert local currency profits into dollars.
 
Friction With Partners
 Disagreements and friction with Chinese partners in a joint venture are common. Here at American Standard, executives say the previous Chinese joint-venture partner bogged down decision-making with bureaucratic second-guessing and complained that the Americans were spending too much money when they went out for hamburgers in the hotel coffee shop.
Finding able employees can also be difficult, a legacy of four decades of lax standards at state-owned companies. Some employees sleep, gamble, drink or fight on the job, and the company had to dismiss an employee who would not stop playing cards when he was supposed to be working.
Then in December, city officials told American Standard that it would no longer be able to use ground water. Instead, the factory would have to tap into city water, with a connection fee of $18,000 in addition to monthly charges. The officials were approaching all the joint ventures and state enterprises in the city to propose water connections, and executives thought it had more to do with a need for money than a water shortage.
 
'The Hidden Costs'
 "The hidden costs of running a joint venture are very high," said Ronnie Y. Cheong, a soft-spoken 40-year-old Singaporean Chinese who is head of American Standard's factory here. "The problems will get more serious. They will have to find more ways of making money."
Local officials are not the only ones trying to extract extra money. The Singer Sewing Machine Company's joint-venture operation in Guangzhou receives three to four letters a month from big Chinese department stores that stock Singer's products. The announcements inform Singer that they are planning store-wide promotions and would appreciate "any assistance" -- meaning $500 donations.
"You have to pay," said Jeremy Watson, Singer's general manager here. "How can you not? I call it a tax, in brackets."

HEADLINE: Encouraged but Still Wary, Union Leaders Gather

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 14

 BODY:
Gerry and Jack, Rich and Al, and Lane, Morty and Moe, all stalwarts of the once-mighty House of Labor, have every reason to gloat after 12 years of Republican administrations that these men, some past 70, found the most hostile they have ever known. Suddenly, there's no one to hate.
"Look at what happened!" Gerald W. McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, cheered to hundreds of union officers on the eve of their annual winter gathering. That only three of the 32 A.F.L.-C.I.O. union presidents, Mr. McEntee among them, endorsed Bill Clinton in the primaries a year ago has been lost in the pro-labor hints and pronouncements from the new Administration. 
 But the joy many union officers feel after President Clinton's first weeks in office could wane Wednesday night, when they assemble before big-screen television to hear Mr. Clinton's address to Congress and find out more of what he means about the shared sacrifices of higher taxes and cuts in Government programs. They are wary about issues like how far he will go to keep jobs from fleeing south of the border, something unions expect from the trade agreement with Mexico and Canada.
 
A Time of Testing
 And for the unions themselves it is a time of testing. For years, they have blamed Ronald Reagan and George Bush for their shriveling membership, to just 15.8 percent of a 1992 work force of 104 million. That unions survive at all is remarkable, says Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
"We've maintained our membership in a most extraordinary combination of adverse circumstances," he said.
But the decline actually started in the 1950's, when more than a third of the work force was unionized. The question that always arises here is whether the leaders have lost touch with the troops. Only one of the presidents here is a woman, two are black, and most are in their 60's and 70's. In the growing services and retail industries, which account for nearly half the work force and have many women and blacks, less than 10 percent of the workers belong to unions.
 
Doing the Right Things
 But for now, the important thing to Big Labor is the Democrat in the White House who has been doing most of the right things. He reversed two of Mr. Bush's campaign-year executive orders that weakened unions. He appears committed to lifting President Reagan's ban on the hiring of the air traffic controllers whom he dismissed for striking 12 years ago. And he has promised to support legislation barring employers from dismissing strikers.
"We don't expect any President to be a rubber stamp," said Jack Sheinkman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union. "We got the change we wanted."
Only a year ago, Mr. Clinton was the seen as the slick and blow-dried yuppie from the conservative wing of the Democratic Party and a state historically unfriendly to unions.
Yuppie? Mr. Kirkland considered the word and replied, "I don't regard that term as applying to him."
 
His Trust Isn't Blind
 Moe Biller, president of the American Postal Workers Union and a supporter of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's noncandidacy last year, is about as skeptical as the leaders come. "He seems to be trying," he said of Mr. Clinton. "Trust him? At this point, yeah. But I don't put blind trust in anybody."
Here, Big Labor and the Democratic Party seem to be speaking with the common voice of the New Deal era. Labor says it wants what Mr. Clinton wants -- a revved-up economy, jobs, job training, health care. "I feel very good, very positive, very encouraged by the actions I see them taking," said Lynn Williams, retiring president of the United Steelworkers of America.
Mr. Williams said he was stunned to see the President go after the drug companies: "That was a long time coming, seeing a President stand up to the pharmaceutical industry and their indefensible price increases."
The unions have also been astonished to find in Robert B. Reich, whom few would have endorsed for the job, a Labor Secretary who behaves as if he is Mr. Clinton's top economic adviser.
 
Saying the Right Things
 Much as they would like it, people here say they do not expect Mr. Reich to build a Department of Organized Labor. "But the issue is, do they think unionization is good for workers?" said Jo-Ann Mort, spokesman for the clothing and textile workers union. So far, he has been saying all the right things, like supporting an increase in the minimum wage, now $4.25, and endorsing an extension of unemployment benefits before the unions even asked.
Indeed, rather than bicker with the Government, unions have begun bickering among themselves. They think the White House might just start taking their agenda into account. So for the first time in years, they risk discord among their memberships' sometimes divergent interests.
For example, Ron Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, would just as soon scrap the trade agreement. Morton Bahr, president of the Communications Workers of America, says the unions here will probably acknowledge that they are stuck with it. "But there has to be financial assistance," he says, for workers who lose jobs to Mexico.
On raising the minimum wage, they appear united in wanting it lifted to its traditional level of 50 percent of the average wage, now about $11.75, an increase to about $5.35. Mr. Reich has said he supports a 10 percent increase, to around $4.70 but has not indicated whether that might be just a first step.
A labor ally in Congress who is here seems ready for more. Representative William D. Ford of Michigan, who heads the House Committee on Education and Labor, said: "The idea of anything less than $5 makes no sense. I don't know of any part of this country where anybody could subsist on less."
For at least as long as the love feast lasts, unions say they are willing to join the President in his appeal for sacrifice. But are they prepared to swallow tax increases for their members?
"Sure!" said Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers. "You can't turn things around with just the richest people."

HEADLINE: Hope Undimmed, Voters See Jobs as True Test for Clinton

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 14

 BODY:
 A winter wind gusting across the parking lot of a sprawling General Motors plant concentrates the mind, so the men and women hustling in and out for the afternoon shift change are succinct in their politics.
Nannygate may have launched a thousand newspaper columns in recent weeks, but there is little doubt here about the main event and the big test of the Clinton Presidency. "Keep the economy going," said John Adkins, 52 years old. "Keep us going. Keep us in a job." 
 This is reality-check time in American politics, and it is filled with opportunities and risks for the new President, judging from interviews with more than three dozen voters around this bellwether region, where former President George Bush and Mr. Clinton struggled fiercely for the loyalties of the Midwestern heartland. Opportunities because many voters here, unlike the pundits, are reluctant to declare the honeymoon over. Factory workers, retired people and homemakers talked unapologetically about their hopes that Mr. Clinton would, this week, begin to address the nation's economic problems decisively.
 
'I Think He'll Try'
 "You have to give him time," said Phyllis Pursiful, a 45-year-old food-service worker at the University of Dayton, after acknowledging and setting aside a few misgivings of her own. "I think he'll try."
Opportunities, as well, because many people talked with unusual, if grudging, acceptance of new taxes. The 1992 Presidential campaign in general, and the candidacy of Ross Perot in particular, seems to have left people with a sense that the deficit has to be tamed -- for the good of everyone. "I think he's doing the best he can with what he's got to work with," said Juanita Erbaugh, who runs a small day-care operation. "I think we'd have taxes no matter who got in."
But there are risks for Mr. Clinton as well here. Hopes are fragile. The cynicism that fueled the 1992 campaign is just below the surface, and people are holding Mr. Clinton to his promise of tax "fairness."
"I think he should tax the real rich," said Jessie Bigler, who turned out on a frigid Saturday afternoon for a senior citizens lunch at the local Democratic club. Viola Fearing, a friend, chimed in, "The real rich," and a few minutes later added, "I also don't think all those big shots in Washington should get raises all the time."
 
People Are Nervous
 Up at the front of the Democrats' hall was a huge, heroic portrait of the man invoked more than once when people talked of the challenge facing Mr. Clinton: Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
Montgomery County, which includes the city of Dayton, was an extremely competitive area in last fall's election. Mr. Clinton ultimately eked out a very narrow victory over Mr. Bush with Mr. Perot a respectable third. The Dayton area is heavily reliant on General Motors, which has about 20,000 employees in the region, and on Wright Patterson Air Force Base, which employs about 27,000. While unemployment has run below the national average, the vagaries of the defense and automobile industries elsewhere keep people here nervous.
"One of the reasons for that," said Robert Premus, an economics professor at Wright State University here, "is that this region had a series of major plant closings back in the 70's and the early 80's. We're talking plants taking out 5,000 jobs at a clip. I think people were concerned they'd have more of the same."
Wesley Wells, president of Local 775 of the International Union of Electronic, Electrical, Salaried, Machine and Furniture Workers, also argued, "In this valley, we've got people concerned about where their kids are going to work, what kind of jobs they're going to get."
For all these reasons and more, Mr. Clinton's promise to preserve and rebuild the manufacturing job base is taken very, very seriously here. Don Rich, who works at General Motors and heads his local union's political committee, argues that the good-paying manufacturing jobs that were once a solid path to the middle class are simply less and less available. "There's nothing a kid from high school can go to now," Mr. Rich said, noting that the average age at the G.M. plants was now in the late 40's. "An inner-city kid just doesn't have a chance."
 
Willingness to Give Time
 This sense that the problems in the economy run deep works to Mr. Clinton's advantage with many voters. For example, Larry Newberry, another auto worker, dismisses the early negative reviews of Mr. Clinton's performance, demanding, "What can a person do in -- what's he been in, three weeks? four weeks? We've had 12 years of being sold down the river, and I think two or three weeks is not going to make much of a difference."
Moreover, Mr. Clinton's carefully orchestrated buildup to his economic address has gotten through: "Cutting the White House staff was an important first step," said Suzanne James, a home health-care aide in Dayton, who urged the President to move on quickly to cutting Congressional benefits.
But Mr. Clinton's backtracking on campaign promises has also gotten through to many voters, and while many are tolerant, some are not.
"He should do what he promised," said Betty Shaw, a 62-year-old retiree shopping at the Wright-Patterson commissary on a busy Friday afternoon. "He promised the middle class they would get a tax cut and there would be jobs. I've been a Democrat all my life, but I don't think I've ever been as disappointed."
And even some committed deficit-cutters, like Bill Cheslock, a guidance counselor who said he had voted for Mr. Perot, voiced skepticism that the revenue raised by new taxes would really go toward balancing the books. "If I were convinced it would go to the deficit, it wouldn't bother me," Mr. Cheslock said.
 
People Are Ready
 For all of that, most people interviewed seemed convinced that the nation needed dramatic economic medicine, although they were pleased that Mr. Clinton had virtually ruled out a freeze in Social Security cost-of-living adjustments.
"He'd better not touch that," said Millie Klepinger, 80, as her friends nodded assent.
People seemed ready for something big. "We think there will be taxes, but I think he's going to try to get things under control, don't you?" asked Wanda Crum, who also works for G.M.
The district's Congressman, Tony P. Hall, a Democrat, said he sensed the same anticipation throughout the area. Back in Dayton this weekend, Mr. Hall told a reporter that Mr. Clinton would set the tone for the rest of his Administration in the next 10 days. The sense of moment is, indeed, strong.
"There is hope here," Mr. Hall said. "There's an anxiety, a nervousness, an anticipation. They're waiting. This is what they voted for. They want change."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1993
 
The Economy 
 President Clinton is seeking to sell his economic program with one of the most intensive public relations blitzes ever staged from the White House. He will deliver his first televised address from the Oval Office tonight as part of an elaborate buildup intended to set the stage before the package is presented to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday. [Page A1.]
This is a time filled with opportunities and risks for the new President, judging from interviews with more than three dozen voters in the Midwest. Unlike the professional pundits, many voters are reluctant to declare the honeymoon over. [A1.]
Union leaders will be watching the President closely after years of exclusion from Republican administrations. [A10.]
The Clinton economic plan will trumpet spending for education, job training and public works as the key to building a richer nation. But these investments could prove a big gamble, since the public may not see the benefits for years -- if ever. [D1.]
American corporations have mounted an offensive, attacking the White House plan to increase the corporate income tax by asserting that it collides with the President's goal of stimulating investment and jobs. [D1.]
Central New Jersey, a hub of the pharmaceutical industry, is feeling pressed by the campaign to contain health costs. [B1.]
 
International
Regional trade agreements are providing a big spur to Latin America's economies. The accords also drop tariffs for overseas trade, sharply expanding markets for U.S. companies. [D1.]
China has finally begun to generate an industrial revolution and the nucleus of a middle class eager to buy foreign products that used to be unavailable to the nearly 1.2 billion people within Chinese borders. [A1.] The Clinton Administration has begun to review trade policies toward China, but does not expect to reach any decisions for a month or two. [A6.]
Giat Industries of France won a $3.5 billion order for battle tanks from the United Arab Emirates. The losing bidders are General Dynamics and Vickers P.L.C. of Britain. [D2.]
OPEC's oil ministers began talks on reducing oil production, with small and large producers disagreeing over what constitutes equitable burdens. [D4.]
Kodak is sharply curtailing its research activities in Japan, seeking voluntary resignations and telling college students it had agreed to hire that there would be no jobs for them. [D4.]
 
Companies
Foodmaker Inc. has canceled plans to open 85 restaurants this year, citing declining sales following news reports of food poisonings at its Jack in the Box fast-food chain. [D1.]
This is the time of year that makes or breaks gross revenues for seed companies like Pioneer Hi-Bred International. [D1.]

The Media Business
Why would anyone want to buy The New York Post? No one can answer with certainty what has drawn Steven Hoffenberg and other potential buyers, but there is no shortage of theories. Confidence of earning a profit is not one of them. [D1.]
ABC's ratings for Oprah Winfrey's interview of Michael Jackson rivaled those for the Super Bowl and had programmers and advertisers talking in cosmic terms. Bill Carter: Television. [D5.]
General Motors says it doesn't plan to begin an advertising campaign or a public relations effort, addressing either NBC News's apology for broadcasting a rigged crash test of G.M. pickup trucks, or a broader dispute about the safety of its vehicles. [D5.]
George Slowik Jr. is making the leap from publisher of Publishers Weekly to publisher of Out, a gay magazine. He sees nothing curious about the shift. [D5.]

 Today's Column
An astronaut who once walked on the moon received a patent for a permanent space station he designed in his home office. Edwin E. (Buzz) Aldrin Jr. wants the station to be the core of a "complete family of spacecraft." Sabra Chartrand: Patents. [D2.]

HEADLINE: A Season for Selling Seeds to Sowers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JEFFERSON, Iowa, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Until his wife phoned with the news that their pickup truck had skidded off icy State Highway 4 into a ditch, Lindsey Larson had been happily reminiscing with Dan and Sue Tronchetti about their high school days. They had also been chatting about last year's bumper crops of corn and soybeans, and what he planned to plant this spring.
Mr. Larson's wife was not hurt, but he was anxious to help her get the truck back on the road. So he set his coffee cup down by the plate of cookies and quickly signed a check for the seed he was buying this year from the Tronchettis. "You fill in the amount when you get it totaled," he told Mrs. Tronchetti. 
 Except for the blank check and quick exit, the visit had been business as usual for the Tronchettis during Pioneer Days, the sometimes hectic but always convivial week in February when they and several hundred other Midwestern farmers who sell Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc.'s seed do a large chunk of their business. For Pioneer, the industry leader in seed, and for most of its rivals, this is the time of year that makes or breaks gross revenues.
 
Hybrids by the Hundreds
 "The farmer has quite a selection job," said Robert N. Wisner, a grain marketing economist at Iowa State University. "There are hundreds of different hybrids." Among the considerations for each corn variety: strength of the stalk; resistance to rot, insects and diseases; length of growing season, and the time it takes the ears dry after harvest.
Pioneer, which derives 80 percent of its sales from corn, has maintained a strategy of investing heavily in the development of premium products and then charging premium prices. That approach faltered during the 1980's when rivals seemed to be narrowing Pioneer's average-yield advantage, but the company has regained momentum in recent years.
"Our sales are up 30 percent this year," said Dan Tronchetti, 36, a farmer himself and now in his second year as a dealer, too. Besides Lindsey Larson, his customers include Lindsey's father, Duane, who stopped by to pay for his own order and ended up staying for lunch. Lindsey's brother, Loel, would come by later the same day.
"We even have an Asgrow dealer who's going to plant 100 percent Pioneer this year," Mr. Tronchetti added, referring to the Asgrow Seed Company, a unit of the Upjohn Company.
So far, 1993 looks like another prosperous year for Pioneer, despite the uncertainty for corn prices after last year's record harvest, which the Agriculture Department estimated at nearly 9.5 billion bushels.
Farmers here in central Iowa had record yields in 1992, and several Pioneer seed lines ranked among the most successful. Dealers say many farmers are now increasing the amount of Pioneer seed they plan to plant. Last year, the company estimates, its market share grew to 38.7 percent from 36.7 percent.
Other big seed companies are also expanding their business, mostly at the expense of smaller rivals. Corn is the nation's largest crop and, unlike hard wheat and others, cannot be produced at high yields from seed retained from the typical farmer's crop. More than 200 companies are involved in the business of distributing new seed corn each year, many of them small regional companies that repackage seed bred by others.
Most dealers, meanwhile, view seed sales as part time, and only the most successful net more than $30,000 a year from the business.
 
Warmth in the Warehouse
 The seed deals may be closed in a dealer's kitchen or parlor, in a storefront, or in an office set up in a corner of a warehouse like the huge metal shed the Tronchettis have rented on the outskirts of this town, an hour's drive northwest of Des Moines.
In nearly every case, the surroundings include a liberal supply of coffee and soft drinks, baked goods and other treats, and a comfortable space for neighbors to visit with each other and the dealer before any money changes hands.
"This is one of the few days we heat the warehouse," said Mr. Tronchetti, guiding a visitor past high stacks of corn and soybean bags to tables with snacks, Pioneer gifts and displays of awards to farmers who achieved yields of 200 bushels an acre last year.
Most dealers have a wide range of "thank you" gifts, from small items like pens and soil thermometers to green Pioneer jackets with the company logo. The Tronchettis give some away immediately and are raffling others.
At the storefront Pioneer dealership run by Clarence A. (Hap) Springer and his wife, Ruby, a few blocks away in the center of town, Mr. Springer shakes his head over the proliferation of gifts.
"You got to count on spending $5,000 to $10,000 on giveaways," Mr. Springer said. The Springers were the sole Pioneer dealer in this town for nearly 40 years, until the company allowed the Tronchettis to open up, after their negotiations to buy the Springers' farm supply store collapsed. Mr. Springer said that he has lost a handful of customers to the Tronchettis but that overall business was up.
Some farmers will spend a couple of hours socializing before completing their business in a few minutes. The Springers' store encourages such activity by the prominent location of a long, cushioned church pew Mr. Springer jokingly calls "the liars' bench."
 
Seed Money
 The deals seem to get more complicated each year. Farmers may till land owned by as many as 10 landlords -- retired locals, banks, corporations, out-of-state investors -- under a variety of cost-sharing arrangements. They may spend as little as $500 for five bags of a special variety of corn they want to test on 15 acres, or tens of thousands of dollars for hundreds of bags, each with 80,000 seeds.
Most also order soybean seeds at the same time, although not necessarily from Pioneer. Asgrow has been the longtime leader in soybeans. Pioneer, which entered that business only 15 years ago, says it is challenging for the top position, and dealers use the rising discounts based on total purchases to encourage customers to buy both types of seeds from them.
Mr. Tronchetti also keeps a sample bag of Pioneer alfalfa seed just outside the office door to remind his neighbors that the company sells more than corn and soybeans.
 
Promotions Elsewhere
 Other corn companies also have seed days and promotional events to close sales, many timed to come just before or after Pioneer Days. Dekalb Plant Genetics, the second-largest corn seed company, this year renewed a tradition by having some dealers organize lunches and presentations by company agronomists to small groups of farmers.
The Northrup King Company, which is neck and neck with ICI for third place in corn seed sales, calls its events Good Farmer days and typically concentrates them in March. Northrup is a subsidiary of Sandoz Ltd. of Switzerland, and ICI is owned by ICI P.L.C. of Britain.
The flood of checks now coming in is the end of a long selling process that actually began last summer, when farmers got a look at how their crops were doing. That is when they began to chat informally with dealers about what they might like to use the next year.
 
Field Work
 Such courtship gets more serious during harvest. Some dealers make it a point to visit customers in the fields. Mr. Springer, who gives his age as "over 70," likes to hitch a ride in combines to get first-hand impressions.
While Dan Tronchetti and his brother, Barry, harvest the family's crops, Sue drives out to customers' fields with a $7,000 weigh wagon that she and her husband bought at Pioneer's suggestion. The wagon gives customers an immediate reading on the productivity of Pioneer and other varieties, while Sue gives out candy bars and soda.
The fall is also the time when farmers get a look at the results in test plots, where side by side grow existing varieties and new seeds that Pioneer and other companies are considering marketing.
 
Ordering Early
 These days, with farmers getting much quicker and more complete information on the yield of their crops, many are willing to decide what they want for the next year within weeks of completing the harvest. Increasingly, orders are placed and even settled by early January. Pioneer is encouraging the trend by giving a 7 percent discount to orders completed by "year-end," which worked out to be Jan. 4 this year.
The key discount, though, is the 6 percent one that runs through Pioneer Days. After that, a farmer gets only 2 percent off full price for buying by early April. Other major companies compete by offering slightly better rates or slightly later closing dates.
The major thrust of the seed companies is to get farmers to buy earlier, said Mr. Wisner of Iowa State. That, along with the decline in the number of farmers and the increasingly businesslike approach of the survivors, may slowly be undermining the social and economic significance of events like Pioneer Days.
"The pace of life, even here in Greene County, has changed," Mr. Tronchetti said.
