HEADLINE: Clinton Gambles on Plan For Federal Spending

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
The economic plan that President Clinton introduces on Wednesday will trumpet spending for education, job training and public works as the key to building a richer nation, his aides say. But these investments could prove the biggest gamble of his Presidency.
The reason: the public may not see the benefits for years -- if ever. 
 Though these spending plans could put thousands of people to work quickly in highway construction or other projects, many experts say it will be 5 to 10 years before the measures produce a noticeable pickup in productivity and competitiveness, which is their underlying aim.
President Clinton is keen to spend more to help poor children by expanding Head Start, for example, but it will be a decade or more before these children enter the labor force as skilled workers. Similarly, it is likely to be a decade before an ambitious nationwide computer network is in place, enabling laboratories and businesses to communicate better and lower their costs.
 
Short-Term Impact
 Many Americans will no doubt want to see a tangible return on this spending soon because Mr. Clinton plans to increase investment by such a large amount -- aides say $140 billion to $200 billion over the next four years. Indeed, the bold promises of investment that helped elect Mr. Clinton in 1992 might come back to haunt him in the 1996 Presidential campaign if he has nothing to show for them by then.
"We can expect a payoff on these investment projects, maybe in four to six years," said David A. Aschauer, an economics professor at Bates College who is an expert on public-sector spending. "But a four-to-six year time horizon poses a serious political problem -- it's not conducive for voters to re-elect this Administration."
Some experts assert that many projects will never pay off at all. If big payoffs were feasible, they say, business would already be doing the spending.
If the economy grows at a strong rate through 1996, voters will probably not question Mr. Clinton's program. Many Americans will simply conclude that the program has worked, even if growth has come for other reasons, like increased exports.
But if the economy inches along slowly and unemployment remains high in 1996, Americans will probably scrutinize the spending plan and ask, "Where's the beef?"
Mr. Clinton then might have to use all his political skills to convince the public that the investments are not futile. The President, economists say, will have to tell Americans not to expect a short-term fix for economic problems decades in the making, like inadequate job training, crumbling bridges and overcrowded airports.
"America knows these problems have been accumulating for 15 years," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview. "There are no magic fixes, no magic bullets."
To justify his spending plan, the President is expected to explain how increased investment is essential for generating faster growth and higher living standards. In the view of many economists, the slowdown in American investment helps explain why American living standards are growing so slowly and why American industry has lost so much ground to its German and Japanese counterparts.
"By the decade's end, Japan and Germany were investing more than 12 times what we spend" as a percentage of their output "on roads, bridges, sewers and the information networks and technologies of the future," Mr. Clinton said during the Presidential campaign. "To reclaim the future, we must strive to close" this "investment gap."
 
For the Children
 In his inaugural address, Mr. Clinton called for sacrifice -- including consuming less today to allow more public and private investment for tomorrow -- to build a brighter future for America's children. With this in mind, the big economic question is whether Mr. Clinton can persuade Americans -- who in the 1980's seemed addicted to feel-good oratory and living beyond their means -- to wait for long-term results.
"What he has to say to people is, 'I'm doing this for your children. They're the ones who are going to be the beneficiaries,' " said Herbert Stein, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Richard M. Nixon.
According to Administration officials, Mr. Clinton's economic plan will include spending on airports, bridges, highways, high-speed railroads, pollution-fighting equipment, sewers and an information network linking computers across the nation.
But many people, especially conservatives, are skeptical. "The idea that there are huge returns to infrastructure investments just waiting to be plucked is wrong, in my opinion," Allan Meltzer, an economics professor at Carnegie-Mellon University, said.
Speaking about computer networks and pollution equipment, Mr. Meltzer added: "If these projects had a fast payback, you wouldn't need the Government to come in and do it. Businesses would be rushing to do it."
There is another side to Mr. Clinton's investment plan, one calling for better education and job training. This effort will include sending all poor children to Head Start day-care programs, providing more for public schools and creating a nationwide apprentice program to teach skills to students who do not go to college.
"Fully funding Head Start or immunizing all children -- these things have a payback," Mr. Reich said. "There is a huge public payback in terms of higher productivity and lower social costs, but those paymakers are not immediate, some do not come until these children are teen-agers or even later."
 
Realistic Expectations
 Administration officials say some aspects of Mr. Clinton's investment plans will provide quick returns, while others, like plans to build high-speed trains, might not produce results until well into the next century.
Beyond the issue of time, many economists worry that a Government prone to pork-barrel politics will choose projects with dubious payoffs. Critics conjure up images of six-lane highways into the hills of West Virginia.
Mr. Clinton's plan to spend far more on job training should in theory make tens of thousands of workers more productive within a year or two -- and these workers and their companies should feel the return on that investment fairly soon.
Repairing roads also should produce quick results. "Fixing potholes means fewer broken axles, less wear and tear on tires and fewer alignments," said Roger E. Brinner, chief economist for DRI/McGraw Hill, an economics consulting firm in Lexington, Mass. "That should help drivers in Boston and truckers on interstate highways."
But how soon these things will translate into a one-tenth of one percent increase in productivity or economic growth is another question.
"All this stuff is going to be gradual," said Charles L. Schultze, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Jimmy Carter. "You have to think in terms of decades, which is not to say it shouldn't be done. You have to tell people to be realistic, and they should understand that Rome wasn't built in a day."
Building an overpass to relieve traffic congestion -- and reduce shipping costs -- often takes four or more years from design to completion. An airport takes even longer, and building a nationwide computer network might take a decade or more.
While acknowledging that such projects might take five years to produce noticeable gains in productivity, Jeff Faux, director of the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research group, said, "In the first few years these projects will produce a lot of economic stimulus." He said that spending about $40 billion more a year on highways and other projects would create almost one million more jobs and stimulate billions in private investment.
Mr. Stein, the economist in the Nixon Administration, is convinced that if Mr. Clinton presents a cogent case for investment, Americans will prove willing to wait for a long-term payoff.
"Americans have typically invested in their children," he said. "They broke the Great Plains, they plowed all that land so that their children could live better than they did."

HEADLINE: Corporations Attack Plan To Lift Taxes

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Even before President Clinton introduces his economic package, American corporations have mounted an offensive, attacking his plan to increase the corporate income tax by asserting that it collides with his goal of stimulating investment and jobs.
Lobbyists' letters are pouring into the White House to protest such an increase, which Administration officials hint will raise the corporate income tax to 36 percent from 34 percent now. 
 "Everyone knows that we have to create more jobs because we have a relatively fragile recovery," said Dirk Van Dongen, co-chairman of the Tax Reform Action Coalition, a group of 300 corporations and trade associations. "This proposal is counterproductive because it takes away from businesses the very asset they need to create jobs: their surplus dollars."
 
Sharing the Burden
 Administration officials and many Democrats defend plans for a higher corporate income tax, suggesting that the pre-emptive howls from the business community show that it is acting like any other special interest group whose ox has been gored.
Corporations should join all other Americans in making some sacrifice to reduce the deficit, advocates of the tax increase say. Besides, Mr. Clinton's political advisers have told the President that before he calls on the middle class to pay higher taxes, he must ask the well-off to cough up more revenues -- and that means asking corporations to pay more, too.
Supporters of an increase in the corporate income tax note that as a percentage of the nation's gross domestic product, revenues from this tax have plunged 40 percent from the 1970's and more than 50 percent from the 1960's.
Advocates of the increase say the main reason for this decline is that the corporate tax rate has been reduced repeatedly, while business lobbyists say the primary reason is that corporate profits are down.
Supporters of a higher corporate tax rate see the issue as a matter of equity. "Over the last decade or two there has been a shift away from the corporate income tax and toward the personal income tax and, in particular, payroll taxes," said Max Sawicky, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal Washington-based research group. "A little bit of a tilt in the opposite direction is not worth fighting about."
Increasing the corporate income tax to 36 percent is expected to increase tax collections by $6 billion a year. The Government expects to collect $105 billion from the tax this year without a rate increase.
 
Bentsen's Backing
 When President Clinton spoke to business executives and their Washington lobbyists last week, he said that Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen had convinced him that if the Administration raises the top personal income tax rate, it should raise the corporate income tax.
Treasury officials fear that if the top personal rate were to rise to 36 percent, from 31 percent now, and the corporate income tax were to remain at 34 percent, that would encourage financial shenanigans in which individuals and partnerships formed corporations so their income would be taxed at the lower rate.
Many companies see the plan for a higher corporate tax as a betrayal of the spirit of the 1986 tax act, in which businesses gave up loopholes for a lower corporate income tax.
"The idea was to take taxation out of business decision-making, to make taxation as simple and fair as possible, so that business could focus on economics in their decisions" said David Berenson, national director of tax policy for Ernst & Young. "If you ratchet up corporate taxes, that means more business decisions will be based on taxes, and not on efficiency and what's best for the economy."
 
Competitive Concerns
 An argument against this tax increase is that by raising the cost of capital it would give American companies one more incentive to move operations overseas.
Several business executives interviewed said the plan to increase the corporate tax flew in the face of Mr. Clinton's plans to re-establish an investment tax credit. The former will reduce after-tax profits and discourage investment, while the latter will increase after-tax profits and encourage investment.
 
Industries Divided
 Some industries are far more opposed to the corporate tax increase than others. Retailers, who have a high effective tax rate and few write-offs, are livid about the plan, while capital-intensive industries, like steel, appear willing to go along with the increase in exchange for getting the investment tax credit back.
James M. Poterba, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said raising the corporate income tax would penalize companies that have already made investments, while the investment tax credit would favor new assets.
"The proposal on the table is a move toward encouraging incentives to new investment and financing it with taxes on old assets," Mr. Poterba said. "That should be a pro-investment, efficiency-enhancing policy."
If the goal is to encourage investment, he said, then it would be wise economics to finance the investment tax credit with a consumption tax, rather than a corporate income tax. Whether it would be wise politics is, of course, a different question.

HEADLINE: Why Would Anybody Want To Be Owner of The Post?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
For sale: Newspaper losing $300,000 a week with poor niche in highly competitive market. Unique opportunity. Previous owners have lost tens of millions of dollars.
Such an ad never appeared in The New York Post, but a candid description of the business challenges facing anyone buying New York City's most troubled tabloid newspaper would describe it that way. 
 So why, people in and out of the newspaper industry ask, has The Post lured not only Steven Hoffenberg, its would-be publisher, but, apparently, a handful of other well-financed people who appear interested in stepping in if he falters?
"It's very, very hard to make a case that this is a rational investment," said John S. Reidy, newspaper analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
The Post has been weakened by years of losses, slipping advertising revenue and declining readership. During his ownership of the paper, Peter S. Kalikow has tried to repair a fundamental financial flaw -- the absence of a Sunday edition. For many publishers, the Sunday paper brings in more than half their annual profit.
In the end, Mr. Kalikow's Sunday edition failed, ceasing publication in November 1989 after eight months, and a loss, he said, of $25 million. And that, Mr. Reidy and other newspaper analysts say, is only a hint of the depth of The Post's problems.
Mr. Hoffenberg is buying The Post by putting up $6 million to, in essence, replace Mr. Kalikow's bank as the newspaper's lender and by promising to provide the cash it needs.
He also said he would pay as much as $4.5 million in employees' withholding taxes that Mr. Kalikow failed to pay. Mr. Kalikow's failure to turn over that money to the Government helped precipitate the newspaper's financial crisis.
As any buyer would have to under these circumstances, Mr. Hoffenberg is assuming The Post's liabilities. He is also taking over the collection of money owed it.
Mr. Kalikow has not opened the newspaper's books to anyone other than Mr. Hoffenberg, but people involved in efforts to save it said the estimates put The Post's liabilities at $11 million, apart from separate pension obligations.
About half of the liabilities other than for pensions, it is believed, would have to be paid only if the paper closed and the owner had to make severance payments to employees.
The other $5 million to $6 million, people involved in the transaction said, would be offset if The Post's new buyer could collect $6 million to $7 million owed the paper.
The Post's pension liabilities may be about $20 million. Some of those who have been involved in financial discussions at the newspaper said there may now be money available to cover only about half of that.
A buyer would become responsible for the total obligation, including finding a way to finance the pension obligations not currently provided for.
Under Federal law, Mr. Kalikow, as the seller of the business, would remain responsible for the pensions for five years as a backup to the new owner. But his responsibility may be largely theoretical, as he is bankrupt.
No one can answer with certainty what has drawn Mr. Hoffenberg, and other potential buyers, to The Post. But among those closest to the deal, there is no shortage of theories. Here is a sampling of the best of them:
THE ALTRUIST. This is Mr. Hoffenberg's favorite. He says he wants to save a New York institution and was drawn into the role of publisher more deeply than he had planned because of the severity of the paper's financial crisis. He has repeatedly denied any other intention.
FIGHT THE REGULATORS. This is the Securities and Exchange Commission's favorite. Agency lawyers broadly hint that Mr. Hoffenberg popped up at The Post only because the watchdogs were on the verge of filing a suit accusing him of defrauding investors in his Towers Financial Corporation.
They suggest that he hoped to help himself by harnessing the status and influence that comes with being a newspaper publisher.
They also suggest he is using The Post to create a platform and a business vehicle for himself as his old one appears to be collapsing under the weight of the S.E.C. attack. Suggestions that he may put The Post in bankruptcy have added fuel to the idea that he is looking for a financial safe haven.
DEBT COLLECTION PLAY. This may be Mr. Hoffenberg's least favorite. It contends that he may want to "save" The Post as little more than a debt-collection maneuver, much like those he has specialized in at Towers.
By buying the newspaper essentially with the $6 million in credit -- and at little real cost to himself because the money would be replenished unless The Post's problems multiplied -- he could, according to this theory, profit by collecting its debts (making, perhaps, $5 million quickly).
THE GREATER FOOL. A standby in the newspaper business, it suggests that anyone who would buy a paper believes there will always be someone else who will be similarly entranced by the idea of becoming a guest at the cocktail parties of the powerful. And that next buyer might even be willing to provide the seller with a healthy profit for his trouble.
Adherents of this theory contend that no other explanation could explain why anyone would buy a newspaper that lost lots of money, even under the stewardship of as shrewd a newspaper operator as Rupert Murdoch. Just the 1987 loss, Mr. Murdoch's last year as publisher before he sold to Mr. Kalikow, is reported to have been $17 million.
REAL ESTATE PLAY.It suggests that entrepreneurs see The Post's river-view headquarters in lower Manhattan as a low-cost development site.
Under Mr. Hoffenberg's purchase contract, the Bankers Trust Company has reduced its mortgage on the building to $15 million from $25 million, essentially giving The Post's buyer a block of Manhattan real estate suitable for, say, an apartment tower.
The only problem with this theory is that, in the still depressed New York real estate market, it is not clear that anyone other than a starry-eyed newspaper suitor would buy The Post's patch of real estate.
BETTER MANAGEMENT. This one is said to be a favorite of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and his aides, who have taken an active role in trying to persuade monied people to buy The Post.
They imply that Mr. Kalikow may have lacked the management savvy a new owner could apply profitably. A new editorial strategy -- more clearly defining The Post's target audience, for example, or turning it once again into an afternoon paper -- might revive its franchise, proponents of this notion say. .
The theories keep coming, including wild scenarios of as-yet-undetected methods of milking dollars from The Post, whose union-level employees have not had a raise in seven years.
But none of the theories seem fully satisfying in the search to understand why a newspaper that has teetered on the edge for years appears to be drawing buyers, including Mr. Hoffenberg.
"Everybody in New York is asking: What is going on with this guy?" said Fred Drasner, the co-publisher with Mortimer B. Zuckerman of The Daily News.
Mr. Drasner, no novice at newspaper finance, said he was one New Yorker who cannot completely explain the lure of The Post.

HEADLINE: Pharmaceuticals' Blue Chip May Be Fading

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOMERVILLE, N.J., Feb. 10

 BODY:
Central New Jersey, an international center of the pharmaceutical industry, is being pushed to center stage in the United States' campaign to contain health costs.
Scattered across the state's midsection -- in the rolling hills here, the corporate campuses of Princeton, the urban clutter of New Brunswick and elsewhere -- is the world's largest concentration of companies that create and market prescription drugs, companies whose steady growth and investment have been the envy of other corporations even in recessionary years. 
 Now, the pharmaceutical industry finds itself under siege from insurers, hospitals, Congress and the Clinton Administration, which calls the containment of health-care costs a major priority in its fight to reduce the Federal deficit. On Friday, the President singled out the industry for criticism, calling its prices "shocking" and saying drug companies are spending too much on advertising and lobbying.
In New Jersey, sometimes called the medicine chest of the nation because it is home to the main research arms of 10 of the world's 18 largest drug companies, the big question now is how the pharmaceutical makers will adapt: whether they can continue to stand out as models of growth, profitability and, by many measures, community involvement.
 
Fear of Turning Gray
 Some fear that economic and political pressure will transform the industry from a cutting-edge producer of high-technology products into just another graying American manufacturer. That has threatening implications across a region reeling from huge manufacturing job losses, including the impending shutdown of the General Motors assembly plant in Tarrytown, N.Y., and thousands of layoffs by I.B.M.
In what some analysts call an omen for the industry, Bristol-Myers Squibb said in October that it was cutting 2,000 jobs in its pharmaceutical group, based in Princeton.
New Federal regulations, combined with fierce competition in the industry, "are going to drive the margins out of the pharmaceutical business over the next five years," said Raymond C. Egan, executive vice president of the Bristol-Myers Squibb group, which has 38,000 employees.
Although fewer than 300 people would be laid off in New Jersey, where the pharmaceutical group has 6,000 employees, other cuts are to be made in the state through attrition.
 
'Pressure on Prices'
 "There is certainly going to be increased pressure on prices, and adjustments have to be made," said Patricia Danzon, a professor of health-care management at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business.
She said cuts may come first in administration and sales. Other experts expect cuts in research and development, which, like administration and sales, are heavily concentrated in New Jersey.
"The health-care industry in the United States has been the most innovative in the world," said Jack Herdklotz, the president of Hoechst-Roussel Pharmaceuticals, a German company that built its Somerville headquarters in 1970. It is completing work on a $20 million molecular neurobiology research center here to develop drugs for Alzheimer's disease and other disorders.
 
Traditions of Involvement
 He said that to contain costs, Hoechst-Roussel was considering producing more generic drugs, and relying more on licensing or other cooperative ventures with outside laboratories and researchers.
Cutbacks could affect more than the pharmaceutical concerns' own employees, since most of the companies have long traditions of community involvement in New Jersey.
In New Brunswick, a once-declining industrial city where Johnson & Johnson built a new headquarters in 1975, the company in January opened a day-care and "parenting center" for teen-age mothers at New Brunswick High School.
In Nutley, Hoffmann-La Roche won an award last year from the Environmental Protection Agency, in part for its programs to recycle waste. Other drug makers have been widely cited for volunteer work and for gifts to community programs.
 
'The Most Admired Industry'
 In its current issue, Fortune Magazine calls pharmaceutical makers "the most admired industry" in the United States and singles out four New Jersey drug makers for praise: Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, Johnson & Johnson, Bristol-Myers Squibb and the Schering-Plough Corporation, based in Madison.
Brenda J. Bacon, who is Gov. Jim Florio's chief of management planning and his top adviser on health-care issues, said, "We need health-care reform, but not by harming one of our strongest industries, and we are sure the Clinton Administration does not want to solve one problem by creating another."
The debate over how to contain medical costs is creating political headaches for Mr. Florio and his administration. Although he is a close political ally of Mr. Clinton, the Governor is under pressure from his own state's pharmaceutical executives to carry their message to Washington.
Ms. Bacon said Mr. Florio planned to meet with top pharmaceutical executives the week of Feb. 14. She said he would urge them to agree to voluntary limits on price increases for prescription drugs, but only if the same limits were agreed to by the entire pharmaceutical industry.
 
Division on Price Limits
 So far, two of the New Jersey companies -- Merck and Hoffman La Roche -- have told state officials they would agree to voluntary limits, in which their prices for drugs already on the market would not be raised above the consumer price index. Others have balked, saying the idea is too broad and leaves them no flexibility in pricing drugs that have only small, highly specialized markets.
New Jersey drug makers were having problems even earlier. Bristol-Myers Squibb, the only major New Jersey pharmaceutical maker that has announced job cuts in recent years, complains about a set of Federal rules made in the Bush Administration requiring pharmaceutical companies to charge Medicaid recipients no more for their drugs than they charge large-volume buyers.
That law has forced some companies to repay large amounts to state Medicaid programs. Bristol-Myers Squibb said it would owe Medicaid $100 million in rebates this year.
The drug companies have been squeezed by a growing reliance on health maintenance organizations, which vigorously negotiated discounts on prescription medications by buying them in bulk. And they have felt pressure from large hospitals and clinics, which have adopted limits on what they will pay for drugs.
 
Convenience or Low Cost
 One result has been a rapid increase in the use of generic drugs, which cost far less than their brand-name counterparts, or medications that may require patients to sacrifice convenience for lower costs. For instance, many customers are opting for drugs that are cheaper but require more frequent doses.
This month, the Clinton Administration said that it would favor a Federal program to buy vaccines en masse for the lowest price possible, and provide them free for school immunization programs.
In a report to the Senate that was bitterly contested by the industry, researchers concluded that several companies that had pledged not to raise their prices faster than the rate of inflation had done so in 1992.
"This report adds to the mounting evidence that voluntary price restraints simply don't work," said Sen. David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat. Among those singled out were Merck and American Home Products.
 
Vast Profits in 1980's
 Despite the mounting economic and political heat, industry analysts say they doubt that the nation's largest pharmaceutical companies will veer far from the strategies that produced vast profits in the 1980's.
"The lifeblood of the industry is new products," said Robert Hodgeson, a health care analyst for Cowan and Company in Boston. "These companies will be looking for efficiencies, but I don't see major cuts in research and development."
That may help New Jersey, which has become a global vortex of drug research. A study by Hal P. Eastman, associate dean of the graduate school of management at Rutgers University, found that the state's large pharmaceutical companies increased their annual research and development budgets nearly fourfold in the 1980's, to a total of $1.93 billion in 1990.
"Our most important approach is still to find breakthrough therapies," said Timothy G. Rothwell, president and chief executive officer of Sandoz, the United States subsidiary of a diversified Swiss chemical and drug concern, which established its base in East Hanover during the early 1950's.
Despite the potential threat from new Federal regulations, Mr. Rothwell said the company needed access to American scientists, hospitals and clinical trials. By the end of the 1990's, he said, it will increase its staff of scientists to 1500 from 600, and its overall employment in East Hanover to 4,000 from 2,500.
"We know the environment is changing, and there will be more pressure on prices," he said. "But our intent is not to slow down."

HEADLINE: Rent-to-Own Stores Becoming a Consumer Issue

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
Buying on the installment plan is the American way. But it requires credit -- unless you're shopping at what is known as a rent-to-own store. These stores lease everything from televisions to vacuum cleaners on a weekly or monthly basis to customers -- without the need for credit checks and with the promise of eventual ownership.
Although installment payments are low -- usually less than $20 a week -- the charges at these outlets are far higher than the interest rates charged by banks or credit-card companies, often running as much as 200 percent. As a result, products end up costing three or four times their retail price. 
 Customers, most of whom are low-income individuals, end up paying $1,000 or more for a $200 television. And the sales tactics of these outlets have also been called into question by consumer advocates.
 
 
New Jersey Legislation
 In fact, rising consumer complaints as the industry has expanded over the last decade have led 31 states to pass laws to regulate these operations. The latest to consider such legislation is New Jersey, where a bill was introduced in the General Assembly last month requiring increased disclosure to customers by rent-to-own operations.
The proposed New Jersey law -- as well as the measures that passed in the 31 other states -- does not go as far as some consumer advocates would like and is, in fact, supported by the rent-to-own industry.
"There's no question that these laws provide a significant amount of substantive protection to consumers," said Chris Korst, legal director for Rent-A-Center, the nation's largest rent-to-own chain with over 1,000 stores and sales of $600 million to $700 million a year -- a 25 percent share of the market.
But critics say these laws do little to protect consumers from what Neil Fogerty, director of the Consumers League of New Jersey, based in Montclair, characterizes as "loan sharking" by such operations.
 
 
Disclosures Required
 The New Jersey legislation requires certain disclosures, including the weekly cost of an item to be rented, the number of payments required before ownership, the total cost to the consumer at the end of an agreement and a description of the goods.
But only Pennsylvania puts a cap, of 18 percent, on the annual interest rate a rent-to-own store can charge. The other states excuse rent-to-own stores from compliance with state usury laws that limit interest rates. Unlike Pennsylvania, they classify these transactions as rentals rather than sales -- as does the New Jersey bill -- which disturbs some consumer advocates.
It is the promise of ownership that attracts customers to the stores, argues Dave Sciarra of the New Jersey Public Advocate's office, a state agency that opposes the bill introduced in New Jersey. He maintains that the stores are not just renting, but selling merchandise.
 
 
'Service to People'
 Yet the industry says that without its service many Americans would not be able to buy common household items. "We provide a service to people who don't necessarily have the means to put down a huge down payment or buy a product outright," said Nancy Johnson, spokeswoman for Thorn EMI Rental Americas, which owns Rent-A-Center.
About 20 percent of Rent-A-Center customers are unemployed or on public assistance, according to Mr. Korst.
"Rent-to-own companies gear their advertisements and sales practices to low-income people who do not believe that they have a lot of credit options," said Margot F. Saunders, managing attorney in the Washington office of the National Consumer Law Center, which is based in Boston.
Charlene Mathis, who lives in a public housing project in Jersey City, for example, agreed to pay one rent-to-own store more than $21 a week for 87 weeks to buy a television and a videocassette recorder. The total cost came to more than $1,800 for items that retail for about $250 each. That represents an annual interest rate of more than 200 percent.
 
 
'I Learned My Lesson'
 Ms. Mathis, who never completed her contract because she could not keep up her payments, went to Rent-A-Center because she didn't have $500 but did have $21. "I was trying to make a bargain," she said recently. "I learned my lesson. I went out there and saved my money and bought a new TV for $90."
As Ms. Mathis learned, retail stores are cheaper. At Provideo, a retailer in Washington that allows customers to pay through a two-year installment plan, a $250 television would cost no more than $330, at an interest rate of about 19 percent, according to the store's manager. Customers who want to buy on credit fill out a short application form and the store runs a credit check, which means customers must have a major credit card or have paid off a loan.
At Rent-A-Center, there is no credit check. The company simply verifies the residence given, the source of income and contacts one or two of the six references a customer is required to provide.
The industry's rapid expansion is evidence that consumers like rent-to-own companies, Mr. Korst says. Modeled after a marketing practice outlined in English law called hire-purchase, the rent-to-own industry has grown swiftly since it emerged in this country in the late 1960's.
In 1992, there were 8,000 stores, up from 3,000 in 1983, according to the Association of Progressive Rental Organizations, a trade group. The industry, which includes large chains and operators who own only two to three stores, rang up $3.5 billion in revenues in 1990, according to the group. Most stores are in inner cities.
 
 
'Unique Package'
 "We are growing because we combine a unique package of goods and services that people can't find anywhere else," like free maintenance, free delivery and no long-term commitment, Mr. Korst said.
Yet in addition to weekly payments, there are other charges, including late fees, home pickup fees, and liability and reinstatement fees, levied if a customer who has missed a payment wants to continue the agreement.
Mr. Korst calls consumer advocates' attacks on rent-to-own companies "utter nonsense" and denies that the businesses even charge interest. "An interest rate does not make any sense in a rental transaction that terminates every week or every month," he said, adding that only 25 percent of all contracts result in ownership.
Critics of the industry say that the high termination rates stem in large part from the industry's sales practices. Many outlets allow customers to fall behind on their payments early in their contracts, but use those late payments later in the cycle to repossess property.
 
Lawsuits Cited
 Practices such as this have led to individual and class-action lawsuits in Minnesota, Florida, North Carolina, Ohio and New Jersey.
Madeleine L. Houston, director of litigation for the Passaic County Legal Aid Society, filed a suit in 1990 on behalf of Iris Green, who had paid Continental Rentals in Paterson, N.J., close to $4,000 on five items before the property was repossessed when she could no longer afford to pay. The $4,000 was more than the full value of all the products. Ms. Houston charged that the stores should be covered under sales laws putting caps on interest rates.
One amendment being considered by New Jersey legislators is a provision mandating that once someone has paid double the cash price of an item, that person automatically owns it, according to Paul DiGaetano, the Republican Assemblyman who sponsored the legislation.

HEADLINE: Rural Home, a City Job and a Modem;
Technology Gives Professionals Best of 2 Worlds: Fast Track and a Woodstock Address

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 8

 BODY:
When the sleek purple, white and orange overnight delivery truck first pulled up to Shaun Johnston's quiet country lane, it looked to him like a spacecraft, so outlandish did it seem in that rustic setting.
But such courier trucks -- and modern wonders like fax machines and computer modems -- have made it possible for a graphic designer like Mr. Johnston and a growing number of other professionals from New York City to live a simple life in the country. 
 Only five or six years ago, advertisers, commercial photographers, video producers, corporate lawyers and book editors generally had to live in or near big cities like New York to survive. But new communications systems have enabled them to do business with customers around the world while living among the farms and hills of places like Ulster and Dutchess Counties.
 
High Response in Sleepy Place
 "I'm running a real high-quality, high-response operation from up here, and this is a sleepy place," says Mr. Johnston, who designs informational brochures for the pharmaceutical industry and, at the moment, labels for the Paul Newman food line.
The self-employed professionals who make up these cottage industries are distinctly different from the flower children of the 1960's and early 1970's who dropped out of the rat race and moved to the country to open leather and tie-dying shops. These professionals do not want to give up their satisfying, high-paying careers. They just want to live in a less frenzied locale.
And they are different from their long-rooted counterparts in the Hudson Valley whose businesses cater mainly to local residents. This new wave wants to sustain the glamour and electricity of doing business in Manhattan, and the newcomers have chosen homes close enough that they can go in for weekly meetings and catch up on industry gossip.
 
Far From Business Hubs
 The emergence of Stewart Airport outside Newburgh as an important hub even makes it possible for them to have national aspirations, to see clients in Toronto or Boulder, Colo., as Pete Mathieu does. Trying to move closer to his 104-acre farm, he started an advertising agency in the village of Montgomery -- population 2,000 -- whose accounts include Perrier and Celestial Seasonings.
"New York's got a sense of itself that isn't totally right," Mr. Mathieu said. "It matters less where you are than what you do."
The trend is hard to quantify. But various census studies of "business services" show sharp and persistent growth in counties like Ulster and Dutchess, said Dr. Ann E. Davis, director of the Marist College Bureau of Economic Research. The number of Dutchess residents employed in business services rose from 2,459 in 1986 to 3,784 in 1992. In Ulster, it jumped from 901 to 1,482.
Longtime residents are aware a new type of cottage industry is forming. From sidewalk chats with newcomers, and from the restaurants, shops and theaters that are catering to the tastes and wallets of the exurbanite influx, these residents realize that their lives, too, are changing.
"The number of such people is still very modest but is increasing very rapidly," said Geddy Sveikauskas, editor of The Woodstock Times.
 
Ties to the Other Village
 He sometimes needles the newcomers for their recidivist passions for artists' colonies like Woodstock.
"They want to see people they would see on Eighth Street," he said, referring to the bustling East Village commercial strip. "They feel that's what separates them from the boondocks."
Sandra Hilton, president of the Ulster County Board of Realtors, estimates that she and other real-estate agents sell 200 homes a year to transplanted professionals, many who were lured here by weekend homes.
"We have always had weekend buyers, but now a lot of New Yorkers are looking for permanent," she said. "They have business connections with the city, but don't physically have to live in the city."
In New York City, the life or death of a business can depend on speed. Clients want everything finished yesterday. Mr. Johnston and his wife, Susan, who designs catalogues for the Book of the Month Club and others, could not have maintained their clientele by promising them layouts and scripts in the mail.
 
Computers and Trucks
 Computers, with their telephone modems, make it possible for Mr. Johnston to transmit intricate layouts and stylishly doctored photographs to New York and get a response from a client within five minutes. Larger layouts and proofs can go aboard an express delivery truck and arrive at his client's Manhattan office the next morning.
"Your workday is between Federal Express delivery and Federal Express pickup," says Mr. Johnston, a native of England.
Allison Craig once worked for the high-powered advertising firm of Young & Rubicam. Four years ago she joined two ex-New Yorkers weary of the stress and the impersonality of large organizations, and, along with a fourth partner, started CCMR Advertising in Kingston, about 60 miles north of Madison Avenue.
The upstart firm's pitch to clients like Berlitz and United Press International is that they can offer a New York level of quality and experience but at a much lower price. Office rents in Kingston's historic quarter are 15 percent cheaper than in Manhattan. And with Woodstock nearby, her agency can call on an assortment of musicians, artists and writers to turn out an ad or promotion.
 
Horseback in 15 Minutes
 "Our clients really don't care where we're located," she said. "They're looking for sound strategic thinking and good creative work and that can come as easily from Kingston as it can come from Manhattan."
On a wooded road just across the Hudson in Rhinebeck, George Langa runs a modern video studio that among its ventures produces in-flight entertainment for USAir.
"Fifteen minutes from here, I can be on a horse farm riding a horse," Mr. Langa likes to say. "Technology-wise, you're not isolated anymore. Life-style-wise, you are isolated, and that's a positive thing."
G. Brewster Cole, the chief executive of a 46-employee engineering firm specializing in municipal water distribution systems, realized three years ago that he could run his company from a telephone and computer. He moved up to a cabin in Woodstock, though he keeps a cot at his Little Falls, N.J., headquarters for weekly overnight visits.
 
Gradually Breaking Free
 Those who make the move do so gradually, and with considerable anxiety. After his New York company collapsed in 1988, Mr. Johnston felt somewhat lost and decided to work out of his one-acre weekend home in Tillson, a few miles north of New Paltz. Gaining a client, he boldly opened a one-room office in Kingston. It has now expanded into a six-room suite with five employees.
For three years, his wife, Susan, had to spend several days every week in New York away from him to continue designing catalogues for the book club.
"It was very difficult and I couldn't see how to break free because I loved my job," she recalled. "Then they started talking about bringing the Macintosh computer into the Book of the Month Club. And I said, 'Ha! This is my ticket out of the city.' "
Since November 1990, she has been working on a Macintosh in the backyard shed of their Tillson home. That shed also contains a studio in which Mrs. Johnston can pursue her other love, drawing pastel landscapes. She still travels into the city by bus one day a week for planning meetings and for her own psychic fix.
"I miss the camaraderie of an office," she acknowledges. "I miss showing my work and getting feedback. Working alone is very isolating."
Several weeks ago, the Johnstons found a buyer for the West End Avenue co-op they had been renting out, and while emptying the apartment they were surprised that they did not feel particularly sad.
"We left there a long time ago," Mrs. Johnston said.
The Kingston area lacks the critical mass of professionals some businesses demand. So when one of his computer graphics specialists recently left to have a child, Mr. Johnston spent several nervous days wondering how to replace her. But he met a good candidate right on the bus into New York.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Housing Organization Finds Itself in Another Cuomo's Hands

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
FIVE years ago, as the first 25 homeless families moved into an imaginative prefabricated housing project in Brooklyn, Andrew M. Cuomo pondered a future political career and reflected on his father's.
He said he would be reluctant to run for office from New York while his father was still Governor. Suppose Mario M. Cuomo happened to be holding office someplace else? 
 "He will be in New York State if he's serving in elective office," Andrew Cuomo said.
Since then, Governor Cuomo was re-elected again and passed up two opportunities to run for President. He is still in New York and if Washington beckons, it will most likely be for an appointive post. As of two weeks ago, though, Andrew Cuomo was in Washington as President Clinton's nominee for Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for Community Planning and Development.
The position will give him wide discretion and visibility to replicate nationally the policies his commission on the homeless recommended last year to Mayor David N. Dinkins. It will also give him a chance to lobby for the construction of homes for the homeless similar to the ones built in Brooklyn and elsewhere by Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged, or H.E.L.P., an organization Mr. Cuomo founded.
Mr. Cuomo's title has been retired, but his organization has been placed in good hands. The executive vice president will be Ilene Margolin, who is currently the associate executive director for operations of the Federation Employment and Guidance Service, and formerly an adviser to the Governor on homelessness. The unsalaried chairwoman will be Maria Cuomo Cole, Andrew's younger sister. Ms. Cuomo Cole, who was a partner in a public relations firm until this year and a H.E.L.P. board member, is married to Kenneth Cole, the shoe designer.
"We could have either really let go or try to continue and fulfill Andrew's agenda and his dream, which is to continue on a national level," Ms. Cuomo Cole said. "We want to keep a family commitment."
Critics complained sometimes that Mr. Cuomo was able to keep that commitment only because he is the Governor's son. No matter. Plenty of progeny never even try to emulate powerful parents.
"We feel confident that other cities will be able to implement this formula without their having any familial relation," said Ms. Cuomo Cole.
"The H.E.L.P. concept was to provide immediate homes for homeless families and support services to find permanent homes. That was our covenant with homeless families. They, in turn, participated in the program by staying off drugs and committing themselves to drug treatment and cooperating with the support staff in training and counseling."
With eight sites serving more than 4,000 people a year in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Albany, Westchester and Suffolk, H.E.L.P. has evolved into what it describes as the largest private provider of housing for homeless in the nation. New projects are pending on 14th Street in Manhattan and in Harrison in Westchester.
Last year, H.E.L.P. itself graduated into becoming an innovative provider of permanent housing. Genesis Homes, a visually striking sanctuatuary in Brooklyn's East New York, houses 150 families evenly divided between the working poor who pay monthly rent of $500 to $700 and the formerly homeless whose rent is federally subsidized. Tenants share any savings if the time and effort they invest in clerical, maintenance or security duties pare the project's annual budget. Welfare mothers who join job-training classes will receive free day care for their children.
The agenda for Genesis and its suburban counterpart, Equity Homes, is simple: to create public-private partnerships that increase the supply of housing for low-income and lower- middle-income families in low-density economically mixed projects in which vital social services are available to provide "prevention before intervention."
Equity Homes plans to sell subsidized two-family homes for about $160,000 to homeowners who agree to lease the second apartment to a low-income tenant eligible for Federal rent subsidies.
Genesis, with Ms. Cuomo Cole at the helm, marks another beginning for a concept that defies partisan politics and ideology. Its first principle is work, not welfare, which to be achieved requires an investment in education, training and child care and that jobs be available. Its second principle promotes independence because "government programs which treat a person as a mere recipient of entitlements can destroy one's sense of pride, value and control." And it limits government's role to planning, financing and regulating while private providers develop and operate the housing and other services.
Those principles are economically and politically sound if advocates for the homeless succeed in melding conscience with the plight of the poor with the middle-class self-interest that predominates in Washington and New York. After the Board of Education ousted Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez last week to protest his social agenda, Governor Cuomo, who raised his family in Queens, reminded the rest of New York that it might well have been the Chancellor rather than the board that had lost touch.
"There has been a syndrome for a long time if you're in Manhattan to see things a little bit different than you see them in Staten Island, Queens and Brooklyn. And I think the 4-to-3 vote -- right, wrong, for better, for worse -- probably reflects where that population is."

HEADLINE: Latin America's Regional Trade Boon

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 14

 BODY:
After years of nationalistic trade protection, Latin America is finding that regional trade agreements can provide an enormous spur to its economies.
Not only are the accords increasing trade within Latin America, but they drop tariffs for overseas trade as well, and the result has been a sharply expanding market for the United States. 
 "Historically, Latin America's intraregional trade has been zilch," said Peter B. Field, director of the Enterprise of the Americas program at the North-South Center in Miami. "But in the last two years, intraregional trade has exploded."
In the latest regional agreement, signed here on Friday, the Presidents of Venezuela, Colombia and five Central American nations knocked down another stack of trade barriers.
In a previous agreement, signed in March 1990, Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay agreed to set a timetable to phase out all regional tariffs by the end of 1994. In response to the liberalization, trade between Brazil and Argentina jumped 50 percent in 1991, a growth rate that was repeated last year. Encouraged by such startling increases in commerce, Latin America's leaders no longer treat regional integration as an abstract ideal.
In January of 1992, Colombia and Venezuela abolished bilateral tariffs. That year, trade between the two Andean neighbors jumped 60 percent. After a bilateral open-skies agreement was signed in 1991, the frequency of weekly flights between Caracas and Bogota jumped to 31 from 7.
Over the last year, four Andean nations -- Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Venezuela -- inaugurated duty-free regional trade. But over the last three years, these nations, plus Peru, slashed their average external import tariffs by two-thirds. In 1989, the average tariff on goods imported from outside the Andes was 41 percent. Today, the average is 13.6 percent.
In the southern common market, known as Mercosul, external tariffs are being cut by more than half to reach a 20 percent ceiling by June. Mercosul, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, encompasses about half of Latin America's economic activity. Chile, South America's only other large economy, has a flat external tariff of 11 percent.
"There is nothing to be feared from regional subgroupings if they lower trade and investment barriers, clearing the path toward larger cooperative agreements in the hemisphere," David Rockefeller, former chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, said in a speech last year at a seminar on integration of the Western Hemisphere.
Bearing out Mr. Rockefeller's words, American exporters discovered that Latin America was the world's fastest-growing market for American goods.
In the first quarter of 1992, United States exports to Latin America and the Caribbean increased 32.5 percent from the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Meanwhile, American exports to the rest of the world grew only 4.4 percent.
In 1991, American export growth figures were similar: an 18 percent jump for Latin America and the Caribbean and a 5.3 percent rise for the rest of the world. With United States sales to Latin America jumping an estimated 30 percent in 1992, Latin America was the only region where the United States had a trade surplus.
 
 
Good for the United States
 "As these countries start to get their houses in order, and start to open up, the United States is going to be a major beneficiary," Mr. Field said, referring to a resumption of Latin economic growth after the stagnant years of the 1980's debt crisis.
As an indication of how serious they are, Latin American nations have gone beyond lowering external tariffs to abolishing import licenses, exchange controls and import quotas.
"Eighty percent of nontariff barriers have been thrown out," Adolfo Lopez Bustillo, a statistician at the Andean group's headquarters in Lima, Peru, said last month in an interview. Last year, Andean regional trade jumped 18 percent to $2.1 billion -- the largest increase since the group was formed in 1969.
In Venezuela, the shift toward a free market is as clear as the changing scene at the land border with Colombia. Where Indian women used to slip across border trails with contraband produce hidden under their billowing skirts, large tractor-trailers now rumble through simplified border controls.
 
 
Improvements at the Border
 "My trucks used to spend two days at the border; now they spend three hours," said Andres Duarte, the owner of a commodities trading company here. "Ford Venezuela and General Motors Venezuela are now exporting to Colombia."
After a free trade agreement between Colombia and Ecuador took hold on Oct. 1, border merchants were so disoriented that they briefly blocked the Pan American Highway. But with under-the-table trade now history, official trade increased threefold in the last quarter of 1992.
The timing of Latin America's regional agreements vary.
With the recent creation of the Andean Free Trade Zone, tariffs immediately dropped to zero for trade between Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Venezuela. In contrast, a 1991 Chile-Mexico free trade treaty calls for phasing out all bilateral trade barriers by 1998. Similarly, bilateral free trade agreements that Chile hopes to sign this year with Colombia, Venezuela and Ecuador are only expected to become fully operative by the end of this decade.
In the biggest leap in the 24-year history of the Central American Common Market, three countries -- El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras -- are to abolish all trade duties by March 1. In contrast, a free trade pact signed in August by Mexico and these countries, plus Nicaragua and Costa Rica, is to become fully effective only by the end of 1996. Similarly, the agreement signed here on Friday by these five Central American nations, plus Venezuela and Colombia, would allow fully free regional trade only by the end of the decade.
A Mexico-Colombia-Venezuela free trade pact that is to start in January is expected to only phase out tariff barriers by the year 2000.
 
 
Slow Approach
 Mexico is believed to be taking a slow approach to this subregional pact out of fear of complicating American Congressional consideration this year of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which is of far greater importance to Mexico. That agreement includes rules on product origin intended to prevent Mexico from becoming a trampoline for Colombian and Venezuelan goods to enter the United States duty free.
As in all trade associations, Latin America's uneven economic policies slow the integration of trade.
In Mexico, where gasoline costs $1.40 a gallon, businessmen complain that Venezuelan goods benefit from subsidized production costs, because gasoline sells in Caracas for 33 cents a gallon.
In Argentina, industrialists complain that their nation's overvalued currency has brought an avalanche of Brazilian goods. Causing a severe strain to Mercosul, Argentina watched a 1990 trade surplus with Brazil of $776 million turn into an estimated 1992 trade deficit with that country of $1.1 billion.
Behind the alphabet soup of regional trade groups, the welter of timetables and the web of bilateral agreements, an overriding goal is to make individual Latin American countries more attractive to foreign investors.
"During the three years that we have been negotiating Nafta, we have already received more than $24 billion in overseas investment," Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the President of Mexico, told leaders assembled here.
Doubling and tripling market sizes, the free trade pacts are prompting companies to consolidate duplicate operations and to seek out foreign partners as they confront new competition.
Near Sao Paulo, Brazil, Kodak do Brasil is building a distribution center to start supplying the Mercosul market later this year. In Argentina, PASA Petroquimica is forming a joint venture with Monsanto as it faces new competition from Brazil in plastics.
 
 
'Dress Rehearsal'
 "I think Mercosul is a dress rehearsal for Brazil to become more competitive, to prepare for an eventual entry into the world economy," said Arturo Jose Furlong, president of Samring S.A., a flour mill in southern Brazil.
Here in Caracas, more than 50 of Colombia's largest companies have set up offices to explore sales and joint ventures. In return, Venezuelans last year bought four Colombian banks. Reflecting accelerating trade and investment, air traffic between here and Bogota has quintupled, reaching 54,000 passengers in the seven months after the open-skies pact took effect.
Encouraged by these results, Latin leaders predict that regional integration will only accelerate.
To promote physical integration, governments are planning to construct during the 1990's two superhighways -- one linking Caracas and Bogota, and the other linking Sao Paulo and Buenos Aires.
At a closing news conference on Friday, Venezuela's President Carlos Andres Perez announced that the next summit meeting of the Presidents of Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela would be with Caribbean heads of state interested in signing a regional free trade pact.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Booming Trade in South America," tracks total trade under several regional trade pacts in South America, for 1986 to 1992; trade pacts include Mercosul Treaty, Chile-Argentina pact, Colombia-Venezuela agreement and Andean Pact. (Sources: Latin American Association for Integration; Venezuelan Foreign Trade Institute)

HEADLINE: French Tank Wins Contract Over U.S. and British Rivals

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Feb. 14

 BODY:
France won a $3.5 billion order today from the United Arab Emirates for nearly 400 battle tanks, against tough competition from the United States and Britain, two of its allies in the Persian Gulf war.
The contract for Leclerc tanks was announced shortly after the opening of the largest military arms show in the gulf. More than 350 weapons manufacturers from 34 countries displayed their wares in what has become the world's most important arms market. 
 The Leclerc tank, made by France's state-owned Giat Industries S.A., had competed for the contract against the Abrams M1-A2 made by the General Dynamics Corporation, based in Falls Church, Va., and the Challenger 2 from Vickers P.L.C. of Britain.
The president of Giat, Pierre Chiquet, said 390 Leclerc battle tanks would be sold to the Emirates, plus 46 armored support vehicles, bringing the total number of vehicles involved to 436.
 
 
First Export Order
 It was Giat's first export order for the Leclerc, which was developed in the late 1980's and previously sold only to the French Army.
A spokesman for the United Arab Emirates, Gamal al-Suweidi, said, "It was a difficult decision choosing between three superior tanks." He did not give the value of the deal, but arms experts said it was at least $3.5 billion.
Mr. Chiquet said only that it was worth more than $3 billion. He said the tanks would be delivered by 1999, with the first five reaching the Emirates in 1994.
The Challenger and the original M1-A1 version of the Abrams were battle tested in the gulf war two years ago. In October, Kuwait agreed to buy 236 of the newer Abrams tanks for its military.
 
 
General Dynamics' Reaction
 Don Gilleland, a General Dynamics spokesman, said the decision "is not critical to our survival," adding that the company had "orders to take us to the mid-1990's." Production of the M1-A2 affects some 5,900 jobs in Warren, Mich., and Lima, Ohio.
Vickers, however, might be forced to shut one of two factories in Britain for lack of sufficient orders, experts said.
Last year, Vickers lost Kuwait's $4.5 billion order for 256 tanks to General Dynamics' M1-A2. The experts said a $300 million deal with Oman in January would prove insufficient to prevent the company's retrenching.
Britain and the United States remain the region's main arms suppliers, but France, eager to penetrate the lucrative market, has close military ties with the Emirates. It sold Mirage 2000 fighters equipped with American armament and air-defense systems to the Emirates in the mid-1980's, and military experts said the two sides might soon enter fresh negotiations for more Mirage 2000's.
 
 
Giat to Reinvest 60% of Deal
 Mr. Suweidi said Giat had agreed to reinvest 60 percent of the deal's value in joint-venture projects in the Emirates as part of that nation's so-called offset program, requiring foreign sellers to invest in its economy and introduce new technologies.
Last month, General Dynamics' Land Systems division offered to create a United States-based holding company that would make investments estimated at $1.5 billion in the Emirates in exchange for the tank order.
Giat officials said that at the Emirates' request, the tanks would be powered by a 1,630-horsepower engine made by the Deutsche Aerospace unit of Daimler-Benz A.G.

HEADLINE: Minority Caucus Adding Political Power in Albany

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 14

 BODY:
When New York State Assembly leaders began talking recently about raising income tax rates for the state's wealthiest residents, few thought much would come of the idea.
But for members of the Legislature's black and Puerto Rican caucus, the mere existence of a debate over the question has offered a sense of vindication. For five years, they have championed tax increases to avoid budget cuts. For five years, they have fought almost alone. 
 If this year is different, it may indicate a changing political climate, ushered in by President Clinton. But to members of the Legislature's minority caucus, it may also illustrate their growing clout in Albany.
"What you're hearing is a recognition of what the caucus has been saying for seven years," said Assemblyman Roberto Ramirez, a Bronx Democrat. "It's either taxes or cuts, and we cannot afford to cut any more."
As the New York State Association of Black and Puerto Rican Legislators, which is run by the minority caucus, concluded its annual conference in Albany today, there was a sense that their time had arrived. With 35 members this year, six more than last year, the caucus is larger than ever before. All but seven are Democrats in the Assembly, making a united minority caucus a potentially formidible force within the 150-member lower house.
 
A Complex Web
 In the complex web of regional politics that dominate the Legislature, the caucus has also emerged as a vital voice for New York City, one that is perhaps more important this year than in the past.
The Assembly's Demcocratic majority, now 101 strong, has more suburban and upstate members than in the past. And because many of those new members are from traditional Republican strongholds, they are considered more vulnerable and in greater need of support from the Assembly leadership.
To many Assembly watchers, that could mean New York City members will lose leverage in a political body they have traditionally dominated. That battle, they say, must increasingly be waged by black and Hispanic members, who now hold 28 of the 58 seats in New York City's Assembly delegation.
"In the past, the impression was you didn't have to worry about the city, that the Assembly Speaker and the delegation will take care of it," said one city official. "But as the Assembly's Democratic majority becomes more upstate, the city delgation has to act more as a united delegation, and that's where the caucus comes in."
 
Emotional Support
 But whether that can happen remains in question. Begun largely as a mutual support group by a handful of black and Hispanic legislators about 30 years ago, the caucus often remains a loose-knit body that provides its members emotional, but not always political, support, legislators say.
"They're not particuarly effective in speaking as one voice," said Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat. "We are all fairly parochial on issues. Like the rest of us, if they have an option of doing something good for the city versus for their district, the general approach is to do something good for the district, which gets you recognition."
In another indication that the caucus may play a greater role in the Assembly this year, Assemblyman Albert Vann, a Brooklyn Democrat, has been appointed chairman of the Assembly Corporations, Authorities and Commissions Committee.
Assigned to oversee independent authorities, including the Port Authority and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the committee has wide-ranging effects on transportation and economic development. For Mr. Vann, who for years was chairman of the Children and Families Committee, the new position could broaden the caucus's influence beyond its traditional bastion in social-service committees.
Sounding a theme that resonated throughout the association's weekend, Mr. Vann said in an interview that he would use his committee to expand economic oppportunities for black and Hispanic New Yorkers.
"The important thing is to expand the economy for everyone," he said. "And as we do that, we should provide opportunities for minority- and women- owned businesses."

With 28 of their 35 members being Democrats in the Assembly, a united minority caucus may become a force within the lower house. (Mike Groll for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Three Painters' Views of Black Life in America

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Tonight comes the premiere of "The Living Canvas," a new PBS series about art. Presided over by Billy Dee Williams, who describes himself as "a painter who acts," the hourlong program offers a view of his off-camera, on-canvas work and the efforts of two other black artists, Dean Mitchell and Thomas Blackshear 2d.
Mr. Mitchell, whose representational style may remind you of Hopper or Wyeth, tells of his desire to celebrate the hard-working people of the rural Florida town of Quincy, where he was brought up. You have probably seen the work of Mr. Blackshear, known professionally as T.B. II, on advertisements for Coca-Cola and Anheuser Busch; he recently turned out a set of portraits of eminent black Americans for the United States Postal Service. Black entertainers figure in Mr. Williams' somewhat abstract paintings. 
 In keeping with African-American History Month, the documentary takes notice of the aspects of black life in America that appear in all the work as well as its special meaning for black youths.
 
'Nova'
'Can Science Build a Champion Athlete?' PBS, Tuesday at 8 p.m.
(Channel 13 in New York)
How is it that athletic records keep being broken? Tonight's answer on "Nova" gives credit to high-tech analysis of what makes champions run and swim faster, jump higher, shoot straighter and so forth.
The program shows how computer imaging breaks down the movements of athletes to find the most efficient uses of their strength, talent and energy, enabling trainers to take it from there. The material is interesting, and the slow-motion pictures of record-breakers in action are always a treat, but perhaps the most significant reason offered tonight for the astounding achievements of recent decades is the breaking down of racial and economic barriers to athletic competition.
 
The Living Canvas
PBS, tonight at 10
(Channel 13 in New York)
 
A special directed by Danny Schechter; Nancy Leiviska and Christopher Maji, segment producers; Mr. Maji, editor; produced by Michael P. Smith for Globalvision; Mr. Schechter, executive producer.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Walker Left to Defend One U.S.O.C. Policy

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Dr. LeRoy Walker, the first black president of the United States Olympic Committee, today found himself in the uncomfortable position of defending the organization's appointment policies toward minority-group members and women.
As a relatively uneventful U.S.O.C. board of directors meeting neared its close, Dr. Evie Dennis, superintendant of a Denver school district and an assistant to the U.S.O.C. president, attacked Walker and the board for failing to fill committee chairs and other power positions with blacks or women. 
 "You look in this room, you see white males," Dennis said. "I said this back in the 70's, and we've only picked up a few black members since then."
"It seems to me the committee thinks naming a black president is all it's got to do," Dennis added. "I think it's ridiculous when you consider the number of medals being won by black athletes."
The U.S.O.C. board of directors has 99 voting members. Of these, 24 are women and 11 are black (including two of the women). On the 21 committees for 1993-1996, there are four chairwomen, a sub-committee chairwoman and no black committee chairs. Three chairs will be named within the next two weeks, and Walker said he was trying very hard to fill them with minority members or women.
"You have to tell me who they are first," Walker said, referring to potential black candidates. "It's a high priority, but unfortunately, I didn't get enough help yet."
Walker said he was seeking minority and female candidates from several available sources: members of the executive committee, staff members, members of the board and members of the Athletes Advisory Council. Walker displayed nomination forms, in which candidates were to be coded according to race and gender.
"This would have been illegal a few years ago," he said, of the classification system he is trying to employ. "Now, they have to tell me who these people are, or I send them back the forms. I think the committee members are getting the message."
Dennis, however, insisted that she had submitted a list of possible minority-member hires to Walker who could fill several posts.
"I just hate to see this organization slip back," Dennis said. "Dr. Walker has to do more."
Alpha Alexander, who is black, is a sub-committee chairwoman for competitive grants. Alexander said she believed Walker was working to improve the representation by minority members, but Alexander said she was still concerned about what she called, "the good-old boy network."
 
'Reflection of Society'
 "This is 1993, and the Olympic Committee has to be a reflection of society," Alexander said. "Just because Dr. Walker is the first black president, that shouldn't take care of that group. They keep saying women and minorites are coming, but is it going to happen?"
Alexander had been one of the sponsors who successfully nominated Andrew Young and Arthur Ashe as public-sector members of the committee. Alexander said she came to the meetings in Phoenix saddened by the death of Ashe, but vowed to work to replace him with another black member. Alexander said she planned to nominate Rachel Robinson, the widow of Jackie Robinson, for Ashe's vacant post.
In other matters, the board of directors meeting closed today with mixed financial disclosures. The U.S.O.C. boasted a remarkably healthy budget, with record projected revenues for the 1993-96 quadrennium at $388 million and surpluses projected in the tens of millions.
The committee expressed a commitment to the San Diego training center, and a capital campaign to raise $21.5 million to complete renovations under way at the Colorado Springs Olympic training center.
The Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, however, was less boastful. Charles Battle, executive vice president for the group, admitted that his organization had overestimated the amount of early interest and sponsorship money the 1996 Games would attract in 1992, a year with the Olympics in Albertville, France, and Barcelona, Spain.
 
Deals Left Undone
 The Atlanta group has lowered its projected profits to about $16 million for the 1996 Games, but Battle said the organization was all but done completing the political and economic deals that would allow the ambitious Olympic Stadium to be built, at the cost to organization of $207 million.
To build the stadium, which will be renovated after the Olympics for use by the Atlanta Braves, the Atlanta organization must reach agreements with the Braves, the city of Atlanta, Fulton County, the county's recreation department and the neighborhood surrounding the stadium. There is still a bailout plan to build a cheaper, temporary stadium if one of the many sides involved backs out.
"We've been a reactive organization in 1992, but we're committed to becoming a pro-active organization in 1993," Battle said.

PUB-DATE: February 15, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 616 words

HEADLINE: Big Science, Big Budget Cuts

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration and Congress search for ways to cut Federal spending, frugal eyes are inevitably turning to the two biggest scientific projects now underway -- the $8.3 billion superconducting supercollider now being built in Texas, and the $30 billion space station. Billions have already been sunk into each project. But if the pain is to be spread fairly, these two research behemoths must be cut along with other vital programs. It is disheartening to hear that the Administration may be yielding to pressure to preserve them.
The easier call is the space station, a costly engineering project that has become, as some critics describe it, "an entitlement program for the aerospace industry." In a perverse inverse relationship, as the costs of the project have risen, the justifications for it have diminished. 
 Last year two expert panels pooh-poohed the notion that studies of materials in space would quickly produce anything of commercial value, supposedly one of the main goals of the station. Other reviews have made clear that the station has only one important goal that can't be met on Earth: it would serve as a base for biomedical studies of what happens to humans and animals who remain in space for long periods.
Such information is needed before humans can safely travel to Mars and beyond in the next century. But there are almost certainly cheaper ways to get it. Like designing a smaller station devoted solely to biomedicine. Or finding ways to extend the shuttle flights for long-duration medical tests. Or making even better use of the small, electronically primitive Russian station already in orbit.
Some budget cutters may be tempted to stretch out this grandiose public works project on reduced annual rations. But it would be far better to kill the present design and replace it with a smaller biomedical platform.
A harder call is the supercollider, a huge scientific instrument, some 54 miles in circumference, that will be built underground in Texas. By all accounts, this is a pioneering research project designed to yield secrets of matter that cannot be found any other way. Digging has just begun on its enormous underground tunnel and some surface buildings are already up.
The project poses two major risks. One is inevitable in basic research: the secrets learned may not be all that exciting. In any case, the knowledge gained will probably have little impact on important social or economic problems. This will be pure science at its purest. The other risk is that, as budgets tighten throughout government, a big-ticket item like the collider may siphon off funds from potentially more important, small-scale research.
In a parting shot of honesty, the Bush Administration finally acknowledged that foreign partners are unlikely to share much of the burden. So now U.S. taxpayers will have to provide another $5.5 billion to complete this project.
Few laymen are in a position to grasp whether this esoteric physics project is worth that kind of expenditure. But there is a way to force the physicists themselves to decide. If they want another $5.5 billion, let them mothball enough of the existing but obsolescent high-energy machines to cover the costs. If they aren't willing to pay that price, then society need not feel obliged to buy them a new machine.
Cutting these big science projects will not be easy. Both benefit the home state of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who can be counted on to fight for their preservation. And President Clinton, while angling for votes during the campaign, pledged to support both projects. But with pain-sharing now a political imperative, Big Science must do its share.
